Title: Surat: Two leopard cubs charred to death in sugarcane farm
Content:
The remains of the cubs were recovered by forest department

SURAT: Two leopard cubs were found charred to death in a sugarcane farm at Pipariya village of Mandvi taluka in Surat district on Sunday. The charred remains of the two-month-old cubs were recovered by forest department officials and sent for postmortem.

Labourers busy harvesting sugarcane crop in the farm of Amit Patel spotted the charred remains of the cubs in the early morning hours. They immediately left the farm fearing attack by the mother leopard, following which villagers alerted forest officials.

"The cubs are too young and that a female leopard was spotted with them a few days ago. The farm owner and labourers were not aware that the leopard was hiding in the farm along with its cubs. The cubs had died accidentally," said Pratik Patel, a farmer from the village.

"The female leopard was seen moving around in the farm in morning. The leopard’s presence created panic among labourers. Villagers had spotted the female leopard with four cubs a few days ago. It is believed that she was able to save the lives of its two cubs," Patel added.

"The work to cut sugarcane began in my farm two days ago. Labourers, who are camping in the farm, never noticed the leopard and the cubs. The cubs died in a fire set to clear dried waste in my farm," said Amit Patel, owner of the farm. Two leopard cubs were rescued from Amit’s farm during harvesting of sugarcane crop in 2015. Meanwhile, forest officials are keeping watch in the area and also have placed a cage to rescue the leopard and its cubs.

"The mother leopard will return to the farm at night in search of its cubs. We will come to know about the other cubs on seeing her,” wildlife activist Jatin Rathod said.

"The cubs are suspected to have died in a fire at sugarcane farm. Our team has recovered the cubs’ remains. Forest department will get their postmortem done which will ascertain the possible cause of their death," said Puneet Nayyar, deputy conservator of forest, Surat.

Dense sugarcane plantation makes it difficult for humans to enter the farm which the leopards prefer for breeding. In a traditional harvesting method, labourers set fire to the dried waste in the farm at night and start cutting sugarcane crop in the morning.

Title: Govt asks all districts to assess crop damage
Content:
PATNA: State agriculture department has sought reports from all districts regarding crop damage due to untimely rain and hailstorm over the past few days. The inclement weather has destroyed standing crops, including pulse, oilseeds and even wheat in many districts.

State agriculture minister Prem Kumar said a meeting through videoconferencing was held with officials of all 38 districts on Sunday.

“Standing rabi crops, including pulses, potato, lentil and wheat have been damaged at many places in the state owing to untimely rain in the past few days. Accordingly, agriculture department officers as well as ‘kisan salahkars (farmer consultants)’ have been asked to visit the villages and talk to farmers. The district officials have also been asked to conduct survey to ascertain damages in their respective areas and submit reports within three days,” the minister said.

Rainfall at most places and hailstorm at a few places in the state were witnessed on several days during the last fortnight. This led to untimely accumulation of water in the agriculture fields and the hail directly damaged the standing crops.

Elaborating on the type of damages to the crops, Anil Kumar Jha, deputy director in agriculture department said, “Since the rainfall occurred along with high speed winds, standing crops fell on the ground at many places. This was also due to the fact that the crops had reached grain formation stage and their upper body or productive parts were comparatively heavier. Besides, crops like oilseeds and mustard got damaged at many places owing to accumulation of water.”

Meanwhile, leader of opposition in state assembly Tejashwi Prasad Yadav said the state government should provide necessary compensation to farmers. “Farmers should be provided compensation without any delay for the damages caused to rabi crops owing to untimely rainfall. Most farmers in the state are facing difficulties in earning their livelihood due to crop damages. Any delay, slackness or corrupt practice in giving compensation to the farmers will not be tolerated,” Tejashwi tweeted on Sunday.

Title: HC to hear only urgent matters
Content:
PATNA: The Patna high court would now hear only urgent matters to avoid mass gathering of lawyers and litigants on its premises as a precautionary measure against coronavirus. A notification to this effect was issued on Sunday. Only regular and anticipatory bail matters would be taken up for hearing on Monday while rest of the cases listed for hearing would stand over for April 6. From Tuesday, only regular bail and urgent matters would be taken up for hearing. Any matter, in which there is a judicial order for listing between March 17 and 31 would now be listed on April 4 before appropriate benches.

Hours before the notification, the coordination committee of all three associations of Patna high court had passed a resolution after discussion with its members, Chief Justice Sanjay Karol and other judges along with advocate general Lalit Kishore, requesting lawyers to file only urgent matters till March 31 and avoid coming to court. The advocates have been asked to request the same to their clients.

Title: Milk booth owner shot in Naubatpur
Content:
PATNA: Two unidentified bike-borne criminals shot dead a milk booth owner inside his shop at Naubatpur Lock under the same police station area in western Patna on Sunday night. The deceased was identified as Guddu Singh (45) of Bela Tarari and the elder son of peasant leader Awadesh Nandan Singh. Sources said the murder may be a fallout of extortion demand. Guddu was rushed to a private hospital near Saguna Mor in Danapur where doctors declared him brought dead.

Naubatpur SHO Samrat Deepak Kumar said the family members had brought Guddu’s body back to his residence. “They have not shared any information. It was not clear if he got killed due to enmity with any one or some other reasons,” he said. The SHO said none at the spot could tell the police how the incident took place.

Two killed in road accident: Two youths were killed when their bike allegedly skidded on a sharp turn near Nadhari village under Sigori police station in Paliganj subdivision of Patna district on Saturday night. The matter surfaced after villagers spotted the bodies along with the bike on Sunday morning.

Sigori police station SHO Manoj Kumar said the deceased were identified as Vipin Kumar (25) and Rangal Kumar (24) of Noorchak village under Sigori police station.

He said Vipin’s uncle had died a few days back and people were called for ‘bramhabhoj’ on Saturday night. “Vipin and Rangal had gone to market to purchase refined oil which had run out of stock during ‘bramhabhoj’. While returning, they met with an accident,” he said. The SHO said though Vipin’s father Ram Lagan Kunwar had lodged an FIR against an unknown truck for the accident, it seems the deceased had lost control over the bike, which colliding with a tree on the turning. He said bodies were handed over to the family after postmortem at Paliganj hospital.

Title: Three who fled from Kerala ‘isolated’
Content:
BAGAHA/DARBHANGA/PATNA: Three youths of West Champaran, who recently fled from Kerala after having symptoms of Covid-19 virus, were brought from their native village and admitted to the isolation ward in Government Medical College and Hospital, Bettiah on Sunday.

According to sources, the three youths from a village in Ramnagar block were undergoing tests for Covid-19 in Kerala, but fled and reached their village on Saturday by train. On getting information, they were sent to Ramnagar primary health centre (PHC) and then to the Bettiah hospital. Ramnagar SDPO Arjun Lal said on Sunday their family members were also confined to their houses under police security.

Also, a suspected case of Covid-19, who claimed to have returned from Qatar recently, fled from Darbhanga Medical College and Hospital (DMCH) on Sunday. He was admitted there for necessary tests and observations. He was later found at home in his village.

DMCH doctors claimed that the 35-year-old patient, a native of Darbhanga district, was admitted for Covid-19 tests, but fled when he was taken to the isolation ward on a trolley. The hospital administration lodged a complaint with Benta outpost police station in Laheriasarai on Sunday about the missing patient.

DMCH superintendent Dr Raj Ranjan Prasad told TOI over the phone that the Covid-19 suspect fled by snatching the bed head ticket, when the hospital staff wheeled him towards the isolation ward. “The patient told the doctors that he had returned from Qatar almost one and a half months ago and went through all the screening process at the airport. At that time, the report of Covid-19 test was negative. However, he admitted that he had developed cold and flu during the last few days. The doctors told him that he would be kept in the isolation ward for the next 14 days and samples will be sent for examination. But he ran away,” Dr Prasad said.

Meanwhile, a statement issued by health department’s principal secretary Sanjay Kumar on Sunday stated that the person who fled from DMCH had no history of visiting any foreign country, including Qatar. “The hospital has the mobile number and address of the patient. The police found him at his home. There is no history of his return from abroad (Qatar),” the press statement reads.

Title: School van caught smuggling illicit liquor
Content:
Bareilly: A man was arrested by police in Moradabad for allegedly smuggling illicit liquor in a school van on Saturday. Police said that acting on a tip off, they caught a vehicle on Moradabad-Lucknow highway under Mudhapandey police station limits.

The vehicle with large quantity of liquor was impounded by the cops and the accused was sent to jail. They seized around 85 boxes of illicit liquor. Earlier, an ambulance was reportedly found transporting such liquor.

Mudhapandey police station house officer, inspector Sahansveer Singh, said that they had inputs that an illicit liquor-laden four-wheeler would pass through the national highway following which they had started checking vehicles.

“Near Mankara crossing, upon spotting a school van coming from the Rampur end, we signalled it to stop. We have recovered 85 boxes of illicit liquor which was smuggled from Punjab. After lodging an FIR under appropriate sections, we sent the accused to jail. He has been identified as Anuj Rana, a resident of Mudhapandey,” the SHO said.

Police officer said that illicit liquor was stored at Tanda in Rampur district from where it was being supplied to Moradabad. Circle officer of national highway, Ram Sagar, said that the value of the seized alcohol was assessed to be around Rs 3 lakh.

Title: Disturbed Areas Act imposed on Rander and Limbayat in city
Content:
The Act has already been in force in some parts of Katargam, Chowk Bazaar, Mahidharpura, Lalgate and Athwa pol... Read More

Surat: The state government imposed Disturbed Areas Act on areas falling under the limits of Rander and Limbayat police stations on Sunday. The Act is already in force in some parts of Katargam, Chowk Bazaar , Mahidharpura , Lalgate and Athwa police stations since 2017. The demand for its imposition was being made by BJP MLAs from these areas for some time.

Rander and Limbayat areas have sizeable population of minority community and migrants. The Act restricts buying and selling of properties in these areas, but people belonging to different communities can still strike a deal with the approval of the district collector. The buyer and seller are supposed to provide various documents to get approval from the government for transferring the ownership of the property to a person from another community.

"We receive over 300 applications in a year at Surat collectorate for transfer of property ownership under this Act. We have a team of officers which has been authorized to undertake the process," Surat district collector Dhaval Patel said.

Limbayat is largely migrant-dominated area. Majority residents in Limbayat are employed in textile and chemical industries and have come from Maharasthra, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Odisha.

"There is sizeable population of minority community in my assembly area. Residents from many residential societies have been demanding for the last few years imposition of this Act. There are only 20 per cent homes of Hindus in many societies. Now, those planning to buy a house of a Hindu in my area will have to take permission from the collectorate,” said Sangita Patil, BJP MLA from Limbayat.

Purnesh Modi, BJP MLA from Surat West seat, too had demanded implementation of the Act in Rander. "After my demand, I have been doing constant follow-up to get the approval. The Act will be updated in near future where a committee comprising district collector, municipal commissioner and police commissioner will give approval to property deals. It will be made further strict to transfer property ownership between members of two communities," Modi said.

"There is no need to impose this Act because people are living in peace and harmony in these areas. No major complaint or issue has been reported over transfer of property ownership from these areas," Congress leader Kadir Pirzada said.

Title: Man robbed of Rs 52k
Content:
Rajkot: Two robbers allegedly waylaid a farmer and robbed him of Rs 52,000 cash near Rapar in Kutch district on Friday night. In a complaint lodged on Saturday, Naran Patel (30), told the police that he was going in his car when the robbers overtook him on their bike and forced him to stop.

“The robbers told the victim that they wanted mechanical tools. When Patel got out of the car, they allegedly beat him up with bats and robbed him of his cash. The accused had also smashed the windscreen of his car,” said an official from Rapar police station. TNN

Title: ABD area gets focus with scores of proposals
Content:
Trichy: With Trichy City Corporation unwilling to spend the general funds as a part of its austerity measures, a majority of the infrastructure announcements made in the budget relies solely on Smart Cities Mission funds, which is focusing on the Area Based Development (ABD) zone. The key demands including Integrated Bus Terminus (IBT), satellite bus stand for Srirangam and foot over bridges were among the misses in the corporation budget.

The Smart Cities Mission has bifurcated the city into two zones namely ABD and pan-city zone. ABD zone covering 7 square kilometre area around the Rockfort hillock will get more focus compared to the pan-city area. Out of the 13 proposals in the budget made under Smart Cities Mission, nine proposals are in the ABD zone covering 4.2% of the city area including Melachinthamani, Thillai Nagar, Rockfort, parts of the Cauvery banks, Puthur, Woraiyur and Gandhi market. The corporation has proposed to revamp the existing pipelines to enable 24-hour water supply and renovate UGD lines in the ABD zone. Similarly, two multi-level car parking facilities in Kaliamman Koil Street and Nandhi Koil Street are also planned in the ABD zone.

"It is unfortunate that IBT and Srirangam bus stand plans were dropped in the budget," Subash Chandran, a resident of Woraiyur, said. The corporation said that the site chosen for Srirangam bus stand at Panchakarai was unviable for the project. Instead, it proposed to establish a science and technology park for children at the site. Smart roads are mooted in the budget using Rs 16.50 crore from the Smart Cities Mission fund. For the pan-city area, three smart toilets and battery-powered solid waste management vehicles were proposed in the budget. The proposals under Smart Cities Mission have to be completed before June 2022. "The revenue we had expected will not be generated owing to the rollback of the tax revision. So we have restricted our new proposals," a senior official with the corporation said.

Title: Two suspected patients test negative for COVID-19
Content: Surat: Health officials of Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) heaved a sigh of relief as two suspected patients tested negative for COVID-19. A 30-year-old male and 42-year-old woman were being kept in isolation at New Civil Hospital for over a week now, sources said. “On Sunday, reports of the two patients arrived. Both have tested negative for COVID-19. No fresh cases have been reported in the city. The two suspected patients, who are not related, had visited many countries in West Asia and Far East several times in the recent past,” said Dr. Ashish Naik, deputy municipal commissioner (health), SMC.“All schools, tuition classes and multiplexes will remain closed until March 31. We are monitoring the situation very closely. However, there is no need for people to panic,” Dr. Naik said. He informed that a total of 283 people are under mandatory 14-day home surveillance for over a week in the city. They too had arrived from abroad.The civic body had on Saturday issued a circular to all department heads to shut down swimming pools across the city and give 100% refund to individuals and institutions who had booked community halls, party plots and auditorium till March 31. The corporation has also suspended biometric attendance for the civic staff. The civic body has set up 15-bed quarantine facility at CHC in Vesu. Additionally, 260-bed isolation wards have been set up in government and private hospitals in the city.

Title: ‘Exempt permits for mini luxury buses’
Content:
Coimbatore: Members of All India Tourist Vehicle Drivers Welfare Association have urged the central government to exempt permits for using mini luxury buses that have 14 to 19 seats.

Recently, the Union ministry of road, transport and highways has sought views from the state government and all stakeholders regarding its plan to exempt AC deluxe buses with a capacity of more than 22 passengers.

At present, private vehicle owners cannot run luxury buses on regular routes without a permit from the regional or state transport authority.

CP Balaji of the association said, “The central government in late 1980s exempted the vehicles that have four to 12 seats and 36 seats from getting permits. Now, the central government is planning to exempt the vehicles that has more than 22 seats. But, the requirement for the vehicles with seats between 14 and 19 is high. So, it should also be exempted.”

Pointing out the vehicles were modified as per the requirement, he said that it would be useful for the public as a minimum of 20–25 people gather whenever vehicles were booked for wedding or other functions.

Either the public were forced to rent additional vehicles or some of the vehicle owners ply without permit due to the practical difficulties in obtaining permit.

Title: Covid-19 in Kolkata: KMC closes swimming pools till month-end
Content: KOLKATA: As a precautionary measure against the spread of novel coronavirus , the Kolkata Municipal Corporation on Sunday suspended activities at 10 swimming pools that operate on KMC land till the end of this month.Debasis Kumar, member, mayor in council (parks and gardens), said, “The novel coronavirus is a global crisis and the government is taking all necessary precautions. Although the swimming season starts from April, some clubs have started activities at their pools. As part of precautionary measures, we have decided to close down the pools till March 31.”According to doctors, the infection generally does not spread in the chlorinated water of a pool. However, it is safe to avoid being in close contact with several people in small gatherings before and after getting in the pool.“Coronavirus doesn’t get transmitted in water, especially in swimming pools that have a heavy amount of chlorine in it. But before getting in the pool, the members are generally exposed to a large gathering in a small space where the virus can spread,” said Arindam Biswas, consultant at RN Tagore International Institute of Cardiac Sciences.Kumar, who is also the chairperson of Bengal Amateur Swimming Association, the nodal body of all private swimming clubs in the city, added, “I can’t take decision on behalf of private swimming clubs, but I urge them to discus and take a decision on whether they want to keep the pools open during this period.”Bhowanipur Swimming Association at Puddapukur and the Hidco-run pool inside New Town Business Club have suspended swimming classes till the end of this month.“Yesterday we took the decision of closing all activities till March 31, including the pool, multigym, table tennis and dance training,” said Ujjal Basu, general secretary.Other multigyms at Puddapukur and Chetla Agrani Club have also suspended activities till the end of the month while a representative of another club said they were facing a decrease in footfall. However, they added that have taken precautionary measures. “We are implementing the use of sanitizers and not allowing anyone suffering from cough and cold to train at our gym,” said Sayantan Roy, owner of Evergreen Fitness gym at Haridevpur.While Rush Fitness Club on Southern Avenue has assigned staff wearing gloves to clean equipment at regular intervals and made sanitizers mandatory at the front desk, gym floor and changing room, Body Shaper Gymnasium in Behala is promoting the use of masks among members.

Title: Gujarat: Patient who fled Rajkot Civil Hospital found
Content: RAJKOT: Health authorities in the city breathed a sigh of relief after they managed to trace a foreign-returned 25-year-old man, who had come for novel coronavirus tests , had escaped from the Rajkot Civil Hospital on Saturday night.The man, who lives in Kalavad Road and is engaged in import-export business, had landed in India four days ago after a business tour to Germany and other European countries. As he was suffering from throat ache, he came to the civil hospital on bike. However, when told that he would have been admitted in isolation ward, he escaped from the campus out of fear, leaving his bike in the parking.At around 11am on Sunday, the health department team found his address and traced him.Dr Manish Bhanderi, district health officer, told TOI: “After escaping from the civil hospital, he went to consult physician the same night. We circulated his name and looks. Based on that, the physician informed us about a person with the same name and matching looks.”When the health officers’ team reached his house, the man initially refused to cooperate and go with them. It was only after the physician convinced him, that he relented.“We have admitted him to the isolation ward and sent his samples for tests. We are also trying to find out other persons whom he got in touch with after fleeing the hospital. If he tests positive, we will require to quarantine him and all others whom he was in touch with,” Dr Bhanderi added.The incident, which left health department jittery, has raised serious questions about handling of suspected coronavirus patients at the civil hospital. According to sources, it was utterly negligent of the hospital staff that despite being a suspect with travel history to coronavirus-affected countries, the man was asked to carry out the formality of making an indoor patient case by standing in the queue. The businessman told the hospital staff that he wanted to inform his family as needed to go out as there was no mobile network inside. However, he fled immediately.When contacted, civil hospital superintendent Dr Manish Mehta said, “A patient or his relative is required to get indoor case made from the window. There was a critical case in the hospital at the same time when this man was there, so the staff was busy in handling that. He might have taken advantage of this situation and escaped.”“His other health reports were normal and he was complaining throat pain. Looking at his travel history, he needs to get the coronavirus tests done,” Dr Mehta added.The civil hospital staff was clueless as the businessman’s mobile number mentioned on the case paper was not reachable and the address mentioned was merely Kalavad Road.

Title: Rajkot: Parcels containing 100 swords seized, five arrested
Content:
Police arrested five persons including the arms dealer in Mangrol on Saturday night

RAJKOT: A total of 100 swords were found from the possession of four persons who were arrested in Mangrol of Junagadh district on Saturday night. Also arrested was the arms dealer who had supplied the weapons to the accused.

According to police, the swords had come in parcels in the bus from Narayan Sarovar in Kutch. The parcels were put in the bus at Anjar.

“We had received a tip-off that the consignment containing swords was supposed to come, following which we kept a watch. As the accused, Shoyeb Chhapara (20), Imtiyaz Bumadia (18), Yaqub Bumadia and Qadar Girnari, both aged 35, took the delivery of the parcels and were going on their bikes, we nabbed them,” said R R Chauhan, sub-inspector with Mangrol town police station.

When caught, the accused produced a bill which was of cutleries. However, when the cops checked the parcels, they discovered swords inside the parcels. During their interrogation, the accused said that one Hasan Vanjha had sought the supply of the swords from Anjar, following which the police arrested Vanjha (40) from Mangrol.

During his interrogation, Vanjha said that one Irfan from Anjar had sent the supply of the weapons and that he had procured the swords with the intention to sell them. Following this revelation, the police have launched a manhunt for Irfan.

Title: Bigbasket, Grofers orders double as malls shut down
Content: BENGALURU: Online grocery retailers like Bigbasket and Grofers saw a spike of 80-100% in orders over the weekend as customers across metros began stocking up staples like flour, rice and pulses besides disinfectants, hand sanitisers, diapers, and personal care items, top executives at these companies said.The development comes as authorities in major metros are urging people to stay at home, shutting down malls and restaurants, while companies are also announcing work-from-home for employees across the country to contain the spread of Covid-19 Bigbasket CEO Hari Menon said he has been camping at the warehouse for last two days tackling a huge surge in orders. “We are seeing 2x (times) kind of growth and baskets are larger by 15-20%,” he said. Menon added that the platform is also seeing a lot more new users and is now ramping up capacity including storage space, delivery van and personnel. Grofers’ founder Albinder Dhindsa said that while the platform had started seeing a spike of 5-7% earlier this week, demand has increased by 80% over the weekend.On an average day, Bigbasket does over 1.6 lakh deliveries for next-day shipments and 1.4 lakh for its micro-delivery business BBDaily, which delivers essentials like milk and bread every morning. Grofers, which only does next-day delivery, does about 90,000 orders a day.The spike in demand is also leading to delays in fulfilment of orders on these platforms, from typically within 1 day to 3-4 days. “Stock availability of essentials will not be an issue. It’s just that we got hit by the huge unprecedented surge and hence struggled with stocks for a day or two. We are getting geared on stocks now,” said Menon, adding that they are advising consumers to not buy more than needed.Dhindsa said the SoftBank- and Tiger Global-backed company has started implementing limits on hand sanitisers and masks, which have been deemed essential goods by the government. It also put dynamic restrictions on grocery items as it fears hoarding by some customers. “We are seeing hoarding behaviour come up, so we are figuring out how to stop that. It is better to be safe than greedy,” said Dhindsa, adding that Grofers has already started implementing restrictions on some grocery items as well.Grofers also saw a customer in Chandigarh run up a bill of Rs 52,000 on the platform, beating the previous record of Rs 24,000. Dhindsa said Grofers has also asked its delivery personnel, which number about 10,000, to take precautions, while giving each of them hand sanitisers. The Gurgaon-headquartered company is also “isolating” warehouses — not letting workers at one, go to the other — so in case there is an infection, multiple locations don’t stop working.Even offline retailers like Future Group , which owns Big Bazaar and Easyday, is seeing a spike of 20-25% according to industry sources. “The demand is significantly higher in select SKUs (stock-keeping units) like rice, daal, atta (flour), milk and ready-to-eat items like Maggi. This is happening over the last two-three days,” said a spokesperson of the Future Group.Supr, food-delivery major Swiggy’s micro-delivery platform, which sells milk and other essentials like eggs, bread, vegetables and fruits, has told consumers it will now deliver the products to consumers by 9am due to high demand. Typically, it delivers by 7am every morning.

Title: Tatas, Wipro propose work-from-home
Content:
(Representative image)

MUMBAI/BENGALURU: The Tata Group and Wipro have recommended — in some cases mandated — work-from-home for their employees in response to the Covid-19 outbreak. Tata Motors has mandated work-from-home for non-customer facing roles from Monday.

Across several Tata Group companies, employees in consumer-facing roles like sales, marketing and customer relationship management have been given guidance on flexible work arrangements. Pregnant women and employees with chronic respiratory and cardiac illness have been advised to work from home .

Tata Realty and Infrastructure will split its employees into two groups, of which one will work on the first three days of the week and the other will come in for the rest of the three days for uninterrupted operations. The conglomerate employs a big salesforce in the country.

The Taj chain has asked its corporate office staff to work from home for a week from Monday. However, the vast majority of its workforce have jobs that require them to be present in its 100-plus hotels.

The Group’s largest employer TCS hasn’t issued a guidance, and has left the decision to functional and business heads. However, its IT counterpart Wipro has advised all employees to work from home “wherever feasible and if their role allows them to do so”.

All support and non-billable employees (including those who’re not engaged in any project) will work from home after consulting their managers. Wipro said video-conferencing should be used to hire prospective candidates.

“Face-to face meetings with potential candidates must not be scheduled until further notice,” it said. It has prohibited group meetings of over 10 people and has put all travel on hold, except for those scheduled to return to their base location due to regulatory requirements (visa).

Title: Noida: Drunk man driving BMW stops to urinate, miscreants flee with car
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only.

NOIDA: Some unidentified miscreants allegedly fled away with a BMW car after the man driving it pulled up to urinate on a roadside here, police said on Sunday.

According to officials, the incident happened on Saturday night in Sector 90 under Phase 2 police station limits, when Rishabh Arora , a stock broker, was returning in the car from a party in an inebriated condition.

The luxury car is owned by Arora's brother-in-law and there is a Rs 40 lakh loan pending on the vehicle, they said.

“Police force including senior officials had reached the spot after a matter was reported that a man's BMW car has been robbed," said deputy commissioner of police, Central Noida , Harish Chander .

Arora had stopped the car midway and came out to urinate. Meanwhile, some unidentified miscreants reached the spot and fled with the vehicle, Chander added.

Prime facie, it appears the robbery has been planned by somebody known to the car's owner, the DCP said.

An FIR has been registered against unidentified people and the police are probing the matter from all angles and would ensure recovery of the vehicle soon, the officer said.

Asked if the stock broker would be charged with drunk driving, DCP Chander told PTI: “The priority is to recover the BMW and ensure arrest of the culprits. It's a serious concern that somebody's car gets robbed like this on city roads.”

Arora has alleged in his complaint that the miscreants, who had arrived on a motorcycle, had put a gun on his back while he was relieving himself but that claim is yet to be verified since he was “highly drunk”, according to officials.

Arora was using his brother-in-law's BMW for about six-seven days now, the officials added.

Title: Covid-19 scare: Sales down as residents prefer to stay home even at weekend
Content: PATNA: With cinema halls, parks and zoo closed, most residents were confined to their homes this weekend. Vehicular traffic was quite less on the streets. People also avoided going to restaurants and eateries owing to rumours over outside food following the instruction and advisories issued by the state government on Friday.Hangouts in the city, including malls, restaurants, roadside eateries, market places, hotels, shops, gymnasium, Ganga riverfront and parks, which usually buzz with activities on Sundays, wore a deserted look this time. Residents have stopped ordering food from restaurant through mobile applications.Vikash Kumar, a sales executive in a mall at Fraser Road, said the government advisory asking people to avoid crowded places has also played a role in people avoiding markets. “The sales have gone down by almost 75% in the last couple of days. We have even come up with several offers on dresses and apparels to entice the buyers, but to no avail,” he said.Anjani, who works for a restaurant near Bandar Bagicha, said the Covid-19 scare has adversely affected their business. “We are normally jam-packed even on weekdays as food lovers queue up to book tables. However, only a handful of people have been coming to our restaurant for the past few days,” he said.Rupa Sinha, who owns a restaurant near Dak Bungalow crossing, said the sales have reduced almost by 80% due to the Covid- 19 scare. “I expect this to continue for the next few weeks. The online bookings have also gone down,” she said.Shobhna, a medical aspirant and hosteller , who lives in Makhania Kuan, said, “I wanted to go out with my friends to a nearby eatery, but my parents have strictly told me to stay at the hostel. The days have become lazy, as I neither have classes to attend nor places to hang out.”Kirti Sinha of Exhibition Road said she has been avoiding eateries. “I’m scared. It is better to stay indoors and safe than taking any risk,” she said.Even the small markets and roadside shops are bearing the loss due to low turnout of customers. Residents are also avoiding places like Gandhi Maidan and Ganga riverfront. “There is no place to hang out after the state government shut cinema halls, parks and zoo. My kids are also getting anxious to go out after the schools were closed. They watched cartoon shows all day,” said Mrityunjay Gupta of Langar Toli.Shweta of Bhattacharyya Road said, “I celebrated my 24th birthday at home with small gathering of friends. We had earlier decided to watch a movie and dine out, but our mother did not allow us.”

Title: Patna University hostels likely to be vacated due to Covid-19 scare
Content: PATNA: All the hostels of Patna University (PU) and colleges affiliated to it are likely to be vacated as a preventive measure against coronavirus . A formal decision to this effect would be taken at a meeting of the wardens and superintendents of PU hostels on Monday.PU students’ welfare dean N K Jha said since classes have already been suspended and all examinations scheduled till March 31 postponed, there is hardly any purpose of allowing students to reside in hostels. Students would feel more secured and safe with their parents at homes, he said.Meanwhile, the wardens and superintendents of all the hostels have been directed to ensure sufficient supply of cleansing materials in hostels and get the washrooms cleaned regularly, said PU registrar Manoj Kumar Mishra . “The railings of staircases and handles of doors of rooms must be sanitized frequently for preventing the spread of coronavirus,” he said.The registrar further pointed out that efforts are being made to get the entire PU office sanitized so that the officers, employees and teachers visiting the university remain safe and protected from the deadly coronavirus. The principals of colleges and heads of departments have also been directed to strictly follow the advisory issued by the state government and the UGC against the coronavirus.The UGC has requested all universities and their affiliated colleges to take necessary precautions for “a coordinated and collective effort in a mission mode”. It advised the universities and colleges to avoid large gatherings on campus. “Any student/staff with travel history to any coronavirus-affected country or in contact with such persons in last 28 days, should be monitored and home quarantined for 14 days,” the UGC advisory said.The advisory further states that everyone should throw away used tissues in a bin and wash their hands after contact with coughing/sneezing. Frequently touched surfaces – door knobs, switches, desk tops and hand railings should be disinfected and alcohol-based hand cleaners and sanitizers provided in frequented spots of the university and colleges, it adds.Patna University Teachers’ Association president and warden of Patna College hostels Randhir Kumar Singh , however, said most colleges and PG departments of PU, especially the hostels for boys and girls, are not at all prepared to face the threat posed by coronavirus. “Most of the departments do not provide for clean water and they do not have well cleaned washrooms either. Hence, it is better all the institutions are closed completely till the threat of coronavirus ends,” he added.

Title: Curtains removed from AC coaches
Content:
PATNA: Railways has removed curtains from the airconditioned coaches on trains as a precautionary measure against coronavirus (Covid-19). All AC coaches are being sanitized and trains are being fogged under East Central Railway jurisdiction.

ECR general manager L C Trivedi has also issued advisory to carry out disinfection process of every passenger contact surface at railway platforms such as benches, chairs, washbasins, bathrooms, door knobs and ticket booking counters at all major stations, ECR chief public relations officer (CPRO) Rajesh Kumar said on Sunday. Sufficient liquid soaps are being supplied in the coaches of every passenger train, he said.

“The GM reviewed the preparations in view of the large number of people undertaking journey by trains from Bihar to other parts of the country after Holi,” Kumar said.

Since Bihar has borders with Nepal and Bangladesh, all possible precautionary measures are to be strictly followed in each division in the light of the Railway Board’s directives,” he added.

According to Danapur DRM Sunil Kumar, railways has set up help desks at all major stations in the division. “Railway security personnel and commercial staff are manning these desks to provide medical assistance to sick passengers. Railway doctors at Patna Junction are also keeping a close watch on sick passengers,” Kumar said.

Title: No entrance test for regular PG courses at Patna varsity
Content:
PATNA: Patna University (PU) will not hold entrance test this year too for the admission of students to its regular postgraduate (PG) courses for the next academic session. Admission to the conventional MA, MSc and MCom courses of the university will be made on the basis of marks obtained in the last qualifying examinations.

It was expected that following the implementation of choice based credit system (CBCS) at PG level, entrance to all the conventional as well as self-financing courses will be made on the basis of entrance test.

PU has already been holding entrance test for the admission to all its self-financing courses, both at PG and undergraduate (UG) level, but for reasons known best to the authorities alone, no entrance test is held for admission to the conventional PG courses. Even admission to the three-year degree courses in arts, science and commerce is made on the basis of combined written entrance test conducted by the university.

According to a decision taken at the meeting of PU’s academic calendar committee on Saturday under the chairmanship of vice-chancellor (VC) Rash Bihari Prasad Singh, the process of admission of students to different UG and PG courses, both under regular and self-financing streams, would commence on April 3 with the online sale and submission of application forms.

The last date for the submission of application forms for all courses, except regular PG courses, is May 23. The last date for submission of applications for regular PG courses is June 15.

Candidates may apply for admission in such courses where admission is based on entrance test, but they would have to submit the copy of their mark sheet of the previous result before the finalization of the selection list for admission. However, submission of mark sheet along with the application forms for admission is mandatory for such courses where admission is based on the marks secured in the last qualifying examination.

Courses offered by PU include MA, MSc, MCom, MEd and LLM (regular PG degree courses), MA in rural studies, MBA, MSc in environmental science & management, MSc in biotechnology, MA in social work, women’s studies, journalism and mass communications, library and information science, MCA and MA in music (self-financing PG degree courses) and PG diploma courses in clinical psychology, applied criminology, human resource development, industrial safety management, computer applications, women and child welfare, women’s studies, yogic sciences and financial services.

Courses offered at the undergraduate stage include three-year degree courses in BA, BSc, BCom and BFA honours (conventional regular mode) and BCom honours, BLib & Information Science, BCA, BA in computer applications, BBA, bachelor in mass communications, bachelor in social work, bachelor in biotechnology, functional English and environmental science (self-financing).

Combined entrance tests for the admission to BCom, BA and BSc courses will be held on May 28, May 29 and June 2, respectively. Entrance tests for admission to all other self-financing courses will be held on different dates in May and June.

PU pro-VC Dolly Sinha said all admissions will be completed by July 9. “Induction meet for the newly admitted students will be organized by the institutions between July 10 and 15 and the classes will start on July 16,” she said.

Title: Government may announce more measures today
Content: PATNA: The state government will hold a crucial meeting on Monday to deliberate on various measures to be adopted by it for coronavirus prevention, including possibility of invoking Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897 to curb visits at public places, malls and multiplexes. There are also chances of the ongoing budget session of state legislature either getting prorogued or adjourned sine die.Earlier, several important decisions were taken at a high level meeting convened by chief minister Nitish Kumar last Friday. Schools, colleges and cinema halls were closed till March 31.Deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi said on Sunday that deliberations would be held on prevailing scenario in the state in the light of fresh guidelines issued by the Centre, including declaration of Covid-19 spread as “disaster”.“The state government is taking all possible steps to prevent spread of coronavirus. Thanks to several preventive measures initiated by the government, no positive case of Covid-19 has so far been detected in the state. While several measures were already taken by the state government, a call would be taken at Monday’s meeting on other steps required for the prevention of the deadly virus,” the deputy CM said.Sources said a copy of Epidemic Diseases Act, which has already been invoked by Delhi and Maharashtra government, was circulated in the meeting on Friday. The Act allows the state to take any step necessary to control the outbreak, including forcible quarantine.As far as ongoing budget session of the state legislature is concerned, sources said a final call on the matter would be taken at the business advisory committee meeting of the state assembly on Monday. The meeting, to be chaired by assembly Speaker Vijay Kumar Choudhary, will be attended by representatives of all major political parties.“The business advisory committee meeting of the legislature has been especially called for the purpose of deciding measures to be taken amid the global outbreak of coronavirus. Though a final decision on the issue will be taken at the meeting, I have personally observed that legislators are of the view that the advisories issued by the government for curbing the spread of coronavirus should be strictly adhered to,” assembly Speaker Choudhary said.Altogether 1,49,135 people have been screened at transit points in the state till Sunday. Besides, 19,216 people have been screened at Patna and Gaya airports. Officials said as many as 274 passengers, who have returned from coronavirus-affected countries since January 15, have been kept in home isolation. Of them, 86 have completed 14-day quarantine. Samples of 57 people have been sent to National Institute of Virology.

Title: Chamber seeks relaxation on GST filings, advance tax
Content:
Chennai: In the wake of disruptions to businesses caused by the Corona pandemic, industry bodies have sought government intervention to cushion businesses against severe shocks, including deferment of advance income tax remittance and GST payments, besides seeking waiver of demurrage or interest among others.

In a memorandum to the union finance ministry, the president of Ramkumar Ramamoorthy, Madras Chamber of Commerce & Industry (MCCI) one of the oldest industry bodies in the country, said, “The spread of coronavirus is leading to shrinkage of exports, cessation of production, inaccessibility of person-power, non-availability of particular imports,slowdown in consumption, among others. Extraordinary circumstances demand extraordinary measures.” The note said: due date for advance tax to be deferred or alternatively defer the interest under Sections 234B and 234C of the Income Tax Act. It also sought deferring the due date for GST for March 2020, besides seeking restraint from the government with regards to recovery proceedings under CGST, given it will further choke an already gasping industry.. The memorandum said, “Given that all cargo is subject to significant examination and there are delays in clearance, there should not be any levy of demurrage or interest or port charges during this period.” It also sought relaxations under the bankruptcy code or IBC. “Defaults during these trying months of dealing and combating with a virus and the paranoia should not result in an IBC trigger. There should be a moratorium for next few months in the context of Section 7 and 9 of the IBC Act. Classification of NPAs as per current RBI guidelines should be deferred for a few months,” the note said.

Title: Villagers block road demanding water
Content: Rajkot: Hit by a severe water crisis , people of Magharwada village on the outskirts of Rajkot staged a chakka jam (road block) on Rajkot-Ahmedabad Highway on Sunday morning. The villagers alleged that they had not received drinking water for the past fortnight, for which they had made representations before the water supply board of Rajkot district, but to no avail. Left with no choice they finally decided to stage a chakka jam. TNN

Title: Fake social media post on coronavirus triggers panic
Content: Mussoorie: A social media post stating that a person has been diagnosed with novel coronavirus in the Landour Community Hospital triggered panic among residents on Sunday. The post was uploaded by a student on Saturday late evening. In no time, the post went viral and alarmed many residents in the town.However, officials of Landour Community Hospital soon clarified that the post is completely fake and none of their patients has been tested coronavirus-positive.

Title: Two commit suicide in separate incidents
Content:
Nagpur: Two suicides, including one at Hot Chips, were reported at different locations in the city. Police have registered a case of accidental death in both the cases and launched an investigation.

In the first incident, a 21-year-old man from Tamil Nadu committed suicide by hanging himself in his rented shop off Chhaoni Road. Sagadevan Swami took the extreme step when he was alone.

According to the police, Swami had come to city along with his elder brother a few months back. The duo took two shops on rent in different locations.

On Saturday, Swami went to his shop and hanged himself in the second room. The incident came to light after some customers gave him a call. When he didn’t respond, they entered the second room of the shop where they found him hanging. After being informed, Sadar police arrived at the spot in no time.

Swami’s brother Prakash, too, learnt about the incident and rushed to the shop.

Cops said the reason behind Swami’s suicide is still unknown.

In another incident, Arun Hedau, 55, died at Mayo Hospital on Saturday, days after he consumed poison at his home in Lalganj. According to the police, Arun took the extreme step on March 3 when he was alone at home.

He was taken to hospital by his family members but he died while undergoing treatment. Shanti Nagar police have registered a case accidental death.

Title: Man held for creating fake social media account of woman
Content:
FILE PHOTO: Silhouettes of mobile users are seen next to a screen projection of Facebook logo in this picture ... Read More

Rajkot: A man was arrested from Vadodara on Sunday for allegedly creating fake social media account of a Rajkot-based woman and uploading obscene messages along with her photographs.

Police said the accused, identified as Prakash Shimpi (29), was arrested from his residence in Rajratna Society of Pratapnagar locality in Vadodara.

“Shimpi had allegedly created the fake Facebook account of the victim after taking her photographs. He also accessed list of her friends and relatives and their social media id from her original Facebook account. He had allegedly put obscene messages in the profile of the woman. He also allegedly sent friend requests on her behalf to her friends and relatives,” said B M Kataria, inspector with the cyber cell of Rajkot police.

Shimpi is a BSc and is pursuing MSc in physics.

Title: Visa confusion, flight suspension spark Bangladesh return rush
Content: KOLKATA: On a day the ministry of home affairs issued a notification banning passenger movement through the India-Bangladesh border from Monday until further orders, Bangladeshi passengers made a scramble to board flights out of Kolkata as the fare for the hour-long journey shot up to Rs 12,000 from Rs 3,500-Rs 4,000. While two Bangladeshi carriers have suspended operations from Saturday evening, Regent Airways and US-Bangla Airlines operated on Sunday. But a US-Bangla Airline official said they will stop flying from Monday till further orders.Indian carriers IndiGo, SpiceJet and Air India are still operating flights on the sector. However, considering the drop in passenger count from Bangladesh to Kolkata — some flights carried just 15-20 flyers — and with tickets selling at third the usual price, the airlines’ officials said they will take a call on the situation this week.Safiul Ahmed, a Bangladeshi citizen who was in Kolkata for his wife’s treatment, was among hundreds of Bangladeshis scrambling for tickets at the airport on Sunday. “My wife has a chemotherapy session on Monday. But on learning that flights are getting cancelled and there is confusion over validity of the visa, we are returning home for the time being. I will bring her back once the situation normalizes,” said Ahmed, who took a US-Bangla Airline to Dhaka on Sunday.The confusion among the Bangladeshi nationals got worse with the ministry of home affairs’ decision to suspend all existing visas, barring diplomatic, UN/international organisations, employment and project visas, till April 15, 2020. However, a senior government official clarified that those already in India will be allowed to go home with their existing visas within the valid dates.Bangladeshi businessman Masood Hussain had come to Kolkata last week and was enjoying a vacation in Agra with his wife Hasina and children Antar and Ananya when he cut short his trip and back to Kolkata airport on Sunday to fly back home. However, he was stumped when he learned that the Rs 4,000 tickets were selling at Rs 15,000 each.“We were scheduled to travel to Jaipur on Sunday but instead I came to Kolkata. I had return tickets to Dhaka with an Indian carrier on March 17, but because of the confusion surrounding flight suspension and visa cancellation, we came back early. I even tried to book tickets for home, but it was costing me more than Rs 60,000 for four tickets. The Indian airline has assured me that they will fly on March 17. So, for the time being, I am staying back in Kolkata,” said Hussain.

Title: Gujarat: Kutch man killed over game of ludo
Content:
Accused in police custody

RAJKOT: A simple game of ludo turned bloody when five players murdered a sixth during a game in Bharatnagar locality of Gandhidham in Kutch district on Saturday. One accused has been arrested, while two minor accused have been detained by police on Sunday. Two more accused are on the run.

Police said the accused, identified as Bharat Sanghar, Prince Goswami, Rahul Chauhan and their two minor accomplices attacked Vikas Ahir (19) with knives after an altercation over the game. The victim was taken to a private hospital where he succumbed to his injuries. According to the police, one of the minor accused had a tiff with the deceased’s friend, Rahul Maheshweri and also allegedly slapped the latter. When Ahir and another friend, Chirag, intervened in the scuffle, an altercation broke out in which Ahir, Chirag and Maheshweri and the minor accused hurled abuses at each other.

“After this the minor accused left the spot and returned armed with knives along with Bharat Sanghar. When the accused found Ahir going home alone, they accosted him and stabbed him twice,” said D V Rana, inspector with Gandhidham local crime branch. Meanwhile, police nabbed Sanghar (29) and detained the two minor accused in Gandhidham. The deceased was married and used to run a food stall.

Title: New norms for card security from today
Content:
(Representative image)

MUMBAI: Credit and debit cardholders that have not used their cards for contactless or international payments may find these features deactivated from Monday. These features will have to be activated using a text message, or mobile or internet banking .

Earlier this year, the RBI had asked all banks to ensure that at the time of issuance, cards are enabled only for payment in Indian stores. Only if the user requests for online usage or contactless usage can the card be activated for the same. Some lenders, like SBI, have already started alerting the customers based on their usage history. These norms are aimed at protecting those who are not familiar with online transactions or payment gateways from being defrauded.

The RBI had said in a circular that “...facility to switch on/off and set/modify transaction limits (within the overall card limit, if any, set by the issuer) for all types of transactions — domestic and international, at PoS/ATMs/ online transactions/contactless transactions” should be provided on a 24X7 basis through multiple channels.

The channels should include mobile applications, internet banking, ATMs, or interactive voice response. The RBI had further said that for existing cards, issuers may take a decision, based on their risk perception, whether to disable the card not present (domestic and international) transactions, card present (international) transactions and contactless transaction rights.

Title: Drainage cleaning work to be over by May 15: PMC
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

PATNA: The Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC) has expedited the sewerage cleaning work for better drainage during the rainy season in the city. The cleaning work had been started on March 3 and will continue till May 15.

Catch-pits and manholes in Azimabad, Bankipore, Kankarbagh, New Capital, Patliputra and Patna City circles, including areas such as Ashok Rajpath, Sudarshan Path, Guru Gobind Singh Path, Indra Nagar , Meethapur bus stand road, Lohia Park road and Exhibition Road among other places were unclogged by the sanitation workers outsourced through private firms.

Executive officer of Azimabad and Patna City circles, S K Mishra, said on Sunday that almost 10-12% of the unclogging work had been completed. “The cleaning work has been executed in a planned way and monitored by the PMC commissioner,” he said.

Prakash Kumar, city manager of Kankarbagh, said the drainage cleaning work has been going on in all the 75 wards of PMC. “The private firm has been providing 15 sanitation workers for each ward. The work has been carried out with the help of JCBs (75), bob-carts (75), haiwas (80) and super-suction machines (6),” he told this newspaper.

“Besides, we are providing safety equipment to sanitation workers engaged in cleaning manholes in the city. A person entering a manhole must carry approved breathing apparatus (oxygen masks), safety helmets, protective clothing, gumboots and gloves, and rescue ropes,” said Kumar.

Patna mayor Sita Sahu said the cleaning of nine big drains and underground drains will be begin from April first week. “For this, the PMC has floated tender and the selected company would provide manpower and experts to unclog big drains. The bidding would be opened on March 21,” she said.

“The work is being monitored by the PMC officials and sanitary inspectors. Now that the PMC is taking measures before the arrival of monsoon, that surely will make the situation better during the rainy season,” she said.

Title: Airfare drops by 10% as people avoid travel due to coronavirus scare
Content: PATNA: Air ticket prices have been reduced by almost 10% due to cancellations of tickets as people are avoiding travel out of coronavirus (Covid-19) scare, airlines executives said.GoAir executives at Patna airport said the demand for air tickets would further drop in the next coming days as people were postponed their travel plan and cancelling tickets. “After Holi or any festival, the airfare increases up to 15-18% than the average price. But the prices have drastically dropped on several routes, including Delhi, Mumbai, Hyderabad and Kolkata,” he said.SpiceJet executives said the aircraft is sanitized after passengers deboard the flight. “The city airport has provided hand sanitizers at boarding counters. Although the number of sanitizers is less than the requirement, we are still taking all precautionary measures,” the executives said.The travel mobile applications and web portals showed that Patna-Delhi airfare has come down to Rs3,366-Rs4,564 compared to above Rs6,000 after Holi. Airfare on Patna-Kolkata route dropped to Rs2,886, on Patna-Mumbai route to Rs6,246 and on Patna-Hyderabad route to Rs5,824.Many people who had come home on Holi are avoiding to go back to their places of work. Some people are also stuck in big cities as they avoid travelling to come back home.Mayuri Jaiswal, who studies in Delhi, said she was supposed to return to Delhi after Holi, but the college has been closed till March 31. “I cancelled my air ticket,” she said.Kunal Singh, a software engineer in Mumbai, also extended his stay after his company asked the employees to work from home. “I spent Rs9,865 on a flight ticket to Mumbai, but had to cancel my ticket and got only half the amount as refund,” he said.Many people rescheduled their tickets by paying extra money. Rohit Kumar of Budhha Colony said he planned to visit his son in Hyderabad on March 17, but rescheduled his flight to April 3 by paying Rs1,800 extra.However, ECR chief public relations officer Rajesh Kumar said there were very few cases of ticket cancellations. “Even people who are in Delhi are coming back to Bihar as schools, colleges and other places are shut,” he said.

Title: Trainee DSPs, SIs to vacate Rajgir centre
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

PATNA: More than 1,800 trainee sub-inspectors and 150 DSPs have been directed to leave for home after their training programme at Bihar Police Academy was stopped with immediate effect.

All other training programmes of state police at BMP centres have also been stopped with immediate effect due to coronavirus scare. The newly-built academy at Rajgir had started functioning on December 3, 2018. This is the first batch of DSPs undergoing training at the state police’s lone multifacility dedicated training centre.

Academy’s deputy director-cum-DIG Parwej Akhtar told TOI over phone that the order to stop all training programmes till March 31 was issued on Saturday. “Trainees started leaving the academy on Sunday,” he said.

He said more than 1800 sub-inspectors were presently undergoing training alongside 150 newly recruited DSP-ranked officers.

“Training of one batch of DSPs was about to end while another was at the beginning stages. Passing out parade for a batch of 200 sub-inspectors was about to take place as their training had been completed,” he said.

“Trainees have been directed to join on April 1. However, the date may change depending on the situation,” he said.

The DIG said support staff at the academy would work in three shifts of eight hours each to avoid mass gathering.

Akhtar said the entire premises was recently disinfected and fumigated. “The trainees had already been made aware about coronavirus and the steps required for maintaining hygiene. They have been asked to avoid handshakes,” he said.

Title: Traders’ body seeks cover for loss in biz
Content:
New Delhi: Amid the novel coronavirus scare that is gradually tightening its grip in the entire country, traders stare at a massive loss .

On Sunday, Confederation of All India Traders (CAIT) shot off a letter to the Union government, demanding a policy to provide insurance cover for business disruption due to coronavirus outbreak.

“Insurance companies should be mandated to introduce ‘Disruptions due to Coronavirus’ as an additional cover to fire and materials damage policies and existing policyholders may be offered an option to add ‘Disruptions due to Coronavirus’ to their cover,” CAIT secretary general Praveen Khandelwal urged the Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman in the communique.

Khandelwal said several precautionary measures have been taken to close down institutions, cinema halls, gyms and other service-oriented trade.

“Both the trade and the MSME sectors are likely to have negative economic impact, ranging from closure of establishments to disruptions in supplies and cancellation of events, contracts and travel plans. Each of this will have a significant cost associated,” he informed the ministry.

The traders’ body also asked for policies that will provide for hospitalisation expenses due to coronavirus or fixed benefits to traders upon diagnosis of Covid-19 .

Title: Varanasi: Harassed by cops, youth commits suicide
Content:
Representative image

VARANASI: A youth committed suicide on Saturday night after he was allegedly harassed by the police in a case of elopement of a girl. The youth identified as Abhishek was a resident of Salempur village under the limits of Mohammadabad Gohana police station in Mau district.

Angered over the incident, locals blocked the road and staged a massive protest. To pacify the situation Mohammadabad Gohana police lodged a case against Sitakiya police outpost in-charge Lal Singh, who is the investigation officer of the elopement case. Following the action taken by the Mohammadabad Gohana police, villagers allowed them to take the body for postmortem examination.

Abhishek’s father Ram Narain said, “Abhishek had been staying in Mumbai to earn his livelihood and support the family as our financial condition is not good. About eight months ago, a girl from a neighouring village fled with someone after which her family lodged a case of elopement against Abhishek.”

“Despite the fact that Abhishek had no involvement in this case, police were pressurising him. In view of it, we had taken stay order from high court against his arrest. He alleged that despite HC’s stay order, police continued harassing the family due to which Abhishek had returned home two months back and stayed here,” Ram Narain said.

“On Saturday evening, when Abhishek was alone at his residence, the investigation officer of the case raided the place and mentally harassed him again,” alleged Ram Narain.

“Shocked over it, Abhishek hanged himself inside his room. The incident came to light when family members returned home,” he added.

SO Mohammadabad, Gohana Niraj Pathak said, “An FIR against the investigation officer has been lodged under sections 306 and 506 of IPC in this connection.”

Title: Bhopal: Cabinet clears 5% DA for government staff
Content: BHOPAL: Amid Coronavirus outbreak concerns, the Madhya Pradesh government has announced that schools, colleges, libraries, cinemas, marriage halls, public gatherings and other common public places will remain shut till March 31 as a part of preventive measures.Addressing a press conference after a cabinet meeting chaired by chief minister Kamal Nath, government spokesperson and public relations minister P C Sharma said that the government is taking all necessary steps to prevent further outbreak of the virus. Moreover the state cabinet approved a 5% hike in dearness allowance for the state government employees, he said.“Legal measures are being taken to keep schools, colleges, anganwadis, public libraries, water parks, gyms, swimming pools, cinema halls and marriage halls in the state closed till further orders. The government has also postponed official travels, trainings and public functions and organizing gatherings of more than 20 people to prevent coronavirus infection,” said Sharma.He said a total of 9,312 passengers have been screened at airports in the state. All the suspected cases of Coronavirus are under observation. “A total 700 outside passengers have entered Madhya Pradesh after the outbreak. We have formed 50 isolation centres and instructed to distribute masks and sanitizers where necessary. We have also pleaded with the High Court to take up only important cases,” he added.Sharma said that MLAs who have come from Jaipur, Haryana, and Bengaluru should also be medically tested. “It was discussed in the state Cabinet meeting that our MLAs who have come from Jaipur should be medically tested. Those in Haryana and Bengaluru should also be medically tested,” said the minister.The cabinet also decided that two names as member of MP Public Service Commission (MPPSC). They are Ramu Tekam from Betul, who had contested Lok Sabha election as Congress candidate in 2019 and Rashid Suhail Siddiqui from Jabalpur.“The cabinet has also approved a 5% hike from 12% to 17%, in the dearness allowance (DA) for the state government employees, which will be disbursed from April 1,” Sharma said.He said the increased amount of DA will be paid from the salary or pension of March 2020 (payable in the month of April 2020). Separate orders will be issued for payment of arrears for the period from July 1, 2019 to February 29, 2020, said Sharma.

Title: Thailand man, Coimbatore woman admitted to CMCH’s Covid-19 isolation ward
Content: COIMBATORE: A 49-year-old man from Thailand and a 28-year-old local woman who had returned from Qatar suspected to be infected with Covid-19 have been admitted to the isolation ward of the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital (CMCH).The man had arrived in Tamil Nadu last week to visit religious places along with a group from Thailand. After visiting some religious places in Chennai, they reached Erode in a car on Saturday. There, the man developed fever, cough and cold. So, people in his group brought him to the Coimbatore airport on Saturday with a plan to send him to Chennai and from there, to Thailand.The special medical team at the airport that checked the man, who is also diabetic, found that he had symptoms of Covid-19. He was taken to CMCH and admitted to the coronavirus isolation ward. Samples of his blood and sputum have been sent for testing.The woman, who hails from the city, had returned from Qatar on Saturday. She had approached CMCH for treatment on Sunday after developing fever and cold. The medical team collected samples from her for testing and admitted her to the hospital’s isolation ward.Public health department officials are sanitizing vehicles entering the state through the Kerala-Tamil Nadu border as a precautionary measure.

Title: Coronavirus in Coimbatore: Coimbatore malls, schools to shut till March 31
Content: To check the spread of Covid-19, shopping malls in the city and movie halls in the district’s border areas will remain closed till March 31 along with nursery and primary classes, from LKG to Class V.After chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami ordered the State-wide closure on Sunday, Coimbatore collector K Rajamani ordered that 10 cinema theatres in the district’s border taluks such as Pollachi, Kinathukadavu and Anaimalai will remain closed till March 31. Representatives of three prominent shopping malls in the city — Brookefields Mall on Krishnasamy Road, Fun Republic Mall on Avinashi Road and Prozone Mall in Saravanampatti — announced that the malls will also remain closed.The collector requested people not to congregate in religious as well as public places. He instructed industrial and other organisations not to conduct events where people would gather in large numbers.The forest department has closed the Kovai Kuttralam falls for a week.Officials of the Coimbatore City Municipal Corporation said they have sanitized bus stands and shopping malls in the city by spraying sanitizer solution. The civic body has also sensitized sanitary workers on Covid-19 and has deployed them to create awareness among public.Health officials said a 108 ambulance has been earmarked to carry patients with Covid-19 symptoms.A communication from the Southern Railway said disinfectants were sprayed on the exteriors and interiors of all coaches. “Audio announcements and videos are being played on a regular basis to create awareness about precautionary measures against Covid-19. We have withdrawn supply of woollen blankets for AC coach passengers and will remove curtains in all classes of AC coaches,” it added.

Title: Kerala: Wedding photoshoot to ward off Covid-19
Content: ALAPPUZHA: A bride and groom from Alappuzha have made their pre-wedding photoshoot and their wedding a platform for creating awareness among people to remain safe from Covid-19 . Their pre-wedding photoshoot pictures became viral on social media Rahul Neelapparambil, a native of Mannancherry, and Sreelekshmi T of Muhamma were eagerly awaiting till Sunday — the day they were getting married after a six-year-long courtship. So, both of them invited over 2,500 people for their wedding and reception programmes.They had a lot of plans on their wedding day and they did a pre-wedding photoshoot (‘save the date’ shoot). That is when Covid-19 phase two struck the state, casting a shadow on their dream-wedding plans. The heath department directed them to conduct their nuptials in the presence of only their immediate family members and avoid a large gathering.“We got directions to avoid functions for the people with only three days remaining for our wedding. We had to inform all our invited friends and neighbours about it. Though initially, we were crestfallen, we decided to turn it into a postive event which would be a platform to create awareness about this disease. We had to re-do our ‘save the date’ photoshoot in which we conveyed the guidelines of the health department to prevent Covid-19 and posted them on social media. Through the pictures we sent across a message to avoid hand shakes and wear masks when coming in contact with people. They were an instant hit and the responses were great. Our invitees soon understood our predicament,” said Rahul.On the wedding day, they exhibited the guidelines of the health department on Covid-19 and clicked the post-wedding pictures were clicked wearing masks.Rahul is the owner of Frame Creators wedding company and the bride Sreelekshmi too is learning photography.

Title: Coronavirus in Uttarakhand: 8 IIT-Roorkee students kept in isolation
Content: ROORKEE: IIT-Roorkee has reportedly kept eight students, including one of foreign origin, in isolation at a guest house in the institute as a preventive measure.Sources told TOI that all the students, who are being kept in isolation, had recently returned from abroad.An institute official, who did not wish to be named, said, “These students are under watch for the past 14 days and will be discharged after they complete the incubation period.”Meanwhile, the institute has claimed that its campus is safe from the outbreak of the virus.“There is no Covid-19 positive case on the campus,” said director AK Chaturvedi.

Title: Jaganmohan Reddy blames Chandrababu Naidu for SEC decision on local body polls
Content:
Jaganmohan Reddy

VIJAYAWADA: Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy on Sunday said state election commissioner Nimmagadda Ramesh Kumar postponed local body polls on the instructions of ‘someone else.’

The chief minister also met governor Biswa Bhushan Harichandan and complained that the State Election Commission ’s decision was unilateral and irrational.

The chief minister alleged that it was a conspiracy hatched by opposition leader N Chandrababu Naidu since he knew that YSRC was going to sweep the elections to local bodies.

“Naidu is using his moles in the system and destroying all the institutions. If the elections were not completed by March 31, we will lose about Rs 5,000 crore from the 14th Finance Commission. Naidu does not want these funds to come and development to take place as he wants to take revenge on people for rejecting him in the recent elections,” he the CM alleged.

The CM said: “He (the SEC) might have got the job from Naidu. He might be from the same caste as Naidu’s but he should act neutrally as election commissioner. It has become a fashion for everyone to use the word discretionary powers.”

Jagan said the even the secretary to the election commission did not know that the order was coming.

He said the government had taken all measures to contain the spread of Covid-19. The situation in the state is normal and there is no need for panic. The indefinite postponement of elections citing the threat of Covid-19 is only a pretext as the SEC consulted neither the health secretary nor the chief secretary before taking the decision, said the CM.

He said that dealing with Covid-19 would have been easier and effective had the elections were completed at the earliest as it is in the stage-I only as far as AP is concerned. Moreover, if the elected local representatives are in charge, the government can take up the awareness and prevention programmes more effectively, the CM added.

The CM also slammed the SEC for transferring and suspending the officials. “Can such right be given to the election commissioner or can such right be taken by him. If such is the case, why should any government come in a democracy when the election commissioner is taking the decisions as if he is the chief minister,” he said.

The CM also found fault with the SEC for giving orders to district collectors to stop distribution of house sites to the poor and other welfare measures. “Quite interestingly a day after he gave the orders to collectors to stop house site distributions, the election commissioner postponed the elections indefinitely, I do not know what has changed overnight,” he said.

The CM said more than 80% of the infected persons have recovered across the globe and the percentage of fatalities among the infected was very minimal. “Life should not come to a halt because of the virus spread instead we have to learn to live with it by taking necessary measures which the government has already taken. Is there any guarantee that the virus can be contained in the next two weeks and if it continue to spread for the next one year and in all probability it will, is it correct to postpone the elections indefinitely,” he asked.

He also down played the issue of unanimous nominations. In 2013, many candidates from all parties were elected unanimously. “YSRC won the recent elections with huge mandate and in the past nine months we have implemented 90% of our promises made in the manifesto which is the reason why more than 2,000 MPTCs and ZPTCs were elected unanimously,” he said.

He said that no local body elections have been held without stray incidents of violence. “This year also there have been some incidents reported and I am proud that the police have acted swiftly by booking cases, including attempted murder cases, without looking at the party affiliations,” he said.

Title: Aurangabad: Externed duo caught on tape dancing with sword held
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: Cidco police were put in a tight spot after a video of two externed history-sheeters dancing with a sword during a pre-wedding revelry in TV Centre area of the city went viral on social media.

After the video went viral, Cidco police tried to find the accused duo — Kapil Ramesh Jogdand (23) and Imran alias Bablu Rauf Shaikh (22) — and arrest them, but failed.

Later, Pundaliknagar police, led by assistant inspector Ghanshyam Sonawne , managed to arrest the duo on Sunday. Jogdand was arrested from near BSGM school ground while Shaikh was held from Vijay Nagar Chowk . Police have also seized the sword seen the video.

As many as nine cases, including a couple of attempt to murder cases, are registered against Jogdand, while Shaikh has five cases (all body offences) registered against him,

Jogdand is also the key accused in the 2018 Pundaliknagar riot that resulted from tearing of Shivaji Maharaj ’s poster. This incident had resulted in serious riots and law and order situation in the city.

Considering his involvement in series of offences, Jogdand was externed by deputy commissioner of police (zone-II) Rahul Khade on September 3, 2019 for a period of one year.

Shaikh too has a record of being involved in brawls at public places and was externed from the city limits on April 20, 2019 for a period of one year.

The video substantiates the fact that the accused duo, despite being externed, continued to live in the city without prior permission or knowledge of the police authorities. The authorities woke up only after the video went viral on social media.
