“We were trying to identify the youths who can be seen dancing along with the accused duo following which their criminal records would also be scanned for initiating stringent action against them,” a police officer said.

Title: Bhopal: Ahead of trust vote, ‘confident’ Congress MLAs return from Jaipur
Content:
Ahead of trust vote, ‘confident’ Congress MLAs return from Jaipur

BHOPAL: A day ahead of the Governor’s directive to the Speaker to conduct a floor test to prove Kamal Nath government’s majority, about 90 Congress MLAs loyal to chief minister, Nath and a couple of Independent MLAs, who were lodged at a resort in Jaipur arrived in Bhopal on Sunday morning. Unlike when they hurriedly left for Jaipur, the ruling party MLAs appeared relaxed and confident with some of them even flashing the ‘Victory’ sign to the waiting media.

MLAs claimed that the Congress government — which plunged into a crisis following rebellion by senior party leader Jyotiraditya Scindia and the 19 MLAs supporting him— would prove majority in the floor test. The number of disgruntled MLAs, who resigned from the Congress has swelled to 23 by now.

Independent MLA Surendra Singh Shera who had made his intent clear by pulically expressing his desire to be home minister, claimed that Congress government is safe. “There is no crisis in the government. All is well, and we shall win the floor test,” said a beaming Shera.

Law minister PC Sharma alleged that the BJP is doing black magic (tantra- mantra) on the rebel Congress MLAs, who are holed up in Bengaluru.

Senior Congress leader from Uttarakhand , Harish Rawat , who accompanied the MLAs to Bhopal, exuded confidence that the party would tide over the crisis and said they were also in touch in rebel MLAs. “We are ready for the floor test and are confident of winning it. We are not nervous, BJP is. Those (rebel) MLAs are also in touch with us,” he said.

Even as they expressed confidence that Kamal Nath government would weather the storm and pass the floor test, some MLAs, who talked to media also hinted that budget session could be postponed in the wake of Coronavirus threat. “Health of legislators and everybody in the state is far more important than anything else and there is nothing more important than containment of coronavirus in MP”, said finance minister, Tarun Bhanot , who has been entrusted with the charge of health department after Tulsi Silawat was removed from the cabinet.

The possibility of deferring the budget session in the wake of Coronavirus threat was also discussed in the cabinet meeting, which took place soon after arrival of Congress MLAs, but a final decision on the issue was left to the Speaker.

After landing at Raja Bhoj airport, the MLAs were moved to a local hotel while ministers among them left for Mantralaya to attend the Cabinet meeting.

Following the Cabinet meeting, the chief minister went back to his official residence, where he was, later, joined by the former chief minister and senior party leader, Digvijaya Singh and eminent lawyer and party’s Rajya Sabha member, Vivek Tankha .

The MLAs were, later, taken to CM House, in buses in the evening to participate in the Congress legislative party (CLP) meeting.

Title: Poll deferral based on Centre’s health advisory, says SEC
Content:
Vijayawada: After reactions over postponement of local body elections from YSRC, including from chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy, the State Commission (SEC) issued a clarification explaining the reasons for its decision.

In a statement, the state election commissioner Nimmagadda Ramesh Kumar said the Government of India (GoI) has issued a health advisory to all states on March 14 to avoid large public gatherings. The GoI has classified coronavirus as a disaster and kept the nation in a state of preparedness.

On the allegations of not consulting with the health department officials on Covid-19, the SEC said the state election commissioner did contact national level functionaries before taking a decision on coronavirus threat posed. If the warning issued by GoI is de-escalated, the SEC will restart the election process without loss of a single day, the statement added.

On the issue of house sites, the SEC clarified that the high court in its observations in the recent judgment given said that the SEC was bound to follow guidelines of the ECI. As the issue of house sites to individual beneficiaries is covered under the Model Code of Conduct (MCC) an appropriate decision was taken according to the ECI guidelines on MCC.

The SEC stated that the violence in the ongoing elections is a matter that is engaging the attention of the commission and various political parties have been highlighting the surge of violence. This is also a subject matter in an ongoing litigation before the high court in which the SEC is a respondent. The SEC is affecting certain measures regarding government functionaries and acted as per the dictum of the Supreme Court contained in the land mark judgment in Kishan Singh Tomar Vs the Municipal Corporation of Ahmedabad.

Finally the SEC stated that it is a constitutional body and the commissioner is at par with the judge of high court. All the safeguards available to a judge of the high court are applicable to State Election Commissioner. To attribute motives for the acts of a constitutional functionary are highly regretted and will only weaken the institution, the statement added.

Title: Chief minister has no right to play with public safety, says Naidu
Content:
Amaravati: TDP president Nara Chandrababu Naidu on Sunday said chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy has no right to play with the public safety.

Reacting to Jagan’s finding fault with the SEC for postponement of local and civic body polls, Naidu said the Centre had already declared novel coronavirus (Covid-19) as disaster and put the states on high alert in tackling the situation.

Naidu said the postponement of the elections was a wise move in view of coronavirus scare.

He told media that Jagan had “exposed his ignorance” by criticizing the SEC’s decision to postpone the election process by a few weeks. “Chief minister appeared bothered only about the politics and his political power. It is not only strange but shocking for a chief minister not taking the grim situation prevailing across the world following the outbreak of coronavirus into serious consideration,” Naidu alleged.

Naidu said that the SEC is a constitutional authority and questioning its decision is nothing but trying to blackmail the institution. He said that the CM should keep in mind that he could not do whatever he desires even if he has the mandate to rule the state.

“In fact, SEC Ramesh Kumar is not my appointee. My government had recommended the name of CR Biswas for the post of State Election Commissioner in 2016. However, then governor ESL Narasimhan had appointed Ramesh Kuamr has SEC,” Naidu clarified. He condemned the way Ramesh Kumar’s caste was being linked only to push the constitutional authority to the corner.

Naidu said widespread violence took place during the filing of papers across the state and in fact TDP had been demanding for taking corrective measures to uphold democracy since the process was started.

He said the state administration had not responded to the TDP’s initial complaints and it acted only after SEC exerted pressure.

He said that Macherla police let off the accused in the attempt murder case with station bail at the behest of the local legislator and they arrested the accused only after TDP’s pressure.

Title: Coronavirus in Tamil Nadu: Engineering colleges tell students to go home
Content: CHENNAI: Major engineering colleges have suspended classes or advanced summer holidays to prevent the spread of Covid-19.Five institutes have suspended all classes from Monday till March 31, or until further notices.“We have advised students to go home and return after academic activities resume,” said Mini Shaji Thomas, director of National Institute of Technology, Trichy. The college has advised faculty against travelling abroad or entertaining guests from foreign countries on the campus. Students who wish to stay back in the hostels were asked to take strictly follow instructions.Central University of Tamil Nadu, Thiruvarur, has directed people with international travel history to report to its hospital. VIT and SRM Institute of Science and Technology have also declared holidays till March 31.“We have asked students to stay in touch with their faculty,” said Ishari K Ganesh, chairman, and chancellor of Vael’s University. He said the institute was helping students to book tickets to home.Official spokespersons from SASTRA University and Sathyabama University said they are yet to decide on the holidays and will have a meeting on Monday.However, IIT-Madras has decided not to suspend classes. “As of now, educational institutes in Tamil Nadu are functioning normally, and we have received guidelines to postpone all foreign travel and avoid large gatherings. We are rigorously implementing the medical precautions,” said Bhaskar Ramamurthi, director, IIT Madras.Some institutions have approached the government for advice as several students have come back from Holi holidays, some after visiting infected areas in other states.

Title: Covid-19: Railways withdraws blankets, curtains from AC coaches, asks passengers to bring their own
Content: BAREILLY: Novel coronavirus outbreak has forced Indian Railways to remove curtains and blankets from AC coaches. Authorities announced on Sunday that in order to prevent the spread of Covid-19, blankets and curtains have been withdrawn with immediate effect till further orders. Noting that the linen is not washed every trip, officials said that passengers are advised to bring their own blankets.The temperature of the AC coaches will be set suitably so that passengers do not require blankets, they said.Madhusudan Rao, additional member (commercial) of Railway Board, said that the member (traffic) has desired this be implemented with immediate effect for a month or a date to be notified later.Meanwhile, Western Railway has posted a tweet to this effect stating, “Kindly note that it has been decided to withdraw curtains & blankets from AC coaches of trains as they are not washed every trip, for prevention of #coronavirus. Passengers may please bring their own blankets if need be. Inconvenience is regretted.”Senior commercial manager of Moradabad division in Northern Railway (NR), Rekha, said that a helpline number of control room – 9760541564 – has been issued, setting up anti-Covid-19 task force at all major railway stations under NR.She said, “Blankets as well as curtains are most likely source of infection. That is why it is decided to withdraw them from service till further orders. However, blankets will be given to passengers only on demand and some quantity of additional bedsheets may be kept for any exigency.”Passengers are advised to bring their own blankets in their own interest. Besides, general managers of Delhi, Moradabad, Lucknow, Ambala and Firozpur divisions under NR are directed for wide publicity to this effect.Only the bedsheets, pillow covers and hand towels will be given to passengers. The reasons for the same may be explained to the passengers if there is any query.Chief public relations officer of North-Central Railway (NCR), Ajit Singh, said, temperature in all AC coaches will be maintained above 25 degrees and prior to the journey, passengers will receive auto generated calls from railway helpline 139, informing them to carry their own blankets till March 31.

Title: Sanitising hands must for entry to Kashi Vishwanath & Annapurna temples
Content:
Representative image

VARANASI: Kashi Vishwanath and Annapurna temples have made cleaning hands with handwash and sanitisers must for the devotees before entering the temple premises from Sunday.

As per the official statement of Kashi Vishwanath temple, arrangements for proper cleaning of hands with handwash and applying sanitisers has been made before the main entry point of the temple.

Mahant of Annapurna temple Rameshwar Puri said that staff and priests at temple as well as the staff at the temple’s food court have been provided mask, besides, arrangements for handwash and sanitiser have also been made at the temple.

Title: Samruddhi Corridor alignment for Nagpur-Mumbai HSR
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The Railways Board is weighing the option of a Samruddhi Corridor alignment for the proposed Nagpur Mumbai High Speed Railway (HSR), whose detailed project report is being prepared by the National High Speed Rail Corporation Limited (NHRCL).

According to a senior railway officer, the project is facing a few issues including the land acquisition for the proposed high-speed HSR track. “It would be too early to comment on how the HSR would move through the Mumbai – Nashik – Nagpur route. One of the proposals being weighed is that of the Greenfield project. The land available with the Samruddhi Corridor cannot be ruled out,” said the officer.

The state-owned NHRCL, which is also looking after the construction of the Mumbai – Ahmedabad High Speed Rail service – commonly termed as bullet train – has been given the responsibility of preparing the detailed project report and the exercise is likely to take about a year’s time.

The officer further pointed out that a survey would be first carried out to finalise the best route between the two cities. “Since this will be high-speed corridor – where trains will run with speeds exceeding 200 km per hour — the existing alignment is of no use. That can best serve semi-high speed trains running in speeds in the range of 150 kmph to 180 kmph. Hence we have to go for fresh alignments,” the officer said.

When asked about possibilities, the officer said that the Samruddhi Expressway (Nagpur Mumbai Super Communication Expressway) could play a guiding role in the new HSR track.

Land acquisition is the biggest hurdle and in certain areas because of the ongoing government works there is hardly any space left to be acquired. “In such cases the Samruddhi Mahamarg has all the features required to run the HSR through it. If that was done, the land acquisition cost could be slashed down drastically. But that is just a possibility,” the officer said.

The officer hinted that at places where there is little scope for getting the land the alignment could be in proximity of the Samruddhi Expressway – whose median is 15 meters wide – enough for the train to run through. At other times the alignment could take its own course.

Title: 70-year-old farmer, who was worried over loan and damaged crops, commits suicide
Content:
Bareilly: A 70-year-old farmer, who had a debt of Rs 4 lakh and suffered damage to his crops because of unseasonal rains and hailstorm, committed suicide by consuming poison at his residence in Kaucha Khurd village in Meerganj area of Bareilly district late on Saturday night.

The victim was upset after the sudden death of his son earlier this year and his only livestock, a Buffalo, had also died four days ago due to disease.

SHO Meerganj police station Vijay Kumar told TOI, “A farmer has committed suicide because of debt in Meerganj. We have sent his body for autopsy and the revenue team has been informed about his death, so that they can carry the procedure of providing compensation to the family members of farmers under government schemes.”

Deceased Dharamdas is survived by his wife, three daughters and son Shivnandan (27).

Shivnandan told TOI, “This year has only brought only sorrow for us, as it started with sudden demise of my elder brother Rajveer in a road accident. We were already burdened with a loan of Rs 4 lakh and the rainfall and hailstorm destroyed our crops. Selling buffalo milk was another source of income, but our buffalo also died all of a sudden, leaving us with nothing. My father was a strong man but he had lost all hopes of revival and consumed poison. We did try to save his life and took him to the hospital, but he succumbed during treatment. So far, no one from the administration has approached us.”

Title: First positive Covid-19 case reported in Marathwada
Content: AURANGABAD: A 59-year-old woman from Aurangabad with a travel history to Kazakhstan and Russia has tested positive for coronavirus , making her the first positive Covid-19 case from the eight districts of the Marathwada region. The Pune-based National Institute of Virology on Sunday confirmed her tests to be positive.The woman, who is currently being treated at a private hospital, is said to be stable and under the watch of senior doctors of the hospital, officials of the Aurangabad municipal corporation ’s health department and district health department said.Sources said the woman was part of a 30-member group that, through a private tour operator, had been on a tour of Kazakhstan and Russia. The group comprised two other people from Aurangabad. Also, the woman’s daughter-in-law, who is a Mumbai resident, had joined her in the trip abroad. All other group members are from different places across the country. Officials are trying to track down everyone from the group, and others who came in touch with them, to test and quarantine them at their homes. They are also in touch with other state governments.Aurangabad district collector Uday Choudhari told TOI, “The woman has tested positive for Covid-19. The administration and the health department are taking preventive measures and for now, there is no need to panic. All the tests carried out on the 16 other suspected patients over the past few days have returned negative.” Authorities said soon that after the 59-year-old patient’s reports were received, the health department started identifying her close relatives, all those had come in contact with her since her return, her domestic help, driver etc. and they are being made to opt for home quarantine.District civil surgeon Sundar Kulkarni, who personally paid a visit to the ailing woman, said: “Her swab samples were collected and sent on Friday. We received the reports on Sunday. Her condition is stable and we are maintaining a close watch.”Following the WHO norms, a team of health officials has been dispatched for counselling and quarantining the patient’s neighbours. Doctors have already recorded her travel history.The woman had returned from her foreign trip on March 3, but only started showing symptoms three to four days ago. She went to the hospital on her own and got admitted. “At the time of admission, the woman had cough, fever and difficulty in breathing,” said a doctor.Authorities said it has been mutually decided that the woman would continue with her treatment at the private hospital. Earlier, the administration had decided that those with symptoms would be treated at district civil hospital, while those testing positive for Covid-19 would be treated at the isolation ward of Government Medical College and Hospital , Aurangabad.

Title: Coronavirus in Chennai: OMR techies prepare to work from home
Content: CHENNAI: With IT companies beginning to tell employees to work from home and the state government thinking of shutting schools and colleges, the city is gearing up for a change in lifestyle — all of a sudden.Since a majority of IT employees reside near OMR, resident associations are concerned water availability and sewage disposal will be hit.Resident welfare associations have begun taking various measures to maintain better standards of hygiene. Federation of OMR Residents Associations, a collective of associations, has anticipated a jump in demand for water if IT firms ask employees to work from home. Its coordinator Harsha Koda said water usage will increase by almost 40%.“Our apartment complex gets about 30,000 litres of water a day during weekdays. This increases by 15,000 litres on weekends. Now, our daily requirement would be 50% more on weekdays if IT workers start work from home,” he said.OMR has 400 apartment complexes, many of them highrises with several hundreds of houses, from Madhya Kailash to Tiruporur. It is home to more than four lakh people. Of them, 80% are employed in IT firms. About 3,000 private water tankers make 10,000 trips a day supplying around 120MLD of water to residential towers and IT parks. “This apart, more food delivery executives will come. We are planning to raise the number of security guards to enhance protection,” Koda added.In localities such as Sholinganallur, water auditing has started to check leakage. Sujatha, secretary of Central Park Apartment Owners Association, said hand sanitisers have been installed in every block of their apartment complex. “We are checking the recent travel history of both occupants and visitors. Water auditing has been advanced to March from May as fixing leakages would save water,” she said.Residents’ associations in other parts of the city have begun to take proactive measures to prevent spread of Covid-19. An association in Anna Nagar has put off celebrations and cultural events to avoid mass gatherings. K V Pari, president of Sivagami Nagar Public Welfare Association at Medavakkam, said an emergency meeting is likely to be called next week. “Though everyone is aware that frequent washing of hands is the need of hour, not many are doing it. We want to sensitise our residents regarding its necessity,” he said.

Title: Uttar Pradesh Bar Council’s panel issues orders to hold KBA election within three weeks
Content:
Representative image

KANPUR: The two-member inquiry committee of UP Bar Council on Sunday ordered to conduct Kanpur Bar Association ( KBA ) elections within three weeks under two observers with certain conditions.

According to the conditions framed by it, the election will be supervised by a team of 50 persons, including a returning officer under close supervision of two members-- Madhusudan Tripathi and Jai Narayan Pandey to be assisted by two local members--Yogendra Swarup and Pankaj Mishra .

The committee suggested that immediately after constitution of the returning officers team, the election dates will be declared within two weeks.

The two-member committee, consisting of Ajay Kumar Shukla and Panchu Ram Maurya, strongly criticised the elders' committee and termed it as inefficient. The committee also indicted KBA's office superintendent for professional misconduct.

The inquiry committee members observed that inclusion of names after publication of the final electoral list, indicates that the persons who were given the responsibility to conduct election were not performing their duty properly. On the basis of several complaints against the elders' committee, an inference was drawn that it was not capable to conduct the election. The versions and allegation indicate that the office superintendent and the elders' committee had committed gross irregularities in the election process, the committee said.

In the present situation it would be unfair to conduct election under the supervision of the elders' committee, and, therefore, the election will be held under the close supervision of two observers of the Bar Council of UP, the committee added.

The observers would constitute a 50-member team including a returning officer between March 16 and March 19 and declare fresh election dates which would be within two weeks time from the date of this order. Voting would be held under the enclosed electoral list. No new addition will take place in it. The candidature of any contestant would not be cancelled, the committee stated.

Taking a strong view against Sriprakash Dwivedi , KBA's office superintendent, the committee stated that his role was suspicious. After getting registered at the Bar Council, he obtained the certificate of practice and concealed the fact that he was KBA's paid employee. Since it was a serious crime, the committee would recommend action against him in its separate order.

The committee in a letter written to the district judge, district magistrate and SSP, Kanpur, has asked them to provide adequate police force to the observers so that the election could be conducted in a free and fair manner.

Title: Covid-19 in Delhi: Sanitisation paper must for interstate buses, says government
Content: NEW DELHI: Delhi government has further intensified its measures against the spread of the novel coronavirus through public transport in the city. It is now mandatory for buses from neighbouring states arriving at the Delhi’s interstate bus terminals (ISBT) to produce certificates confirming that the vehicles were disinfected at the originating points. The government is planning to soon start disinfecting autorickshaws, Grameen sewa and other paratransit vehicles at the bus depots.“The government has already issued an advisory for drivers of autorickshaws, Grameen sewa vehicles, mini-buses, etc. to create awareness about the necessity to keep their vehicles clean and disinfected. They have been advised to thoroughly clean the vehicles before hitting the roads and also follow general dos and don’ts regarding the coronavirus outbreak ,” a Delhi government official said.“This is not only important for safety of their passengers, but also their own,” the official said.“While mini-bus owners can disinfect their vehicles on their own, the government is planning to help owners of smaller vehicles who might not have the resources to disinfect their vehicles daily,” he added.“Though no official announcement has been made yet, we have already started disinfecting a few autorickshaws and taxis near the bus depots of Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC),” the official claimed.“There are around one lakh autos in Delhi, apart from thousands of other paratransit vehicles. The government plans to disinfect these vehicles for free at DTC and Cluster bus depots where buses are already being disinfected daily. However, since the number of such vehicles is high, proper arrangements have to be made before an official announcement is made,” he said.While all DTC and Cluster scheme buses are being disinfected daily and Delhi Metro Rail Corporation has also intensified the cleaning of its trains and stations, inter-state buses coming from neighbouring states are also being thoroughly disinfected at the three ISBTs– Kashmere Gate, Anand Vihar and Sarai Kale Khan. All ISBTs are also being disinfected daily, particularly the platforms and common surfaces.Total 3,467 buses from other states arrive in Delhi every day. Most of the inter-state buses arrive from Uttar Pradesh (1,519), followed by Haryana (757) and Uttarakhand (313).

Title: ‘Objectionable’ tweet lands Allahabad man in trouble
Content:
Representative image

PRAYAGRAJ: A man was booked on Sunday for allegedly using objectionable language against a minority community in a social media post.

An FIR under section 153 A (promoting disharmony, enmity or feelings of hatred between different groups on the grounds of religion), 295A (destruction or defilement to a place of worship or an object held sacred, with an intent to insult the religion of a class of persons) of the Indian Penal Code and section 66 of Information Technology (IT) Act was registered against him. The accused Nitish Sahoo had uploaded the objectionable post on Twitter.

Inspector (Colonelganj) Arun Kumar Tyagi said Sahoo tweeted the comments with an intention to insult a particular religion, following which a case under appropriate sections was registered.

He also said that police are trying to trace the social media user and stern action would be initiated against him.

Title: Fourth suspect held in Nashik cocaine smuggling case
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The city police have arrested one more person in connection with the case involving smuggling of cocaine worth Rs 89 lakh. The product was seized from three people in the Nashik Road area on March 6.

Police inspector Dinesh Bardekar of the crime branch said that the suspect has been identified as Ashok Yadav (45), a resident of Firozabad, Uttar Pradesh .

Yadav was produced in a city court and remanded to five-day police custody. Bardekar said that the custody of the other three suspects has also been extended by five days till March 18.

On February 6, the city police received a tip-off about a person from Firozabad — Manoj Kumar Jaiprakash Yadav — who had come to Nashik with cocaine worth Rs 89 lakh. He was accompanied by two others — Sahebjan Sabidali Shaikh of Ambad Link Road, Satpur, and Nitin Sopanrao Khodke of Nashik Road.

Shaikh, Khodke and Yadav were caught red-handed by the police when they were finalising a deal in a deserted place in the Nashik Road area.

During investigation, police learned that a few more people were involved in the smuggling of the drugs, following which a team of the crime branch had visited Firozabad from where Ashok Yadav has been arrested.

Police said that they are keeping a strict watch in the city to ensure that there is no sale, purchase or consumption of drugs. A special squad has also been set up at the police commissionerate level to keep a tab on drug-related activities.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Farmer shot in leg over land dispute in Muzaffarnagar
Content:
Representative Image

MUZAFFARNAGAR: A 35-year-old farmer working on his farm at Datiyana village in Muzaffarnagar was shot at on Sunday over a land dispute . The farmer claimed that two men were behind the attack. A probe has been ordered into the matter.

The injured farmer, identified as Pradeep, claimed, “I was working in my farm when two men from the village came and shot me in the leg. I know them and have a land dispute with them.”

Kuldeep Singh, deputy superintendent of police, said, “It is a case of a property dispute. We are investigating the matter and action will be taken accordingly.”

A member of Pradeep’s family filed a complaint at Chhapar police station. A hunt is on for the two suspects

Title: Changing colours of transplanted hands
Content:
Kochi: Three years after Shreya Siddanagaowda had a double hand transplant from a brain dead male donor, she is excited as the transplanted hand is becoming “more feminine” and skin tone is also almost matching hers. However, her hand transplant doctors at Amrita Institute of Medical Sciences (AIMS) called it a “unique situation” in which they don’t have enough scientific evidence to explain the changes.

“Since last few months, I have noticed changes in my hands. They are less bulkier, the fingers are turning more leaner like a woman’s and even the skin colour is now lighter. At first the hands functionality was my concern but now these changes are definitely a bonus,” said Shreya over the phone from Pune.

Shreya is happy that she is able to do most of the things with her hands. “This October, I also wrote my exams though after an hour my hands start to ache,” said Shreya, who is now pursuing BA (Economics) from Fergusson College, Pune.

Shreya, the only daughter of Suma Nuggihalli and Fakirgowda Siddanagaowda from Pune, had lost both her hands in a mishap involving a bus in which she was travelling in September 2016 to her engineering college in Manipal.

She was 19 then. She was rushed to a hospital where both her arms had to be amputated at the elbow.

Meanwhile, her doctors admit that there is not much research to show this change. “It is difficult to get evidence for the cause here as it is a unique situation and there is not enough understanding on the subject. We don’t know how much change has occurred, how much more will occur or why it has happened,” said Dr Subramania Iyer, who headed the team that did the hand transplant on her at AIMS.

Around 172 hand transplants have happened globally so far, of which most of the hand transplants are in Europe or China.

Dr Mohit Sharma, who is part of the hand transplant team, said that double hand transplants are few and male to female hand transplants above elbow are even rarer. “We are looking at possible reasons for the colour change. Maybe this could be because pigment cells of the recipient have now been replaced by that of the donor or the lightening could be due to steroids. However, further research is needed to get exact reason,” said Dr Sharma.

Title: BJP issues whip to MLAs, leaders call on Governor Lalji Tandon
Content:
File photo of Lalji Tandon

BHOPAL: The BJP legislative party in Madhya Pradesh on Sunday issued a whip to all its MLAs to remain present in the House during the assembly session that begins on Monday, and vote in favour of party during the trust vote. Earlier in the day, the BJP leaders also met Governor Lalji Tandon and urged him to ensure the floor test takes place and instruct changes in the process due to technical snag in electronic voting.

The whip was issued by BJP chief whip Narottam Mishra. “It has been instructed to all BJP MLAs to remain present during the assembly budget session beginning March 16 throughout the proceedings and vote in favour of the BJP during the floor test in the House,” read the letter issued by Mishra.

The Congress issued a whip to all its MLAs for the legislative assembly session which is scheduled to be held from March 16 to April 13.

Meanwhile, BJP LoP, Gopal Bhargava and chief whip in assembly, Narottam Mishra called on Governor Tandon on Sunday seeking instructions on the floor test in the House as per the schedule.

“We have urged Governor Tandon that floor test be conducted on Monday only. The Congress is trying to avoid the test,” Bhargava told reporters after the meeting.

Mishra also reacted sharply to the speculations that Congress government is trying to avert the floor test on Monday.

The BJP leaders have also urged the Governor two change the pattern of floor test from ‘pressing button’ to other practical methods like division or showing attendance in person. They said the assembly secretariat has pleaded technical fault on the functioning of the buttons. This could be changed by a more practical method as alternative, they said.

Later in the evening, Governor Lalji Tandon through another letter to chief minister Kamal Nath instructed to take up the trust vote by asking members to raise hands. “Since Annexure 10 (scheduled) is implemented in Madhya Pradesh, I instruct to conduct the trust vote by raising hands and no other method,” read the letter by Governor.

Title: Coronavirus in Karnataka: Shutdown for a week may affect blood banks
Content: MANGALURU: The department of immunohematology and blood transfusion, Kasturba Medical College Manipal , encouraged its staff to donate blood on Saturday, fearing a shortage of blood in the coming days. About 30 staff members participated in this drive. With the weeklong shutdown declared by the state government, and blood donation camps being called off, there are fears that there will be a shortage of blood at the blood bank at Kasturba Hospital, Manipal.Dr Shamee Shastry, professor and HoD, said, “After the Covid-19 outbreak and a weeklong shutdown declared by the government, blood donation camps have been cancelled. On an average there is a demand for 100 units of different components of blood.The Covid-19 outbreak does not mean that there is a reduction in road accidents, or oncology cases or cases of excessive bleeding during deliveries. People are hesitant to come to the blood bank and donate blood. The major supply to blood banks comes from blood donation camps,” she said.She asserted that the blood bank is a safe place, and all precautionary measures to tackle Covid-19, including placing hand sanitizers, are in place. Requesting healthy people to donate blood, Dr Shamee said, “Our current stock is sufficient for the next two days.” Whenever, there is a blood donation drive about 100-150 donors participate.No shortage of blood in MangaluruDr Sharath Kumar, senior specialist, Regional Centre of Excellence, Blood Transfusion Centre, Wenlock Hospital, said that they are not facing any shortage of blood and that blood donation camps are taking place as per schedule. There is sufficient blood in our bank.“Shortage is generally seen when colleges are closed for two months during summer. We are already working to ensure that there is no shortage during this season,” he said.

Title: Residents want funds for Thillai Ganga Nagar bridge sanctioned
Content:
The government had proposed the bridge in 2016

CHENNAI: Nanganallur and Adambakkam residents have urged the Tamil Nadu government to sanction funds for the Thillai Ganga Nagar bridge project. The announcement was made by late chief minister J Jayalalithaa in 2016 at the state assembly under rule 110. Edappadi K Palaniswami, now CM, was the state highway minister back then.

“Subsequent to the announcement, there has been no mention about the bridge in the state assembly and no fund has been allocated. We expect a mention this year,” said V Rama Rao, secretary, People Awareness Association, Nanganallur chapter.

State highway department’s demand for grants is scheduled on March 18.

A senior official from the department said it would cost Rs 85 crore to construct the 1-km-long structure, with minimum six lanes, connecting Inner Ring Road with Grand Southern Trunk Road over the existing subway. The proposal has been sent to authorities for final approval for sanction of funds. At least seven lakh people will get benefited by the bridge.

There are four subways within a radius of 5km — Alandur, Thillai Ganga Nagar, Pazhavanthangal and Meenambakkam — in south Chennai. During monsoon, these get submerged on most evenings, making it difficult for motorists to commute. During the December 2015 floods, many residents from Adambakkam, Nanganallur and Madipakkam, who had left for work were unable to return home as the subways were flooded. They stayed back in hotels near their workspaces.

Since then, repeated representations were made to the government to construct a bridge over any one of the four subways. After studying the feasibility at all locations, the highways department choose Thillai Ganga Nagar as adequate land was available back then. But now that MRTS works are underway, the design might have to be altered although seamless connectivity will be ensured, the highway official said.

Title: Tamil Nadu: No match, matrimonial site asked to pay
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: The consumer grievances redressal forum has ordered Bharat Matrimony to pay Rs 1.2 lakh as compensation to a man from Kochi who had sued the site for not finding a right match within one year as promised.

The complainant, E V John, subscribed for ‘Elite Premium Package’ by paying Rs 1 lakh on May 5, 2015. The matrimonial firm in its email assured that if customers were not satisfied with their services and were unable to provide a suitable match within one year from the date of subscription, the amount would be refunded.

Between May and July 2015, John claimed that he was bombarded with a lot of “unsuitable profiles” which were not verified and some had incomplete details. John complained that the relationship manager had failed to look into details of profiles before forwarding them to him.

Though John received 23 profiles in the said time period, only one was suitable and there was no response from that profile too when contacted for further enquiry.

Irked with the quality of service, John asked Kerala Matrimony, unit functioning under Chennai-based Bharat Matrimony, to refund the subscription amount. But there was no reply from the firm. He approached the North Chennai consumer forum seeking compensation.

Bharat Matrimony in response said the complainant initially paid Rs 10,000 to get personalised assistance by using advances tools in finding matching members from thousands of profiles. Later he upgraded to ‘elite’ category which aimed at catering to needs to rich, affluent families from business or industrial background, professionals and similar customers who want to finish search for prospective life partners soon, said the matrimony’s counsel in response.

The counsel added that elite service neither guarantees positive responses from prospective brides all the time nor marriage within the service period. Their only obligation was to search, shortlist profiles based on members’ preferences and share it later and the same was done without any deficiency.

On hearing it, the forum on February 18 ordered Bharat Matrimony to pay Rs 1,00,000 towards subscription paid with 6% interest from complaint date (February 2017) to till date and another Rs 22,000 as compensation and litigation expenses.

Title: Aurangabad: Jeweller, three others booked for duping woman of gold chain
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: The Cidco police on Saturday booked a jeweller along with his three accomplices for allegedly cheating a woman of her gold chain worth Rs 1.28 lakh.

According to the complaint filed by the woman, she, along with her sister and mother, had been to the jeweller’s shop on March 6 to sell her 40-gram gold chain as the family was in need of money.

The jeweller and his staff, after weighing the gold chain, promised the women Rs 1.28 lakh in return. But much to their shock, when the jeweller melted the chain, it turned out to be made of copper. The jeweller then refused to give the cash. The woman claims that her chain was made of real gold, and the jeweller is somehow involved in falsely making it out to be made of copper.

Based on the complaint lodged by the woman, an offence under sections 406 (criminal breach of trust), 420 (cheating), 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke a person to commit breach of peace) and 506 (criminal intimidation) of the IPC has been registered with the police.

Police-sub inspector Balasaheb Aher said none of the suspects have been arrested as the investigation is at its preliminary stage. “We are cross verifying the claims being made by the complainant as well as the suspects,” said Aher.

According to police sources, the jeweller has claimed innocence. “The police are checking the CCTV footage” said the source.

Title: With my 21 MLAs captive, would floor test be constitutional: CM Kamal Nath
Content:
File photo of Kamal Nath

BHOPAL: Chief minister Kamal Nath held a meeting of Congress legislative party on Sunday evening, where he said: “How can there be a floor test in the House when our MLAs are captive? Would it be constitutional?”

According to sources in the party, the CM said: “The smile on my lips, despite this crisis is your smile. I have full faith in my MLAs.”

Congress would overcome the “immoral and unconstitutional political crisis created by BJP”, Nath told legislators, adding that the party stands united. “The morale of every Congress worker is high as every one of them tries to save democratic values,” he added.

The CM said that the Congress MLAs who went to Jaipur were free to move around and use their mobile phones, but those in Bengaluru are “held hostage, and not being allowed to talk to their kin”. “Why are they not being brought to Bhopal,” he asked, adding: “If BJP wants a floor test, it should bring the Congress MLAs to Bhopal or else the floor test would have no meaning.”

AICC observer Harish Rawat said that toppling elected governments has become a “fundamental character” of BJP. “They did the same thing in my state, Uttarakhand. Congress MLAs can unitedly thwart BJP’s design to topple the government. The manner in which Congress MLAs are facing the crisis in is commendable,” he remarked.

State Congress chief spokesperson Shobha Oza , when asked about proceedings of the CLP meeting, said: “They are all united, excited and full of confidence.”

Title: Basti villagers alert health department about suspect coronavirus case
Content:
Representative image

GORAKHPUR: Following awareness drive against COVID -19, villagers of Basti district informed the health department about a suspect who returned from Dubai on Friday. His family was trying to hide his symptoms and was taking medical help from a private hospital. The man is in isolation ward since Saturday.

The suspect returned from Dubai to his village in Basti on Friday. He was suffering with fever, cough and cold and was also having difficulty in breathing but his family silently went to a private hospital.

Deputy CMO CL Kannoujia said, “The man was admitted to a private hospital. Neither the family nor the private hospital informed the health department about the suspect. With the help of suspect’s phone number his location was traced and he was shifted in isolation ward. His blood sample has been sent to KGMU Lucknow for test and the report is awaited.” DM Ashutosh Niranjan has applied section 144 in the district from March 16 to March 31 in view of Covid-19 scare.

Rly staff union agianst biometrics: The NER employees union has objected to use of biometric at diesel lobby of NER Gorakhpur and has demanded masks for staff in view of corona scare. “NER Gorakhpur is still using biometrics at diesel lobby,” said NER employee union, general secretary, Vinod Kumar Rai. CPRO NER, Pankaj Singh said, “The staff uses sanitiser before and after marking attendance there.”

Title: Four of a family admitted to isolation ward in Sonbhadra
Content: VARANASI: A Renusagar power plant employee and three members of his family were admitted to isolation ward of Renusagar hospital in Sonbhadra district on Sunday after he alerted the authorities about coronavirus like symptoms on tollfree number.Chief medical officer Dr Shashikant Upadhyaya reached the hospital and took stock of their condition. Samples of the employee and his family members have been sent to Banaras Hindu University laboratory for confirmatory test, said the CMO.Projects spokesman GS Tiwari said that the 50-year-old employee along with his wife, son and daughter-in-law had gone to Nepal. After they returned on March 2, they started suffering from cold, sneezing and respiratory problem. As the problem existed for long he alerted the health department through the tollfree number.The CMO said that they all have been kept in isolation ward for observation while their pathology report from BHU laboratory is awaited.

Title: UP: 16-year-old nose slit, raped by youth in Kheri
Content:
Representative image

BAREILLY: A 16-year-old girl was raped and her nose was slit allegedly by a youth who barged into her house in Shardanagar area in Lakhimpur Kheri district on Sunday afternoon. An FIR has been registered against the youth and the girl sent to hospital for treatment. Since the accused belongs to another community, a force has been deployed at the village to ensure that no untoward incident takes place.

According to police, the survivor is a school dropout, On Sunday morning, her parents, who are wage labourers, had gone out for work and she was alone at home. The youth, identified as Gautam Raidas, 20, allegedly barged into the house with a knife and locked her inside. When the girl put up a fight against him, he allegedly slit her nose with the knife and raped her. After the assault, Gautam fled and did not return to his house.

The girl somehow managed to get help from her neighbours who called her parents.

She was then taken to the police station and an FIR was lodged.

Ajay Mishra, SHO of Kotwali police station, told TOI, “A minor girl belonging to the minority community was raped by a local youth and sustained injuries on her nose, We have booked Gautam Raidas under IPC sections 376 (rape), 326 (voluntarily causing hurt by a dangerous weapon), 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of peace), 506 (criminal intimidation) and provisions of the POCSO Act. The accused is absconding but we will soon arrest him. The victim has been sent for treatment at a hospital. The girl’s statement will be recorded in front of the magistrate after she is treated.”

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Buldhana deceased tests negative
Content:
Nagpur: Sunday brought partial relief to Vidarbha region as no new positive Covid-19 cases emerged. The total number of patients who tested positive remain at 6 — 4 from Nagpur and 2 from Yavatmal

Swab samples of the 75-year-old Covid-19 suspected man from Buldhana, who died on Saturday, tested negative on Sunday which means the man was not infected with novel coronavirus. Even the four-year-old girl, who was admitted in the isolation ward of the Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) tested negative. This girl had a travel history to Saudi Arabia.

However, there is still cause for concern. In GMCH, a junior resident doctor who was on duty in the isolation ward where three positive patients are under treatment, developed symptoms like cough, cold and fever. He was immediately admitted to the same isolation ward and his swab samples were sent to the IGGMCH for testing.

A senior official in GMCH told TOI that though the symptoms appear mild, “we are not taking any chances”.

In Yavatmal, where two positive patients are already under treatment, two more were identified with coronavirus symptoms on Sunday. GMCH Yavatmal now has two positive and 2 with symptoms. .

In Khamgaon (Buldhana district), a total of 12 tourists from Malaysia and Indonesia have been kept under observation as three of them developed mild symptoms. Chandrapur also reported three new cases. All of them were admitted to the GMCH, Chandrapur.

Nagpur divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar issued an appeal on Sunday that people who have been identified after talks with the positive patients should cooperate and submit their samples for testing. The administration is calling people who have been identified as high-risk contacts of the positive patients.

On Sunday, 19 such suspects reported to the GMCH and their samples were collected. All of them were admitted to the isolation ward. Officials at GMCH told that a total of 40 samples have been sent for testing at the lab facility in IGGMCH from Saturday (21 on Saturday and 19 on Sunday). Out of them, 39 have tested negative.

District collector Ravindra Thakre, and divisional deputy director (health services) Dr Sanjay Jaiswal visited both government hospitals on Sunday and took review of the facilities available at the isolation wards. They also visited the MLA hostel where quarantine facility is being prepared for cases coming from the high-risk seven nations.

At medical colleges, they were accompanied by deans and medical superintendents. They also interacted with the people admitted in the isolation ward and positive patients under treatment in separate rooms. The officials were seen wearing safety masks. They claimed to have maintained a safe distance from the patients as well as suspects.

“It was an effort to motivate the patients who are undergoing treatment. The collector interacted with them and told that all are with them in this fight against coronavirus. All patients and suspects shared their views about the facilities in hospital,” said Dr Sajal Mitra, the GMCH dean.

Meanwhile, the administration has made an important policy decision to not collect any samples from homes now, according to civil surgeon Dr Devendra Paturkar.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: 27-year-old found murdered near state highway in Bijnor
Content:
Representative Image

BIJNOR: The body of a 27-year-old youth was found in a jungle in Bijnor early on Sunday morning. The body bore several injury marks, indicating that he was attacked with a sharp-edged weapon. Police are probing the matter and an FIR has been registered against unidentified assailants.

According to police, the deceased was identified as Singhraj from Bagarpur village under Chandpur police station. His body was found lying near the state highway on Sunday around 9 am by passersby who informed his family.

Susheel Kumar, brother of the deceased, informed police, who came and took charge of the body, sending it for an autopsy to the district hospital.

Kumar told policemen that his brother, a driver by profession, lived in a separate house with his wife and two- and-a-half-year-old daughter. His wife along with their child had gone to her maternal house at Kelanpur for the past one month. He was staying alone at home. He was last seen coming home on Saturday evening.

Luv Sirohi, Chandpur station house officer, said a case has been registered against unidentified assailants. Police are awaiting the post-mortem report, he added.

Title: Delhi Coronavirus News: Jamia Millia Islamia fully shut, students asked to go home
Content: NEW DELHI: Jamia Millia Islamia announced on Sunday that as a precautionary measure against the spread of the novel coronavirus, it is shutting down its hostels, libraries and canteens. It has asked students to go home and not assemble at the university. However, students of Jamia’s Joint Coordination Committee (JCC) sitting on protest for around three months outside gate number 7 have yet to take a call on if they would disband their congregation as part of social distancing.Two days after announcing that they are suspending classes till March 31, the Jamia administration came out with a notice on Sunday to announce the shutting down of student accommodations too.In their advisory, Jamia said that Covid-19 epidemic will enter into the phase of exponential growth, which is “highly dangerous in terms of magnitude and dimension as an infectious disease.” Stating that many educational institutes are now shut, the advisory said that it is beyond them to contain the danger.“Places of gatherings like hostels, dining halls, libraries, kitchens are highly vulnerable and susceptible to the threat. The best course of action is to secure the students, teachers, workers and non-teaching staff,” the advisory said.This has been seen by many at Jamia as an advisory for students sitting on protest. Responding to the advisory, JCC member Safoora Zargar said that “JCC will discuss on their course of action and decide on if they would continue the protest.”

Title: Three from Tamil Nadu arrested for mobile theft
Content:
Representative image

PRAYAGRAJ: Two Tamil Nadu-based mobile thieves were arrested with five stolen phones on Sunday. Police also seized 480 gram of an unidentified powder from their possession.

The accused were identified as Prakash Nateshan and K Babu.

Shahganj police said they were tipped off about the whereabouts of a gang of mobile thieves which targeted visitors in public places like malls. Station officer of Shahganj police station Brijesh Singh said police are looking for other members of the gang.

Title: Kukke temple ritual: Devotees asked to come in less numbers
Content:
Kukke Subhramanya Temple

Mangaluru: Additional deputy commissioner M J Roopa has requested devotees visiting the state’s richest temple, Kukke Shree Subrahmanya, to perform the Sarpa Samskara puja , to come in less numbers . In the wake of the Covid-19 outbreak, she said, “Instead of a large group coming, the person who is offering the puja may be accompanied by one or two people.”

Killing of a cobra in their home territory is considered as a sin among Hindus, and is believed to bring misfortune (naga dosha). As a remedy to the sin, they mostly visit Kukke Shree Subrahmanya Temple, about 100 kilometres from Mangaluru, and offer pujas such as Sarpa Samskara, Naga prathishta or Ashlesha bali. Sarpa Samskara is the cremation ritual for the snake. It is performed only for cobras and no other snakes. This puja is performed in case the reptile is found dead in the property the devotee owns, or is accidentally killed by labourers, or is found run over by a moving vehicle.

M J Roopa, the administrator of the temple, said, “On an average 172-180 Sarpa Samskara pujas are performed at Kukke temple and about 100-120 Ashlesha bali is performed every day. I have directed the temple staff to call every devotee who has booked the puja, and request them to come in small numbers,” she said. An average 20,000 devotees visit the temple every day.

Other measures

Dakshina Kannada district has about 500 temples of which 40 are under the A category (that earn an annual income above Rs 25 lakh), 25 are under the B category (annual income of above Rs 5 lakh, but within Rs 25 lakh) and 435 are under C category.

The temples have been asked to set up help desks to provide information on general health issues, and announcements will be made on hygiene. Meanwhile, since most temples will be observing their annual festivities during this season, the administration has sought directions from the religious endowment department about the festivities. The rituals at most temples are going on as usual, and some temples even claim that there is not much reduction in footfalls for the time being.

Special pujas offered

Many temples in the coastal district offered special pujas so that the spread of Covid-19 is controlled and the world returns to normalcy. A special puja and mass prayer was held at Kadri Sri Manjunatha Temple in Mangaluru on Sunday.

Priests and devotees recited of Dhanwantari japa, Rudrapatana and Vishnusahasranama and later offered mass prayers in the Kadri temple premises, seeking relief from Covid-19. Japas and prayers were led by Dakshina Kannada District Kannada Sahitya Parishat president Pradeep Kumar Kalkura, Mangaluru City South MLA D Vedavyasa Kamath, VHP state working president M B Puranik and former MLA Yogish Bhat.

Special prayers were also held at Sri Kshetra Gejjegiri Nandana Bitthl, Badagannur near Puttur on Sunday. Shridhara Poojary, temple trustee, said, ‘apoorva shatlhoushadhi dravya kalashabhisheka’ was offered to Deyi Baidethi, the presiding deity of the temple. Pavamana homa, Dhanvantari homa and kalashabhisheka have been offered to the deity,” he added.

Title: Fleeing isolation ward may land one in prison for up to 2 years
Content:
Nagpur: The four suspects who left the isolation ward of Mayo Hospital could suffer imprisonment up to two years if city police go ahead and register offences against them under relevant provisions of Indian Penal Code (IPC) for disobeying authorities at the government hospital.

Agra police became the first in the country to register an FIR in the Covid-19 related case on Sunday, against the father of a woman who tested positive in Bengaluru. Tehsil police are now waiting for legal opinion and documents from Mayo Hospital related to the four escapees to take a final decision on the complaint filed with it.

The complaint was filed by superintendent of Mayo Hospital at the instance of the divisional commissioner regarding the two male and two female suspects, who sneaked out of the isolation ward on Friday night without being discharged.

Though the suspects subsequently turned out to be coronavirus ‘negative’ in tests, the legal sword continues to hang on them, with the police receiving a formal complaint from a senior official of the government hospital on instructions of the chief of the revenue department in the division.

Legal experts, like high court lawyer Rajendra Daga and additional public prosecutor Vijay Kolhe, said citizens have no option but to toe the line of the government now as far as Covid-19 guidelines are concerned, especially with the Maharashtra Covid-19 regulations, 2020, under the Epidemic diseases Act, 1897, being enforced in the state. The archaic British law, enacted to tackle the bubonic plague in Bombay, gives sweeping powers to the Central and state government to set norms and regulations to contain the spread of the epidemic diseases. The power is delegated to officials, who are also protected against legal action under the Act.

Daga said the action of fleeing the hospital is generally covered under sections like 269 and 270 of IPC. “Section 269 IPC is applicable in the Nagpur case, where the suspect has a ‘reason to believe’ that their action could put lives of other citizens in possible peril, by spreading the infection they were ailing from. It has a prison term that may extend to six months or fine or both,” he said.

Daga said section 270 IPC may not be invoked as their act cannot be classified as a ‘malignant’ one, without criminal intent. “Section 270 IPC may not be attracted as the suspects had fled due to fear and not criminal intent,” he said.

Kolhe, former special prosecutor for CBI, said offences under section 188 IPC for disobeying government order can be invoked against anyone now, whether individual or organization head, for violating norms and guidelines related to Covid-19.

WHAT IS SECTION IPC 269

Whoever unlawfully or negligently does any act which is, and which he knows or has reason to believe to be, likely to spread the infection of any disease dangerous to life, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.

WHAT IS SECTION IPC 270

Whoever malignantly does any act which is, and which he knows or has reason to believe to be, likely to spread the infection of any disease dangerous to life, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

Title: Probe into woman’s ‘fall’ during raid in Prayagraj
Content:
Representative image

PRAYAGRAJ: A probe has been ordered into the case of a 22-year-old woman mysteriously falling from the terrace of her house in Georgetown during a police raid on Sunday morning. The woman is currently undergoing treatment at Swaroop Rani Nehru Hospital.

Senior police officers ordered a probe into the incident after it was alleged that the woman had allegedly fallen from the roof of her house when a police team raided her house on Sunday to nab her brother, who was wanted for mobile theft.

SP (city) Brijesh Kumar Srivastava said the woman’s family has not yet filed a complaint regarding the incident.

According to reports, police reportedly detained one Shankar Lal from Allahpur area as they suspected him to be mobile phone thief. Lal was later handed over to Georgetown police for interrogation, but he managed to escape from the thana campus. After Lal fled, police raided his house and brought his father to the police station.

An hour later, police received the information that Lal’s sister had fallen from the terrace of her home and sustained serious injuries. Police rushed her to SRN Hospital.

However, senior police officials denied that any raids were conducted at the woman’s home and said that they were probing how the woman fell from the roof.

Title: Despite coronavirus scare, tourists flock to SoU
Content:
Vadodara: The coronavirus pandemic and advisories to avoid public places has not deterred tourists from visiting the Statue of Unity (SoU)

In last one week, nearly 40,000 tourists have walked in at SoU and enjoyed the other facilities and parks around. “There isn’t much impact of coronavirus scare on tourist inflow. The number of foreign visitors may have gone down a little, but overall the walk-ins are still good,” said MR Kothari, Narmada district collector.

The SoU management, though, isn’t taking any chances. Visitors are being screened at the entry and every suspicious case is being reported.

Title: Lawyers on strike today, seek more funds for government schemes
Content:
Lawyers on strike today, seek more funds for government schemes

PRAYAGRAJ: Allahabad high court lawyers will boycott judicial work on Monday to draw government’s attention to their long pending demand for more funds for welfare schemes for advocates.

The call for strike was given by Bar Council for Uttar Pradesh, the apex body for lawyers in the state. High court lawyers will be joined by their counterparts from district courts and other tribunals in the boycott.

Earlier on March 2, BCUP had called for a statewide strike of lawyers to protest against the government’s non-cooperation in providing sufficient finances for welfare schemes for advocates. BCUP chairman Hari Shankar Singh said, “As the government has continued to ignore our demands, we have no option but to boycott judicial work again.”

The other demands of the council include adequate security for lawyers in wake of the recent attacks on them across the state.

Outgoing secretary of Allahabad High Court Bar Association (HCBA) JB Singh said, “Following the call for protest by BCUP, HCBA has also passed a resolution to abstain from judicial work on March 16. Hence, lawyers in Prayagraj will abstain from judicial work on Monday.”

Title: Man from Aurangabad duped of Rs 1.8 lakh in car sale fraud on social media
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: The Cantonment police on Sunday booked a man for duping a 38-year-old of Rs 1.8 lakh on the pretext of selling a used car on a social networking platform.

According to a police complaint filed by Shaikh Waseem, a resident of Aurangabad Cantonment area had opted to purchase a used car on the Facebook business page. Waseem found attractive car deals on the platform and contacted the mobile number mentioned on the page.

After finalising the deal, the suspect asked him to make an advance payment, before the car is delivered. Waseem agreed to pay the remaining payments in installments after successfully transferring the vehicle on his name.

Falling prey to the trap, Shaikh transferred Rs 1.80 lakh to his account through Paytm. But after taking the money, he failed to deliver the car. The suspect started demanding more money and when Shaikh refused to pay till the car is delivered, he threatened to block his account.

Suspecting that he has been cheated, Shaikh approached the police and filed a complaint.

The police booked the suspect on the charges of cheating and various other sections of the Information and Technology Act.

Title: MP political crisis: BJP using black magic on Congress MLAs, says minister
Content:
Madhya Pradesh Minister PC Sharma

BHOPAL: Amid war of words between the Congress and the BJP over rebel MLAs found to be holed up in Bangaluru, state legal affairs minister P C Sharma alleged that the Congress MLAs have been ‘kidnapped’ and kept in Bangaluru hotel where BJP leaders are performing ‘tantra mantra’ (black magic) on them.

“BJP leaders kidnapped our MLAs and have kept them in a Bengaluru hotel. From the videos, it seems that they are being hypnotised and terrorised. Black magic is being performed on them,” said Sharma during a press conference on Sunday.

The BJP mocked the statement and dubbed it as superstition. “The Congress leaders have turned superstitious. We can understand their mental situation at this moment when their government is going to fall anything. We have sympathy with them,” said BJP state spokesperson Rajneesh Agrawal.

Title: A marathon mission to trace contacts of the Italian tourist
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: The medical team, which embarked on the task of tracing places where the Italian tourist frequented before he was tested positive for Corona , had to circumvent the hurdles posed by the longest window of exposure recorded among the recently confirmed Covid-19 cases.By Sunday evening, over 100 contacts were traced of which less than 50 were categorized as ‘high-risk’; which means persons who got in close contact with the patient within a distance of one metre. The time-space matrix on a daily basis, which was easily prepared for other two cases , could not be done accurately in this case simply because data had to be collected over a period of more than two weeks.A marathon mission by another team, which spanned over six hours on Saturday night, helped track down 117 passengers who travelled with him in the domestic flight from Delhi to Thiruvananthapuram on February 27.The team, which received the contact numbers of the passengers, were able to establish contact with more than 80 persons. All of them were advised to go on quarantine. However, as for 36 contacts, the number was either wrong or remained out of coverage area. The team is now in the process of tracking down these contacts as soon as possible.The prolonged period of exposure and his stay at Varkala posed numerous challenges in tracking. The team learnt that he visited multiple places; for instance during his stay he would have lunch, breakfast and dinner from different places. Being a regular, he visited friends’ places more than once in a single day. A narrow lane that runs from the resort he had stayed comprised many small shops and it was run mostly by non-Keralites. He was friends with all of them and he had spent time chatting at these shops since his arrival on February 27.The team could come across only two-three CCTV footages. However, even the length of footages over an extended period of time threw up another challenge. There was a money exchange centre he had been to but with no entry recorded on register. Chances were slim to pinpoint the exact time at which he visited the centre. Over 30 interviews were done by the team on Saturday and while some claimed that the Italian was cautious enough not to shake hands with them, the health team has not bought it completely because the officials suspect that they could be saying that to avoid being put on quarantine.In one case the team took a screenshot from a footage, took a print and showed it to the foreigner to confirm whether he had visited that place, however he said that he was not the person in the picture. The team, which came up with a route map on Sunday, is now finalizing the list of secondary contacts as a precautionary measure. If one of the persons in high-risk primary contacts is tested positive in the coming days, precaution can be taken for all those in the secondary contact list.Tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran will hold a high-level meeting in Varkala on Monday.

Title: U’khand to treat coronavirus as ‘notified disaster’
Content: Dehradun: The Uttarakhand government is going to treat coronavirus as a ‘notified disaster’ in order to contain the spread of the infectious virus. The notification in the regard was issued by the Union home ministry on Saturday.Officials told TOI that the inclusion of coronavirus in the list of notified disasters will allow state government to utilise money from the State Disaster Response Force (SDRF) fund to pay ex-gratia payment to families of deceased and for the treatment of the patients suffering from the virus.“After the central government included Covid-19 in the list of notified disasters, the state will be able to provide assistance for the treatment and other purposes under SDRF allocation,” said Piyoosh Rautela, executive director of disaster mitigation and management centre (DMMC).As per the notification issued by the Union home ministry, the families of the person(s) dying of the contagious virus, which includes those involved in relief operations or associated in response activities, will get an ex-gratia of Rs 4 lakh.Also, the cost of hospitalisation for managing Covid-19 symptoms will also be borne by the state government. Moreover, the procurement of equipment to curb the virus and to strengthen the surveillance and control measures will be incurred from SDRF funds as well.The state government had on Saturday specified that “a fund corpus of Rs 50 crore has been earmarked for creating isolation wards and other preparations for Covid-19.

Title: Yes Bank writes down Rs 8,415 crore AT-1 bonds
Content:
Mumbai: Yes Bank has said it will write down additional tier (AT-1) bonds worth Rs 8,415 crore of the Rs 8,695 crore issued. This could have implications for mutual funds , life insurance companies and pension funds that have invested in the scheme, and their investors.

The lender has also said it will issue fresh shares worth Rs 10,000 crore to boost its capital which has been largely wiped out after its record Q3 loss. The bank has limited its capital raising under a government-notified reconstruction scheme to Rs 10,000 crore with SBI bringing in Rs 6,050 crore as against the initial commitment of Rs 7,250 crore and IDFC First Bank joining with a contribution of Rs 250 crore.

The bank’s capital adequacy has been boosted by writing down Rs 8,415 crore of the AT-1 bonds . The write-down of the AT-1 (quasi-equity) bonds will also impact high net worth individuals who, drawn by the higher rates, had bought these bonds. The reconstruction scheme was notified by the government last week to enable the distressed bank to exit a moratorium on withdrawals.

In a letter to stock exchanges after the results on Saturday, Yes Bank said the lender is deemed to be “non-viable or approaching non-viability and accordingly the triggers for a write-down of certain Basel III AT-1 bonds have been triggered”. It added that in light of the provisions of the Basel III circular, AT-1 bonds worth Rs 3,000 crore issued on December 23, 2016, and another lot of Rs 5,415 crore issued on October 18, 2017 stand extinguished. In its results, the bank had said that Rs 8,695 crore of these bonds can be used to enhance the equity of the bank. It is not clear whether the difference of Rs 280 crore between the bonds issued and bonds written down has been converted to equity. Yes Bank did not respond to queries till the time of going to press.

The bank said its common equity (tier-1) ratio fell to 0.6% after the quarterly loss. The losses were due to gross NPAs jumping to Rs 40,709 crore from Rs 5,158 crore in the previous year and Rs 17,134 crore in the preceding quarter. By making a Rs 22,328-crore provision for bad loans, the bank has managed to restrict the ratio of net non-performing assets to 5.97%, just below the 6% level which triggers prompt corrective action by the RBI.

After considering a capital infusion of Rs 10,000 crore and write-down of Rs 8,415 crore of AT-1 bonds, the common equity (tier-1) ratio improved to 7.6%, which is just above the statutory requirement.

Yes Bank faces a major challenge in convincing bulk depositors to retain their funds. The lender has seen a flight of Rs 72,000-crore deposits in less than six months and is meeting the mismatch through borrowings. There could also be legal challenges from shareholders holding more than 100 shares, who have been forced into a lock-in under the scheme.

Title: With 2 new operators, garbage reduces by 96-160MT/day
Content:
Nagpur: The city’s garbage collection has reduced by 96-160 metric tonne (MT) per day in the last four months, since the time the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) replaced 11-year-old operator Kanak Resources Management Limited (KRML) with two new operators — AG Enviro Infra Projects Private Ltd and BVG India Ltd. Though it is saving expenditure by Rs5 lakh per day, the civic body has started an inquiry to know the reasons behind such a drastic reduction.

The garbage collection from households was at an average of 1,255 MT per day during the tenure of KRML. The two new operators took over from KRML on November 16, 2019.

As per the NMC’s data, 13,507.03 MT garbage, which means an average of 900.46 MT per day, was collected between November 16 and 30. In initial days, the operators had struggled to ensure garbage collection from all areas of the city.

Between December 1 and 31, the collected garbage was 35,672.17 MT, an average of 1,150.71 MT per day. The figure between January 1 and 31 was 36,596.12 MT, an average of 1,180.52 MT per day.

The quantum of garbage collection reduced further in February and March. Between February 1 and 29, collected garbage was 33,219.59 MT (1,145.50 MT per day average). The quantum drastically reduced in the current month. It was 7,652 MT, an average of 1,093.14 MT per day, between March 1 and 7. This means that the average reduction in the last four months was 96-160MT per day.

During KRML’s regime, the NMC had exposed various types of scams which included inflation of quantum of garbage.

A KRML official told TOI, “The garbage quantum might have reduced as KRML used to also collect and transport construction and demolition waste. But the NMC exempted two new operators from collecting these wastes. The construction and demolition waste was over 150 MT per day. There is no issues of any irregularity on our part,” he said.

An NMC official said the exact reasons can be known only after an inquiry. “We doubt that the construction and demolition waste was over 150 MT per day. The process to appoint a new operator for collection and reuse of construction and demolition waste is going on,” he said.

The issue also raises a question mark as to where this huge quantum of construction and demolition waste is lying since last four months. As per average, such waste counts to 18,000 MT for four months.

The NMC official added that the two new operators are covering over 90% areas of the city as against 70% by KRML. “KRML had engaged 140 motorized and 550 rickshaws for garbage collection. The two new operators had roped in around 400 motorized and 150 rickshaws. Each motorized transport takes 800kg whereas each rickshaw takes 300kg. Thus, the garbage collection and transportation of two new operators is higher as compared to KRML,” he said.

If the data of past 11 years is taken into account, the quantum of garbage increases with each passing month.

The NMC is saving Rs5 lakh per day, which counts to Rs18 crore per annum. The average charges being paid to the two operators is Rs1,875 per MT. KRML used to get Rs1,436 per MT.

NMC official also said that the quantum of garbage reduced further since municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe visited Bhandewadi dumping on February 12, warned of stringent action in case of any irregularity and taking review on daily basis.

Title: Truck mows down woman, mob damages vehicle
Content:
Vadodara: The road in Bhutadizampa area was filled with angry people who came out in hordes to protest the mowing down of a 60-year-old woman, Niru Solanki, by a truck on Sunday. Angry mob pelted stones on the heavy vehicle while the police have registered an offence against Sunil Saroj, driver of the truck. The incident occurred on Sunday at about 11 am when Solanki was walking by the roadside in the area.

According to the police, Solanki, who worked in a private hospital, was on her way to work. The truck loaded with cement bags ran over Solanki who died on the spot. Soon, locals gathered at the spot and began pelting stones at the truck after the driver fled the scene. The mob demanded immediate action against the driver and also a ban on entry of heavy vehicles within city limits.

The city police have already issued a notification banning movement of heavy vehicles in the city limits till 1 pm. But, dozens of heavy vehicles are seen moving with ease well before 1 pm in different areas of the city.

Title: Teejan’s mantra: Teach kids to preserve folk art
Content:
Teejan Bai with CM Yogi Adityanath

Lucknow: Learning begins at home, Padma Vibhushan recipient Teejan Bai said here on Sunday to underscore that India’s rich folk art and culture could be well preserved in this digital age if parents created an environment of awareness for children.

The leading exponent of Pandavani — a musical rendition of the saga of Pandavs from the Mahabharata — left Lucknow spellbound with her powerful performance based on the Kurukshetra war when Bhim, the second-born Pandav, defeated and killed Kaurav prince Dushasan.

She was awarded the Lok Nirmala Samman by CM Yogi Adityanath at his residence in the morning. Later, the award was conferred on her again at UP Sangeet Natak Akademi in Gomtinagar with a purse money of Rs 1 lakh at a function organised by Sonchirya Foundation , a nonprofit that honours folk artistes. Armed with her ektara and a peacock feather, Teejan unleashed her prodigious talent despite failing health.
