Born and bred in Chhattisgarh, she charmed one and all with her rustic rhythm and inimitable simplicity. Speaking to TOI, she said today’s generation was still drawn to folk music and just need a little push. “I teach more than 200 kids and meet more every day who want to take this culture forward.

They need assistance of both their families and the government,” she said. Teejan who trained in Pandavani under her grandfather made her first public appearance at the age of 13. A village show slowly made way for bigger cultural events and festivals. She received Padma Shri in 1988, Padma Bhushan in 2003 and Padma Vibhushan in 2019.

“Himmat to andar se aati hai (The strength comes from within),” said the woman who broke the glass ceiling. “Earlier, Pandavani only had male performers. When I learnt the art, I realised women were equally capable. They only need to believe they are,” she summed up.

Title: Bhopal: Rebel MLAs say fear for life stopping them from return
Content:
File photo of Jyotiraditya Scindia

BHOPAL: Amidst speculations whether they would participate in the floor test in the House on Monday, 23 rebel MLAs from MP lodged at a resort in Bengaluru on Sunday talked to a couple of media channels. So far, they were only sharing their videos, informing about their resignation or their unqualified support to rebel Congress leader, Jyotiraditya Scindia .

MLAs like Bisahulal Sahu were also among them in addition to 19 Scindia loyalists.

In their brief interviews to media, they expressed apprehension that they could be “attacked” on arrival to Bhopal and they don’t trust Kamal Nath ’s police. They urged for provision of CRPF security or any other central agency when they return to Bhopal. They said that they wished to meet the speaker when he summoned them for one-on-one talk on their resignation but for fear of their life, they didn’t turn up.

They further alleged that their kin are being “harassed” by the police to lodge a “missing” complaint about them and requested them not to give in. They said they are happy at Bengaluru but want to return to Bhopal soon.

Title: Croaker renamed corona by fishermen
Content:
Mangaluru: When Narendra Modi became Prime Minister in 2014, the humble sardines coming from the Gujarat coast were called as ‘Modi Bhutai,’ similarly, when Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussain was executed, ‘Neimeen’ or butterfish caught in the coast were rechristened after him. Now it’s the turn of large size croakers or koddai in the local language, which have found a new name—corona.

Recently, fishermen who ventured into the sea got lucky and caught a large black spotted croaker . It is also known as sciaenidae or Jewfish. The fish is costly because its dried air bladder is used as a clarifying agent in breweries. The fishermen who caught the fish rechristened it corona . A kg of the fish fetched somewhere between Rs 1,200 to 2,000, said a fishermen at Old Port Mangaluru. A large croaker usually weighs somewhere between 7kg to 8 kg. “A month ago, a fishing boat had netted a ‘corona’ fish worth Rs 2 crore. The fish is mainly exported to foreign countries and buyers come from Gujarat,” the fisherman explained.

Pratibha Rohit, principal scientist and head, Central Marine Fisheries Research Institute (CMFRI), Mangaluru, says that though fishermen have named the fish as Corona but it’s the real name is croaker or koddai in the Tulu language. However, there is a fish called Melanotaenia Corona, which is a freshwater fish.

“It is common in the coast to name a fish according to the situation or after a person. Fishermen in Malpe dock call neimeen or butterfish as Saddam and it is still in practice for a long time. The trend started after Saddam Hussein was executed. A few years ago, large size sardines (bhutai) were named after him. These sardines, also called as Oman sardines, were transported here from Gujarat. It looks like fishermen have renamed croaker or koddai as corona, which is now declared as a pandemic,” she explained.

Another marine expert, requesting anonymity, said that croaker/koddai is very much in demand, and used for preparing fish maws or dried air bladder. Maws is a Chinese word and used mostly for purification of wine and beer. Its swim bladder and meat is expensive, which is used to prepare soups and home decor.

“The bladder of the croaker fetches about US $1,000 in Hong Kong and South East Asia. The fish is also used for medicinal purposes. The price is higher than shark fins,” the expert added.

Title: Rare mid-March fog takes Lucknow unawares
Content:
City witnessed a rare phenomenon in mid-March

LUCKNOW: City witnessed heavy dew followed by shallow fog in the intervening night of Saturday and Sunday, a rare phenomenon in mid-March.

Met officials attributed the unusual weather to heavy moisture in the air following two days of rain and thunderstorm coupled with north-westerly winds from snow-fed mountains.

The fog descended around midnight catching people unawares and was clear after sunrise. The day remained partly cloudy. Maximum temperature on Sunday was recorded at 26.8 degrees Celsius, five units below normal, while minimum temperature was normal at 17.3 degrees Celsius.

State Met director JP Gupta said, “Western disturbance caused thundershowers and hail in plains, including Lucknow, in past few days. It also caused snow in the hills of Himachal Pradesh and Uttarakhand. The cold wind from hills condensed the moisture content in air leading to fog.”

“As western disturbance has fizzled out, sky will be partly cloudy on Monday and will remain clear from Tuesday. Possibilities of formation of fresh fog are remote,” he said. Gupta said though a rare phenomenon, fog has occurred during the month of March in the past. According to long term average (1981-2010) taken out by the Met department, the mean number of foggy days in March is 0.1, which means it has occurred once in a decade. Meanwhile, describing fog in March as an unusual phenomenon, director of Lucknow University ’s climate monitoring station, Prof Dhruvsen Singh said it could be an indication of climate change.

“Global warming due to climate change is not only melting glaciers, it is also affecting circulation pattern of currents in the ocean that have an impact on wind pattern and leads to formation of cyclonic circulations,” he said.

Title: Kanpur: Brother-sister duo killed; SP MLC detained
Content:
Representative image

KANPUR: A brother-sister duo died of bullet wounds while a man was injured in a clash between two groups allegedly over one-upmanship in Narainpur pocket under the limits of Sadar Kotwali police station area in Auraiya district on Sunday.

On being informed, senior district and police officials, along with heavy police force, rushed to the spot and supervised the investigation.

Police have detained six persons including former Samajwadi party minister and MLC Kamlesh Pathak and his brothers Santosh Pathak and Ramu Pathak.

Family of the deceased alleged that Kamlesh’s brother -Santosh Pathak allegedly opened fire with his licenced gun on Manjul Chaubey (35), an advocate and his sister Sudha (28) following which the two sustained serious bullet wounds and collapsed, said the police. “While Sudha, who sustained serious gun shot wounds died on the spot, Manjul succumbed on way to Kanpur,” said the police.

Injured identified as one Ajit Kushwaha , a passerby, has been admitted to the district hospital where doctors stated his condition to be stable.

According to the police sources, the incident took place on Sunday afternoon when Kamlesh Pathak had gone to a temple in Narainpur locality of Sadar Kotwali police area. Kamlesh and his two brothers Santosh and Ramu allegedly entered into a scuffle with Manjul Chaubey and his sister Sudha over some issue, said the police. The scuffle soon turned violent with firing, allegedly started from Kamlesh’s side, which injured Manjul and Sudha, said the police sources further.

Manjul succumbed on way to Kanpur while his sister Sudha died on the spot. A passerby Ajit Kushwaha also suffered bullet injuries and is undergoing treatment at the district hospital, said the police.

“It is being alleged that Santosh Pathak, Kamlesh’s brother, shot Manjul and his sister with his licenced rifle. A forensic team reached the spot and collected evidences. Bodies have been sent to mortuary and investigations are continuing,” said SP Auraiya Suniti.

“Police have detained six persons including former SP minister and MLC Kamlesh Pathak and his brothers Santosh Pathak and Ramu Pathak. We are interrogating them” said the SP.

Meanwhile, a senior police official said, “As per the locals, the murder was fallout of a past rivalry between the two sides. A heavy police force has been deployed in the Narainpur locality particularly at the house of the deceased. Entry of outsiders has been banned in the locality.”

Title: Raut flayed for ‘Brahmin’ slur
Content:
Nagpur: Energy minister Nitin Raut came in for severe criticism from the opposition camp on Sunday for purportedly passing an objectionable remark regarding the Brahmin community, during a public speech in north Nagpur last week.

Senior leaders, including ex-MLA Milind Mane and leader of the house in NMC Sandip Jadhav, led a group of their supporters to Jaripatka police station to lodge a complaint against Raut for his alleged statement during a speech at a public gathering. Raut was criticizing the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) when he passed the remark, stoking the controversy for which the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) is trying to corner him.

Senior police inspector Khushal Tijare of Jaripatka police station said that a decision on the deputation submitted by BJP activists would be taken after due discussion with senior officers. “We are now looking into the allegations,” he added.

Addressing a press conference on Sunday, BJP leaders Dharampal Meshram and Jadhav condemned Raut for “insulting Brahmins”. "Congress leaders Jawaharlal Nehru, Indira Gandhi and Rajiv Gandhi were Brahmins. Former party president Rahul Gandhi is a Brahmin. Is the minister calling them outsiders? He should clarify his remarks immediately," they said.

Meshram and Jadhav demanded that the minister should publicly apologize or resign from his post. They asked chief minister Uddhav Thackeray to sack him.

BJP MLA Krishna Khopde too, criticised Raut for the statement. Khopde, in a press statement, said that the Congress leader should not have uttered a statement which does not behove his position as a minister in the government. Congress’s communal face stood exposed with the statement of the minister targeting a community, he added.

Despite TOI’s repeated attempts to contact Raut, there was no response from the minister’s end.

Title: Ban order on entry to malls, beaches revised
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: A day after the district administration imposed a complete ban on entry to beaches and malls in the city, the ban order was revised on Sunday.

The new order doesn’t mention about the ban but advises the public to exercise caution while entering tourist spots, beaches, parks, public playgrounds and malls. The public has been advised not to assemble in groups in these places.

Police and owners of malls have been directed to ensure that people do not assemble in groups in these places. The revised order was issued by the chief executive officer of district disaster management authority on Sunday.

Collector K Gopalakrishan said on Saturday that entry to beaches and malls will be completely restricted and an order banning the entry was also issued on Saturday.

Later, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said that complete ban on malls was not necessary and it was pointed out that such directions would create unnecessary panic.

The chief minister reiterated the need to not cause panic towards the end of the video conference held on Saturday.

The city went into partial shutdown mode on Saturday after the collector ordered a ban on entry to beaches and malls.

A notice was displayed banning entry of people at Shangumugham beach on Saturday. The district administration is learnt to have revised the ban order to avoid a conflict with the state government.

The ban on entry to beaches and malls was decided following a review meeting convened by the collector on Saturday.

In the meeting, it was cited that malls are places which are highly vulnerable to the spread of infection through chances of contact in supermarkets, toilets, escalators and eateries. Sources said that the decision to impose a ban on entry to malls and beaches was taken after an elaborate decision.

Title: Madhya Pradesh News: BJP leaders seek legal advice
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: Ahead of the crucial floor test in the Madhya Praesh assembly on Monday, top BJP leaders from Madhya Pradesh held crucial meetings at the residence of Union ministers Narendra Singh Tomar and Amit Shah in New Delhi, to discuss party strategy. The BJP leaders also took legal opinion on the political crisis in the state.

The first meeting was held at Tomar's residence where former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan , Union minister Dharmendra Pradhan and newly inducted Jytiraditya Scindia held discussions for three hours on the current situation in Madhya Pradesh. The leaders also discussed about BJP MLAs lodged in Manesar in Gurgaon and rebel MLAs in Bangaluru, said sources.

Another meeting was held at the residence of Amit Shah where the leaders briefed him about the current situation in the state and the MLAs supporting the party. The leaders is also learnt to have called on Solicitor General Tushar Mehta where they discussed the legal aspects of the political turmoil in the state and sought his opinion if matter reach the Supreme Court, sources added.

The meetings came after Congress and BJP issued whips to all their MLAs to be present in Bhopal on Monday ahead of the floor test. Sources said that Scindia is also planning to visit Bhopal to meet his six loyalists, who are likely to reach here from Bangaluru. Chouhan is also learnt to have met the 105 BJP MLAs lodged at ITC Grand Hotel in Gurugram before leaving for Bhopal.

After his return, the BJP state leaders held meeting at Chouhan's residence on Sunday evening. "We will ensure that the floor test be conducted in the House," said Chouhan.

BJP chief whip in assembly Narottam Mishra said, "The fog clouds will be cleared very soon. By night everything will be clear. The Governor and the Speaker are holding constitutional post and will take right decision. To defer the assembly session and the floor test the government is pushing the ministers and MLAs to speak out their fear."

Title: Gujarat: Five Dahod cops attacked during raid on bootlegger
Content:
Cops had gone to raid the house of notorious bootlegger Arjun Panda

VADODARA: A team of five policemen from the state vigilance team came under a massive attack from a bootlegger and his accomplices in Dahod ’s Jalat village late on Saturday night.

Police had to fire five rounds in the air after a group of around 30 people resorted to heavy stone pelting when they had gone to raid the house of notorious bootlegger Arjun Panda.

The vigilance team had received information that Panda had brought a huge stock of liquor and stored it in his house. When the squad began checking the house and seizing the liquor stock, Panda returned with a group of around 30 people and began pelting stones on the cops, who were caught unawares.

Though no policeman suffered injuries in the attack, the rioters badly damaged their three vehicles in an attempt to scare them away.

The squad members then fired five rounds in air to disperse the mob. When the rioters did not relent, the squad sought the help of Dahod police that rushed in to help. Panda managed to escape in the melee but the police seized liquor stock worth Rs 5.39 lakh from his house. Three cars and two mobile phones too were seized from the spot.

An offence has been registered against Panda and others under the Prohibition Act and rioting.

Police said that Panda had brought in the liquor from Alkesh Bakaliya, a bootlegger from Madhya Pradesh, and he was preparing to distribute it locally.

Dahod police have now launched a hunt for Panda who has reportedly fled from the district.

Title: Swimming pools, gyms, theatres to remain shut amid coronavirus scare
Content: The state principal secretary, on Sunday, had issued a communication to the district collectors, civic body chiefs, commissioners and superintendents of police across the state asking them to keep swimming pools , theatres, gyms , auditoriums and museums shut in their respective jurisdictions till March 31.Authorities said that the steps are being taken to contain the spreading of the disease. The directives have been issued as the state has imposed the 123-year old law ‘Epidemic Diseases Act 1897.

Title: SDMC grants old property tax relief in illegal colonies
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: South Delhi Municipal Corporation has announced an amnesty scheme to provide relief to residents of unauthorised colonies. SDMC mayor Sunita Kangra explained that as per the terms of the scheme, the outstanding tax prior to the current year shall be exempted for residential properties in the unauthorised colonies on payment of only the current year’s tax.

“In case of non-residential properties in these colonies, if the taxpayer pays the outstanding property tax for the financial years 2017-18, 2018-19 and 2019-20, his property tax arrears for the prior period shall be exempted,” she added. The scheme will be operational only till March 31. Kangra added that that property tax department of all four zones will organise special camps in these colonies in association with the respective councillors.

The mayor said that under this scheme, residential property holders have to pay property tax only for the current financial year (2019-20) and the entire due property tax since 2004 will be waived off.

“The owners of non-residential or commercial properties will be charged property tax from financial year 2016-17 and they have to deposit the due property tax of the last three years,” she said.

Title: Andhra Pradesh govt fully prepared to deal with Covid-19, no room for panic: CM
Content: VIJAYAWADA: Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy said that Andhra Pradesh was ready to manage coronavirus COVID-19 ) situation and there was no need for panic.The CM held a review meeting with the officials over the preparedness of the state.He said mortality rate due to coronavirus has been very low and the virus has affected the elderly and people who have been suffering from other ailments. The government has taken a series of measures to curb the spread of the virus, like any other disease, he added.Stating that the coronavirus situation in the state was not serious, Jagan said the people need to avoid large pubic gatherings, avoid visiting crowded places for some days. He said that schools and colleges in the state will be given leave for some days, while board exams will be conducted.So far two labs have been set up for testing of coronavirus-- SVIMS in Tirupati and another in Vijayawada. The government is planning to open a third lab in Kakinada of East Godavari district, Jagan added.Jagan claimed that paracetamol tablet can cure coronavirus. He said across the globe, 81% of the coronavirus infected persons have recovered from the virus in their homes (home isolation) while only 13% of the infected people were admitted to hospitals for recovery, he added.The officials of the Medical and Health and Family Welfare department in their bulletin mentioned that at present 512 persons have been kept under observations in the state and 21 admitted to various hospitals in the state. As many as 70 samples were tested and one sample was proved positive and 57 negative. The test results of the remaining 12 are pending.

Title: IIT Kanpur forms task force to check Covid-19 spread
Content:
IIT Kanpur forms task force to check Covid-19 spread

KANPUR: Amid coronavirus scare, IIT-Kanpur administration has taken measures to keep the campus residents, including students, faculty members, their families, staff and visitors safe.

In this regard, the institute’s administration, besides constituting a task force for covid-19, has put into immediate implementation the protocols laid down by it. All the campus residents and visitors have been asked to follow the guidelines to stay safe from the deadly virus.

These measures have been taken keeping in view the movement of regular visitors and the faculty members and students often visiting foreign universities for academic work.

As a precautionary step, the institute had already suspended all the classes and exams till March 29. Also, the annual technical and entrepreneurial festival of the institute, Techkriti, which was to begin from March 19, has been cancelled.

A mail, containing a set of instructions for each resident of the IIT campus, has been sent out by the institute’s deputy director Prof Manindra Agarwal. TOI is in possession of a copy of the mail sent out to the entire IIT-Kanpur community (residents of IIT-K campus).

The students, who went outside the campus during vacations, have been instructed to stay at their homes. “The institute will turn away the students if they come back as it will not be able for it to manage so many students”, says the mail.

Employees, campus residents and regular visitors, who had visited any foreign country during past four weeks, have been instructed to report to the health centre on the campus and fill a self-declaration form and if they had visited foreign country in past two weeks then they have been asked to enter into quarantine until two more weeks. They are also required to inform district epidemiologist, Dr Dev Singh on his no. +91 9473701284 as well as to the institute’s health centre in case flu-like symptoms develop within four weeks of their visit to a foreign country.

The employees of the institute, campus residents, regular visitors to the campus, who have participated in any conference or seminar or any large gathering in the country in past three days, have also been asked to report to the health centre for screening.

The concerning persons, if develop flu-like symptoms, have been directed to report to the health centre and enter into isolation for three days and report back to the health centre again for examination. The mail says that the faculty members, staff, family members and regular visitors should avoid interacting with anyone.

A cell has been set up for students in the visitors’ hostel no. 2 which became operational from Sunday morning. Food and other items will be provided to them in their rooms, the mail further said.

Title: Farmers bear the brunt of unseasonal rain, hailstorm
Content:
Kanpur: March has turned out to be rainy month with the city already receiving over 32 mm of rainfall. While the average rainfall in the month of March is between 10mm and 15 mm, the rain gauge so far is 32.8 mm.

According to the Met department of Chandra Shekhar Azad University, usually March is a dry month and there is not much rainfall during this period of the year but due to the western disturbances intermittent rains are lashing some places in the state.

The rains are also a result of repeated snowfalls in Uttarakhand, Himachal Pradesh and the upper Himalayan reaches. The rains, accompanied with hailstorms, have caused much damage to the crops leaving the farmers worried.

In the first 14 days of this month, it rained on eight days. On March 5, the city received 14.6 mm of rainfall and 7.4 mm on March 7. The Met office has predicted more rains till March 16.

After thunderstorm and rains that had lashed the city on Friday, the rain gauge recorded was 2 mm only. However, the rains have made the weather chilly.

The day temperature, which had upped to 29.6 degrees Celsius on Thursday, came down to 24.2 degrees on Saturday.

The minimum temperature which had reached 19.6 degrees Celsius came down to 13.2 degrees on Saturday.

Agrometerologist at CSA University, Naushad Khan while talking to TOI said, "The rains and hailstorm will definitely cause damage to the wheat crop. The unseasonal rains have come as a setback to farmers whose crops have perished in several districts of the state".

Title: District admin orders shutdown of cinema halls, clubs, coaching centres
Content:
Agra: To prevent the spread of novel coronavirus, the district administration on Sunday ordered shutdown of all schools, technical and vocational institutes, coaching centres till March 23. However, board and competitive exams will be conducted as per the schedule.

Besides, district magistrate Prabhu N Singh has ordered all cinema halls, multiplex, clubs to remain shut from March 16 to March 31.

Besides, the district magistrate has also ordered ban on private and public use of swimming pools in schools, hotels, residential society and other places in the district till March 31.

In a similar order, the Lucknow district administration on Sunday ordered forthwith closure of cinema halls, multiplexes, clubs, discos, swimming pools and gyms. These facilities will remain closed till March 31, Lucknow District Magistrate Abhishek Prakash said in an order, issued on Sunday.

“All the owners, managers and coordinators of cinema halls, multiplexes, clubs, discos, swimming pools and gyms in the district have been directed to close them with immediate effect till March 31,” the order said.

On March 13, the Uttar Pradesh government had announced closure of all primary and upper primary schools till March 22. It also directed closure of colleges nd educational institutes including medical, technical and vocational in the state. The decision will however not affect the scheduled exams in these institutions. The board exams will take place as planned.

The government also issued an advisory which discouraged mass gathering of any kind. The decision was taken after a high level meeting of the coronavirus situation in the state in Lucknow on Friday.

Title: Camel kills owner in Bikaner
Content:
Jaisalmer: A camel attacked its owner and killed him at Naya Shahar, 10km away from Bikaner on Sunday.

It is said that when a camel gets angry, it does not spare even its owner. In an incident reported on Sunday under Naya Shahar police station at railway colony in Bikaner, an angry camel chewed his owner to death.

After getting the information, Naya Shahar C I Guru Bhupendra reached the spot and took the body away. According to police, Bhanwararam Jat (45), a resident of of Kirmisar, was taking gravel on the camel cart. The camel caught Bhanwararam by his neck and did not leave him for a long time. As a result, the head almost got severed from the body.

Around 15 days ago, in a similar incident under Nokh police station area in Jaisalmer district, a camel had attacked its owner and injured him seriously, who then died while undergoing treatment. A large number of people gathered at the spot and a few of them somehow controlled the camel and tied it to a tree.

Title: Sadanand Fulzele, an ardent Ambedkarite, passes away
Content:
Nagpur: Sadanand Fulzele (92), a prominent figure in Babasaheb Ambedkar’s historic conversion to Buddhism at the Deekshabhoomi ground in Nagpur on October 14, 1956, passed away on Sunday. The death will leave an irreversible loss in Babasaheb Ambedkar Smarak Samiti in the city.

Sadanand Fulzele was born on November 1, 1928. He contested the NMC elections in 1952 and was elected as corporator from Ambedkar Nagar. He himself took Deeksha with Babasaheb Ambedkar and nearly half a million followers, which was one of the biggest such events recorded in history.

Arvind Joshi, organizing committee member of Ambedkar College, mourned the loss, “It a big loss for the family and the samiti. Fulzele worked selflessly and was a source of inspiration to all.” Fulzele played an important role in building and designing the entire architecture of Deekshabhoomi, which is the main attraction of Orange city, he said.

Fulzele, an ardent Ambedkarite, was instrumental in building the stupa at Deekshabhoomi, the site of Babasaheb Ambedkar's conversion to Buddhism in 1956. Fulzele, incidentally, was deputy mayor of Nagpur when the Dalit icon converted along with over 6 lakh followers. Fulzele was elected on a scheduled caste federation ticket in 1952, winning by just one vote. He was not only a witness to Ambedkar’s historical legacy but was also part of the Republican Party of India (RPI).

“We have lost our inspiration and guide. He was the ever-guiding light for us, the samiti will miss his presence,” said Kabir Rawelkar, vice principal, Ambedkar College.

Nitin Raut, state energy minister, expressed grief on his demise. “Sadanand Fulzele was an icon of Ambedkarite ideology and the face of progressive thinking. We hope to continue his mission, which focused on taking society ahead together. His loss is irreparable for not only Nagpur and Maharashtra, but the entire country.” he said

Fulzele’s body will be kept in Deekshabhoomi for people to pay homage on Monday from 3pm. Sudhir Fulzele, son of Sadanand Fulzele, said, “A huge procession will be avoided in public interest. The body will be later cremated at Ambazari Ghat around 5pm.”

Chief minister Uddhav Thackeray said, “Entire responsibility of the conversion was taken care of by Sadanand Fulzele. He dedicated his life for educational, societal and political field. He worked immensely for the education of backward children, and we must always remember his noble deeds, that’s our homage to him.”

“He personally took care of all the arrangements on the historic conversion day. He was very close to Ambedkar. We have lost a great human being and the pillar of Smarak Samiti,” tweeted ex-CM Devendra Fadnavis.

Nitin Gadkari, minister of road transport and highways, also expressed grief. “Sadanand Fulzele was an idol in the field of social work, politics and education. His contribution in social upliftment movement in Maharashtra was extraordinary. His demise is a personal loss for me along with an irreparable loss for the Ambedkarite movement,” he tweeted.

Title: DC’s office complex may require another year for completion
Content:
Moodbidri MLA Umanath Kotian held an inspection at the new DC’s office complex site at Padil on Sunday

Mangaluru: The new deputy commissioner’s office complex, which is under construction at Padil , will require one more year for completion. The 2.3 lakh square foot three-storey building is being built on 5.8 acres.

The building will accommodate 38 departments and offices of MLAs and MP. The construction was initially planned at an estimated cost of Rs 41 crore, but the actual cost may cross Rs 55 crore, said Umanath Kotian, MLA, Moodbidri .

He told reporters, after inspecting the work on Sunday, that though the project was started in 2018, it suffered a financial deadlock due to the farm loan waiver, and the flood that resulted in huge losses in the state. Later, the cost of construction increased due to the hike in price of materials. The government will release funds and expedite the work, he said.

“Though the site for the construction of the DC’s office complex was identified in 2014, the project could not be taken up due to litigation related to the forest department. Within a month we will convene a meeting here which will also be attended by the eight MLAs from the district, Dakshina Kannada MP Nalin Kumar Kateel, district minister Kota Shrinivas Poojari and district in-charge secretary V Ponnuraj. The meeting will discuss initiatives to complete the project at the earliest, and a delegation will meet chief minister B S Yediyurappa seeking funds. We will make this DC’s office complex a model one for the entire state,” the MLA said.

The new DC’s office complex will sport a spacious parking facility and accommodate 175-200 cars.

Prabhakar Yeyyadi is the project contractor. In fact, the project, which commenced on February 9, 2018, should have been completed before August 2019. At present, Rs 32 crore has already been spent to complete the structural work of the complex. The government has already released Rs 24 crore, he said, adding that the remaining funds will be released in a phased manner.

He said there are plans to hand over the old DC’s office complex in the city to the Mangaluru Smart City Limited. However, discussion in this regard is still in the initial stage, he added.

Title: Vadodara: Teen detained for digital rape of 3 girls
Content:
Representative image

VADODARA: A 17-year-old boy was detained by the Chhani police for allegedly sexually assaulting three four-year-old girls in the school van.

Parents of the girls had hired the school van service of the boy’s father who is a driver by profession. However, for the past few weeks, the boy had been driving them to the kindergarten school as his father was not keeping well.

“About a week ago, he began touching the girls inappropriately. He even digitally raped the girls when they used to take them home from school in his van. One of the girls told her mother about his acts two days ago,” said RS Dodiya, Chhani police inspector.

The girl’s mother went to the school next day and raised the issue with the management. Incidentally, the mother teaches in the same school. During the parent-teacher’s meeting, mothers of two other girls said that their daughters too had complained about the boy’s acts. The teacher then decided to file a complaint with Chhani police.

The boy, who has dropped out of studies, was detained by the police immediately and booked for rape.

“We will bring in a counsellor to examine the boy’s mental condition,” Dodiya added.

Police is now trying to ascertain if he has committed such crimes in the past.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Coronavirus in Lucknow: Two more suspected cases of coronavirus in Lucknow, 60 test negative
Content: LUCKNOW: Two more suspected cases were found in the city. Both are residents of Lucknow and recently came back from foreign trips. On the other hand, tests of 12 persons who came in contact with the two positive cases undergoing treatment in KGMU were found to be negative.KGMU spokesperson Dr Sudhir Singh said that 60 other samples sent from across UP were also tested on Sunday and all were found to be negative.Among the two fresh suspected cases, one had visited Spain and has been admitted to KGMU, while the other had gone to Jordan and has been hospitalised at RML Institute . On return, they were scanned and advised to isolate themselves at home for 15 days as a precautionary measure.“They developed flu-like-symptoms on Sunday and informed health officers. Their swab samples have been sent for confirmation test,” said Dr D Himanshu, isolation unit in charge, KGMU.Dr Vikram Singh, nodal officer, communicable diseases, RML Institute, said the condition of the patient is as of now is stable. Further course of action will be decided after receiving the report, he added.

Title: Bhopal: Binding or not? Legal twist to Governor's ‘directive’
Content:
File photo of Digvijay Singh

Asked what the legal position in this regard, he refused to comment, but one of his close aides said: “Article 175 (2) for the President of India and Article 86 of the Constitution for the Governor make it clear that any communication from the President to speakers of Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha and from the Governor to the speaker of an assembly would not be a direction but a message.”

After the meeting, Digvijaya said: “We expect the speaker to decide on floor test according to set traditions of the House, procedures, and law.” Attempts to contact governor, Lalji Tandon , for a comment in this regard proved futile.

To add to the drama, the 22 rebel MLAs issued video statements on Sunday, urging the Speaker to accept their resignations just as he has accepted the resignations of the six who have been sacked from the Nath cabinet. If the floor test happens, and they are absent, BJP will have the upper hand with its 107 MLAs.

As of Sunday evening, the assembly strength is 222 — after six resignations and death of two MLAs — putting the majority mark at 112. If the 16 other resignations, in the wake of Jyotiraditya Scindia ’s shock quitting of Congress are accepted, Congress would be down to 92 members in the House, which would then have a strength of 206, putting the majority mark at 104.

Even with its allies, who have not said anything yet about withdrawing support, the ruling Congress alliance will fall short of the magic mark. BJP has the edge in the event of a floor test in the present circumstances.

On Sunday, Prajapati again waited for the summoned rebel MLAs to arrive and explain to him the circumstances under which they resigned, but no one came. Just as the previous two days. “Even after seeking clarification, none from the 19 MLAs appeared to reply in person. Why are they not contacting me when they have sent their resignations to me through somebody else,” he wondered.

“I am a constitutionally elected Speaker. I am also their patron, but now I am worried. What is happening to the members? I owe a responsibility to the House and also to all MLAs. I have been waiting for the members who have been held up in other towns, to present themselves for verification but, it was futile. I will now decide about the issue at an opportune moment,” said Prajapati.

Congress minister Pradeep Jaiswal exuded confidence that Congress will be able to prove majority in the House, and said that the floor test might not take place. “We have the numbers. The chief minister is also confident. We have to wait and watch. It is not necessary that the floor test will take place tomorrow, as we all are grappling with coronavirus pandemic,” said Jaiswal after the cabinet meeting on Sunday afternoon.

P C Sharma also referred the coronavirus scare and said, “We are always ready for a floor test. In the previous test, two BJP MLAs increased our strength during voting. The given procedures and guidelines should be followed in conducting proceedings of Vidhan Sabha. The Speaker should take care of this.”

Even finance minister Tarun Barot told reporters that the Coronavirus scare is more concerning. “The Congress government is ready for floor test but the MLAs should return to participate in the test,” he said.

The BJP MLAs lodged in Manesar are likely to return to Bhopal on Sunday night. But what of the 22 Congress rebels? Former minister Umashankar Gupta , who is with the breakaway Congress MLAs in Bengaluru, told TOI, “I cannot say whether we will return or not.” tnn

Title: Andhra Pradesh govt fully prepared to deal with Covid-19, no room for panic: CM
Content: VIJAYAWADA: Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy said that Andhra Pradesh was ready to manage coronavirus COVID-19 ) situation and there was no need for panic.The CM held a review meeting with the officials over the preparedness of the state.He said mortality rate due to coronavirus has been very low and the virus has affected the elderly and people who have been suffering from other ailments. The government has taken a series of measures to curb the spread of the virus, like any other disease, he added.Stating that the coronavirus situation in the state was not serious, Jagan said the people need to avoid large pubic gatherings, avoid visiting crowded places for some days. He said that schools and colleges in the state will be given leave for some days, while board exams will be conducted.So far two labs have been set up for testing of coronavirus-- SVIMS in Tirupati and another in Vijayawada. The government is planning to open a third lab in Kakinada of East Godavari district, Jagan added.Jagan claimed that paracetamol tablet can cure coronavirus. He said across the globe, 81% of the coronavirus infected persons have recovered from the virus in their homes (home isolation) while only 13% of the infected people were admitted to hospitals for recovery, he added.The officials of the Medical and Health and Family Welfare department in their bulletin mentioned that at present 512 persons have been kept under observations in the state and 21 admitted to various hospitals in the state. As many as 70 samples were tested and one sample was proved positive and 57 negative. The test results of the remaining 12 are pending.

Title: Ganga Mela festivities beat coronavirus scare, ‘Rangon Ka Thela’ taken out
Content:
Ganga Mela festivities beat coronavirus scare, ‘Rangon Ka Thela’ taken out

KANPUR: The coronavirus scare failed to dampen the spirit of the devotees visiting the Ganga Mela held here on Sunday. Several locals paid tributes at various city ghats, including Sarsaiyya and Massacre Ghats, to the revolutionaries who fought for the country’s freedom struggle on this occasion.

Ganga Mela is celebrated every year after Holi on ‘ Anuradha Nakshtra ’ in memory of the revolutionaries who were released by the British government after being made captive during the 1857 War of Independence.

During the day time, people after smearing each other with colours, head towards the banks of Ganga for a dip, and because of this unique trend, the festival got its name ‘Ganga Mela’. The localities known as ‘Purana Kanpur’ like Hatia, Nayaganj, Birhana Road etc are the places where Ganga Mela celebrations are organised at a grand level.

Continuing with the tradition, the locals took out processions, which culminated at various city ghats. In these processions, the people, carried big sized drums filled with colour on ‘thelas’ pulled by buffaloes with people dancing and playing with ‘rang and gulal’ on the tunes of popular Holi songs and Bollywood numbers.

Since early morning, a crowd was seen in the Old City areas like Birhana Road, Hatia, Maniram ki Bagia etc palying colours.

The procession started from Rajjan Babu Park from Hatiya and as it reached Birhana Road, the residents of the area threw colours from rooftops on the revellers. The ‘matkis’, filled with colours, hung on Birhana Road, were broken by youths.

Meanwhile, the biggest attraction of the day was at Sarsaiya Ghat which wore a festive look. Several representatives of political parties and the district officials also took part in the Ganga Mela and the Holi Milan function.

People were seen hugging and wishing each other. The administration had deployed a large number of policemen at the ghats. District magistrate Brahmadeo Ram Tiwari , DIG Anant Deo and other administration officials also exchanged Ganga Mela greetings.

Pushpendra Jaiswal, a local claimed, that origin of the Ganga Mela could be traced to 1942 when the Britishers imposed a blanket ban on playing Holi, but residents of Hatia, performed the ‘ Holika Dahan ’ and played with colours to mark the protest against Britishers and to save their tradition. This led to the arrest of around 72 people for disobeying the British decree.

Enraged over this, the denizens played Holi continuously for seven days until all the captives were released by the Britishers.

“It is for this reason, that this day is not a mere festival for the people, but is a celebration to commemorate the victory of Indians over the British rule,” he added.

Title: IRMA hosts nat’l business plan event
Content:
Vadodara/ Anand: The Institute of Rural Management, Anand (IRMA) organised a one-of-its-kind inter B-school event – Aadhyam – on Saturday and Sunday.

The two-day national business plan competition for farmer producer organisation (FPO) opened with a panel discussion on the topic – ‘Access to credit: Opportunities and challenges for FPO’.

The panel discussion focused on ecosystem support services required for government’s plan to form 10,000 FPOs in the coming five years and the real factors of success of FPOs in the country.

The inaugural ceremony was graced by T Venkatakrishna, MD and CEO of NABKISAN Finance, R Ramaseshan, ex MD and CEO of NCDEX, Emmanuel Murray, senior advisor at Caspian Impact Investments, L Prabhakar from ITC agribusiness and Luv Bhardwaj, public policy expert at NITI Aayog.

Bhardwaj said that government is focused on enhancing the FPOs by providing better capacity building and bringing in efficient management information system for the same.

The panel also discussed on the need for policy changes related to CSR to sponsor management professionals in helping FPOs to prosper and having a holistic delivery of services like warehousing, processing among others.

Title: Apartment complexes in capital in preventive mode
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: After the district administration advised caution, apartments in the city have started taking measures to prevent spread of Covid-19. Most apartments in the city have stocked disinfectants to keep the high-touch areas clean. Residents associations have suspended all meetings in view of increasing number of Covid-19 cases.Trida-Sanjeevani apartment at Medical College Junction is among the various apartments in the city which have taken a proactive stand to keep the pandemic at bay. Sanjeevani apartment secretary Saiju Gopalakrishnan said that they have specifically asked the staff to keep the areas such as panels in the elevators, doorknobs and handles disinfected.“Cleaning staff have been given necessary instructions. They are given proper protective gear such as masks and gloves. No meetings or functions will be held as there is direction to avoid public gatherings,” he said.Gopalakrishnan said that the apartment has a good number of doctors and paramedical staff from Medical College Hospital, who are well aware of the precautions. “Since the gym and recreational facilities are under maintenance for the past few months, we didn’t have to give specific instructions regarding that,” he said.Regarding disposal of items like masks, he said that cleaning staff were asked to dispose it using incinerator.Artech Thampurans apartment complex in Thampuranmukku has temporarily stopped its biometric access system so as to avoid shared contact areas. Artech Thampurans apartment residents’ association president K Padmakumar said that restrictions are imposed on outsiders, such as food delivery personnel, in entering the apartment.“Several get togethers have been postponed now. Common areas are being disinfected frequently. Women’s group of the apartment is very active and they share awareness messages in our social media groups,” he said.Intimate Agasthya apartment complex at Kazhakkoottam too has temporarily shut down the bio-metric entry and exit system.“Sterilization of common areas and points of contact are being done as per the advisory received from health department. Periodic application of biomedical spirit and sanitizer lotions on lifts, rails, handles and entry points has been directed. In addition to this, disinfection measures are being carried out on the premises. Communication has been issued to residents to strictly follow the advisories issued by state government especially for those who have recently returned from foreign countries, especially places affected by Covid-19,” said Intimate Agasthya apartment residents’ association secretary Jagadeesh Parameshwaran.Federation of residents’ association Thiruvananthapuram (FRAT) chairman M S Venugopal said that all residents’ associations have suspended meetings and get togethers. “Even executive meetings of residents’ associations are cancelled. Since there are restrictions with regard to public gatherings, we are not planning any awareness events,” he said.On Sunday evening, health minister K K Shailaja has asked offices and apartments to provide a common hand-washing area as part of the ‘break the chain’ campaign.

Title: Covid-19: Italian tourist in Rishikesh found suffering from fever, admitted to AIIMS
Content: Dehradun: The owner of a guest house in Rishikesh on Sunday informed police about an Italian woman tourist who had not come out of her room since Holi. Soon after, a police team along with health department officials reached the hotel and checked on the 34-year-old woman, who was found to be suffering from throat infection and fever. The woman was admitted to AIIMS Rishikesh by police officials where she is being checked for coronavirus infection.“The guest house owner called us after noticing that the woman hadn’t stepped out of her room since Holi. She had been taking pills on her own for the past few days as she didn’t want to see any health provider,” said Kanhaiya Lal Singh, a local intelligence unit (LIU) official.Health officials told TOI that the woman was suffering from flu-like symptoms since her arrival in India but the infection became severe after she played Holi. They fear that if the woman is tested coronavirus-positive, then all those with whom she had played Holi would be at risk.“She told us that she had been suffering from sore throat and fever since her first day in India. But she never visited a medical facility. Her condition worsened after Holi and on Sunday, she complained of breathing issues as well. She has now been admitted in AIIMS Rishikesh,” said Dr Rajeev Kumar, in-charge of Government Allopathy Centre, Rishikesh.Meanwhile, the guest house owner told TOI that the woman had been staying in his facility since February 29. She had come to India on a one-month visa to learn yoga in Rishikesh.

Title: Delhi: GMAT aspirant loses Rs 5 lakh to two women from Madhya Pradesh
Content:
Anjali (Left), Nargis

NEW DELHI: Two women thieves from Rajgarh in Madhya Pradesh have been arrested for stealing Rs 5 lakh from a woman after engaging her in a conversation at a stationery shop. The incident took place in West Delhi’s Tagore Garden area.

The victim was preparing for her entrance exam, and had withdrawn the money to pay her coaching fees and for some other expenses.

The accused have been identified as Nargis (35) and Anjali (23). Both of them are married and hail from Kadiya village in Rajgarh.

On March 7, Garima approached police informing them about the theft. She told the cops that she was preparing for GMAT exam. She had gone to a bank at Tagore Garden shopping complex and withdrawn Rs 5lakh. Two women later followed her till the stationery shop where Garima went to get some photocopies done.

“While one of the accused engaged her in a discussion, another one managed to open the zip of her bag and steal Rs 5lakh from it,” said Deepak Purohit, deputy commissioner of police, West Delhi.

The accused then left the shop immediately. When Garima checked her bag to pay for the photocopies, she realised her money was missing.

“We identified and tracked the women and the auto driver with the help of the CCTV footage. The accused duo would usually live on the city outskirts and travel by autorickshaw. They have ten cases registered against them in Rajgarh and three in Delhi,” said a police officer.

The arrested auto driver was later identified as Pramod Podar. He told the cops that he charged Rs 2,000 to ferry the women to various malls and shopping areas. The gang members would later meet in Gurgaon.

They had handed over the stolen money to Geeta Bai, Anjali’s mother, who left for Rajgarh a day after the incident.

“The gang members from Madhya Pradesh have committed similar crimes in other states as well. They dress up well and enter wedding venues, banks and shopping complexes to look for possible targets,” the officer added.

Title: AMU VC writes to CM Yogi demanding continuation of property tax exemption
Content:
Agra: With the Aligarh Municipal Corporation (MC) raising a demand of Rs 13.77 crore from the Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) on account of outstanding dues towards property tax payments, vice chancellor Prof Tariq Mansoor, has written a letter to UP chief minister, Yogi Adityanath, urging him to continue the tax exemption that the varsity was getting earlier. He also pointed out that no such tax is being charged from the Banaras Hindu University (BHU).

Incidentally, the MC has threatened the varsity with seizure of its bank accounts, if they fail to pay the outstanding property tax and the interest accrued on it since 2005, immediately. The VC said that the university had written a letter to the university grants commission (UGC) and the Ministry of Human Resource Development (MHRD) demanding a budget allocation for payment of the outstanding tax dues, but they had received no response from them.

Talking to TOI, the university’s registrar, Abdul Hamid, said that the varsity classes, lab and library were exempted from the tax but the municipal corporation now claims that the earlier order was applicable only during the tenure of the Nagar Palika.

“This is a central university and funds are allocated by the Centre for every purpose and we cannot pay this huge amount until the ministry approves the same,” he said, adding that they will be in trouble, if MC seizes their bank account, as all projects and salaries will be stopped.

Chief tax officer Vinay Rai told TOI that the university officials are giving incorrect logic. He said the letter they are showing was of 1990 during the period of Nagar Palika and the corporation had already clarified to them that this was the new assessment by the corporation since 2005 under UP Municipal Corporation Act, 1959.

“UP government has already given its nod for recovery amount of Rs 13.77 crore including Rs 7.33 crore interest from the AMU,” he said, adding that “a warrant in this regard will be issued soon and movable and immovable property of the varsity will be attached, if required”.

Title: AMU students booked for violating section 144
Content:
Agra: Aligarh police has registered an FIR against over 60 AMU students for allegedly violating prohibitory orders by taking out a candlelight march outside the campus on Saturday evening.

The students had organized the march to demand justice for Mohd Tariq who died a day earlier after being shot at and injured by a former BJYM officer bearer Vinay Varshney.

According to the police, the students crossed the main gate of the university even after they were informed that section 144 was imposed across the city. The slogans that the students were shouting against the UP government and the police could have vitiated the atmosphere, stated the police FIR.

The FIR was registered against 11 identified varsity students along with 60 unidentified persons under section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant), 342 (wrongful confinement), and 353 (assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty) of IPC at civil lines police station.

To maintain law and order situation in the city, police personnel patrolled the areas outside the campus on Sunday.

Title: Four in Kakinada GGH on Covid-19 suspicion
Content: Kakinada: East Godavari district is on high alert as four people were admitted to Government General Hospital in Kakinada on Friday with suspected symptoms for Covid-19.The medical authorities are waiting for the results of the samples sent for test to National Institute of Virology in Pune. All of them have a history of foreign travel. An IT engineer returned from Malaysia to Rajahmundry on March 11 and complained of cough.A person from Devarapalli village of Ravula Palem came back from Dubai on March 12 and was identified by field survey staff and was admitted to GGH in Kakinada on March 13. Another software engineer from Biccavole returned from Toronto on March 9 and was admitted to GGH on March 13.Another person from Kondagunturu village came back from Dubai on March 3. When he developed cough and cold, he was admitted to GGH on March 13. District medical and health officer Dr Satya Suseela said the department is conducting cluster containment treatment where suspects are reported. She said hypo chloride solution is being sprayed at houses and bleaching powder sprinkled in surrounding areas. She said filed surveys are being conducted in a three kilometer radius.

Title: Three held in Ajmer with weapons
Content:
Representative image

AJMER: Police on Sunday arrested three youths who extorted businessmen by showing arms. Police registered a case under the arms Act.

Acting on a tip off that three youths were threatening a businessman with a pistol at Kundan Nagar Road, police raided the area and arrested them and seized the weapons.

According to police, Manish Sharma (34), a resident of Ramganj , and Ruchir Dixit (26) of Alwar Gate were armed with country-made pistols. Another youth Devender Yadav had five bullets of 8mm on him.

In another case, Beawar police arrested Sunil Kumawat (46) of Beawar for running a cricket betting racket and seized Rs 20 lakh, 12 mobile handsets and a laptop.

Title: Aurangabad couple barred from contesting polls after lying about number of children
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: A woman gram panchayat member in the Latur district and her husband were recently disqualified by the Aurangabad bench of the Bombay high court from contesting any election for having more than two children after the prescribed cut-off date.

The cut-off day for the implementation of two-child rule in panchayats was September 12, 2000 and the couple had twins in 2005. The twins were disowned by the couple for which the court took them to task for lying and suppressing information.

Lalita Nagnath Patil of Koraliwadi in Nilanga taluka of Latur district was elected to gram panchayat as member, but her election was challenged by Bhaskar Birajdar and others.

Additional divisional commissioner had disqualified her on December 18, 2019, concluding that two 2 biological children (twins) were born on March 30, 2005 to the petitioner and her husband, Nagnath, and this information was suppressed by them.

Lalita then moved high court challenging the additional divisional commissioner’s orders stating that she was ready to file an affidavit on the next date declaring that these two children are not her biological children.

She was also willing to undergo a DNA test if these two children are produced and if their DNA matches, both are willing to deposit an amount of Rs 5 lakh each in this court as costs and willing to face permanent disqualification as well as criminal prosecution.

Government pleader Suresh Munde said the couple stated that they did not know about the twins, while one of the respondents, Birajdar, pointed that the twins were studying in an English-medium school.

“The court had even granted the petitioner one opportunity before fling their individual affidavits, to reconsider their stand and if they want to resile from their stand, they would be at liberty to make a statement before the court on March 7, 2020,” he said.

The court later directed Latur superintendent of police to immediately embark upon a search for the two children by interrogating persons or relatives of the petitioner as deem fit and proper and shall follow all lawful methods for carrying out such interrogation and shall endeavour to produce two children before the court on March 7, 2020 at 10.30 a.m.

The petitioner and her husband were also directed to remain present in the court on the said date. When the matter came up for hearing before justice Ravindra Ghuge on March 7, the petitioner and her husband submitted that they are tendering an apology and desire to withdraw this petition.

During the course of hearing on the petition, the court also came across five birth certificates issued to the petitioner’s husband on a single day in support of their claim.

While dismissing the petition, the court imposed a fine of Rs 1 lakh on the petitioner, and directed the amount be deposited in this court on or before April 15, 2020, failing which, this court would initiate suo-moto contempt proceedings and would also direct the Latur district collector to initiate proceedings for recovery of Rs 1 lakh with an additional fine of Rs 50,000 as arrears of land revenue.

The court also directed Kasar Sirsi police station to register an FIR against Nagnath for manipulating the records of the birth dates of the five children. The court directed the district health officer to “locate the person, who had issued the birth certificates on December 22, 2016 to Nagnath and initiate disciplinary action against him for manipulation of records”.

Title: Telangana govt junks Abhaya Hastham, says Aasara a better scheme
Content: HYDERABAD: The state government junked Abhaya Hastham scheme started by previous Congress government in the undivided state.The state assembly on Sunday passed the bill repealing the Telangana Self-Help Groups (SHG) Women Co-Contributory Pension Act, 2009. Panchayat Raj minister Errabelli Dayakar Rao said the scheme was repealed as the state government has brought in an even better scheme, Aasara pensions, that covers all beneficiaries of Abhaya Hastham.As per the Abhaya Hastham, each woman member aged between 18 and 59 years contributed Rs 1 per day and the government also co-contributed Rs 1 per day for each member. Once the member reaches 60 years of age, she is entitled to a monthly pension of Rs 500 per month.The minister said that state government, which introduced Aasara pensions from October 2014, is giving Rs 2,016 and Rs 3,016 monthly pension to those aged above 65 as per stipulated eligibility norms. From the ensuing fiscal, those aged between 57 and 65 would also get Aasara pensions. “There is no purpose of continuing Abhaya Hastham scheme as Aasara pension scheme is offering more money,” he said.The assembly also passed three more bills—Telangana GST (Amendment) Bill 2020, Telangana Payment of Salaries and Pension and Removal of Disqualifications (Amendment) Bill 2020 and Telangana Lokayukta (Amendment) Bill 2020.As part of the Disqualifications (Amendment) Bill 2020, the TRS government has included 29 more offices such as chairman of MBC corporation, Musi River Front Development Corporation, Telangana State Rythu Samanvaya Samithi, Kaleshwaram irrigation project corporation, Yadagirigutta Temple Development Authority to name a few. As per the amendment, MLAs and MLCs cannot be disqualified for holding any of the offices mentioned in the Act. The assembly also ratified the extension of SC/ST reservations by 10 more years as passed by Rajya Sabha and Lok Sabha.

Title: U’khand reports first coronavirus case as IFS trainee, who had visited Spain, tests Covid-19+ve
Content: Dehradun: A 26-year-old trainee forest service officer from the Indira Gandhi National Forest Academy (IGNFA) was on Sunday found Covid-19 positive, making it the first confirmed case of the disease in the Himalayan state. The officer had returned from an international study tour to Spain, Finland and Russia along with other probationers on March 11. In all, 62 trainee officers had gone on a study tour of these countries.All the probationers were under quarantine since they returned. As reported by TOI on Saturday, blood samples of six of the trainees who had showed symptoms of cough, cold and fever had been sent for testing. Sources said that while one of the samples has been found to be positive, the reports of the rest are yet to be received.Officials said that the trainee officer who has tested positive for the virus was showing “mild symptoms and therefore holds strong chances of easy recovery.”“We are following strict protocols as laid down by the ministry of health and all the probationers are in quarantine. Although we have received the positive case information from the health authorities, we are yet to see the report,” said SK Awasthi, additional director of IGNFA. The Forest Research Institute (FRI) campus where IGNFA is situated, has also been closed for public till March 31So far, Uttarakhand has put 544 people in quarantine of which 187 are still under observation. In all, 29 blood samples of suspected people have been sent for test to Susheela Tiwari Government Medical College in Haldwani.Meanwhile, two students — a boy and a girl — of a Selaqui-based college were kept in quarantine at Doon Hospital on suspicion of coronavirus late on Sunday. The boy had returned from Dubai recently and was in contact with his classmate. Their blood samples have been sent for testing with two others — an Italian woman tourist in Rishikesh and an employee of a Doon-based company.

Title: Annual Urs of Shah Jahan to begin on March 21
Content:
Agra: The three-day annual Urs to commemorate the death anniversary of Mughal emperor Shah Jahan will be held at the Taj Mahal despite the UP government’s advisory against large gatherings in view of Covid-19 threat. The Urs will begin on March 21.

While entry into the Taj will be free from 2pm on the first two days, visitors will not be required to buy tickets on the last day.

A member of the organising committee said, “A 1,223-metre long ceremonial ‘chadar’ will be offered on March 23. Every year, Khuddam-e-rauza (caretakers of the Taj) committee offers a long multi-colour ‘chadar’ representing different faiths of the country on the original grave of Shah Jahan during Urs.”

Last year, a chadar measuring 1,221 meter was offered on April 4, while in 2018, 1,111 meter-long chadar was offered on April 15.

When contacted, superintending archeologist in Archeological Survey of India (Agra circle) Vasant Swarankar said that no advisory has been received from the government to stop gatherings at the Taj.

Title: 24-yr-old electrician booked for impregnating minor girl
Content:
Hyderabad: A 24-year-old electrician was booked for sexually exploiting a teen and impregnating her at Shamshabad. He was taken into custody on Sunday.

The teen girl, a Dalit, approached RGI Airport police claiming she was raped by the 24-year-old electrician when she was a minor. The girl is now four months pregnant.

RGIA police said the survivor claimed that when she was 17-years-old, she became friends with the electrician while pursuing Intermediate.

They became close and got into a relationship. During that time, the accused sexually exploited her several times, promising to marry her. The survivor recently turned 18, police said. A few days ago, the girl complained of stomach pain and her parents took her to a nearby hospital, where doctors confirmed that she was pregnant.

When the girl’s kin questioned her, she disclosed the incident. On confronting him, the electrician reportedly refused to marry her, police said.

The accused was booked and taken into custody. TNN

Title: Coronavirus in Agra: Four members of shoe exporter’s family ‘cured’
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

AGRA: Four members of Agra-based shoe exporter’s family who tested positive for novel coronavirus (Covid-19) were said to have been recovered from the virus and discharged from Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital on Saturday. After being discharged, one of the family members said that doctors have asked them to “avoid social gatherings for a few days and maintain a high level of hygiene and sanitation”.

The four members returned home on Saturday evening. Notably, six members of the family who had returned from Italy in the last week of February were quarantined on March 3. Two other members of the family are still at the hospital.

Recalling the experience of their 13-day recovery, the family members praised the arrangements made by the doctors along with efforts of the Centre, the state government and district administration to control the spread of the virus.

Six members of the shoe exporter’s family were recently transferred to the hospital in Delhi from Agra district hospital. They were the shoe exporter (aged 44), his father (72), mother (62), wife (37), son (16) and younger brother (38). Except for the shoe exporter and his son, the other four members were discharged on Saturday. The father and son also reportedly tested negative. Another sample was then collected. A final test report was awaited.

The shoe exporter’s younger brother told TOI, “Doctors at the district hospital in Agra and Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital took good care of all the family members. We were kept in separate rooms. There was no television, but mobile phone was allowed. Isolation was a little depressing for all of us. We are happy to return home now. Both Central and state governments are doing a commendable job in preventing the spread of Covid-19. We want to thank the district administration as well.”

The shoe reporter’s father said, “Efficiency of doctors helped us to fully recover in a short span of time. We have been advised by doctors to avoid social gatherings for a few days and maintain hygiene. I hope my son and grandson will return home soon. I would like to suggest everyone to follow health advisory issued by the government.”

Title: Madhapur land tussle in SC, co files contempt plea
Content:
Hyderabad: The tussle over Rs 6,000 crore prime land in survey number 1,007 near Hi-Tec City (Madhapur) has reached the Supreme Court with a buyer approaching it with a contempt plea, charging the authorities and some private parties with violating the status quo order issued earlier by the apex court in the matter.

Aditya Constructions, through its authorised signatory Thota Satyanayana, moved the contempt plea on behalf of the pattadar farmers against Najeeb Ahmed, Anil Kumar Chalamalasetty, Vellore Venkat Kamal Kumar, Narasimharao Bandaru and NRVSV Koteswara Rao charging them with violating the status quo order granted by the apex court on October 1, 2018 in respect of the land in survey number 1007 situated in the erstwhile Rangareddy district.

Aditya Constructions, in its plea, contended that despite a categorical order from the top court of the land asking the parties and the authorities to maintain status quo in respect of possession of the land, the respondents had without any right or title in their favour, executed certain documents on behalf of certain private companies.

The rightful owners, Pilli Mallaiah and six others, who entered into an agreement with us, had possession of this land for the last 60 years,” Thota Satyanarayana said.

Aditya Constructions also filed a separate plea before the apex court informing it about an earlier order of the high court that directed the authorities to update the names of Aditya firm owners in the digital revenue records since they happen to be the authorised persons for a portion of the land in survey number 1007. “But a bench of the high court recently heard a third party appeal filed by a company called Prime Properties and stayed the ‘digital direction’ without hearing us,” the company said, adding, “We want this order to be nullified because it was passed without following principles of natural justice.”

Title: APERC to help state become energy efficient
Content:
Vijayawada: As part of efforts to improve energy performance in industrial sector, the AP Electricity Regulatory Commission ( APERC ) would support implementation of ISO 50001: 2018 energy management standards in industries which is essential to improve energy performance, reduce wasteful energy consumption and sustainable development.

According to sources, BEE secretary RK Rai met APERC chairman Justice C V Nagarjuna Reddy and sought support for effective implementation of ISO standards and other energy efficiency programmes in Andhra Pradesh.

Rai said BEE wants to provide an international framework for industrial plants for good energy management and prioritise new energy-efficient technologies that help industries to use energy more efficiently. In view of AP’s potential, effective implementation of these standards will help the state reduce energy costs, improve cost effective productivity, profitability and promote industrial development.

Rai said the industrial sector was the highest energy consumer accounting for 40% of the total consumption in the country. The energy consumption is expected to reach 443.4 million ton of oil equivalent (Mtoe) by 2031against the present total energy consumption of 347 Mtoe in industrial sector due to which the ISO 50001:2018 would be implemented initially in industrial plants, identified under PAT (Perform, Achieve and Trade) scheme, he said.

Title: 1 red sanders smuggler held, 18 logs seized
Content:
Tirupati: Sleuths of red sanders anti-smuggling task force arrested a smuggler and seized 18 logs near Nagapatla East Beat forest, near Tirupati on Sunday. The smuggler, identified as Silambarasan (25), is of Vellore in Tamil Nadu.

Speaking to reporters in Tirupati, Task force SP P Ravi Shankar said, sleuths were conducting combing operations inside the Seshachalam forest area under the Nagapatla East Beat forest, in the early hours on Sunday, when they found a vehicle parked inside the forest area. The approached it only to find Silambarasan loading red sanders logs into the vehicle. tnn

Title: Ninder farmers call off indefinite hunger strike
Content:
Jaipur: The farmers of Ninder called off their indefinite hunger strike while sitting inside the pit, half burying themselves on Sunday.

The strike was called off after receiving assurance from the state government that an empowered committee will be constituted to resolve their issue. The farmers, however, announced to protest on land till their demands are met. But, they will not sit inside the pit.

The decision was taken after the chief whip of Congress, Mahesh Joshi, assured the farmers on government’s behalf.

After the talks turned futile and their three demands, including compensation as per Land Acquisition Act 2013 were not met, the move was taken to catch the government’s attention.

Samiti coordinator Nagendra Singh said, “We were forced to intensify our protest in peaceful manner as government did not take concrete steps to resolve our issues. The protest will continue till the time decision on the scheme is not taken. But we will not sit inside the pits.”

Title: MSU to hold exams only till Wednesday
Content:
A child and his father wear masks during a ride in the city

Vadodara: Following Gujarat government’s decision to close down all schools and colleges till March 29, teaching work at M S University campus will also remain suspended for the next two weeks to combat COVID-19.

Ongoing exams starting from Monday will, however, continue till March 18 as scheduled. “All examination including mid-semester exams, additional exams, university exams after March 18 are postponed till further orders,” said MSU’s officiating registrar Dr KM Chudasama.

“Due care is to be taken for keeping safe distance between students if any exams are conducted till March 18,” said Chudasama.

Teaching and non-teaching staff members, however, have been asked to remain present during office hours but all teaching activities will remain suspended, said dean of Faculty of Science professor Hari Kataria.

Currently, exams of semester five (ATKT university exams) are underway at our faculty and will continue only till Wednesday. The decision regarding the rest of the exams will be taken later.

Apart from science faculty, exams are also scheduled at Polytechnic College, Faculty of Arts, Faculty of Family and Community Sciences, Faculty of Performing Arts and Faculty of Pharmacy. On Monday, a total of 123 students are scheduled to appear for exams while 307 and 271 students are scheduled to appear for their exams on Tuesday and Wednesday.

Title: 162 more people under observation
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: As part of the precautions against spread of Covid-19 , 162 more people have been put under observation in the district on Sunday.The total number of persons under observation in the district so far is 1,148.As many as 24 persons are admitted to the isolation ward of the General Hospital while there are 19 persons at Medical College Hospital.The collectorate control room received around 101 calls and Disha call centre got 210 calls on Sunday.The mental health helpline received six calls. As many as 710 persons received psychological counselling so far through the helpline.The district administration urged people who returned from foreign countries in the last 28 days to call the toll free number of district administration at ‘1077’.Those who came from abroad and show symptoms such as fever, cough, cold or breathlessness should immediately call Disha at ‘0471 2552056’ or ‘1077’ and follow instructions. Whatsapp number is ‘9188610100’.District administration also informed that such persons should never use public transport.

Title: More trauma: Family of Covid-19 patient in Lucknow flooded with crank calls
Content: Lucknow: The 12 individuals in city who have been advised home isolation for 15 days after they came in contact with a Covid-19 patient have been receiving multiple crank calls, suggesting that their personal details have been leaked on social media from the CMO’s office.LUCKNOW:Angry and frustrated, some of them described it as a violation of their right to privacy and threatened to move court. CMO Narendra Agarwal has ordered an inquiry into the alleged leak, saying strict action would be taken against anyone found guilty.The crank call victims are all relatives of the Toronto-based doctor who tested positive for coronavirus on Wednesday. The CMO’s office had prepared a list of the doctor’s contacts, including their names, age, address and phone numbers for collection of samples and other precautionary measures.“We have been receiving 150-200 calls a day. We get calls from various parts of UP and other states like Gujarat and Madhya Pradesh . While most are curious about symptoms, a few presume we are already infected. They ask us how we contracted the disease and if we are noticing any physical changes . One person even blamed us for spreading the infection,” a member of one of the three families in Gomtinagar told TOI.The person said his family was even apprehensive of an attack or ostracism after they spotted a few men taking pictures of their house on Saturday. “I alerted health officials on the helpline, but nothing has been done to save us from this harassment,” he added.A 31-year-old doctor in Indiranagar, who is also on the list, said the leak was blatant violation of their right to privacy. “I will sue the authorities if people continue to call and ask questions that they should not. We have already tested negative and are in self-isolation at home as precaution,” he said.Another Gomtinagar resident said their personal details had been leaked on social media, which triggered the flood of crank calls. “That is when we realised that our names, addresses and numbers have been leaked,” the victim said.A family in Vikasnagar said their neighbours were supportive, but the calls had left them terrified. “Health workers have sanitised our home. Neighbours bring us essential items. But, we don’t know how to handle these callers,” said a member.“I have received complaints from families and ordered a probe. We’ll lodge an FIR against anyone found guilty,” CMO Agarwal said.

Title: Bombay high court asks Parbhani ZP to consider job claim of man who lost father at six
Content:
Bombay high court asks Parbhani ZP to consider job claim of man who lost father at six

AURANGABAD: The Aurangabad bench of the Bombay high court directed the chief executive officer (CEO) of Parbhani zilla parishad to consider the claim of a man, who lost his father — a primary teacher with the ZP — when he was six, for appointment on compassionate ground at a post commensurate with his qualifications.

The man’s father was a confirmed employee of the ZP working as a primary teacher. He died on September 6, 2005.
