He has directed the administration to increase the isolation wards as per the requirement.The state government has already issued orders through the respective collectors to ensure closure of schools, colleges, theatres, drama halls, swimming pools, gyms, anganwadis, technical institutions, malls.On Sunday, Tope said all museums too would be closed till March 31. “The only way is to ensure that there is no gathering at any of these places. The Epidemic Act is in place and we will ensure that those violating it are penalised,” he said.

Title: Catchy slogans to steer basic education drive in Lucknow
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: Come March 16, a team of education crusaders will match slogans with ‘munadi (beating of drums)’ to encourage people to send their children to schools.

The basic education department is launching an extensive primary school enrolment campaign covering 25 districts in each of its three phases which will continue till the first week of June. The first phase will include Lucknow, Gorakhpur and Ayodhya.

As part of the campaign, 25 LED vans will be rolled out to screen audiovisual clips highlighting various education programmes like Operation Kayakalp (to strengthen infrastructure in schools) and Mission Prerna (focussing on learning outcomes). Dedicated teams will reach out to people through street plays. DG, school education, Vijay Kiran Anand said awareness would be created among people on the need to educate girl child and against social evils.

Using slogans such as ‘Bal vivah ki bedi todo, shiksha se beti ka rishta jodo’, ‘Bal vivah hai ek kalank, lagne naa do iska dank’, ‘Beta, beti ek samaan, dono ko do shiksha daan’, the government aims to increase enrolment of girls in schools.

At the end of each show, parents will have to take pledge that they will send both boys and girls to government schools, and participate in school meetings, say no to child marriage, spend time with kids and make efforts to turn UP into a model state.

Title: 28-year-old Maoist surrenders
Content: Hyderabad: A dalam member of Communist Party of India (Maoist) surrendered before Kothagudem police on Sunday. He worked with Maoist party for five years. Police said Kistaram SGS Dalam member Sodi Unga, 28, had joined the outfit in 2015 due to influence of Sabitha, a dalam commander. He told police that he decided to surrender since support for Maoists was dwindling from the public. TNN

Title: 60-yr-old held for rape attempt
Content: Hyderabad: A 60-year-old man was arrested on Sunday by Jagadgirigutta police for attempting to rape a nine-year-old girl. The accused is a neighbour of the victim. On Saturday night, the accused molested the victim when she went to use the washroom outside her house. The victim’s mother heard her crying and came to the rescue. The accused has been booked for attempt to rape and under POCSO Act. TNN

Title: 3 phones, charger, handsfree found in jail
Content:
Ahmedabad: During Operation Clean-Up in the Ahmedabad Central Jail on Saturday, three android mobile phones, a charger and a handsfree equipment were found hidden in one foot deep pit dug under a tree on the New Jail premises.

According to sources, the phones belonged to an undertrial prisoner Rakesh alias Rocky Gupta. Jail authorities have lodged a complaint with Ranip police for further investigation.

According to the FIR, during a surprise check at about 12 noon, a jail sepoy found some loose mud near a tree just opposite Veer Bhagat Singh Yard Barrack.

“He informed his seniors. We then dug up the mud and at about one foot below the ground, found three android mobile phones wrapped in newspapers and a plastic milk bag. A charger and a handsfree were also found there,” said a senior jail official.

Jail officials said one of the phones had some photos of the undertrial, Rakesh Gupta.

“When questioned, Gupta said he had got the phones in January 2020 and had hidden them when the Operation Clean-Up began,” the official added.

Title: Eateries in Pune reduce number of tables catering to patrons
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: If you plan to visit a restaurant anytime soon, be prepared for some conspicuous changes. To begin with, restaurants have been told to reduce the number of tables in dining area and increase the space between tables to ensure social distancing due to the Covid-19 scare, as per an internal advisory issued by the Pune Restaurants and Hoteliers Association (PRAHA) on Friday.

PRAHA president Ganesh Shetty told TOI, “Restaurant staff will have to follow stringent hygiene measures like washing hands after eating and using tobacco, after handling money or other forms of payment, when switching from preparing uncooked foods to working with ready to eat foods, after touching face or hair, cleaning and sanitizing surfaces such as remote controls, kitchen counters, door knobs, bathroom surfaces, keyboards, tables and chairs.”

He said that the footfall in restaurants have dipped by 10-15% after the virus outbreak, hence the number of tables will be decreased and more space will be created between tables to maintain a distance between customers.

“As per protocol outlined for staff, as soon as anyone experiences flu-like symptoms, they must immediately get checked by a recommended chest physician/GP/ENT. If symptoms exist, a doctor will recommend if they must undergo further tests. Staff should immediately contact their restaurant manager and report the case if tested positive,” Shetty said.

Hotel chains and restaurants in the city have been enforcing precautionary measures and issuing hygiene advisories for its staff and guests. Hotel and Restaurant Association of Western India has asked all its members to take precautionary measures by upping the hygiene at their hotels. “We have asked the reception and front-end staff to be vigilant about guests exhibiting flu-like symptoms. Such guests are immediately encouraged to see the on-call doctor,” association president Gurbaxish Singh Kohli said.

Title: Covid-19 scare in Gujarat: Not what doctor ordered for exam calendars
Content: AHMEDABAD: Following neighbouring states’ decision to suspend academic activities to prevent spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) Gujarat announced a two-week shutdown of academic institutions ranging from anganwadis to colleges and private coaching classes from March 16 to 29. The move would affect the overall academic calendar and would result in delay for exams and new academic sessions, opined educationists.Dr Himanshu Pandya, vice-chancellor of Gujarat University (GU), said that teaching, examination and other meetings are suspended up to March 31 till further orders by the state government. GU officials said that the examination for repeat students was concluded recently. “From March 23, the exam for undergraduate and postgradute courses was to commence. With the notification, it will be deferred to April. Administrative work will however continue at the head office,” said an official.Sources in education department said that senior officials had fought hard against the decision to close academic institutes. “Till Saturday, senior state officials maintained that there was no need to panic and close the schools and colleges. The officials cited examples of China and European nations to support the argument. In less than 24 hours, the stance however got changed,” said an official.Jayvantsinh Sarvaiya, senior official of an association of college administrators, said that if the state can conduct exams for Class X and XII, why not college students? “Delay in exams will affect an academic year for the students. We are yet to go through finer details of the notification,” he said.City-based universities and schools sent out messages to the parents, informing them about at least two weeks’ suspension of academic work. Non-teaching staff will continue to attend the schools and colleges.For the schools, the annual exams were to commence from March 27. With the notification in place, now the exam is likely to be conducted in the first week of April. Several CBSE schools have completed their exams. A few of the schools might conduct the last exam on Monday.Bhaskar Patel, president of All Gujarat School Administrators’ Association, said that the move will definitely affect the academic calendar. “About 10% of the course is still to be taught. The schools will have to devise ways to cover it. Moreover, this is the first year of the state’s ambitious plan to start the next academic year’s session. It will take a hit due to loss of the fortnight,” he said.

Title: Delay raises fears of battling it out in peak summer heat
Content:
Vijayawada: Candidates to local body elections have expressed concern about having to bear the brunt of high summer temperatures following the deferral of elections by the State Election Commission ( SEC ) in the wake of the coronavirus crisis. Summer has already set in in the city and daytime temperatures are steadily rising.

With elections being deferred for at least six weeks, it will be early May—the peak of summer—before polls are held. The revised schedule will be released based on the severity of the coronavirus crisis, however, candidates fear that maintaining the momentum of campaigning will be difficult with the progress of summer.

Historically, May has been the hottest month in the state and temperatures are likely to go above 40 degree Celsius from April. Further, campaigning in summer is expected to involve large expenses for candidates, even with restrictions on election expenditure, besides posing a physical challenge.

Candidates contesting in MPTC, ZPTC and panchayat elections are more worried than the urban contestants. “With the fight between political parties is so intense in the villages and margins between winning and losing being very narrow it would be very hard for us to sustain the momentum for six weeks. Keeping the flock together for such a long period would be a costly affair as it is an undisputed fact that there will be a lot of money influence in the elections,” said a contestant for an MPTC seat in Krishna district.

Title: GHMC steps up sanitation measures for workers’ benefit
Content: Hyderabad: As a part of precautionary measures to check the spread of coronavirus, GHMC has strictly instructed officials to ensure safety gear for sanitation workers. The safety gear includes masks, aprons, head gear and hand sanitizers. Additionally, GHMC has decided to remove the sanitation staffers who skip work for more than 30 days to improve sanitation. “Bio-metric attendance will be taken from 5am to 6am, the attendance is designed in such a way that names of the staffers will be deleted automatically if they don’t attend the duty for more than 30 days,” said mayor Bonthu Rammohan.To counter the coronavirus threat, GHMC is focusing on Information, Education and Communication (IEC) activities. “We are trying to reach out to maximum number of households to spread awareness about coronavirus and preventive measures. A total of 24 lakh pamphlets have been printed with precautionary measures to be taken,” said Badhavath Santosh, GHMC additional commissioner, health wing.“I have asked the GHMC zonal commissioners to monitor the city and keep a vigil on coronavirus. Sanitation workers should wear radium aprons, gloves, masks and should be equipped with safety gear,” said Bonthu Rammohan. “In my zonal office, usage of hand sanitizer is mandatory, we are also ensuring the sanitation workers use it too,” said Ravi Kiran, GHMC zonal commissioner, Serilingampally.GHMC officials, along with residents are distributing hand sanitizers, handkerchiefs and safety gear to sanitation workers. Residents of Methodist Colony, Begumpet distributed handkerchiefs to sweepers recently.

Title: Directions issued to check coronavirus in Rajasthan
Content: JAIPUR: In view of Coronavirus , the district administration on Sunday issued directions to 17 departments including Devestan, Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC) and others how to check the spread of the virus.As a precautionary measure to check the spread of virus, the administration instructed temples to wipe railings with disinfectants. Directions have also been issued to request people not to gather in large groups at temples.The JMC has been directed to spray and mop floors with sodium hypochlorite in public areas. Moreover, the department should create awareness campaign by installing hoardings, posters and banners in the city.According to JMC officials, they have already begun spraying insecticides in public areas as a mode of precaution. It has procured 1% sodium hypochlorite solution for this purpose. Govind Devji, Moti Dungri temple and garbage depots in the city are being kept as priority. Insecticides are being used multiple times a day, including the headquarters of JMC and zonal offices. Regular spraying is also being done in buildings and toilets. Most of the malaria staff at JMC have been appointed for this work.The (JMC) has been asked to identify buildings that can be used to quarantine coronavirus patients if the situation in the city turns worse.

Title: 55-year-old woman trampled to death by elephant
Content:
Coimbatore: An 55-year-old woman was trampled to death by an elephant near Chennampatti village abutting the forests of Andiyur in Erode district on Sunday . The deceased was identified as S Vellaiammal, 55 from Kolathur in Salem district.

Vellaiammal and Kulanthaiammal had gone to Neethipuram in Chennampatti forest range for grazing goats. Vellaiammal noticed an elephant and started to run from the area. However, the elephant chased her and trampled her to death.

Field staff from Chennampatti forest range rushed to the area and sent the body to the Bargur government hospital for postmortem . Kulanthaiammal was admitted at the government hospital.

Title: Cong works to control damage
Content: Ahmedabad: Even as four MLAs deserted the party, the Gujarat Congress swung into damage control mode on Sunday, looking to keep its flock together ahead of the Rajya Sabha polls on March 26. A second batch of 22 MLAs were flown on Sunday evening to Jaipur by the party. The Congress party clarified on Sunday evening that both its candidates will contest the Rajya Sabha election from Gujarat.AICC Gujarat in-charge Rajeev Satav flew to Gujarat on Sunday afternoon and held a marathon meeting with state Congress leaders at the house of Siddharth Patel. “Although four MLAs have resigned and the party’s strength in the assembly has decreased, it has been decided that both Congress candidates will contest the Rajya Sabha election. We are confident of winning two of the four seats,” leader of opposition Paresh Dhanani said after the meeting.Congress has nominated Bharatsinh Solanki and Shaktisinh Gohil as its candidates for the RS election. With four MLAs having resigned, the strength of the party has been reduced to 69. While the Congress is not in a position to get both candidates elected, it is banking on the support of other parties and the lone independent MLA in the assembly.

Title: Make U-turns to decongest Delhi Road: Meerut IG
Content:
Representative Image

MEERUT: Meerut IG and SP, traffic, inspected Delhi Road for bottleneck jams and instructed that necessary steps be taken to ensure that traffic lights are followed thoroughly and wherever required, U-turns be made to ease the situation.

“An inspection was carried out at Delhi Road on Sunday to determine the ways we can adopt to clear the bottlenecks on the entire route. The inspection was carried out by Meerut IG Praveen Kumar Tripathi ,” said Meerut SP, traffic, Sanjeev Bajpai.

This comes a day after plans were made to identify where the encroachment are and have to be removed.

During the inspection, the IG also found that UP roadways buses were also to blame for the traffic jams as they picked up passengers from random points.

“Suggestions have been given to set up U-turns, identify areas where encroachment are and take measures so that the encroachments do not come up again,” said Bajpai.

Title: Arrest all extremist elements in city, state BJP chief Murugan tells police
Content:
Coimbatore: State BJP president L Murugan on Sunday demanded police to arrest the people who were involved in violence in the city over the past few days.

In his first visit to the city after becoming the state BJP chief, Murugan said while two men have been arrested for attacking a Hindu Munnani functionary a few days ago, police were yet to nab another duo who assaulted Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh functionary Suryaprakash.

“All the extremist elements should be arrested and put behind bars to restore peace and harmony in the city,” he told reporters. The BJP leader also urged police not to show any leniency towards anti-social elements since such attacks were continuing without an end.

Murugan, who was given a warm welcome by the BJP cadres at the city airport, said he would strive hard for the party’s growth in Tamil Nadu. “We have had MLAs, MPs as well as union ministers from Tamil Nadu in the past. We would work towards increasing the numbers of such public representatives.”

Vowing to intensify the efforts to enhance the party’s presence in Tamil Nadu, he said the BJP would embrace people from all sections of the society, irrespective of caste or religion.

Title: Uttam: Cong is nation builder, KCR is the real coronavirus
Content: Hyderabad: In a strong counter-attack to chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao’s comment that Congress was coronavirus of the country, Telangana Congress president and Nalgonda MP Uttam Kumar Reddy termed ‘ KCR as the real coronavirus’ while Congress is a nation builder.“KCR said that a paracetamol tablet was enough to fight coronavirus and was not serious about the issue until the state cabinet took a decision to shut down places of public gatherings,” said Uttam.“His comments in the assembly that coronavirus does not survive in temperatures above 27 degree celsius only exposed his lack of knowledge about the virus and the magnitude of damage the virus can cause if it spreads,” Uttam added. The TPCC chief demanded that KCR withdraw his remarks and tender an unconditional apology to the Congress. TNN

Title: Rajasthan: 84% polling recorded in 704 panchayats
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: A turnout of 84.46% was recorded till the end of elections across 704 gram panchayats, where polls were held for the posts of sarpanch and ward panchs. A gram panchayat in Jaisalmer’s Mohangarh panchayat samiti has registered highest polling in the state, at 98.2 per cent. Meanwhile, Siwana panchayat samiti recorded lowest polling percentage at 68.32 per cent. Among others, Jaisalmer’s Sam panchayat samiti recorded percentage of 95.28%, Barmer’s Adel panchayat samiti registered 92.22 per cent polling and Jaisalmer recorded 92.06% polling. On the other hand, Sirohi district’s Sheoganj panchayat samiti recorded only 68.33% polling.

These elections are being held for panchayats where nominations were already conducted but the nomination papers were kept in sealed envelopes after Supreme Court’s decision to stay the HC order cancelling two delimitation notifications.

The elections were held in Ajmer, Alwar, Banswara, Barmer, Bharatpur, Ganganagar, Jodhpur , Jaisalmer, Baran, Bhilwara , Churu, Dholpur, Jalore, Jhunjhunu, Nagaur, Sawai Madhopur and Sirohi. The polls for the post of upsarpanch will be held on March 16.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Brahma Temple and Dargah to be sanitised daily
Content: The administration also asked Ajmer Municipal Corporation to keep the adjoining residential areas of dargah... Read More AJMER: In the wake of the coronavirus, the district administration has directed Brahma Temple Trust and Dargah Committee to arrange continuous cleaning of Brahma Temple in Pushkar and the dargah of Khwaja Moinuddin Chishti in Ajmer. They were also asked to use sanitisers to clean walls and doors of both the religious places. District collector Vishwa Mohan Sharma asked subdivisional officer of Pushkar to manage cleanliness on religious places and also make devotees aware about cleanliness and precaution against this virus. The administration also asked Ajmer Municipal Corporation to keep the adjoining residential areas of dargah clean. This region is congested and hundreds of devotees throng the area right through the day. AMC chief Chinmayee Gopal formed a task force to keep the region clean. She also directed the cleaning staff to spread awareness among local residents. Sources said though the number of devotees coming to Pushkar and dargah declined on Sunday, there were still hundreds of people coming there. The district administration has also launched a 24-hour control room and anyone can provide information about the infection so officials can send a rescue team. The district collector also directed shutting down of anganwadis till March 31. He directed anganwadi officials to distribute food to children at their homes.

Title: Lucknow: Chandrashekhar Azad launches Dalit party, double whammy for BSP
Content:
Chandrashekhar Azad addresses during the launch of his political party

LUCKNOW: Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad launched his political outfit, Azad Samaj Party, on Sunday on the birth anniversary of BSP founder Kanshi Ram. Before launching his party at Safai village in Noida, the 37-year-old Dalit leader made Kanshi Ram's photograph his Twitter profile picture and launched the party flag — a white band between two blue strips with Azad Samaj Party inscribed in middle. He said the Bhim Army will run parallel to the party and continue to fight for Dalit rights and enroll members.

And for BSP, which took forward the Kanshi Ram’s legacy, the birth anniversary of its founding president could not have come at worse time, not just because of exodus of its foot soldiers, but also the heralding of Azad’s Dalit party, which threatens to nibble into its vote-bank.

On Sunday, a battery of Kanshi Ram loyalists who were associated with him since the days of DS4 (Dalit Shoshit Samaj Sangharsh Sangthan) and nursed BSP with “blood and sweat” joined Samajwadi Party . “I sacrificed my youth to build BSP and unite the Bahujan Samaj . Then we were thrown out of the party,” said Tilak Chand Ahirwar , former BSP MLC, who said he joined the party in 1984 on Kanshi Ram’s clarion call to uplift Dalits in Bundelkhand.

Former BSP MP from Azamgarh Balihari Babu was equally emotional. While fondly recalling Kanshi Ram, he avoided an attack on Behanji even though he was sacked from BSP along with Ahirwar. “We don’t know what is our crime,” he said. This was the refrain of all those who joined SP under the leadership of Akhilesh Yadav .

Prominent among those who had quit BSP included Ghoora Ram, Indrajit Saroj , both former ministers, and former MP Ram Prasad Chaudhary. Former IAS officer and once a BSP loyalist, Kunwar Fateh Bahadur , too had rebelled against the “Brahminisation” of BSP by Mayawati. The cadre is watching helplessly the exit of commanders and the fading away of Kanshi Ram’s mission of socio-economic uplift of Dalits, he said.

SP president Akhilesh Yadav is happy poaching on Mayawati’s camp even as he played out a film on the life and times of Dalit icons at the party national executive. With an eye on expanding SP’s social base beyond the Muslim-Yadav arc, Akhilesh Yadav had invited the once influential faces of BSP — Ghooram Ram (Jatav), Indrajit Saroj (Pasi) and Ram Prasad Chaudhary (Kurmi) — as special guests to the party national executive.

Title: In R’seema, oppn hails ‘timely’ notice amid alleged violence
Content:
Tirupati: The decision of the State Election Commission ( SEC ) to defer elections to local bodies in view of the coronavirus crisis has dampened the spirits of the YSRC in Rayalaseema while opposition parties have hailed the move as a timely one.

The decision of the SEC to also temporarily relieve and suspend some poll officials, including police personnel, most of who are from the four Rayalaseema districts, has cheered opposition parties that have alleged that the YSRC has instigated violence during the poll season.

Addressing the media in Tirupati on Sunday, former TDP legislator M Sugunamma hailed the intervention of the SEC. “The ruling party had bulldozed all the guidelines with only one intention which was to win unanimously as many wards as possible. If the state election commission had not intervened, there was no one to stop the ruling party leaders, who threatened and kidnapped many opposition party candidates to stop them from filing nominations,” she said.

“Is it fair for the ruling party to obstruct candidates from opposition parties from filing their nominations? With the help of police support, false cases were also being slapped against TDP candidates,” said Sugunamma.

Data released by the district administration show that of the 65 ZPTC seats and 858 MPTC seats in Chittoor district, single nominations by the YSRC have been filed in 29 ZPTCs and 323 MPTCs, while in 19 MPTC seats, only the TDP has filed nominations.

In a press conference, Chandragiri MLA Dr Chevireddy Bhaskar Reddy said he had advised followers and party activists contesting the elections to maintain peace until the election process is restored.

Title: New orders for exporters drying up, may lead to job losses
Content:
Jaipur: Garment and handicraft buyers from European countries have started putting on hold the orders they had placed with exporters in Rajasthan. Similarly, buying agents, who act as middlemen between buyers and suppliers, have also started asking them to extend the payment cycle from 30 days to 90 days, exporters here said.

With finished goods starting to pile up at the factory-end and many manufacturers looking to reduce their capacity utilisation, pressure is mounting to undertake cost-cutting measures which may lead to employee layoffs.

Many exporters said new orders are drying up to the extent of 50%, while existing supply contracts are increasingly getting frozen. “We are actually clueless as to what is going to happen. This is for the first time we are facing such a dramatic disruption to our businesses,” said Dileep Baid, a leading handicraft exporter in Jaipur.

Baid said handicrafts is a manpower intensive business and if the situation does not show signs of improvement within a month, the inevitable will happen. “The industry will have to scale down operations and that would impact large number of jobs,” added Baid.

The garments exports industry is also in a similar predicament. Buying agents have already asked for rescheduling the payment period to 90 days from the general 30 days.

“Buyers are now telling us to put the orders on hold and such requests are increasing by the day after the lockdown in many European countries. Buying agents and buyers are now telling us to extend the payment period to 75-90 days,” said Aseem Singla, General Secretary of Garment Exporters Association of Rajasthan ( GEAR).

But Baid said the bigger risk was that the default of buying companies in the absence of business. “If the companies in Europe or other parts of the globe go bust in the absence of demand, they would lose the money pending with them,” said Baid.

Already many handicraft exporters are suffering because of the Chapter 11 bankruptcy of Pier 1 imports and if this happens because of corona contagion, they would lose all the money.

Title: Election process in Macherla may come under SEC scanner
Content:
Guntur: The nomination process for elections to local bodies in Macherla assembly constituency has stoked a controversy as single nominations have been received for almost all posts, including MPTC, ZPTC and ward councilors in Macherla municipality.

All posts will be secured uncontested by YSRC candidates.

In Macherla, the nomination process has been a one-sided affair with candidates of opposition parties who filed their papers for MPTC elections in some villages withdrawing their nominations by Saturday, the last day for withdrawals.

The State Election Commission (SEC) has placed a caveat on seats that will be secured uncontested, declaring that all those elected unopposed will take charge along with other elected representatives, but the SEC will review the conditions that led to their being elected unanimously.

The SEC’s decision, experts said, might lead to countermand of the elections. “The SEC might go for fresh elections if someone approaches it with the complaints that they have been restrained from filing the nominations or threatened to withdraw the papers,” said a senior official.

Data made public by the SEC show that 14 MPTCs each in Rentachintala, Macherla, Karampudi and Veldurthi mandals in Macherla assembly constituency have a single candidate contesting the polls. In Durgi mandal, candidates in 13 of 14 MPTCs will be elected unopposed.

The YSRC will corner 69 of the 70 MPTC seats in Macherla constituency as no other candidate is in the fray. Similarly, elections to the five ZPTC seats will be uncontested as the TDP has not fielded any candidate.

Elections to the 31 wards in Macherla municipality will be uncontested as well, with single candidates contesting in all 31 wards in the town. The TDP has been faced with a lack of leadership in the constituency for over two decades.

Title: Green adieu to pyres: Lucknow to get three eco-friendly crematoriums
Content: LUCKNOW: If an ambitious civic plan succeeds, the city will soon boast three green crematoriums or ‘greenatoriums’ that will offer residents an environment-friendly way to bid the final goodbye to their loved ones.According to LMC officials, the ‘ greenatorium ’ is a cross between the traditional funeral pyre made of wood and an electric crematorium comprising a metal chamber and an exhaust pipe. Chief engineer RN Tripathi said the green crematorium system would comprise a burning chamber equipped with a body tray, two exhaust pipes or chimneys and a water tank to “neutralise” the fumes.“The body will be placed in the drawer-like pyre and covered with wood. It will be lit and then pushed into the chamber, which will be then closed. The toxic, black smoke will be passed through the first chimney and a water tank before being released as white smoke through the second chimney,” Tripathi explained.The ‘greenatorium’ has several advantages over a traditional pyre. One, it will require only 75kg of wood instead of around 350kg used in last rites. Two, the cost of burning a body will come down to Rs 300-500 against Rs 4,000-plus. Three, the system can bring down air pollution levels, besides aiding conservation of trees.The LMC has allocated a budget of Rs 1.35 crore from the 14th Finance Commission for these eco-friendly crematoriums in Kudiya Ghat, Baikunth Dham in Gomtinagar and Alambagh. A Gorakhpur-based private company has been roped in and installation work is expected to begin from the first week of April.Mayor Sanyukta Bhatia said Lucknow would be the first city in UP to boast green crematoriums. “The ‘greenatoriums’ will offer people the opportunity to light a traditional wood pyre without damaging air quality,” she added.Taking its environment concerns farther, the LMC will set up smart dustbins in 12 prominent areas of the city. Each sensor-equipped bin will send an alert to the command centre as soon as it reaches capacity. A budget of Rs 1 crore has been set aside for this project.

Title: Man held for assaulting minor girl in Coimbatore
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: A 32-year-old man was arrested for sexually assaulting a Class X girl at Singanallur in the city on Saturday.

The arrested has been identified as Arunkumar, of Ganeshapuram near Ramanathapuram in the city. He was working as a food delivery boy.

Police said the 15-year-old victim’s father was a close friend of Arunkumar. “He often visited Singanallur to meet the girl’s father, who had separated from his wife a few months ago.

On Saturday, the minor girl was alone at her residence when Arunkumar visited the house and sexually assaulted the girl.

Arunkumar escaped after the girl raised an alarm. Based on the girl's mother complaint, the all-woman police (east) registered a case against Arunkumar under Sections 7 and 8 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) Act and arrested him.

He was later produced before a local court and lodged in jail under judicial custody.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Akhilesh Yadav: Ordinance is a grave contempt of court
Content:
File photo of Akhilesh Yadav

LUCKNOW: Questioning the government’s haste in promulgation of UP Recovery of Public and Private Property Ordinance, 2020, Samajwadi Party president Akhilesh Yadav on Sunday said the move is an admission that its act of putting up hoardings of anti-CAA protesters was unlawful.

“Countering a court order in this manner amounts to grave contempt of the court. Those who are enacting draconian laws today should note that the same laws may also apply on them as they have been involved in rioting and arson in the past,” Yadav told reporters at party headquarters.

“In fact, the SP government committed a blunder by not recovering compensation from rioters in the BJP. Yogi Adityanath is the only chief minister in the country to have withdrawn criminal cases against himself,” he said.

On his recent telephonic conversation with the CM, Yadav said: “I objected to the manner in which the BJP government is implicating senior SP leader Mohammed Azam Khan in fabricated cases.”

“I have directed my rank and file not to create disturbance in the Prime Minister’s public meetings but my rallies should also not be disrupted by BJP workers,” he said.

On the completion of three years of the Yogi Adityanath government, the SP chief said the BJP government had only changed the names of cities and SP’s development projects.

“If the BJP government really wanted to glorify former prime minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee, who was a great statesman, it should have set up a university in his memory on the lines of Cambridge or Harvard instead of renaming the international stadium built by SP government,” he said.

Yadav said he would see if the CM was able to fulfil his commitment of dedicating Purvanchal Expressway to the people by Diwali. “It will not be completed by then. It will be completed only when we will come to power and celebrate Diwali in 2022,” he said.

Meanwhile, senior leaders from various political parties including ex-MP Balihari Babu, Dilip Chand Ahirwar of BSP and former BJP MLA Indrapal Pal joined the SP on Sunday.

Title: Study: Gujarat among India’s startup incubator champions
Content: Ahmedabad: A working paper titled ‘Incubators in India — A Multilevel Study’ by IIM-Ahmedabad (IIM-A) says that the period from 2015 to 2018 recorded a rapid expansion of startup incubators and three states — Gujarat, Maharashtra and Karnataka — set up most of them.The study carried out by IIM-A assistant professor Neharika Vohra and CIIE.CO partner Supriya Sharma says that compared to metro cities, the growth rate of incubators in non-metro centres was very high. Analysis of the incubators also suggested that over 60% of the Indian setups were housed within educational institutes. The rest were supported by businesses, industry bodies, or ministries.“Gujarat followed a similar model. The majority of universities/institutes have an incubation centre, most affiliated to government schemes,” said Vohra. “Many of them are channelling the state government’s support such as the availability of Rs 10 lakh for product development and an equal amount for marketing products.” Vohra went on to say: “Our estimates tell us that there may be over 180-200 startups that received such support. In terms of sectors, we see startups in pharma, industrial manufacturing, education and energy sectors among others supported by these centres.”Sharma said there is value in enabling potential entrepreneurs get a closer brush with the process of setting up and running a business — without the glamour or heroism attached to it.“We find initiatives like SSIP hold immense promise as they enable students/alumni experiment, build and fail fast while pursuing their degree/course,” she said.Of the 284 incubators covered in the study, 90% were set up after 2000 and 70% of them were set up between 2008 and 2018. Government and sectoral push along with favourable business climate could be the possible reason for the spike, said researchers.Business advice, connection with mentors, domain experts and assistance with fund-raising were found to be the most common services whereas assistance with branding and support with physical infrastructure were the least common. The study found wide disparity between incubators in terms of activities, policies and support.What startups wantThe researchers interviewed startup founders to understand their needs in the incubator ecosystem. Some of the needs included connecting with specialized mentors and subject experts, help in connecting to customers and vendors, and advice on branding and brand building and better processes to remain engaged. The study also found the presence of incubators lopsided and recommended more in northeast, east and central parts of India.Need for better assessment‘Given the diversity among incubators, relevant performance metrics need to be devised to measure the performance robustly by incubators, policy designers, and researchers of incubators. New ones can be assessed on startups they are able to attract whereas mature ones may be evaluated on the success of supported startups as well as the ability to generate resources and become sustainable, the study said.

Title: With murals, housing units at Ukkadam sport a posh look
Content:
Coimbatore: It is hard for anyone to miss the huge murals on Tamil Nadu slum clearance board’s housing units at Ukkadam while passing through the area.

As commuters stop for a while to appreciate the work, the residents are filled with happiness. For, the paintings have not only beautified the buildings, but also have boosted their spirits. The murals are done by St+art India Foundation.

“The painting of elephants on the walls of my block is very attractive and I really like it. I have been telling about the murals to the friends ever since they started painting. But they think I am just lying about it. May be, I should bring them to my place one day to make them believe it,” said a 10-year-old resident of the housing unit, Devendran. He said despite several requests, none of his friends had visited him at his house.

Pointing out that the residents of the housing unit generally have a low self-esteem, Rishwana, a college student, said, “We always feel that outsiders are looking down on us and that we are being judged by our living environment, which we think is substandard. The housing unit is not only surrounded by piles of garbage but also filled with foul smell. Now, the paintings have not only beautified the housing unit but also have boosted our self-esteem. We feel proud every time the public look up at the murals.”

Another resident Deepa Ramesh Kumar said people from other parts of the city have been flocking to their area just to appreciate the work. “Even those who were not aware of the housing unit earlier have been coming to our place to take photos. There is also a perceptible change among the residents, who were earlier hesitant to call it their home. Today, they are going around telling about the paintings at the housing unit. However, we could continue to be proud only if we keep the murals and surroundings clean.”

After Kannagi Nagar in Chennai, it’s the second destination in the state to be transformed into an art district by the St+art India foundation. About a year ago, they had painted the walls of government buildings, including that of Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital, and created an art trail in the city.

“We had two reasons for selecting the place. First, the buildings have huge beautiful walls and second, the place was neglected. With the murals in place, public would start keeping the place clean and stop littering around. The public attention in turn would pave way for development,” said Ritesh Sharma, project manager of the foundation.

He said they would visit the place again next year to paint the remaining walls. As of now, they have completed three murals and the remaining one is expected to be completed in another week.

The credit for beautifying the walls goes to artists Amitabh Kumar, Avinash Kumar, Jeeva, Munir and Chifumi. The project is sponsored by Asian Paints and is supported by the city corporation.

Title: Will move court over nomination process: TDP
Content:
Amaravati: The state election commission’s ( SEC ) decisions to defer the local body elections and evaluate the conditions, which led to single nominations being filed in several seats across the state has blown wind in Telugu Desam Party’s ( TDP ) sails.

Taking the opportunity, the TDP has demanded that the SEC should cancel the nominations to seats where only one candidate has filed a nomination .

Speaking to the media here on Sunday, former minister Devineni Umamaheswara Rao criticised the SEC for not cancelling the elections to seats where candidates have been nominated uncontested. This despite admitting to a large-scale violation taking place during the filing of nominations. He said the SEC should evaluate the entire process and issue fresh notification for the local body elections.

Earlier in the day, SEC confirmed that all those who were deemed to be elected unanimously would be sworn in along with the other elected representatives after the completion of the election.

The SEC was also quick to clarify that the elections had only been deferred and not cancelled. “We have neither suspended nor cancelled the elections. The process completed till now holds good. There is no change to it. The election of all the candidates who are bound to be declared winner from uncontested seats are also valid,” said state election commissioner N Ramesh Kumar.

However, TDP leaders flayed the move stating that the SEC’s decision to look into the conditions, which led to candidates being selected uncontested, would be defeated if the elections were to go through.

TDP MLC P Ashok Babu said they would approach the high court if the elections were to go through with the current set of nominations. Ashok Babu accused the SEC of failing to take proper action despite complaints by candidates.

TDP MLC Deepak Reddy demanded that SEC should immediately suspend the entire process carried out till now and go for fresh elections. “The process should begin afresh with issuance of fresh notification. We will not accept the SEC’s decision to merely defer the elections,” said Deepak Reddy.

He alleged that not even a single nomination was filed in Pulivendula constituency, the home town of chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy.

He also alleged that the YSR Congress leaders in Macherla, Dhone, Punganur and other areas have threatened rival candidates and forced them to stay out of the race or withdraw their nomination papers.

Title: Coronavirus scare: SEC to ask Rajasthan government to move HC to postpone municipal body polls
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: After collectors of Jaipur and Kota urged department of local self government (LSG) to reschedule and postpone the elections to the six newly-formed municipal corporations in the wake of coronavirus, the department on Sunday wrote to the state election commission (SEC) requesting it to consider the same. Hence, the commission, instead of taking a decision on deferring the elections, will urge the state government to move the High Court and get the elections postponed, according to sources.

Rajasthan High Court had directed the state government to complete the elections to the municipal corporations in the state by April 18.

Jaipur collector Joga Ram and Kota collector Om Prakash Kasara on Saturday wrote to secretary local self government department (LSG) Bhawani Singh Detha urging him to postpone elections scheduled for April 5. The elected ward members will elect the mayors on April 16. ACS (health) Rohit Singh had also written to state election commission to postpone the polls.

Meanwhile, minister of state for women and child development (independent charge) Mamta Bhupesh issued directions to keep all Anganwadi centres and mini Anganwadi centres closed till March 31, as a precautionary measure against the spread of coronavirus. The Rajasthan government decided on Friday to close schools, colleges, coaching centres, gymnasium, movie theatres and theatre halls till March 30.

Title: AMC lets utility companies’ rents sink
Content: Ahmedabad: Just how much do utility companies — gas, telephone, optical fibre cable, and electricity — owe the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) as rent after digging our roads to lay their service lines?Interestingly, the AMC is yet to evaluate this amount. The AMC is being directed by the state government since 2010 to compulsorily collect an annual rent.Standing committee chairman Amul Bhatt had admitted in a press briefing on Thursday that the tax and estate departments are yet to provide an estimated sum. Today, about 13,000km of utility lines of various companies criss-cross Ahmedabad’s roads, which are often dug for repairing utility lines.The state urban development department had asked the AMC to not only claim the restoration charge from these companies — which is the cost of repairing the dug-up portions of roads — but also claim an annual rent. Today, this rent runs into crores. “Close to 90% of the companies do not pay this annual rent, leading to a huge loss to the municipal corporation,” said a senior AMC official. “Except for one type of utility company, all are supposed to pay a rent to the civic body.”TOI has a copy of the state government’s direction dated 25 April 2008. Under this, the AMC had to increase rent and restoration charge at a rate of 10% each year. The restoration charge and the rent depended on the types of roads: asphalt, WBM, earth road, footpaths, CC road, internal roads, and road junctions. Take for instance the case of asphalt road. The AMC in 2010 was to charge Rs 781 for restoration for every metre while the rent was Rs 22 per metre for regular roads and Rs 55 per metre for crossings.“Neither the estate department nor the tax department has been able to extract rent out of the companies,” the official said. “Each time the issue is raised in our board meetings, there is political pressure not to levy the charges. This is a huge loss for the municipal corporation.”

Title: Coronavirus scare in Goa: Invoking epidemic act allows state to lean on private healthcare system
Content: PANAJI: The health department is sparing no efforts to deal with Covid-19, although the state is yet to detect its first case. However, the invocation of the Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897, has put the health department in a better position to tackle the situation.Goa Medical College and Hospital (GMC) dean Dr S M Bandekar said that there are 3,500 beds in the private hospitals in the state and if need arises those can used. “All patients don’t have to be in GMC. If the need arises, private beds can be used. The invocation of the Epidemic Diseases Act allows us to do this,” he said.GMC has 30-beds in ward no. 113, which is an isolation facility. The hospital has six ventilators and is likely to receive 12 more this week. Bandekar said that “not all cases of Covid-19 need to be put on ventilator”.With Covid-19, the risk of patients developing acute respiratory problem remains high. Goa has over 90,000 senior citizens, this segment is vulnerable to contracting the disease as is observed in other countries that have reported a spurt in Covid-19 cases.State government-run facilities itself may have few ventilators, but the Epidemic Diseases Act allows the state to utilise the facilities available with the private healthcare to combat the disease, state epidemiologist Dr Utkarsh Betodkar said. With this, there is lesser possibility that the healthcare of senior citizens may be compromised if there are Covid-19 cases, he said.The Goa Epidemic Diseases, Covid 19 Regulations, 2020, mandates that all hospitals — government and private —have flu corners. The areas for screening of suspected cases of Covid-19 should be away from common out-patient departments (OPD).Even before the act was invoked, the state had made efforts to rope in private healthcare facilities. A targeted workshop on Covid-19 was recently conducted for Indian Medical Association (IMA) members of Goa branch. The association has over 1,400 members.Indian Medical Association (IMA) Goa branch president Dr S Samuel Arawattigi said they are committed to help the government.Betodkar said they are putting in all efforts, but the next two months will be crucial. “People should avoid travel for the next two months,” he said.He said that India cannot be complacent even if there is a decline in cases during next few days. We have to be vigilant until the spread of the disease in other countries is not contained.The Goa Epidemic Diseases, Covid 19 Regulations, 2020, mandates that all hospitals — government and private — have flu corners

Title: Rajasthan: Subordinate courts asked to contain Covid-19
Content:
Representative image

JODHPUR: Rajasthan High Court administration issued a circular with several instructions to all the subordinate courts on Sunday in the wake of coronavirus. The instructions read that public gatherings on the premises of all subordinate courts should be avoided as far as possible. These courts should not insist on the presence of the parties unless it is unavoidable.

The subordinate courts have been instructed that requests for personal exemptions of accused/complainants/witnesses, parties be accordingly considered and adverse orders may be avoided in their absence.

The circular also stated that as far as possible, remand of all the prisoners should be given only through video conferencing. Overcrowding in the lock-up should be avoided and that any mediation process should be held only in urgent matters.

Members of the bars have also been requested to advise their clients not to visit the court premises unless it is unavoidable.

Instructions have also been given to officials to disinfect all court rooms and offices, the furniture, gates and other items at least twice a day.

Also, paramedical personnel will be deployed in all the court complexes to screen those coming to the courts.

A full bench meeting through video-conferencing is scheduled for March 17 to discuss the measures that need to be taken to contain Covid-19. Chief justice and all the judges from Jodhpur and Jaipur benches as well as the Advocate General, Additional Solicitor General and members of the bar will attend this meeting.

Title: Coronavirus: Meerut cinema halls to use thermal scanners
Content: MEERUT: The district health department has issued a novel coronavirus advisory stating that cinema halls should check people coming in for fever using thermal scanners and stop their entry in case they are detected with fever. Instructions have also been given to sanitise chairs after every show so that the chances for the spread of infection are minimised.“All the theatres have been asked to make provision of thermal scanners and check the body temperature of those coming to watch movies. In case anybody is detected with fever, that person should not be allowed entry to the cinema hall. This is being done to contain any infection which a local resident might be carrying and might end up infecting some other person,” said Meerut chief medical officer Dr Raj Kumar.So far Meerut has sent nine samples for test, all of which have tested negative. The isolation wards set up in the city at government hospitals have been kept ready for any suspected case that might be reported.“City residents should try and avoid going to any public events and programmes, unless very necessary. Not just this, travels – unless unavoidable – should be postponed. Travelling in public transports should also be avoided,” said Dr Kumar.The health officials further said the people should understand that masks are to be worn only by those who have cough or cold to prevent anybody else catching the infection. Healthy people need not wear masks, doctors said.

Title: Two die after lorry rams motorbike
Content:
Vijayawada: Two persons died on the spot after their motorbike was hit by a speeding lorry near Kuntamukkala village under G Konduru police station limits in Krishna district on Sunday morning.

The victims have been identified as Dasari Radhakrishna (33) and D Arunu (30), both employees with a private firm and natives of Burg village under Reddigudem mandal in the district.

The incident took place when the duo were on a motorbike and heading towards Mylavaram to attend a family programme.

The driver of a tipper lorry lost control over the vehicle when trying to overtake another vehicle, and instead hit the motorbike from behind. The duo received head injuries and died on the spot.

A case was registered and the bodies shifted to a government hospital for conducting a postmortem . The driver of the lorry was arrested for rash and negligent driving.

Title: T chief secy issues GO to implement shutdown orders
Content:
Hyderabad: Chief secretary Somesh Kumar has issued a GO directing district collectors, superintendents of police, police commissioners, district disaster management authorities and other authorities concerned to ensure strict implementation of shutdown orders issued by the state government.

Any attempt to create fear or confusion regarding Covid-19 by propagating fake news shall be dealt with firmly and action will be taken as per Section 54 of the Disaster Management Act, 2005, the chief secretary said. tnn

Title: Coronavirus in Goa: Isolation is not jail, but isolation of virus, says expert
Content: PANAJI: Some states have reported non-cooperation by persons suspected of Covid-19 to the extent that a few of them fled from the isolation facility much to the distress of health authorities, but so far Goa has not seen any such incident.All 16 suspects in isolation at GMC complied with health authorities. Most of them have been discharged after completing the requisite isolation period, GMC doctors said on Sunday.“Their cooperation made the task easier. Isolation ward is not jail, but a facility created to isolate the virus,” state epidemiologist Dr Utkarsh Betodkar said.The suspects as well as those under home quarantine, he said, have been extremely cooperative even when one of the suspect’s identity was disclosed by the media. “The suspect received a lot of calls after his name was disclosed, but he cooperated,” he said, adding that “public cooperation” is essential in eliminating chances of Covid-19 spreading.The suspects, Betodkar said, are not immediately discharged from the hospital even if they test negative for Covid-19. Doctors treating the patient decide if the person should continue to be in isolation or can be quarantined at home.“If a patient continues to be symptomatic, he or she will not be discharged immediately,” he said.No Covid-19 case has been detected in Goa yet, but the probability can’t be ruled out, specially when other states have reported cases.The state epidemiologist said that even if a Covid-19 positive case is detected in Goa it wouldn’t be a problem to control the virus from spreading, provided people help.

Title: Indians from Iran reach Jaisalmer military station
Content:
Jaisalmer: In all, 236 Indians were airlifted from coronavirus-hit Iran and brought to Jaisalmer by two Air India flights on Sunday amid elaborate preparations made by the civil airport authorities, the army and the district administration.

Doctors from Jodhpur Medical College were deployed at the civil airport here when the passengers were taken to the wellness centre of army’s military station in four buses.

Two flights carried 118 passengers each, out of which 139 were students and 97 pilgrims. Airports Authority of India director B S Meena, district collector Namit Mehta, SP Kiran Kung and other officers were present along with the doctors at the airport.

One more flight carrying Indians airlifted from Iran is expected to arrive at Jaisalmer on Monday.

Meanwhile, two of the 236 Indians were found to be suffering from cough and cold. They have been admitted to the Airforce Hospital and their samples will be sent to check for the virus. Both are under medical observation.

Meena said the Indians arrived in Delhi from Iran in two flights at 3am, and after immigration and customs clearance, they reached Jaisalmer at 7.30am and at 8am. Meena added that the SOP was made in such a way that they did not need to come to the main terminal and were screened at the apron and were made to sit directly in the bus and were sent to military station.

District collector Namit Mehta said that these Indians were tested coronavirus-negative and there is no need to be scared and that they are kept at the military station as a routine medical process. The district administration and the army have been coordinating in this regard.

SP Kiran Kung said that security arrangements were made so that no nuisance takes place and the buses were sent to the military station under security cover. World-class arrangements have been made at the centre in military station.

Army official said, “As a precautionary measure, these evacuated persons are to be kept under quarantine for a period of fourteen days. The Indian Army has set up a wellness centre at various locations to provide a credible response to Covid-19.”

Defence spokesman said, “The wellness centre at Jaisalmer is fully equipped to help the Indian citizens undertake the mandatory quarantine period under the supervision of skilled medical authorities. Soldiers have volunteered to provide care and support to our countrymen returning from overseas.” The source added, “The wellness centre is working in total synergy with the civil administration, airport authorities and Airforce, to ensure proper care is provided to all evacuated citizens. Prophylactic measures are being taken to prevent the spread of the contagion. There is no need to panic as requisite medical infrastructure is in place to handle any eventuality.”

Title: TTD prepares to perform two ‘yagams’
Content: Tirupati: The Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams has decided to conduct two ‘yagams’ for universal well-being this month in view of the spread of coronavirus The temple body will first launch a 10-day long Sri Srinivasa Veda ‘mantra arogya japa yajnam’ programme at the Asthana mandapam at Tirumala on Monday. Nearly 30 Vedic scholars from all southern states will take part in the ‘yagam’, which will conclude on March 25.Along with the ‘yagam’, TTD institute—SV higher vedic studies—will organise a Chaturveda Parayanam during the 10-day period.On March 26, TTD will organise Sri Srinivasa Shantyotsava Sahita Dhanvantari ‘maha yagam’ at the Dharmagiri veda patashala at Tirumala.Meanwhile, TTD chairman YV Subba Reddy said the temple body will take a decision towards establishing a Lord Venkateswara temple at Ulundurpettai in Tamil Nadu, after consulting chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy.

Title: Edappadi K Palaniswami to lay foundation stone for new TTD temple in Chennai on April 9
Content:
Edappadi K Palaniswami

TIRUPATI: Tamil Nadu chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami will lay the foundation stone for a temple of the Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams ( TTD ) at Chennai on April 9.

TTD chairman YV Subba Reddy, executive officer (EO) Anil Kumar Singhal and special invitee to TTD trust board J Sekhar Reddy met Palaniswami in Chennai on Sunday and requested the chief minister to lay the foundation stone for the new temple.

This will be the second TTD temple in Chennai to be dedicated to Goddess Padmavathi, the consort of Lord Venkateswara. TTD had established a temple and information centre at T Nagar in Chennai several years ago.

Speaking to reporters after meeting the chief minister, YV Subba Reddy said the TTD trust board had resolved to construct Sri Padmavathi Ammavari temple in Chennai based on requests from devotees in the city.

“During our meeting with chief minister Edappadi Palaniswami, we requested him to speed up the process of handing over the 11 acres of land which the TTD has identified as suitable for the construction of the TTD temple located on the OMR-ECR road in Chennai. The chief minister responded favourably and has consented to extend all support needed to speed up the process. CM has also consented to take part in the ground breaking ceremony of the new temple scheduled on April 9,” added the TTD chairman.

The TTD chairman also requested the chief minister to grant tax exemptions for construction activities by the TTD in Tamil Nadu.

“TTD is a religious and charitable institution performing dharmic activities as per the Andhra Pradesh Endowments Act. Hence we requested the TN CM to grant tax exemptions to TTD, to which he agreed,” said Subba Reddy.

Title: Rajasthan turns into learning ground for treatment of coronavirus
Content: JAIPUR: Doctors of Sawai Man Singh (SMS) Hospital are receiving phone calls from other states and countries including the US after it cured three coronavirus patients using combination drugs. The World Health Organisation (WHO) has already declared Covid-19 as a pandemic.Since there is no such standard protocol available for treatment of Covid-19, the treatment provided to these patients was on ‘trial’ basis who eventually recovered from the disease.“Many states, Centre and many from the US called us and wanted to know more about the treatment we provided to the patients for their complete recovery. Most of them are doctors who contacted us,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary (ACS), health department.He said the job was quite challenging for the doctors as two patients were senior citizens and otherwise vulnerable due to their medical conditions, aged 69 and 85, respectively. “With timely detection and due care under appropriate supervision and drug regime, any medical challenge can be met, it has now been proved,” said Singh.The SMS Medical College administration officials too are receiving such calls demanding protocol of treatment of Covid-19.Since, there was no clearly beneficial targeted treatment for Covid-19 available before the first case was reported in the state on March 3, the SMS doctors held a meeting on the same day to decide the protocol of the treatment. The meeting was headed by SMS Medical College principal and controller, Dr Sudhir Bhandari and the treating doctor Prakash Keswani and other doctors of SMS Medical College.They decided to provide the patient three anti-viral drugs, two of them are useful in treatment of HIV and one is helpful in treatment of swine flu. Besides, one medicine they decided was chloroquine, which is useful in treatment of malaria.“We immediately sought the permission from the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), New Delhi, which gave its nod for the treatment that we had decided upon,” said Dr Bhandari.They took the consent of the patients before they provided medicines to them. “We want those drugs which are safe to treat Covid-19 patients. Since Covid-19 is a viral disease, we selected safest anti-viral drugs for their treatment. Now, all the three patients are free from virus of Covid-19. They need treatment for the lung damage caused by the virus,” said Dr Keswani.

Title: Chennai metro rail phase 2 may offer ‘Monroe’ moments
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: You could find yourself having a Marilyn Monroe moment in the underground metro stations that are to be built in phase-2 as ventilation shafts in the premises could blow up your skirts or dhotis.

CMRL will be building ventilation shafts closer to the ground level, instead of tall concrete structures like those in phase-1 stations. For commuters and pedestrians, these road level shafts could be good selfie spots. For CMRL, building smaller shafts is one of the design changes to be introduced in phase-2 stations to save space and reduce construction cost and time. It means much of the structures that are jutting out of the phase-1 underground stations will disappear in phase-2.

A metro rail official said the shafts may either be louver grates made of iron grills or as a slightly raised platform covered with a glass panel with provisions given on the sides for air circulation. Since it will be on the street level, walkers or vehicles could pass over it.

“We have already attempted one at Central Metro on top of which we have laid a glass panel. Though people can walk on top of it, we do not allow that right now as passengers walking under the glass pane could see those walking above and we do not want to cause any inconvenience,” a metro rail official said. “But the tall shafts will not be there in phase-2 stations,” the official added.

In phase-1 underground stations, CMRL has built tall concrete structures with louver type grill on all four sides for ventilation. These structures are 14m tall and stations have exhaust fans for air circulation.

Metro rail and subway networks in Seoul, Los Angeles and London have ventilation shafts on the footpath that blow out air every time a train passes by.

In addition to the changes planned for design of the shaft, there will be fewer shafts for each station. Compared to eight ventilation shafts for each station in phase-1, there will be only three shafts linking the tunnels and the two levels of the station in phase-2.

In phase-1, shafts are built on either side of an underground station closer to large exhaust fans to allow air circulation in the tunnels, platform and concourse levels of the stations and the mechanical equipment room of the stations. An emergency shaft also has been built with doors in the tunnels between Central Metro and Government Estate station as the stations are nearly 2km away instead of the less than 1km distance at which other stations are built. “But these shafts take up about 20sqm. Now it will take up very little space,” an official said.

Title: Travellers Being Categorised On Risk Levels
Content:
Hyderabad: With one more person testing positive for coronavirus (Covid-19) in the city, the state government has urged the Centre to permit mandatory quarantine for anyone returning from affected countries.

Health authorities said that anyone returning from China, South Korea, France, Germany, Spain, Italy and Iran, irrespective of their symptoms can end up spending 14 days in isolation.

Passengers have been categorised into A, B and C categories depending on their risk levels.

Asymptomatic passengers coming from any coronavirus-affected country, but having co-morbid conditions like diabetes and hypertension fall in category ‘B’ (moderate risk), while asymptomatic passengers without any health condition fall in category ‘C’ (low risk).

So far, category ‘A’ (high risk) passengers with symptoms and those under category ‘B’ have been place under hospital isolation, while category ‘C’ passengers have been advised self-isolation at home.

“Many passengers do not follow our guidelines and this increases the risk of spreading the virus. Instead, we want to quarantine all of them at hospitals,” said a senior official from the state health department.

Health department officials, on Sunday, discussed how to handle unruly passengers who refuse to cooperate with health authorities with top police officials. “The modalities and the role of the police was discussed. It is important to prevent the spread of Covid-19 before it goes out of hand,” said an official on conditions of anonymity.

Title: Blindfolded, senior sculptor in Chennai gives shape to what Derrida spoke of
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: In the book “Memoirs of the blind”, French philosopher Jacques Derrida explores issues of vision, blindness, and their relation to drawing. He chose the works that depict blindness from Old and New Testament scenes to the myth of Perseus, to interpret how drawing was rooted in one’s memory. Blindfolded , senior sculptor G Chandrasekaran (Chandru) and artist Narendran did a similar attempt in the city recently. As Chandru, who has been an artist for more than four decades, worked on the sculpture of a woman he had seen in the ancient Buddhist site of Amaravati, Narendran documented the experiment in his camera.

The blindfolded experiment was part of a video installation project conceived by Narendran. It took more than six hours for Chandru to come up with a sculpture of the woman, covering his eyes with a thick cotton cloth. “We think ‘visual’ means only those that can be seen through our eyes. Our five senses have got a sense of visualisation. Even a touch can give us a visual feeling. A blind person who feels the warmth of a touch can visualise that touch. This is what I was trying to explore while creating the sculpture blindfolded,” said Chandru, who has made many sculptures, including the one of revolutionary communist leader Vladimir Lenin in Tirunelveli.

“When we hear ‘cow’, we get the image of a cow in our mind. Similarly, on feeling warmth, one can visualise something that can be corelated with that feeling,” he said. “When I worked blindfolded, I touched upon the subject and I visualised something I could correlate to my touch. By the time I opened my eyes, I had fully transferred that feeling into sculpting.”

“We shot this work for a whole day. Sir (Chandru) worked for almost six hours with three small breaks. We will exhibit it in the art exhibitions soon,” said Narendran, a city-based artist. “We know what is around our house even in darkness. Whatever place is very much familiar to one, can be visualised even when blindfolded. This is the thought that sparked the idea. I am also influenced by Derrida, who interpreted the connection between blindness and art,” he said.

Title: 26 more Gujarat MLAs arrive in Jaipur
Content:
JAIPUR: With four Congress MLAs tendering their resignations in Gujarat, the party shifted a batch of 26 more MLAs to Jaipur on Sunday fearing horse-trading by the ruling BJP ahead of the Rajya Sabha polls in the state.

A batch of 15 Congress MLAs from Gujarat arrived in Jaipur by a flight on Saturday night. They were being lodged at Shiv Vilas resort on Jaipur-Delhi Road. According to Congress chief whip Mahesh Joshi, “With around 26 MLAs having arrived on Sunday, the total number of MLAs would be 41.”

Of the total, 19 MLAs have come from Ahmedabad, 4 from Surat and 3 from Delhi. Earlier, Gujarat Pradesh Congress Committee president Amit Chavda said, "Around 20 MLAs will be shifting to Jaipur today. MLAs will be reaching Jaipur from different directions including Ahmedabad, Surat and New Delhi. Some of the MLAs will stay back as the assembly session is going on here."

While the BJP has fielded Abhay Bhardwaj, Ramila Bara and Narhari Amin for RS election in the state, Congress party has fielded senior leaders Shaktisinh Gohil and Bharatsinh Solanki. With 103 MLAs in the state assembly, the ruling BJP can win only two seats unless it manages cross-voting from the opposition camp. The strength of the Congress party in the 182-member Gujarat Assembly has reduced to 69 from 73.

Congress, which was caught off guard after a section of MLAs loyal to former Congress leader Jyotiraditya Scindia sending their resignations to the speaker putting the Kamal Nath government on the brink of collapse, acted fast on Gujarat.

Title: Two suspected cases from Dubai, Saudi Arabia
Content: Ahmedabad: On Sunday, the Civil Hospital in Asarwa area of the city received two suspected cases of COVID-19. Senior hospital authorities said that the men, aged 30 to 40 years, had travelled to Dubai and Saudi Arabia . “Samples of the duo have been sent for analysis,” said an official. “In all, 18 samples from hospitals were analyzed till Saturday and we have not got any positive case.” The state health department officials said that till Sunday afternoon, state-based labs had got 78 samples of which 77 are negative and the result for one is pending. “Over 2,300 persons have been put under house quarantine of whom about 1,300 have completed their 28-day isolation period,” said a health department official. “Periodic follow-up is being taken by our teams. We have already issued general directives such as covering the nose and the mouth while sneezing and coughing, avoiding handshake, washing hands periodically and thoroughly, avoiding crowded places, and avoiding spitting in the open.” The official said that improving immunity is also a way to reduce infection.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Hyderabad blood banks report shortage
Content: HYDERABAD: With most establishments closed amid Covid-19 outbreak, shortage of blood was reported on Sunday. The situation is likely to get worse and even become a major problem for Thalassemia patients.Sources said that donation has gone down in the last few days as people are now avoiding hospitals and health camps. “Since we get blood donations by conducting camps at IT companies and colleges, both of which are closed now, our catchment area has gone down to zero. This is a problem especially for children with Thalassemia who might even succumb,” said DR KP Reddy, medical officer, Red Cross Blood Bank, which runs a transfusion centre for thalassemia patients. As many as 25 patients are given transfusion each day at the centre.Most other blood banks too were scrambling to get blood units and alerts sent on various platforms had hit a high on Sunday. “I have been asked to get blood for a surgery scheduled after two days but since I have not been able to get any donors, the surgery is likely to be rescheduled now,” said Satish Rao, a patient’s relative who is to undergo an orthopaedic surgery at a private hospital in Hitech city.

Title: Overflowing bins, nauseating stench at govt hospitals
Content:
Photo of overflowing bins at Gandhi hospital shared on Twitter

Hyderabad: From damp walls to garbage bins overflowing with putrid matter left in the corridors, state-run hospitals in the city seems to have turned into a nightmare for both patients and doctors.

While hygiene is maintained in isolation wards set up to quarantine suspected Covid-19 cases, patients point out that other wards in government hospitals are in a bad shape.

The Gandhi Medical College, where the first Covid-19 isolation ward was set up, is perhaps the worst in terms of hygiene and sanitation. Patient and doctors complain of overflowing bins, flooded washrooms, tobacco-stained walls and a nauseating stench everywhere.

“Unless an official is scheduled to visit or there is constant media presence, the sanitation staff do not clean the premises or dispose medical waste regularly. The garbage bins are left open in the corridors,” said Dr Lohit Reddy, president of Junior Doctors Association (JUDA), Gandhi hospital.

Osmania General Hospital paints a similar picture. “You cannot walk through the hospital corridor without feeling nauseous. The toilets are also in a bad shape. There is no proper water supply and the taps have been stolen,” said Dr Srinivas, a junior doctor at the hospital.

The chief justice of Telangana HC, while hearing a plea on the hygiene and structural stability of OGH recently, had asked the director of the health department if he would admit his kin in the hospital

Shenaz Sultana, a 31-year-old patient at Gandhi Medical College, said, “I went to Gandhi a couple of days ago for an x-ray. I could not even lean on a wall in the out-patient ward because of all the tobacco stains. Every time I go there, I am scared of getting an infection.”

While the superintendent of Gandhi Medical College was unavailable for comment, OGH superintendent Dr B Nagender said, “I went for rounds this afternoon and got the corridors and other areas cleaned. Timely cleaning is being done but since it is an old building there are a few issues. It is sometimes not possible to meet all expectations.”

Title: Bengaluru: Family picks up megaphone to stop muck menace
Content:
Mahadevamma does her job

BENGALURU: With people from the neighbourhood dumping garbage next to their house, a gynaecologist’s family from south Bengaluru hit upon a novel idea to fight the menace.

They cleaned up the place and kept a few idols of gods at the spot. But realised that the fear of gods may not deter the littering neighbours, they installed a public address system and announced that those dirtying the place would be fined Rs 5,000.

On Friday, gynaecologist Dr Kavitha Rani ’s family residing near 5th Main of Kempegowda Nagar, off Bull Temple Road, got a truckload of muck dumped next to their compound wall cleared. The same day they also kept some idols at the spot.

Fine threat

Soon after, Mahadevamma, who works as a cook with the family, was given a megaphone to make a public announcement that dumping garbage at the spot would attract Rs 5,000 penalty.

“I sit there for two hours in the morning and in the evening to make an announcement. That’s the time people walk in with dustbins and bags to throw garbage,” said Mahadevamma.

“We hope the menace stops with this,” said Dr Kavitha. She said the local BBMP health inspector helped them clear the black spot and was supportive of the initiative. The area has been wearing a clean look since Friday.



In Video: Watch: Bengaluru family’s novel way to fend-off garbage menace

Title: Permanent structure on Kumbh mela land ‘will not be removed’
Content:
Haridwar: A consensus was reached between Kumbh mela administration and seers at Niranjani Akhara meeting in Haridwar on Sunday that permanent structure at mela land’s Bairagi camp area “will not be removed”.

Urban development minister Madan Kaushik and mela officer Deepak Rawat met Akhil Bharatiya Akhara Parishad (ABAP) chairman Swami Narendra Giri to discuss Kumbh preparations. After the meeting, Giri said, “It has been decided that no permanent structure, including temples and ashrams on the mela land in Bairagi camp, will be demolished.”

He explained that encroachments here are only those structures which come in the way of “peshawai” or royal procession of akharas during Kumbh. “It also hinders movement of people on the roads. Only these should be removed,” he said.

On the pace of Kumbh work progress, he said, “The speed at which various projects are being executed is an indication that all preparations will be completed.”

Giri also said that permanent construction in akharas, which they have been demanding, will take time. As such, the administration should begin it as early as possible.

Meanwhile, Kaushik told TOI that he will talk to the chief minister about the matter and a decision will be taken soon. Steps will be taken to remove encroachments on all main roads, he said, adding that other encroachments will not be such a problem for the Kumbh as about 90 per cent of the mela will be held outside the city.

On encroachments at Bairagi camp, he said, “No action is being contemplated against concrete structures.”

Title: Bengaluru: Man held for forging Sudha Murty's signature
Content:
Representative Image

BENGALURU: A 23-year-old mobile app developer was arrested on Saturday for allegedly forging the signature of Infosys Foundation chairperson Sudha Murty to rope in Telugu actor Vijay Devarakonda as an app’s ambassador.
