The arrest of Laveti Sai Krishna alias Krishna ML, a resident of Nidamanuru, Krishna district, Andhra Pradesh, comes a year after the case was registered. Jayanagar police registered a case against Krishna on February 26, 2019 based on a complaint filed by Lt Col (retd) M Ramesh, representative of Infosys Foundation. The complaint was filed after the forged letter didn’t reach Devarakonda and came back to Infosys Foundation instead.

App developer is a B.Pharma holder

“We conducted an investigation and traced the app designer. We caught him and based on information provided by him, we learnt that Krishna was the brain behind the forged signature,” a senior police officer said.

Krishna confessed that he developed a mobile app — ‘Offer nearby’ — and planned to launch it in a big way. He wanted Telugu actor Vijay Devarakonda to be the app’s brand ambassador and tried contacting him. Krishna, however, was unable to meet Vijay.

Krishna then thought he could easily reach the actor if he sent a recommendation letter in the name of Sudha Murty.

“He forged the letterhead of Infosys Foundation and Sudha Murty’s signature. We are verifying his antecedents to know if he committed any other offence earlier,” said Rohini Sepat-Katoch, DCP (south). Rohini said Krishna is a B.Pharma holder and worked with an advertisement firm. Later, he planned to develop an app that provides details of offers for retail customers. He floated Laveti Technologies, and with help from a friend, developed ‘Offer nearby’.

As per the complaint, Krishna created a fake letterhead in the name of Sudha Murty and wrote to Devarakonda, asking him to become the brand ambassador/ partner for his mobile app. Krishna sent it through SpeedPost mentioning the sender’s address as Infosys Foundation. Krishna’s game was up when the letter, which wasn’t delivered to Devarakonda, came back to Infosys Foundation.

Title: 74% of Bengaluru’s major road network two-lane: Survey
Content:
Representative Image

BENGALURU: With 80 lakh registered vehicles, Bengaluru’s roads are bursting at the seams. However, while the number of vehicles is growing, road capacity remains the same, causing severe traffic congestion.

A survey conducted by RITES, an engineering consultancy firm, covering 2,537km of the city’s major road network, revealed 1,871km (74%) has just two lanes.

It is also found that 320km (13%) are four-lane roads and 161km (6%) are three-lane ones. Only 186km (7%) have six or more lanes. These were the findings of a report prepared to identify Phase 3 corridors of Bengaluru Metro.

The report finds that only 5% of the surveyed road network has service lanes. Of the total kms surveyed, 2,420 doesn’t have service roads. “Almost all primary roads in the city don’t have a service road. This affects their capacity adversely due to intervention from activities on the roadside,” said a senior urban development official.

Though government agencies proposed several road-widening projects, most remain on paper due to the delay in acquiring land from private individuals. Experts say widening roads by acquiring expensive land parcels will be a threat to trees and only encourage more private vehicles.

Traffic expert MN Sreehari said: “Bengaluru isn’t a planned city. It was a sleepy village, which turned into a town and later into a city. Majority of the roads are narrow as buildings came up first. It’s now difficult to demolish buildings to widen roads. There should be a crackdown on illegal parking along both sides of roads.”

“Only 20% of the road network has four lanes or more. However, when effective width available is considered, the length is very less. Ring Road network is weak or discontinuous at many locations. Parking interference has been observed at many locations in almost all major roads, resulting to reduced effective width available for traffic movement...,” an urban development department report said.

It’s also found that about 43% of roads have Right of Way (RoW) up to 10m and 13% has RoW between 20m and 30m. “This indicates the limitations of widening in case of most roads,” said an official. This means majority of the road network doesn’t have footpaths. In fact, several road-widening projects taken up in the city have resulted in the reduction of pavements.

Road expert Advait Jani said adding more lanes or flyovers won’t solve snarls. “We have examples in Delhi and Mumbai. The more sustainable solution is to invest that money to encourage public transport, including cycling and walking.”

Average speed on the city road network is less than 20 kmph and below 11kmph during peak hours in core areas. Bengaluru’s road network (around 14,000km) consists of ring roads, major roads (arterial, sub-arterial) and residential streets. They are managed by agencies like BBMP, BDA, PWD and KRDCL.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Gujarat: Clubs shut pools, gyms, theatres; some cancel events
Content: AHMEDABAD: Following the state government order of shutting down all public swimming pools across the state as a preventive measure for curbing COVID-19 spread, most clubs have shut down their swimming pools, movie theatres and in some cases even gyms.“Based on orders from the state government, home theatre, health club and swimming pool at the club will remain shut from March 16-29. Your cooperation is solicited,” read a message issued by Karnavati Club management.Similarly, Gujarat Sports Club has also intimated members about the development in the wake of advisory. “We have shut down the swimming pool and two in-house theatres for screening of movies in the club. Since there is no guideline to shut down the gym, we will keep it open and make sanitisers available and take all hygiene precautions. At the same time, we will also consult all the state health authorities and take appropriate steps,” said an official.Rajpath Club called off a Club Housie scheduled on Sunday. “We told members in advance that the housie has been cancelled. No other events will take place at the club and the gym, swimming pools and theatres will be shut. Members can visit the club for other activities,” said Mishal Patel, secretary, Rajpath Club.

Title: Churches conduct Sunday prayers amid shutdown, screen attendees
Content:
Hyderabad: A day after the state government announced a ban on public gathering to prevent spread of Covid-19, churches across the city used thermal scanners to check temperatures of all attendees who came for Sunday prayers and also provided them with hand sanitisers. Christians are currently observing Lent.

Paramedical staff with thermal detectors checked all attendees at Calvary Temple in Miyapur and the church refused entry to those who were found to have cold and flu symptoms.

Breaking away from tradition, priests at Roman Catholic churches gave Holy Communion in the hands of those who attended the mass instead of their mouth. Holy water was also kept away from the designated water points at the entrance.

Archbishop of Hyderabad Thumma Bala, in a letter to all priests and religious heads, said, “The threat of coronavirus pandemic is looming large. If anyone has contact with a person who has been diagnosed with coronavirus, please ask them to temporarily not to come mass, missions and stations of the Cross. Encourage people not to shake hands at the sing of peace but to greet each other with Namaste. Encourage people to receive Holy Communion in hand. Before the distribution of Holy Communion priest could purify hands in a bowl of water or sanitisers.”

Meanwhile, special prayers are being conducted in various churches hoping to prevent the spread of Covid-19.

Title: 5 held with over 6,000kg poppy husk
Content:
Jaipur: The Special Operations Group (SOG) arrested five people and seized over 6,000 kg poppy husk in 320 bags in Sikar’s Khandela on Sunday. Cops had received information about the storage of the poppy husk and raided the location. It was to be supplied to Punjab. The accused were identified as Gajanand Sharma, 45, Hansraj Verma, 28, Vinod Sharma, 21, Suresh Sharma, 25, and Kailash Meena, 30.

A case under Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, 1985, was registered against the accused.

TNN

Title: Wear mask on duty: Mehsana SP to cops
Content: AHMEDABAD: Mehsana district with a population of approximately 20.4 lakh and an area of about 4,500km has become the first district where policemen have been instructed to wear masks to protect themselves from coronavirus “There are about 2,200 policemen and officers in Mehsana district and we cannot afford to expose them to the virus. I have instructed them to wear masks. It is not that they have to wear a particular type of mask but whatever is available in the market they have to use it. The SP office will bear the expense of the masks so that the policemen don’t have to worry about the prices also,” said superintendent of police Manish Singh.A 2013 batch IPS officer, Singh, who was recently transferred to Mehsana, said policemen run high risk of getting infected by the virus. “When the World Health Organisation has declared it as pandemic and the state and the central governments have issued advisories, it becomes necessary to come with such instructions,” he said.According to sources, more than 30 persons from Mehsana have been screened for coronavirus and have come out safe. Top state police officials said the decision to instruct policemen wear mask while on public duty and in public places is under consideration and soon an order will be passed for the policemen across the state.

Title: Para forces asked to set up quarantine camps, says Kishan
Content:
Hyderabad: Union minister of state for home affairs, Kishan Reddy, on Sunday announced that all paramilitary forces, including the Indo-Tibetan Border Police (ITBP), Border Security Force (BSF), and Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) have been told to set up quarantine camps for coronavirus suspects as a preparatory measure.

Interacting with the media, he said the Indian government has responded quickly on the spread of the virus, and crucial announcements on precautionary measures may be announced on Monday. The minister said that currently, the ITBP is operating a quarantine camp, which can house about 500 people near Delhi. Two batches of people have been released from these camps so far.

He said the Union government has identified certain places for the camps and they are ready. They can accommodate any number of people as being directed by the health ministry, the nodal agency for coronavirus. The central health ministry is reviewing and directing state governments on the virus and measures to be taken, he said.

The minister expressed confidence that India is handling the situation well, and there is no need for any panic. “Our country shares a large border with China, the epicentre of coronavirus. Since we have been very alert, the presence of virus in the country is very less,” Reddy said.

Explaining the measures taken by the Centre, he said Indians stranded in Italy faced problems as the country was not allowing them to board the flights. “Even after the Indian government sent medical teams with equipment, they were not allowed to take the samples. The central government pursued the issue with embassy officials, and the samples have now been taken, and will be tested at NIV, Pune,” he said.

The Centre is sending medical teams to other countries where Indians are stranded, and tests will be conducted. Arrangements are being made to get them back, he said.

Title: Cops blame errant bus drivers, careless citizens for mishaps in Jaipur
Content:
TimesView The mowing down of two youths by a low-floor bus has again brought to the fore the menace of rash driving. But blaming drivers will not improve the situation. Stakeholders such as the traffic police, civic body, private contractors who provide drivers and citizens each play an equal part to ensure public safety. While drivers need to be trained to follow traffic norms, motorists also need to adhere to the rules. The civic body must ensure that drivers are not overburdened and at the same time traffic police should penalise drivers who violate rules.

JAIPUR: The menace of low-floor buses continues unabated in the city, with untrained drivers turning the buses into killer machines. The traffic police claims it has been penalising the drivers of these buses to rein in the number of accidents in the city, but with regular instances of mishaps involving low-floor and government buses, the effect is yet to be visible.“In majority of the accidents, it is the mistake of the drivers. The bus drivers are locked in stiff competition to get maximum number of passengers on board. Therefore, they are in a rush to reach the bus stops before other buses and pack as many passengers as they can. Rash driving is one of the reasons for the accidents,” said a police official.Traffic department also claimed that they are focused on curbing rash driving and have penalised many such drivers. Rahul Prakash, DCP traffic told TOI, “The drivers of these buses are not trained properly and often drive without paying heed to other vehicles. They break signals and also block traffic. I have instructed the traffic personnel to catch all the bus drivers violating traffic norms as well as to penalise as many as possible. We have been running campaigns to curb such violations. However, at times it is also the fault of the two-wheeler riders who also do not have proper training and do not even wear helmets. Awareness has to be raised among the citizens as well.”Traffic department had also spoken to the department concerned to train these drivers but nothing materialised. According to the data available at the traffic department, last year, 213 roadways bus drivers were fined for violations between May 2019 to October 2019, and in the same period, 45 low-floor buses have also been penalised. Apart from this, action was also taken against 11,106 mini-bus drivers for breaking traffic rules.An official also pointed out another issue and claimed that in majority of the buses, there are no speed governors, which is compulsory in commercial buses, because of which the drivers tend to speeding.

Title: ‘No AC booths, so no fear of virus to vote’
Content: Panaji: BJP state president Sadanand Shet Tanavade said the zilla panchayat voters need not worry about the coronavirus as all polling booths are non-AC.“ZP elections will be held on March 22 as scheduled. Our voting booths are not air conditioned, but well-ventilated and people need not fear getting coronavirus. In fact, they should come in large numbers and exercise their franchise,” Tanavade told reporters on Sunday.Earlier in the day, Andhra Pradesh state election commission postponed the civic body polls by six weeks due to coronavirus scare. The election commissioner Nimmagadda Ramesh Kumar said that the decision was arrived at after conducting a high-level meeting.Leader of the opposition Digambar Kamat had accused the BJP-led Goa government of being unprepared to handle the coronavirus threat.Reacting to Kamat, Tanavade said if the leader of the opposition wanted any precautionary measures to check coronavirus, then he should call on the chief minister and bat for it instead of indulging in political rhetoric.He lauded the government efforts to curb the spread of the virus.He urged the people to abide by the decision taken by the state.On Saturday, Sawant had said that sanitisers would be made available for the voters at polling booths for ZP polls and the staff would be provided with masks.

Title: 3 years of BJP govt in U’khand: How did CM Rawat fare?
Content:
Dehradun: The Trivendra Singh Rawat-led BJP government in Uttarakhand will mark its third anniversary this Wednesday. After having completed three years in office, has chief minister (CM) Rawat delivered on the expectations that voters had of his government that was elected with a massive mandate in 2017?

The jury seems divided on this point. Political analysts say that while efforts have been made by the state government, the results are yet to show comprehensively on the ground as many of the government’s projects are still to be implemented properly. Terming the tenure of Rawat as “a mixed bag”, Doon-based analyst Udit Ghildiyal said, “If we look at the positive side, Trivendra Rawat has been successful in ending corruption within the CM office and other ministries. Now, you will not find middlemen hanging around who will claim to get official work done through their contacts, which is a positive move.”

On the flip side, he added, not much work is visible on the ground to improve health and education facilities in the hills. “People in the hills continue to migrate. Primary schools are closing at a rapid pace and owing to poor health services, people of the hills still prefer to bring their patients to hospitals in Dehradun and Haldwani, adding to the pressure on these cities,” Ghildiyal said.

The chief minister while highlighting the work done by his government, had told TOI that to check migration and encourage reverse migration, the state government has opened 83 growth centres in the last three years. “We are also encouraging homestays. Presently, the state has 2,100 homestays. Also, the ‘13 districts-13 destinations’ project has been launched to boost tourism in the state.”

Coming to the health sector, the CM said that the number of doctors in the state has doubled since he assumed office. “There are 2,045 doctors in the state against a total of 2,735 posts. As many as 253 health sub-centres have been upgraded in rural areas and 1,030 more such facilities would be upgraded by the end of this year,” the CM told TOI adding that under the Atal Ayushman Yojana, which provides for a health cover of Rs 5 lakh, 1.3 lakh people have received free of cost treatment.

While terming the measures taken by the CM as “positive”, analysts say that much more focussed attention needs to be given to the pressing issues facing the state. Doon-based political watcher Jay Singh Rawat said, “A big issue facing the youth in the state today is unemployment. Though the CM recently said that new industrial units have provided employment to over 50,000 youth, the bitter reality remains that people of hills are not getting adequate employment opportunities.”

He added that the government’s priorities need to be right. “The CM had earlier said that his government will reduce dependence on liquor sales for getting revenue but the excise revenue target has been constantly increasing and has now shot up to over Rs 3,600 crore this year. So this comes as a surprise,” said Rawat.

Noted environmentalist Anil Joshi while evaluating the CM’s performance, said, “Uttarakhand was created with the view to develop the hills, but is has not happened in the past or the last three years. I find CM Rawat an honest and sincere person but his performance has been average till now. His announcement on Gairsain as summer capital of the state is a welcome move, but only if some development is carried out in the area. Otherwise, it will be seen as just a political declaration.”

This is the first in a series of articles on how the Uttarakhand government has performed in the past three years

Title: Decoding the pathway to a memorable victory in Kargil
Content: SECUNDERABAD: If there were those at the forefront in the Kargil war driving out the enemy, there was an unseen and unheard of army in the background facilitating every move and manoeuvre. The backroom boys had the task of deciphering secret messages that were being exchanged by the enemy and pass on the decoded messages that helped in making strategies for the war.After having served 37 years in the Indian Army and retired, Lt Col Parvathesam can only say how greatly satisfying his job was – of encoding and decoding messages as a cryptographer and then a cypher officer.Operating from Delhi during the Kargil war, the challenge was to do a quick job and clear a pile of messages. For demonstrating excellence in that, he was also given an award by the vice chief of the Indian Army.As an 11-year-old, Parvathesam, who hails from Polavaram in Andhra Pradesh, had heard of the Chinese aggression and war. He decided he would join the Indian Army. Having joined as a radio operator in the army in 1970, he served at the border area near Punjab and subsequently got selected as cryptographer. The job meant monitoring suspicious calls and decoding secret messages. “This was something I enjoyed doing,” he recollected.Thanks to a friend who guided him, he took the necessary examination, got selected as a cypher officer and was trained at the Indian Military Academy, Dehradun. His job took him to Bhutan where he spent two-and-half years with the Border Roads Organisation (BRO) as a cypher officer as well as an administrator.The then-King of Bhutan, Jigme Singye Wangchuk, even visited the headquarters where he was posted in Bhutan. “The stay in Bhutan was memorable. We used to build roads for the people, provide medical care and had good interaction with the locals,” he recollected.There is more than one reason for Parvathesam for choosing to join the army. Since his childhood he was a sportsperson and he knew being in the army would give him the opportunity to engage in sports and enjoy his spirit of adventure. “Someone also told me that it is only in the army that one does not demand, give or take bribes. For this reason too I was attracted,” he said. His father, a forest guard, was open to his son joining the army though it took some time for his mother to understand his decision.“I have had a fulfilling life in the army. That is the best place to be,” Lt Col Parvathesam, who retired in 2008 said. He may have retired from the army but continues his sports activities as he goes to RSI in Secunderabad from his home at Yapral to play. “Happy to be winning even now,” he says with a sense of pride.

Title: 64k passengers screened for coronavirus at RGIA: Sajjanar
Content:
Hyderabad: Passengers who are above 60 years of age and suffering from respiratory problems and diabetes or returned from any Covid-19 affected countries, have been quarantined for 14 days, said Cyberabad police commissioner VC Sajjanar after reviewing screening arrangements at Rajiv Gandhi International Airport (RGIA) on Sunday.

“As many as 64,000 passengers arriving from China, Iran, South Korea, Italy, Spain, Germany, and France have been screened at RGIA so far,” he said

“Around 200 doctors and medical staff with sufficient ambulances are working 24x7, while around 200 police staff and CISF are providing security at RGIA,” Cyberabad police said in an official statement.

Title: Two farmers commit suicide in Bharatpur
Content:
Representative image

ALWAR: In separate incidents, two farmers committed suicide in Bharatpur allegedly over damage to crops due to rains and hailstorms in the state recently. This is the third case of farmer suicide in the district in less than a week.

Suresh Kumar, 45, a resident of Uptela village in Udhyog Nagar police area, committed suicide on Saturday late night after returning home from his fields by hanging himself. His body was handed over to the family on Sunday. The deceased had less than half acre land on which he had cultivated mustard.

Minister of state for health, Subhash Garg, under whose constituency Uptela falls, said, “This is an unfortunate incident and the state government is constantly taking measures to support the farmers. I have spoken to CM Ashok Gehlot and all possible help will be extended to the deceased’s family as per the set guidelines.” In the second incident, Mukesh Singh (37) of Jiroli village in Bharatpur on Sunday hanged himself.

Title: Coronavirus: Pharma companies eye profits, put marketing staff on the line
Content: HYDERABAD: Even as most corporate offices are encouraging people to work from home, employees of pharma companies and hospitals rue that they do not have such facilities.While hospitals are taking extra precaution with sanitisation and use of personal protective equipment (PPE), most medical representatives are still doing rounds of multiple hospitals and clinics each day and in the process endangering many lives.“Several pharma executives are still working because firms have not given any holiday to them. They are the ones who visit several hospitals everyday and this is dangerous to their health,” tweeted Shaik Naseer Ahmed, a medical business associate from the city.Apart from the possibility of contracting the virus, medical representatives also run a risk of spreading it to healthcare staff as they go around 10-12 hospitals each day. “I have been to atleast 10 hospitals each day in the last one month and this is the case with most medical representatives as firms want to make the most of the current crisis. Since a variety of drugs are available for most health issues and patients have to be given symptomatic treatment only, managements insist that we are aggressive in our approach,” said another executive from a pharma company.

Title: How beats of parai turn sound of empowerment
Content:
Parai artists of Tamilnadu Theological Seminary in Madurai

CHENNAI: It has been 15 years since former professor at Tamilnadu Theological Seminary (TTS), Rev. James Theophilus Appavoo’s demise. But to this date, ‘Parattai Annan’ or ‘brother with wild hair’ — as his loved ones knew him — remains immortalised by the humble drum he embraced and refashioned from a symbol of cultural subjugation to one of individuality, pride and emancipation.

Almost five decades since Appavoo set the precedent of using the parai as an instrument of glory and worship inside the church , its beats have changed worship traditions across Tamil Nadu’s Christian institutions. More importantly, it has endowed long-oppressed communities with the art forms of their birth and celebrated their roots.

"Appavoo, who then was also the minister at the church, used the parai in the middle of the liturgy, and sang every section — the greetings and praise, the Lord’s Prayer, the confession — in the Tamil folk songs he had composed," says Zoe C Sherinian, professor of ethnomusicology at University of Oklahoma. Twenty years ago, as a student of anthropology, Sherinian flew down and stayed back at TTS in Madurai to study this unique practice employing native folk music as a means of cultural and social empowerment of oppressed castes in rural Tamil Nadu. "Missionaries and upper caste Christians rejected folk music. And here it was, becoming the language of ‘liberation theology’ among dalit Christian communities," says Sherinian, who went on to start a parai drumming ensemble at the University of Oklahoma.

Today, this revolutionary model of worship and ethnomusicology is part of the four-year Bachelor of Divinity curriculum at TTS. And among a whole generation of students, many of them now ordained priests and bishops across the state, who have imbibed and popularised it, is Rev. C R Samson Rasa of CSI Diocese of Madras.

"For most of us, parai is a legacy that runs in our veins. My community members played it for funerals and temple festivals in my village in Chittoor. However, in spite of its unparalleled importance in these ceremonies, it was looked upon as a symbol of what the caste system perceived to be our ‘contaminated identity’ (associated with certain oppressed caste members working with animal hide)," says Rev. Samson. And his uprising – as that of Appavoo’s and many others of their league – has been to fundamentally revolutionalise the parai’s identity from a representation of the subaltern classes to a musical language that could result in individual and spiritual freedom. And so, he brought the first waves of this movement to Chennai at a youth retreat in 1998.

"We trained a group of youngsters in the percussion and Tamil folk compositions, and tested the waters at a public service at St Paul’s Higher Secondary School grounds in Chennai. Our performance was initially met with murmurs from orthodox and dominant caste Christians. But by day three, our dynamic youth board director announced that these songs were ‘vazhipaatu kudiya paadalgal’ (songs of worship), and a language of liberation," recalls Rev. Samson. The team went on to play at a CSI Madras pastor’s conference, and later at workshops with youngsters across the city.

Striking a similar chord at Dindugul, two Catholic nuns — also the subject of Sherinian’s work-in-progress film — have been using the parai as a tool of reclamation and empowerment of young scheduled caste women in the village. At her Sakthi Folk Cultural Centre, Sister Chandra uses native folk art forms as a campaign against gender, class and caste discrimination for the girls, who have performed to audiences across Tamil Nadu, as well as the US, Japan and South Korea.

Director of Dalit Resource Centre at TTS, Cruz Durai, says the aim is also to revive celebratory parai traditions that popular narratives have kept out. "The parai is believed to be one of the earliest discovered instruments by hunter-gatherers out of leftover animal hide," he says. "The word ‘parai’ also translates to the act of speaking. It was played to make important announcements in the village, and also in the battle cry to invoke the warrior spirit in soldiers. But in today’s counterculture movement, the parai’s role and essence surely lies in the celebration of all that was once shunned as tainted — from the music of death, to an ode to life, from a symbol of ‘polluted identities’, to one of holiness, union and brotherhood."

Title: Coronavirus memes on Hollywood actor Jason Momoa's take over the internet!
Content:
@dysondoc https://t.co/eBGZpFUZhb — The Drawback (@the_drawback) 1583561198000

The World Health Organisation has declared Coronavirus as Pandemic. The Coronavirus has led to the cancellation of various events, award functions, interviews and shooting schedules. Now, to spread awareness, WHO has started a new campaign titled 'Safe Hands' challenge. In this challenge, they have asked to share a video of how to wash your hands neatly to safeguard yourself from the virus.Among these days of panic and havoc, to lighten themselves, people always need some humour. And that's when Hollywood actor Jason Momoa became the main content of the memes. Netizens used his pictures and added a caption on it, "Wash your hands like you’re washing Jason Momoa".Well, check out the memes here:The outbreak, which was declared a pandemic by the World Health Organisation (WHO) on Wednesday, has infected more than 150,000 people worldwide and killed over 5,600.Here in Maharashtra, the Chief Minister, Uddhav Thackeray announced the heath scare on Friday. A decision of keeping the cinema halls across the state closed until further notice was to tackle the COVID-19 outbreak, in which the state has seen over 15 positive cases.

Title: Golden jubilee of a golden voice with golden heart
Content:
UNNIKRISHNAN NAIR

1970s was the golden era for Indian film music. Live performances used to be relished in those days and orchestra groups of stalwarts from city like Ahmed Kadir and Yogesh Thaker would see full houses.

A young boy in his mid-20s, hailing from Mannarkad town of central Kerala, used to stand in the last row and enjoy these shows. He was trained in basic classical music and was confident enough to perform on stage. But it was hard for part-timers or amateurs to get an opportunity.

With his love and perseverance for music, Unnikrishnan Nair not only created opportunities for himself but also brought 600-plus amateur singers like him on the stage during his five-decade long musical journey. They include well-known doctors, engineers, teachers, bureaucrats, builders, politicians, advocates and many young students from city.

Over the years, his ‘Sargam’ group has groomed those gifted with musical talent but could not follow it academically or professionally due to various reasons.

“My story is no different. Being the eldest among siblings, it was necessary for me to find a job and earn. As soon as I completed my pre-degree course, my father asked me to go to Nagpur and find a job. He was aware that I was learning classical music at that time. And like most fathers, he was not willing me to waste my time in it,” recalls Unnikrishnan who came to his uncle in Nagpur and later got a job as a typist in the Coal Mines Authority Ltd.

“I continued with my singing in Nagpur too. Earlier, I used to sing only in Malayalam. My first attempt to sing a Hindi song was when movie Chitchor was released (1976). My idol, legendary singer KJ Yesudas, made a Hindi debut with this movie,” says Unnikrishnan who cherishes his identity as ‘Nagpur’s Yesudas’.

The man has much more to present than the trademark ‘Yesudas’ style. He sings in all genres — right from bhajans to film songs — in eight languages. He single-handedly organizes several innovative musical events throughout the year.

“Today, so many musical events are organized. Organizers charge money from singers to perform on stage. One who contributes more gets to sing more number of songs. But, at Sargam, we have never charged even a rupee from singers. Only talent works here,” says Unnikrishnan.

Raising funds for such ‘open for all’ events is challenging, and many times he has to pay from his own kitty.

“Music is an universal language of the heart and I am always in search of new talent,” says Unnikrishnan who has recognized many talented singers from city and gave them their first public platform at a tender age.

Aniruddha Joshi, Manjiri Vaidya and Parvathi Nair are only a few names that have taken a bow on Unnikrishnan’s stage.

Since this is 50th year of Unnikrishnan’s musical career, singers he introduced had planned a big event to celebrate this occasion in March. The novel coronavirus outbreak has postponed this for now. But the music scene of Nagpur will continue to celebrate this golden voice with a golden heart forever.

Title: Coronavirus in Telangana: Schools closed in Telangana, but teachers asked to work
Content: HYDERABAD: Even though the state government has directed all educational institutions to closedown from March 31, many schools and colleges have declared holidays only for students.“When the Telangana government has announced closure order for schools, why are educational institutions asking their teachers to come for work...are adults safe from Covid-19. Schools are informing their staff through WhatsApp group messages,” read a tweet where MA&UD minister KT Rama Rao was also tagged.Meanwhile, president of Telangana Private Teachers Forum Shabir Ali said, “Most of the schools have asked teachers to come to work even though there are no classes.”“Some schools are also mulling to terminate a few teachers immediately so that they need not pay salaries for the months of April and May,” he alleged.

Title: Covid-19 scare: Shut till Mar 31, schools introduce online classes for new academic year
Content: HYDERABAD: With the state government directing all educational institutions to remain closed till March 31, many schools have asked parents to buy books for the 2020-21 academic year so that the students can prepare for online classes.Many schools, especially those affiliated to CBSE and ICSE, which were scheduled to start the new academic year in the last week of March, have sent out e-mails to parents saying that online classes will begin shortly.“Anticipating this situation, our teachers have been working for the past two weeks on developing online modules to compensate for the academic hours that the students will miss in the case of closure. Virtual classes in times such as these are the only practical alternative and we shall intimate you about the date of their commencement once your children have the books and resources they need to avail the online lessons,” read an e-mail from Chirec International School.The e-mail further read that issuance of new books for the coming academic session for grades 6, 7, 8, and 9 will begin from Monday. The school, however, asked parents to refrain from coming to school to collect the books if they have any history of travel to countries affected by Covid-19 in the last 14 days.Several other schools are conducting online classes for current students, especially for those in high school, and have framed a special timetable to be followed by students from their homes.“We have initiated online classes for Grade VII students as schools are closed as a precautionary measure to prevent the spread of Covid-19. A specific timetable has been prepared and sent to parents so that the students can join the classes from home. This initiative is done so as to ensure children don’t lose touch with their subjects,” said Narasimha Murthy, executive vice-chairman of Global Indian International School, Uppal campus.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Pune: Door-to-door survey Cantonment limits
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The PCB and the Local Military Authority (LMA) will start a two-day door-to-door survey from Monday in the Cantonment’s bungalow area to identify people who show symptoms of the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) infection.

There are around 240 bungalows (old grant bungalows) in the area. The properties are occupied by senior Army officers and civilian families with a history of frequent domestic and foreign travel.

“We are taking all the possible measures to prevent the virus in our limit. The drive is aimed at identifying people suffering from cough, fever, among other symptoms and screen them at the Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel Cantonment General Hospital. If required, we will also take their samples to test,” Amit Kumar, the chief executive officer of Pune Cantonment Board (PCB), said.

A decision in this regard was taken at a meeting chaired by Sub Area Commander Major General Navneet Kumar of the Dakshin Maharashtra and Goa Sub Area (DMGSA) on Saturday evening.

According to the Cantonment authorities, over 1,000 people are estimated to be residing in these properties. A team of officials from the station cell and health officials from the Cantonment will be involved in the drive. “Our staffers will visit each house and screen those who had recently travelled abroad and to other cities in the country. We will maintain their records and will be in contact with them for the next few days. If any individual faces any health issue, s/he will be immediately tested at our ward. If required, the person will be sent to Naidu hospital,” VD Gaikwad, resident medical officer of PCB, said.

“Our members will also keep records of the surrounding people who reside in the vicinity of unwell or suspected persons. This is for our reference so we can control the situation if we find someone who tests positive for the virus in the future,” he added.

The Cantonment authorities have been focusing on creating awareness among residents through posters and pamphlets for the last few days. “Our officials are working in tandem with the Army as well as district administration to take the necessary measures to tackle the situation. We will soon conduct special awareness drives and medical check-ups in each ward. We will chalk out a comprehensive plan in this regard by taking help of the elected members,” Kumar said.

The Cantonment authorities have urged people to come forward if they have symptoms such as cough, fever, among others. “These patients will be screened at our hospital on priority and will be provided necessary medical care. The people who frequently travel to different places, even within the state and country, should visit the Cantonment hospital,” Kumar said.

The Army authorities too have taken counter measures and told officers, personnel and their family members to avoid gatherings. “They have been sensitized about the virus in the last few days. Activities such as weekly movie, social gatherings at clubs and mess, among others have been cancelled temporarily at all military stations. People have responded positively to our calls,” a senior Army officer from the Southern Command said.

Title: Netizens catch up on the trend of masked selfies in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: People from all walks of life — youngsters, especially students of different institutions, working professionals and even actors — are posting selfies while wearing masks on the social media platforms with trending hashtags such as “maskselfie” or “coronaselfie”.

Social media sites such as Twitter, Facebook , Instagram and even WhatsApp are being increasingly flooded with such photographs taken at homes, work places and housing societies. The trend is swiftly taking the form of a fashion statement.

College student Krishiv Sharma said, “There is a variety of masks available in the market. My friends decided to buy four varieties and we took a selfie with those masks.”

Not only common citizens, but actors have also been posting selfies, which have been trending on the sites.

On Saturday, actor Abhishek Bachchan took to Instagram and shared a selfie wearing a face mask with a caption “stay safe”. His picture received over 1.3 lakh ‘likes’ in about 24 hours.

Netizen Vinaya Nair said, “My college friends and I decided among our group to post each of our selfies and share it with one another. Masked selfies are trending so we decided to join the bandwagon.”

Apart from the three-layered surgical masks, the N95 one and other colourful netted varieties are in high demand. Many chemist shops are facing a shortage in the wake of a spurt in the number of people testing positive for coronavirus.

Software professional Ketan Walimbe took a group selfie with office colleagues on Friday after they received free masks from the HR department. Walimbe said, “I took a selfie with some of my colleagues for memory’s sake to keep in mind the ongoing coronavirus crisis. We shared it on our social media handles and the picture was liked by many.”

IT professional Ketaki Bhajan said, “On Sunday, my husband and I had invited my parents at our place for lunch on my birthday. Since large gatherings are not allowed we decided to celebrate it with my parents. We were surprised to see both of them reach our home with their masks on. Of course they had worn it as a precautionary measure but we decided to click their picture anyway to frame the moment.”

Title: Coronavirus scare in Pune: Cops impose shutdown on Fashion Street market
Content: PUNE: The Cantonment police on Sunday issued a notice under the Maharashtra Police (MP) Act, imposing a shutdown of all shops and establishments in the popular Fashion Street market area till March 31 in view of the Covid-19 situation.The notice, issued by assistant police inspector Harish Shilamkar under Section 68 of the MP Act, also warns of legal action against establishments found in violation. A copy of the notice has been sent to MG Hawkers and Pathari Seva Sanstha (MGHPSS).“The police should have got interim stay from the court to close down the market. How can they send notice arbitrarily? We are going to challenge it in court on Monday. We fail to understand why such a notice has only been given to us. We strongly feel that the police and cantonment want to close the market permanently under this garb,” said advocate AV Akolkar, president of MGHPSS.About 600 shops make up the market, considered one of the most crowded places in Pune Camp.“We are considering all measures to tackle the spread of coronavirus in the cantonment limit. We are soon going to take action against street hawkers as they do not have necessary measures in place. As far as closure of the market is concerned, the district administration has taken the decision and directed us to implement it. Accordingly, we have sent the notice,” said inspector Chandrakant Bhosale of Cantonment police station.The police have also decided to survey Shivaji Market on Tuesday. “If we find the place dirty and crowded, we will prefer to close it for few days until the situation improves,” Bhosale added.

Title: Teachers too demand holiday, associations advise ‘balance’
Content:
Nagpur: As soon as the state education department issued a circular confirming closure of schools and colleges across the state, both teachers and parents heaved a sigh of relief. But with the academic work pending, some state board and CBSE schools have asked their teachers to report for work.

As per the government directives, board exams need to continue as per schedule. Hence, it’s the teachers not involved with board work who feel that the holiday notice should apply to them as well.

One such CBSE school teacher said, “When it has been categorically mentioned that schools and junior colleges must be shut till March 31, I wonder how we can be called for work.”

Another teacher from a state board school said “Our principal has asked the entire staff to be present on Monday. He claims that teachers are not exempt.”

She added that students have been given a holiday, but teachers called till the local education department provides clarity.

TOI spoke to two principals from each of these schools. They said that with the official letter from Mumbai coming on Saturday night, there was not much time to go over the logistics.

One principal, whose school is on the outskirts, said, “There is some academic work which needs to be done and teachers will be briefed on Monday. The best part is that with no regular classes, teachers can work without distraction and get things done faster.”

The state board’s principal said teachers need to be ‘realistic’. “Lesson plans can be made in advance and there are preparations to be made for pending exams and evaluations for recent internal exams. This can be wrapped up quickly now with students not coming,” said the principal.

Even teacher association leaders say a balance has to be maintained. Rajendra Zade of Shikshak Bharti said “Teachers will be called when it’s absolutely necessary because and we will also try to discuss this issue with principals. I am sure on Monday when everyone sits together these things will be clarified because the decision itself came when schools were already closed.”

Ashok Gavhankar, general secretary of Vidarbha Junior College Teachers Association (VJCTA) said that a balance has to be maintained. “See we cannot have a situation where no teacher turns up. It’s fine for a day or two, but two weeks is a very big gap. The basic purpose for closure is to control the crowd, which was mostly students. Hardly a few teachers are there in every school or college,” said Gavhankar.

He added that the balance will have to maintained by adjusting the timings. “If colleges cannot give teachers holiday, then daily work hours can be reduced. I think three hours a day will suffice for all major work,” said Gavhankar.

Title: Hyderabad News - Times of India
Content:
Cashing in on corona mania

Shopkeepers are cashing in on the coronavirus scare. Believe it or not, the owner of a helmet shop at Nallagandla put up a banner outside his shop saying ‘buy one helmet, get a mask free!’ In no time, there was a long queue with many doing brisk business at others’ misery -- Preeti Biswas

Rumour mills result in police complaint

A day after rumours spread about GHMC deputy Mayor Baba Fasiuddin being attacked and beaten up in front of his house, his staff lodged a complaint at Jubilee Hills police station and SR Nagar police station on Sunday, surprising Fasiuddin himself. It turned out that the deputy mayor had mentioned on a lighter note to Arekapudi Gandhi, the Serilingampally MLA, that he hit his head on the bathroom tap and got injured, triggering rumours about an attack on him. With rumour mills doing the rounds about Baba Fasiuddin’s injury on social media, it seems his staff did not take a chance.

Nabinder Bomalla

Taking no chances

Amid coronavirus scare in the city, bike riders working with ride hailing startups, are also taking precautions as they come in contact with several people on a daily basis. One such rider in the city, wearing a mask, offered hand sanitizer to his customer. He was also carrying wet wipes to sanitize his bike seat after the end of the ride.

Aditi Mallik

Fake orders, confusing orders

With the state government taking its own sweet time in releasing GOs regarding closure of educational institutions and public places until March 31, quite a few people, including a few officials, have started sharing orders released by other states. In fact, they have tactically cropped out the name of the state from the order to make it look authentic. But, what they forgot was that it had the neighbouring state official’s name on the order.

Nirupa Vatyam

Title: Pune: Fergusson College victim of fake tweets amid coronavirus scare
Content: PUNE: Fergusson College on Sunday fell victim to fake tweets that spread confusion among its students. A tweet carrying the Prime Minister’s photo and the Twitter handle @narendramodi read: “I request principal of Fergusson College to declare holidays till 31 March. Fergusson College is one of the most prestigious colleges of India and we cannot risk the future of our country."Many students of the college logged on to social media sites to check its authenticity, another fake tweet with the name of the principal of college RS Pardeshi read: “@NarendraModi Bhai nahi ho payega Sorry”When this tweet was circulated students suspected that the tweets were fake and an act of mischief. Another fake tweet of US President Donald Trump was created and it read: “I had a discussion with prime minister @narendramodi about declaration of holidays in Fergusson College, Pune. Both nations agreed to give holidays till March 31.”When contacted , Pardeshi said, “We will sit with our IT team and dig into this matter. We will file a complaint with the cyber crime police on Monday.”

Title: NU exams to go on, KKSU puts them off
Content:
Nagpur: The Nagpur University (NU) and Ramtek-based Kavikulguru Kalidas Sanskrit University (KKSU) have suspended all teaching activities till March 31 after implementation of Epidemic Diseases Act 1897 by the state government to control the outbreak of coronavirus (Covid-19).

While the NU has only suspended classes at all of its PG departments, conducted colleges and affiliated colleges, its summer exams would go on as per schedule. “The state government has not issued any directive on postponing the exams,” a notification released on Sunday by NU stated.

On the other hand, KKSU has put off its summer exams which were scheduled to start from March 20. “A new date will be declared on April 2,” KKSU notification said.

NU has also closed library, suspended work assignments under earn and learn scheme to students, and all sporting activities. It wouldn’t allow outsiders on its campuses at D Laxminarayan Campus (housing Subhedar Hall), and exam section where people come for morning and evening walks.

NU has also issued detailed guidelines for students during the break till March 31.

It has advised students staying at its different girls and boys hostels to return home. Those preferring to stay back must not venture out in the city unless important, the notification reads.

Action would be taken against students who are found loitering on campuses or elsewhere in the city during the suspension of classes.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Tata Motors’ office staff in Pune to work from home
Content: PUNE: Automaker Tata Motors has asked its office-based staff and purchase team in Pune to work from home from Monday.Others were asked to follow the safety protocol on distance and using sanitizers, among other steps.This is the first instance of a large manufacturer resorting to such a measure. The company asked its employees to stay connected.“This is significant change on how we work at Tata Motors and you will receive additional information to adapt to the new way of working,” CEO Guenter Butschek wrote in a memo to employees, shared with the press.The memo also told them to be read all communication on the subject that will be rolled out for two weeks at 8pm every day.Where travel is essential, the company has told employees to use the company car pool and avoid public transport. Even distance in canteen has been increased, it said.“The situation has been fast evolving over the last few days, ... (coronavirus) spread in India appears to be accelerating,” the company said in a press statement.

Title: Pedestrian-safe model street plan for Sector V, New Town
Content:
TimesView It is a good start to making our roads safer. Both New Town and Sector V start with the advantage of being planned urban zones, where these experiments can work.

KOLKATA: One street each in New Town and Sector V will be developed as model pedestrian-safe streets by the New Town Kolkata Development Authority ( NKDA ) and Nabadiganta Industrial Township authority ( NDITA ) respectively following the recommendations of the Society of Indian Automobile Manufacturers ( SIAM ).The two streets, on which SIAM has conducted an extensive survey, are street No. 13 in Sector V that connects Wipro with the Ring Road via College More and street No. 165 in New Town. The survey was part of their CSR activities to carry out a pan-India study in Kolkata and four other cities for the National Road Safety Year 2019-2020 regarding how streets can be safer for pedestrians.Instead of major arterial roads, these two streets were chosen for the survey so that the research team ’s recommendations for pedestrians’ safety can be applied to other roads across Sector V and New Town.Hidco, NKDA and NDITA officials, along with traffic police inspectors of New Town and Sector V, attended a workshop recently on model safe roads where the study was discussed. “Engineers of NKDA and NDITA have been asked to ensure that all the recommendations are followed for a model streets in each of the two townships. The model can be applied to other streets in the future,” said a Hidco official. The research team worked on the two streets for several months to find how small interventions can make roads safer for people. They made over 300 location-specific recommendations. For examples, they found that traffic signs have faded in some spots while branches of trees obstruct traffic signals in some other areas.The team pointed out that in some areas, zebra crossings lead to a blocked end on the road median. In some areas, pedestrians were seen crossing the road divider or median in between traffic movement while motorists have low visibility there due to the garden hedges spreading into the road. There were also some instances of obstructions faced by pedestrians due to trees, shrubs, pillar boxes and encroachment by hawkers. In some places, the height of the footpath on the main road was found to be too high for pedestrians. The research team has recommended an optimum speed limit of 40 kmph for the two streets.

Title: No blankets, curtains in AC train coaches
Content:
Nagpur: The Central railways, in Nagpur division, have taken up numbers of measures against the coronavirus outbreak including withdrawing curtains and blankets from the Air-conditioned coaches of the trains like Duronto Express, Sewagram Express and Nagpur-Pune Express.

They have also decided to raise the temperature of the AC coaches in the view of the epidemic diseases and also provide extra bed-sheets.

On Sunday, an awareness campaign against the coronavirus was undertaken at different places on the Nagpur railway station under the supervision of Chief medical superintendent Dr Sandhya Hedawoo and Asst divisional medical officer Dr K Vinay Babu.

Counselling of cleaning and sanitation staffers were also held as a part of the anti-coronavirus measures. They were briefed about the precautionary measures required to be undertaken.

The measures include disinfection of entry door handles, partition door handles, push cocks, liquid soap container bottles, latches and others were conducted under Senior division mechanical engineer Akhilesh Choubey. The station premises and toilets also have been also disinfected.

The CR authorities, under Divisional regional manager Somesh Kumar, are set to continue with different rigorous measures against coronavirus spread in the division, said Asst commercial manager SG Rao.

Title: No HC relief for society staffer who stole jewellery
Content:
Madurai: Refusing to grant relief to an employee of a cooperative society who was dismissed from service on charges of misappropriation of jewellery pledged by customers, Madras high court observed that the woman had breached the trust shown by the society and hence the order was right.

K Mariyayee, saleswoman at the Thirukampuliyoor primary agricultural cooperative credit society in Karur district, was dismissed from service in 2012. The society said she stole the gold jewellery pledged by customers, replaced them with fake ones and re-pledged the original ones at a private finance company for monetary gain. She moved the high court Madurai bench in 2012 seeking to quash the dismissal order and to reinstate her.

The petitioner’s counsel submitted that her duty as saleswoman was only to sell commodities at the fair price shop and she had nothing to do with the jewellery pledged in the society. The counsel further submitted that the inquiry officer had obtained signature from the petitioner forcibly without providing proper opportunity to her to explain. The authorities countered this saying the petitioner herself had accepted her guilt during the inquiry, redeemed the re-pledged jewellery and handed it over to the inquiry officer.

On perusal of the submissions, Justice V Bhavani Subbaroyan observed that since the petitioner herself had admitted her guilt before the inquiry officer, the disciplinary authority had rightly dismissed the petitioner from service for her misdeeds. The judge further observed that though the only remedy available to the petitioner is to file a statutory appeal before the competent authority, the petitioner had filed the petition which is not sustainable in law.

Title: Cong: Pass on benefits of oil price dip
Content:
Panaji: Condemning the central government’s recent hike in excise duty on petrol and diesel, Congress on Sunday demanded that the benefit of drop in international crude oil prices be passed down to the people.

“We demand that the rates of petrol, diesel and LPG be reduced by at least 35 to 40%,” party spokesperson Trajano D’Mello said on Sunday.

Congress condemned the increase of excise duty on petrol and diesel.

“BJP’s strategy has always been to first get the common man used to pin-pricks and then, in due course of time, pierce them. This is clear from the high inflation rates of all commodities,” D’Mello said.

Congress said that since coming to power in 2014, the Modi government has hiked excise duty over a dozen times.

“The increase by 15% on petrol and over 400% on diesel by the NDA government has been the major cause of hikes in various transportation costs, resulting in high inflation,” D’Mello said.

The government is crushing the lower middle class which constitute 80% of the nation’s population, he said.

Title: GU postpones PG exams, will start on Apr 15
Content: Panaji: In view of the Covid-19 pandemic, Goa University on Sunday decided to postpone exams of its undergraduate programmes in affiliated colleges to April 15. The exams were originally scheduled to begin from April 6.On Sunday, GU officials held a meeting with its faculty deans, vice-deans, heads of departments and principals of affiliated colleges to review the schedule of exams. Instructions will be issued on revised examination schedules accordingly, Goa University registrar YV Reddy stated in a circular.The review was held by GU after at a meeting chaired chief minister Pramod Sawant on Saturday decided to suspend regular classes in schools and colleges from March 16 to 31 in view of the Covid-19 pandemic.The CM had said that the ongoing exams will however continue in case of state board, schools and colleges.But GU has done a relook at its exam schedule.The circular also states that administrative offices will remain functional and teachers will have to report to work.

Title: Bengal boy on GATE Top-5 list
Content:
Kolkata: A fourth year UG student of Jadavpur University ’s electronics and tele-communication engineering department has secured an all India rank of 5 in the Graduate Aptitude Test in Engineering ( GATE ) Examination, 2020.

Arghadip Das, whose examination paper was electronics and communication engineering, got 78.3 out of 100. His total GATE score is 953.

Das, who hails from Diamond Habour and did his schooling from Ramakrishna Mission Sikshamandir, stays at Jadavpur’s Palbazar area for studies.

He had already done an internship and got a pre-placement offer while he was preparing to appear in the GATE examination.

“GATE was my main target. I had been taking coaching for the last two years after my second year, to appear in the GATE examination. I prepared myself by solving previous question papers and also took online test series. My future plan is to do Master’s from IISC, Bangalore,” he said. Das’s department professors were elated over his achievement, saying that he has always been a class topper and a bright and intelligent student all along.

“He comes from a very humble background and is dedicated to his studies,” said a department professor. “We expect the number of candidates securing high rank will soar by Monday once more students get to know their scores. Even last year there were GATE students from the state, who had secured a top rank in some of the engineering streams,” said a JU teacher.

Title: Punishment of ex-forest official, 96, set aside
Content:
Madurai: Setting aside the punishment imposed on a 96-year-old retired forest official for causing revenue loss to the state government, Madras high court has directed the authorities to disburse gratuity to him.

P Krishnan Nair was working as the divisional forest officer of Varushanadu Soil Conservation Scheme in Theni district when a charge memo was issued to him saying he connived with two other officials to create false records to show the plantations were raised during 1994-95 on 180 hectares of forest land. However the plantations were raised only on 111.20 hectares thereby causing monetary loss to the government. The memo was issued after the conservator of forests inspected the nursery and found insufficient number of saplings to raise cultivation on 180 hectares.

Thereafter, the petitioner was promoted as deputy conservator of forests and permitted to retire on attaining superannuation in 1996. After the inquiry, punishment of pension cut of Rs 300 for three months and recovery of Rs 11,396 was imposed on the petitioner in May 2008. Nair moved the high court in 2009 seeking to quash the punishment order and also sought disbursal of his gratuity amount.

The petitioner’s counsel submitted that the incident took place during 1994-95 and Nair had issued a charge memo to the forest ranger who failed to maintain the nursery. He noted that a few days after issuing the memo, the petitioner was transferred to the social forestry division in Madurai. Justice V Bhavani Subbaroyan observed that the petitioner’s case was in a very pitiable situation.

Title: Divine intervention: Religious leaders take lead in creating mass awareness
Content:
Normally buzzing with visitors, Futala lake wore a deserted look on Sunday

Nagpur: Be it temples, mosques, churches or gurudwaras, the faithful are flocking to seek divine blessings, but religious leaders say there is definitely a growing awareness among their members about coronavirus.

Gurvinder Singh Dhillon, president of Baba Deep Singh Nagar Gurudwara, said that pecautionary steps are being taken during langars (community meals). “We are washing the cloth mats in hot water ever since this coronavirus scare started. We have also advised friends and family to use masks on the road. These masks can be made from old turbans,” said Dhillon. He added that this is only about taking precautions and in no way related to diluting religious beliefs.

“When it comes to health and life, the final word is always the almighty’s. We can only take precautions as per directives of the health department,” said Dhillon.

Fr Patrick, a Catholic priest with the Nagpur Archdiocese, said, “Though church services are being held as per schedule, we have postponed an outdoor gathering as per the government directives. As a regular practice, we have advised our members to ensure sanitizing of hands and maintaining cleanliness to ensure that there’s no spread of any kind of infection. People will come to church because of their faith in God.”

He added that there is no visible drop in the attendance at church services due to the virus scare. For Christians, the holy period of lent is under way and will end on Good Friday in April. During this period, there are prayer meetings at homes.

Rachna Singh, a member of the All Saints’ Cathedral, said, “Church services and meetings are being held as per schedule. Church leaders have advised people about precautions to be taken due to the current situation.”

Sarabjit Kalsi, a prominent member of the Sikh community and member of Gurudwara Gyanprakash Prabandhak Committee, said there is an increased awareness among people about Coronavirus.

“People themselves are taking a lot of precautions like wiping hands and greeting each other in a traditional way by saying Sat Sree Akaal, which is similar to namaste,” said Kalsi.

He added that though devotees can come anytime during the day to pray, more crowds are present during prayers. “Ardaas is held in the morning and evening and usually more people come at these times. We keep advising people about health protocols in the backdrop of the virus scare,” said Kalsi.

Even in mosques there is no visible sign of drop in attendance. A Muslim cleric, who did not wish to be identified, said, “Friday prayers are going on as per schedule and even on a daily basis we see that the numbers have not dipped. People who come to pray anyway come after washing themselves, so the basic guidelines of personal hygiene are already followed.”

Title: High court rejects bail plea of accused in sex racket
Content:
Panaji: The high court of Bombay at Goa has dismissed the bail application of Mohd Bapari, 28, who was arrested in November last year for allegedly running a prostitution racket in Pernem .

The court found that one of the three victims made a pointed reference to Bapari for having brought her to Goa to involve her in prostitution activities. “It is also borne out from the statement that money used to be collected from her after she prostituted herself,” the court stated.

Additional public prosecutor Gaurish Nagvenkar submitted to the court that Bapari’s criminal antecedents were not available despite an attempt by the police to get his whereabouts which were traced to an address in Mumbai.

Justice Nutan Sardessai while dismissing his bail application said that the gravity and seriousness of the offence under Section 370 (3) of the IPC cannot at all be undermined. “The applicant is not at all entitled to the benefit of bail even assuming at the highest that he has no criminal antecedents,” Sardessai said.

Title: HC dismisses plea to cancel sand quarrying licence
Content:
Madurai: Madras high court has dismissed a public interest litigation seeking to cancel the quarry licence granted to a person in Sivaganga district saying it appeared to be a motivated one.

A division bench of Justices P N Prakash and B Pugalendhi passed the order on a petition by N Rajesh Kannan seeking to cancel the quarry licence issued to P S K Balasubramanian claiming that he is illegally quarrying sand in violation of the licence conditions. The judges observed that the petitioner has stated in his affidavit that he had earlier filed another petition seeking a direction to the revenue authorities to stop Balasubramanian from quarrying sand.

Balasubramanian’s counsel submitted that in the earlier petition, Kannan had made his client and another person respondents and averred that quarry licences were issued to them. However, in the present petition, only Balasubramanian has been impleaded as respondent.

The judges observed that according to the affidavit by the petitioner, he is a resident of Madurai district whereas the quarry in question is located at Ilayankudi in Sivaganga district, over 100km from the petitioner’s residence. The judges observed that these facts clearly showed that there is no public interest involved in the case and the litigation appeared to be motivated.

Title: Underage marriage ‘arranged’ in Tirunelveli district thwarted
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: It was not an easy job for officials from the District Child Protection Unit (DCPU) and the Special Juvenile Police Unit (SJPU) to stop the marriage that was arranged for an underaged couple at Melapalayam in Tirunelveli city on Saturday. After putting in efforts for nearly six hours it was stopped around 9.30 pm.

Marriage between the girl aged 15 and the boy, 20, was arranged by their parents on Saturday evening. Since the girl is below 18 and the boy below 21, personnel from the SJPU reached the place around 3 pm to conduct an inquiry and stopped the wedding.

It is learnt that the girl attended school till class X and the boy assists his father in a juice shop. The girl lives with her mother who is separated from her father. The bride and the groom are residents of adjacent streets. “Their families initially claimed that a wedding was not taking place,” district child protection officer B S Devananth said.

The officer said the representatives of the Jama-at and their families stated that they have a separate law and that the marriage is legal. “We made it clear that such a marriage is illegal under the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006, and that it does not differentiate minors on religious grounds,” he added.

Both the bride and the groom could not be questioned by the officials as the parents claimed that the duo was not available. After a series of arguments, the girl’s mother and the boy’s father gave it in writing that they will not arrange the marriage till the girl turned 18.

Title: Quepem rape case: Curtorim police book offence for circulating survivor’s photo
Content:
Margao: The Maina Curtorim police on Sunday booked an offence against unidentified persons for circulating on social media the photograph of a 13-year-old minor girl who was raped at Ambaulim, near Quepem, last week.

The accused has been booked under Section 66 of the IT Act and under provisions of the Protection of Children against Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act.

On Thursday, Maina Curtorim police had arrested 23-year-old Melvin Antonio Fernandes, a resident of Moll, Sao Jose de Areal, for abducting and raping the minor.

On Wednesday afternoon while the survivor was walking home from school, the accused, a seaman, offered her a lift on his motorcycle. As he was an acquaintance, the survivor didn’t suspect anything amiss and accepted his offer. However, the accused, instead of dropping her home, took her to a hillock in distant Ambaulim, and raped her.

Title: Govt rolls up its sleeves to boost use of electric vehicles
Content:
Panaji: The state is hoping to set an example for the rest of the nation by emerging as a frontrunner in electric vehicle standards.

To accomplish this, it has some ambitious plans. By 2020, 30% of vehicles registered annually will be electric and by 2025, there will be 10,000 direct and indirect jobs created in the sector.

To this effect, the government has drafted the Goa Electric Vehicle Promotion Policy which proposes world-class infrastructure and ecosystem across passenger and commercial segments.

The objective of the policy is to encourage startups and investment in the field of electric mobility and associated sectors such as mobility as a service (MaaS), autonomous vehicles, data analytics and information technology, to promote service units which would include electric vehicles (EV) and battery repair and maintenance stations and to promote R&D, innovation and skill development within the EV sector.

The government plans to have charging stations every 25km on highways and every 3km within city limits. Battery swapping and fast charges are also included in the ambit of this policy.

All EV charging stations, both private and public, will adhere to protocol approved by the government of India, as updated on October 1, 2019, that is Bharat EV charger AC-001 and Bharat EV charger DC-001, and any other protocols as and when notified.

In keeping with the government’s green initiative, solar-powered stations will be given priority and encouraged in the case of both private and public charging stations. “Adoption of EVs for daily commute is essential for a wide range of goals, including better air quality, reduced noise pollution, enhanced energy security along with lowered carbon dioxide and greenhouse gas emissions. With vehicular pollution being a persistent source of reduced air quality within the state, rapid adoption of zero emission vehicles is of great importance,” the policy states.

If the state approves the policy then it will be applicable for four years, following the notification after which it may be revised or extended.

The policy will be applicable to all classes of EV, including two-wheelers, three-wheelers, passenger cars and commercial light/heavy vehicles that are operated in the state with a Goa-based RTO passing.

Title: Suicide bid hits Kolkata Metro services
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: Metro services were disrupted for over half an hour between Mahanayak Uttam Kumar and Maidan stations around 10.35am on Sunday after a man attempted suicide at Rabindra Sarobar. The man was injured and taken to a hospital. Truncated services were run between Kavi Subhash and Mahanayak Uttam Kumar and Maidan and Dum Dum stations though. Normal services resumed at 11.18am.

Had it been a weekday, thousands of commuters would have suffered due to the disruption.

“The man jumped in front of a Dum Dum-bound train at Rabindra Sarobar station. The motorman applied emergency brakes but the train stopped only after a few coaches passed the point where the man had jumped. It took a while for rescue operations to start as the rake had to be evacuated first and then reversed to avoid any further injury to the man,” said Metro Railway CPRO Indrani Banerjee.

Power to the third rail could only be switched off after the rake was reversed. Metro staff got down on the tracks and brought the man to the platform. He was injured but alive when shifted to hospital with the help of Kolkata Police .

Title: Excavation works at archaeological sites in Tuticorin and Erode to begin in a week
Content:
Madurai: The excavation works at archaeological sites at Adichannallur and Sivakalai in Tuticorin district and Kodumanal in Erode district will start in a week, said minister for Tamil culture and archeology Ma Foi K Pandiarajan on Sunday.

He inspected archaeological sites at Keeladi including Agaram, Manalur and Kondhagai villages along with minister G Baskaran. Talking to reporters, K Pandiarajan said that while the sixth phase of excavation began in Agaram, Kondhagai and Keeladi villages on February 19, it will start soon in Manalur.

“Evidence suggest that Agaram and Manalur were habitation sites while Keeladi was an industrial site and Kondhagai a burial site. Six complete urns have been excavated from the sites since the work started last month. Around 150 to 160 people are involved in excavation works at these sites,” he said.

“Work on the on-site museum in Kondhagai, at an outlay of Rs 12.2 crore, will commence soon as tendering process nears completion. It has been planned to complete the work by January 2021. Chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami will inaugurate the construction work either by making a visit or through video-conferencing,” he said.

The three-storey museum will house 15,000 artefacts including around 8,000 artefacts belonging to the Archeological Survey of India.

“Although excavations have been made at many places in Tamil Nadu, only Keeladi has kindled interest of the masses. More than 55,000 copies of a book printed on Keeladi excavations have been sold so far. A large number of people visited the archaeological site during earlier phases of excavation. The tourism department will arrange amenities for more visitors,” the minister said.

When asked whether Chola era paintings from Thanjavur Big temple had got damaged during recent cleaning works taken up by ASI recently, the minister said that he checked with the department but they denied of any such incident, adding he will look into the issue.

Title: Goa: Gold worth over Rs 1 crore seized at Dabolim airport
Content:
The gold bars worth over Rs 1 crore were seized from the Air India flight’s rear toilet

VASCO: Customs officials of the air intelligence unit (AIU) at Dabolim International airport seized gold bars worth over Rs 1 crore from the rear toilet of an Air India flight on Saturday.

Customs officials who were conducting a routine check of the flight on its arrival from Dubai, found the pouch containing three gold bars, weighing 992g each, amounting to Rs 1.1 crore.

The pouch had been concealed in the cavity behind the commode, in a blind area of the aircraft, the officials said. The gold has been seized under the provisions of the Customs Act 1962.

The search was conducted under the guidance of commissioner of customs, Goa, Mihir Ranjan.

Since April 2019, the AIU of Goa customs has seized gold worth Rs 2.8 crore.

Title: Free e-seva centre opened at Central MLA’s office
Content:
Madurai: An e-seva centre was inaugurated at the office of the Central Constituency to provide hassle free access to government services, on Sunday.

Central MLA PTR Palanivel Thiagarajan inaugurated the centre at his office and issued certificates to applications received online.

“The new facility will allow people access government services for free without the need to travel far or spend money to apply for certificates and government services including residency certificate, income certificate, birth certificate, downloading Aadhaar copy, address change and family head change in family card,” said Palanivel.

This is the first time an e-Seva centre has been inaugurated at an MLA’s office in the state. “It was created to celebrate DMK leader M K Stalin’s birthday, which was on March 1,” he added.

Palanivel Thiagarajan has brought in various novel initiatives to connect with residents and to solve their issues.

He had introduced a complaint box system to hear grievances from residents in his constituency, which has become a hit as many are dropping complaints in it.

He has also been vocal about various issues which affect the people, including condemning state and central government decisions.

Title: Low-floor bus mows down two youths on Tonk Road
Content:
A crowd gathers on the road after the mishap on Sunday

JAIPUR: Two youths on a bike were killed after they were mowed down by a low-floor bus on Tonk Road on Sunday afternoon. The driver fled from the spot and was yet to be arrested till reports last came in. A case has been registered against the driver.

The deceased were identified as Samarth Singh (26) and Raunak Thakkar (24). “The victims were on a bike and it appears that they were trying to overtake the bus from the left side when the vehicle hit them.
