They fell off the bike and their heads were crushed under the wheels. They were taken to a hospital where they were declared brought dead,” said an officer of accident police station (east).

Both the deceased were artists and initial investigation says that they were not wearing helmets and one of them was wearing a turban. Elaborating further, the official added, “As of now, the exact cause of accident is not confirmed and it is difficult to ascertain as to who was at fault. We are trying to obtain the CCTV footage but the cameras are placed a bit far from the accident spot and it is difficult to say if we will get a clear picture of the incident. We are also talking to the witnesses who saw the accident, but till now, have not got any concrete details.”

Samarth’s post-mortem was done and his family donated his eyes, following which the body was handed over to them. Raunak’s autopsy will be done on Monday, as his family was called from Gandhidham in Gujarat.

The driver is yet to be arrested and the official said, “We have been in touch with the bus contractor and asked him to send the driver to the police station. We have his details and he will be arrested soon.”

Title: Madurai airport adjudged cleanest and safest airport
Content:
Madurai airport director S Senthil Valavan received the award from Union minister of civil aviation Hardeep Si... Read More

MADURAI: The Madurai airport has been adjudged the cleanest and safest airport in the country among the airports, which handled 1.5 million to 5 million passengers for the Swachhta Pakhwada Awards 2019.

Madurai airport director S Senthil Valavan received the award from Union minister of civil aviation Hardeep Singh Puri on Saturday on the sidelines of Wings India 2020, an event organized by Ministry of civil aviation, Airports Authority of India (AAI) and Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industries (FICCI) held in Hyderabad.

Valavan said that the award was the recognition for various cleanliness drives carried out by airport officials including tree plantation drives, cleaning drives, bike rally and sensitization programmes carried out both inside and outside the premises last year. The award will motivate them to strive harder in keeping the airport safe and clean, he said.

Chandigarh airport and Thiruvananthapuram airport received second and third prize respectively in this category. Under more than five million passenger category, Kolkata airport received first prize, which was followed by Chennai airport in second spot and Jaipur airport in third spot. Under private airports category, Cochin airport was adjudged as cleanest and safest airport.

Title: Bhopal Municipal Corporation plans to privatise water supply operations
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: The Bhopal Municipal Corporation is planning to transfer the operation and maintenance of Narmada water supply project in the state capital to private players. The decision is being seen as a means to try and streamline piped water supply in the state capital.

Officials said installation and maintenance of 185 MLD facility pumps is key to water distribution in the state capital. About 30% of Bhopal’s water supply is linked to Narmada project.

BMC would sublet manning, operation and maintenance of 185 MLD Narmada water supply project comprising water treatment plant at Khatlapura and its other nodes. Corporation is expected to shell out more than Rs 2 crore for a yearly contract.

Earlier in February, district administration sought a detailed plan from the BMC and other agencies for ensuring uninterrupted water supply during the summer season in Bhopal. Activating all Narmada project linked overhead water tanks and other system is a key challenge for the BMC. It also includes SCADA is a system operating. It will be added to Narmada monitoring too, said a BMC official.

The system uses ultrasonic transmitter with flow measurement capability is installed right at the process measurement point. It is designed specifically for municipal applications such as water, wastewater and sewage.

The system is compatible with a remote water monitoring system for water quality testing including chlorine level in water. Many of the areas in the state capital report water shortage during summer season. To ensure proper availibility of water, BMC has to rely on dozens of private tankers. Besides areas with piped water supply lines also report of frequent damage and leakage to supply lines.

Despite a good monsoon, last year, several areas in the state capital have started feeling the crisis of water. BMC has identified areas with water scarcity and are devisiong plans to ensure regular supply to these areas.

The areas identified include, Koh-e-Fiza including Khanugoan, Aishbagh, Kolar, Idgah Hills, Mata Mandir, Saket Nagar, Pancsheel Nagar and some parts of Karond, Damkheda and Kolar areas.

Title: Corona scares, still people venture out in city markets
Content:
Footfall increased in Sitabuldi market by evening, though it was not as much as regular Sundays

Nagpur: At Sitabuldi Main Road, Mohammed Hussain walked quickly, holding a scarf to his face, trying to keep away from passers-by. Though the coronavirus scare was evident at the street market here — arguably the most crowded place in the city — many others like Hussain were treading about cautiously.

As the city woke up to the first day of the implementation of the British era Epidemic Act, it appeared to be a dull Sunday. The Sitabuldi market, which is clogged with people as the day begins, was clear enough for even cars to navigate. Hopes lit up for the hawkers after sundown as footfalls increased, though they were not as much as the regular Sunday crowds at Sitabuldi.

“My agents sell hosiery items in the street market here. I am here to monitor them but the crowd is not even a quarter of what is expected on a Sunday evening,” said Hussain.

As TOI moved around the town, major malls were seen closed, though there were a few exceptions too. A complex and mall on West High Court Road and one on Wardha Road were open. Back on Sitabuldi Main Road, the word corona could often be heard amid the din of street vendors hard-selling their wares.

The news of patients testing positive in the city has only added to the slump here. Crowds began receding a couple of weeks ago, due to the scare. Today, business is less than half, said traders. Earlier, the outbreak’s impact in China had hit business here as vendors largely sell cheap goods imported from China, said traders.

“Most of the goods sold here come from China. Since a month we have not been able to procure fresh stocks due to China shutting down. Now, people are scared of venturing into crowded places, so footfalls have come down drastically,” said Gopi Ambhore, president of Sitabuldi Welfare Association — the union of street vendors.

“It’s my child’s birthday so I could not avoid shopping, but yes even I am scared of being infected,” said Manoj Nikule, a contract worker in the ordnance factory.

The streets of the otherwise crowded Mominpura too had sparse traffic. Some people were moving around with masks on their faces but business is as usual, said shopkeepers here. The Boipura pocket of Mominpura locality shares its boundary with Mayo Hospital, where patients have been kept in isolation ward. The mood at Boipura was nonchalant. “We are tough people and prayers will shield us from corona,” said residents here

“There is no scare at all. People venture out of the homes after offering prayers. Clerics are going to people’s homes to offer prayers and we are confident that everything else will be taken care of after that. Of course, we are also taking other precautions, like abstaining from non-vegetarian food,” said Mohammed Vakil Ansari at a shop nearby.

The Shaheenbagh-like protest at Farooq Nagar grounds at Teka continued as usual despite the scare, said organizers.

Title: BJP eyes 3 Gujarat Rajya Sabha seats as 4 Congress MLAs quit
Content:
Rajya Sabha (file photo)

AHMEDABAD: In a major setback to Congress in Gujarat that could end its dream of winning two of the four Rajya Sabha seats from the state in the biennial elections, four of its MLAs have resigned, reducing the party’s strength to 69 in the 182-member assembly. Consequently, Congress is assured of winning only one seat while BJP is poised to win the remaining three.

Speaker Rajendra Trivedi said on Sunday that he received the resignations of four Congress MLAs “between 5pm and midnight on Saturday”. None of the four MLAs who quit and whose resignations were accepted — Somabhai Patel, J V Kakadiya, Pradyumansinh Jadeja and Pravin Maru — could be reached for comment.

Before the resignations, Congress was hoping to win two RS seats as first preference votes of 37 MLAs were required to win a seat. With the support of Independent MLA Jignesh Mevani, the tally of the Congress camp before the resignations stood at 74 — just enough to win two seats. But in the changed scenario, one of the two Congress candidates — Bharatsinh Solanki and Shaktisinh Gohil — could face defeat.

Sources do not rule out the possibility of more Congress MLAs resigning before the elections scheduled for March 26.

After the resignations, the assembly’s strength has been reduced to 176, which means a candidate will require 36 first preference votes to win the RS berth.

Despite himself contesting the RS election from Maharashtra, AICC Gujarat in-charge Rajeev Satav rushed to Ahmedabad on Sunday afternoon and held a series of meetings to assess the situation arising out of the resignations.

Gujarat PCC chief Amit Chavda put up a brave face, saying his party was hopeful of winning both the seats. No decision has been taken yet to withdraw the candidature of one of its two nominees, Chavda said. “The speaker has not spelt out names of MLAs who resigned, so we will wait until Monday,” added Chavda.

Leader of the opposition Paresh Dhanani said, “We enjoy the support or NCP, BTP and independents and we are in a position to win two RS seats.”

State BJP president Jitu Vaghani said Congress has already lost the numbers game and some of the MLAs flown to Jaipur will also vote for BJP candidates. “There is a tussle among the two Congress candidates over who should withdraw his nomination,” Vaghani added. Congress had on Saturday moved 15 of its MLAs to Jaipur, fearing attempts by BJP to influence them for votes.

The term of four RS members from Gujarat — Chunibhai Gohel, Lalsinh Vadodiya, Shambhuprasad Tundiya and Madhusudan Mistry — ends on April 9. While Mistry represents Congress, the remaining three are from BJP.

Title: State govt to challenge CAA in SC today
Content:
Jaipur: The Ashok Gehlot-led Congress government will move the Supreme Court on Monday to challenge the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), which was passed by the Centre in December last year.

“The state government will file a suit against CAA in the Supreme Court tomorrow (Monday),” said the state government’s additional advocate general (AAG) Manish Singhvi on Sunday.

Gehlot had earlier announced that his government would not implement the Act and the National Register of Citizens (NRC) in the state.

A resolution against the CAA was also passed in the state assembly on January 25. The resolution, which was passed by a voice vote, also asked the Centre to withdraw the new questionnaire framed for preparation of the National Population Register (NPR) on grounds that it “would cause huge inconvenience” to people.Gehlot has been quite vocal about the issue and had repeatedly attacked the BJP government at the Centre over the controversial legislation. “We have urged the Centre to repeal the law as it discriminates against people on religious grounds, which violates the secular principles of our Constitution. This is the first time in the history of the nation that a law has been enacted which discriminates on religious grounds,” Gehlot had said after the passage of the resolution.

The CAA, passed in Parliament on December 11, 2019, allows Indian citizenship for Hindu, Sikh, Buddhist, Jain, Parsi, and Christian religious minorities who fled from the neighboring Muslim majority countries of Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan before December 2014 due to “religious persecution or fear of religious persecution.” However, the Act excludes Muslims.

Under CAA 2019 amendment, migrants who entered India by December 31, 2014 and had suffered “religious persecution or fear of religious persecution” in their country of origin, were made eligible for citizenship by the new law. These type of migrants will be granted fast track Indian citizenship in six years. The amendment also relaxed the residence requirement for naturalization of these migrants from eleven years to five.

Title: Retracing events leading to Battle of Plassey
Content:
Lt Gen Anil Chauhan of Eastern Command flags off the expedition

KOLKATA: The Panagarh-based Brahmastra Corps embarked on an initiative to retrace the rich history of West Bengal and the events related to the Battle of Plassey , which was fought on June 23, 1757, through a cycling and sailing expedition traversing the hinterland of the state from Plassey to Kolkata via Murshidabad . The expedition was flagged-in by Lt Gen Anil Chauhan, GOC-in-C, Eastern Command on Saturday.

It was in 1756 that the original Fort William in Kolkata was sacked by Nawab Siraj-ud-Daulah. The fort that replaced it is today the headquarters of the Eastern Command.

“The event was conducted from March 9 to 14 in two phases. The first phase involved the team cycling from the War Monument at Plassey to Hazarduari Palace at Murshidabad that was built in the 19th century by architect Col Duncan Macleod of the Bengal Corps of Engineers under the reign of Nawab Nazim Humayun Jah of Bengal (1824–1838). The second phase of the event started at Murshidabad where expedition members sailed the Hooghly/Bhagirathi river in DK Whaler boats of the Naval NCC Batallion. The sailing team covered a distance of 260 km to Kolkata,” said a senior official of the Eastern Command. The team halted at historical places in Katwa, Nabadwip and Chinsurah on their way to Kolkata.

The team also visited several monuments including the obelisks of Mir Madan, Nabe Singh Majari and Bahadur Khan; Nizamat Imambara and Jafarganj Cemetery.

Title: Mhadei not plank for zilla panchayat elections: Tanavade
Content:
Panaji: Congress and MGP are looking to make electoral gains in the zilla panchayat polls by raising the Mhadei issue. However, BJP state president Sadanand Shet Tanavade on Sunday said that the Mhadei issue will not be a major poll plank and expressed confidence of winning both the districts.

Defending the government, Tanavade said that chief minister Pramod Sawant has already met Prime Minister Narendra Modi over the Mhadei issue and that he has assured Sawant of protecting the state’s interest. He also blamed Congress for the Mhadei as well as mining issues.

“The opposition criticised the government for not doing enough on Mhadei. But when the chief minister recently met the PM, there have been no complements from the opposition. They are only looking for excuses to criticise the government. People of the state are aware of this, and will vote wisely,” Tanavade said.

Though the state BJP president acknowledged MGP’s visibility through their election campaign led by former deputy chief minister and Marcaim MLA Ramkrishna Dhavalikar who has been raising the Mhadei issue, Tanavade exuded confidence of a good showing by the BJP for the polls. Tanavade said that he has covered around 22 constituencies and has been getting a good response.

“The opposition is only restricted to press conferences. They are trying to create a perception that they are winning the elections . Congress candidates are waiting for their state party president Girish Chodankar and leader of opposition Digambar Kamat to visit their constituencies and campaign for them,” he said.

Title: Covid-19 rumours bring down demand, price of chicken in Madurai
Content: MADURAI: The demand for fish and mutton has increased in the city following unfounded rumours that Covid-19 spreads through consumption of chicken, apart from bird flu cases reported in Kerala.Although doctors have dispelled the rumours stating that the meat is safe for consumption after cooking it well, awareness on the topic seems to be low.Fish and mutton stalls were found crowded, whereas there were fewer takers for chicken in the city. However, the demand has not come down for indigenous chicken varieties. The price of fish has increased by around 20% due to the increased demand in the last one week.M Ashraful, a chicken vendor from Anna Nagar, said that he used to sell at least 50kg of chicken every Sunday, but it came down to 20-30kg this Sunday. “One kg of chicken, which was sold for not less than Rs 160 until a couple of weeks ago, is now being sold at Rs 100. However, there are only a few takers for it. We hope the government will take measures to inform the right message to the people,” said Ashraful.This is similar to the formalin scare a few weeks back after a check was conducted food safety officials at Karimedu market, following which the demand for fish came down. “The price has picked up in the last one week. The price of all varieties of fishes has gone up by at least 20% this weekend,” said K Vinayagam , a seller from Nelpettai fish market.A source from the prison department said that the demand for mutton sold by the inmates has increased this week as the crowd was bigger than usual this Sunday. Many, who came late, had to return empty handed as it was sold out.V Chandru, a mutton stall owner, said that they have not increased price of mutton despite increased demand and continue to sell it for Rs 750/kg.

Title: From ridicule to empathy: Shabana Azmi charts portrayal of LGBTQ community in cinema
Content: Veteran actor Shabana Azmi is glad that the discourse around the LGBTQ community is a lot more open today, with even mainstream cinema portraying them with compassion. Azmi starred in filmmaker Deepa Mehta 's acclaimed 'Fire' (1996), about a lonely woman in love with her sister-in-law, played by Nandita Das The actor recalls how the trio were asked if they were lesbians at the London Film Festival because they had done 'Fire'."Today, it's fine. I must give credit to the mainstream industry that instead of making them a subject of ridicule, they are watching them with empathy," she says.In an interview with , the actor says she was aware during 'Fire' that some would be "outraged, moved and shocked", but at least a dialogue would start in a society, which was so afraid of the "other" that it hated them and was quick to stigmatise."Starting a dialogue is the maximum you can do with a part or a film. I felt if the audience could empathise with the two sister-in-laws, then they would be able to extend that empathy to the other race, nation, colour, the other choice. You demonise the other because you don't know them."The actor now features in 'Sheer Qorma', an upcoming love story between two queer women, played by Swara Bhasker and Divya Dutta Azmi says doing 'Sheer Qorma', directed by Faraz Arif Ansari, was a logical move forward after 'Fire'."There has definitely been a great change in society as there should be. It is far more visible now, there's far greater acceptability, considering that even in mainstream cinema you get to witness it. Earlier it would just be a subject of ridicule, but it's shown with empathy and compassion."The notion of family is changing today. It's no longer the heterogeneous family of man woman child. Now two women have children, two men are having children, single mothers are having children. So the notion of family is expanding, which is healthy."The 69-year-old actor says her character in the film, that of a mother trying to adjust to the revelation of her daughter's sexuality, represents many people, who have difficulty facing the truth."She's a woman who doesn't say, 'This is just unbearable.' She tries to cope with it but feels really stretched because as long as it was abroad, it was there, but she has brought this home. When she's confronted by her daughter, that makes her realise."I see so many people who have had troubles accepting this of their children but finally they come around because the mother's love wins."While Bollywood films have been often criticised for an inaccurate or caricaturish representation of the LGBTQ community given its huge impact on the mindset of masses, Azmi believed it would be a stretch to say that films alone have played a role in othering the community."Anybody, who strikes out as looking different, who's more visible, the society in any case finds it difficult to adjust to the LGBTQ community. Anyone who wants to look different is looked at (strangely)."To give perspective, the actor recalls an incident where a gay friend of hers arrived to pick her up in the US, dressed in a faux fur long jacket, diamond necklace, with an eyeliner, and she had remarked, "If he could have dressed up soberly.""And he said, 'Excuse me for breathing!' I said no, it wasn't about breathing but attracting attention. He said, 'You think it's about attracting attention but this is the way I want to be.' That really started for me the feeling that we are so conditioned that we are easily outraged by anyone who doesn't fit the norm."Azmi says it's important to understand that minorities and oppressed communities have to take dramatic steps for their identities to be seen and included. This is why, she says, she understands why people from LGBTQ community developed their own fashion sense, art and culture."When there's this kind of social shift and change, you have to do something dramatic which captures people's attention. So the LGBTQ community, dressing in a way which brings visibility to them, is a way of seeking comfort. Why should they have a problem of, first, coming out in the open, then dressing the way they feel like."Another criticism against Hindi cinema over the representation of LGTQ community has been that often such characters are one-dimensional with nothing apart from their sexuality given any importance.Azmi says it's a fair argument that members of the community shouldn't only be represented for their sexuality."You can't define a person from the LGBTQ community only by that. There are so many aspects to them and that's fair to demand, that you don't see me only as this."With 'Sheer Qorma', scheduled to be premiered at BFI, London on March 21, Azmi hopes the conversation moves ahead and her character resonates with people.."I hope when the mother accepts, she represents the people who have troubles with it. She comes with her own sets of conditioning and prejudices, to finally realise-which I hope people do too-that love is not a sin."

Title: Youths geo-tag trees on city outskirts
Content:
Madurai: A youth forum from Thirunagar, on the city outskirts, has taken up an initiative of geo-tagging trees to create a database in order to stop rampant felling of trees.

On Sunday, a team from Thirunagar Pakkam geo-tagged around 75 trees located on a stretch of around 500 metres.

They are planning to cover entire Thirunagar area, consisting of more than 30 streets, in a week’s time by taking up the work daily.

The members said that in the geo-tagging process, the geographical positioning of each tree is recorded along with details like photograph and variety of the tree.

It is done by capturing photograph of the tree using a mobile application, which is increasingly being used in various areas for sighting of animals during annual surveys carried out inside forests.

P R Vishwanath of Thirunagar Pakkam said that they have previously used the App while taking part in forest surveys and during snake rescue activities to keep a record of the spots where they are set free.

Geo-tagging is being used by various departments for various purposes. Recently, waterbodies were also geo-tagged by public works department. This could be probably the first-time that geo-tagging is being done for trees in this part of the state, Vishwanath said.

“The database can be used to trace if a tree has been felled illegally. Often, roadside trees are chopped down whenever there is a construction of a house or a commercial building. The database can also be used for a comparative study a few years later to ascertain whether number of trees has increased or decreased,” he said.

Works will be speeded up as volunteers have now got used to the process, youths said.

They said that a copy of the data will be submitted to district collector and corporation commissioner once the work is done.

Title: Missing man from Damoh districts found near Pakistan border
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: A 25 year old man missing from his village in Damoh for more than 4 years was found near a Rajasthan village bordering Pakistan. Omkar Singh , resident of Damoh district is believed to be mentally unstable and had left his house more than 4 -year back after his wife deserted him.

Police in Damoh would leave soon for Rajasthan to pick up the man.

Few months back, a man from Jabera village of Damoh identified as was found in Pakistan and the process to bring him back to India was already on.

Police said that Omkar was missing from his village Harpalpura for the past more than 4 years. He has two sons . Few years after his marriage, his wife left him. Omkar was searching for his wife and gradually lost his mental balance, police said.

Police in Damoh said that Rajendra Sharma , a shop owner of Kesrisinghpur village of Sri Ganganagar , helped out Omkar to connect to his village.

After Rajendra spotted him in the village, he asked him about his whereabouts. Unable to recall his village name, the shopkeeper asked about some landmark. Omkar then talked about Kundalpur, the famous Jain pilgrimage of Damoh district.

Rajendra said that he searched for Kundalpur on Google and found that the man belongs to Damoh.

Soon the cops in Kesrisinghpur police station were also informed about the Omkar.

Title: Coronavirus in Jaipur: Three patients in Rajasthan cured; combination drugs helped, claim experts
Content: JAIPUR: In a heartening piece of news that could lift the coronavirus gloom, combination drugs used for the treatment of swine flu, malaria and HIV have helped cure three patients in Rajasthan, experts claimed on Sunday.The 69-year-old Italian tourist, who was the first to test positive for Covid-19 in the state and was undergoing treatment at SMS Hospital, was declared free of the virus on Sunday, but would need further treatment for an underlying lung condition. His wife, who was the first to recover, has been shifted to RUHS College of Medical Sciences for observation in keeping with the recommended protocol.The third patient, an 85-year-old man who returned from Dubai on February 28 and tested positive on March 10, also remains under observation after testing negative in post-treatment investigations, the hospital said.The couple came to Jaipur on February 28 after touring major tourist destinations of the state as part of a 23-member Italian group which landed in Delhi on February 20.TOI was the first to report ‘Italian coronavirus patient being treated with HIV, swine flu & malaria medicines’ on March 5. While the World Health Organisation (WHO) declared Covid-19 as pandemic, SMS Hospital doctors achieved a major success by curing all three patients with some of the common anti-viral drugs.Currently, a 24-year-old youth is undergoing treatment for Covid-19. He tested positive on Saturday.“All the three Covid-19 patients were given the same treatment, which is a combination of anti-viral drugs — lopinavir and ritonavir. The doctors provided two tablets of 200/50mg of lopinavir and ritonavir twice a day,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary (health).Apart from lopinavir and ritonavir, the two drugs useful in HIV treatment, doctors gave them oseltamivir, a medicine useful in the treatment of swine flu, and chloroquine, a drug used to treat malaria.Age factor and co-morbidities made the task even more challenging for the doctors. The 69-year-old Italian tourist has an underlying lung disease. The 85-year-old patient, a resident of Jaipur, is suffering from diabetes, hypertension and renal kidney failure. “It was a difficult task for doctors. But, we used anti-viral medicines, which are safe for even pregnant women. It was the hard work of doctors and healthcare staff who worked round-the-clock and helped the patients in their recovery,” said Dr Sudhir Bhandari, principal and controller, SMS Medical College.SMS Hospital’s senior professor (medicine) Dr Prakash Keswani is a happy man as he was the one under whom all the three Covid-19 patients defeated the disease. “We first conducted tests on Saturday. They both tested negative in the first test. For confirmation, we conducted re-test on Sunday and they both tested negative again. It is a proud moment for all of us as we used some common anti-viral medicines which helped in their treatment. We did not use any new medicine. The medicines are available in the market,” Keswani said.“The Italian tourist has lung disease and he still needs oxygen support. He has recovered from Covid-19. But, for lung disease, he still requires treatment. The 85-year-old has the same situation. He still needs treatment for chronic kidney failure, diabetes and hypertension,” said Keswani.

Title: Park to replace S Dum Dum dump zone in three years
Content:
Kolkata: The state urban development department plans to dispose of the garbage on the dumping ground in Pramod Nagar, between Dakshineswar and the Kolkata airport, using biomining to process and develop the area as a park within three years.

Biomining is the process of using microorganisms to extract metals of economic interest. The move will give relief to the residents of the area under the South Dum Dum municipality from pollution.

State urban development minister and KMC mayor Firhad Hakim on Sunday said, “Many have suffered for long due to this huge dumping ground. The waste of five municipalities is dumped here.”

Hakim was speaking at the inauguration of a 30 MLD sewage treatment plant set up by KMDA for South Dum Dum municipality.

“There are three ways to improve the waste disposal system — door-to-door waste collection through segregation, using dry waste as fuel and separating garbage that can be crushed and used for road construction. The problem of Pramod Nagar will be solved within the next three years,” Hakim added.

An animal crematorium is also coming up in the area. The Bidhannagar Municipal Corporation is also using biomining to dispose of the waste at Mollar Bheri.

Title: Extend holidays up to class IX: Teachers
Content:
After the Tamil Nadu government on Sunday announced holiday for LKG to Class V till March 31 as part of precautions against Covid-19, teachers and principals of various government and private schools in the district have called to extend the same for students up to Class IX.

“We welcome the government’s move to ensure safety of kindergarten and primary school students who are most vulnerable. However, it is appears the government is doing it half-heartedly, as the holidays should be declared for all school students,” said the principal of a government school. Teachers said that even if middle and high school students can manage their own hygiene, it will be still tough to monitor them.

Teachers however said that public exams could be easily conducted, adding that since students of Classes XI and XII have already completed half their exams, it would be unfair to stop mid-way and stress them out. “Public exams are only for a few hours and held on select days. This can be harmlessly handled. On the other hand, with most of their portions also complete by now, students of Classes VI to IX don’t have any urgent need to come physically to school and exams can always be scheduled later accordingly,” said a Class VIII teacher from a private school.

“The government has said to avoid large gatherings as much as possible. It would be hypocritical to keep schools open then. If adults are being asked to work from home in some places, why should children be under pressure to come to school?” said the head master of a private school. City schools also have zero control over monitoring if their students have been in contact with someone who may have recently returned from abroad, even in case of a family member.

Title: Kolkata: Victoria, Indian Museum shut down amid coronavirus-spread fear
Content: KOLKATA: Victoria Memorial Hall and Indian Museum along with two popular science museums Science City and BITM were shut down on Saturday as authorities became increasingly jittery over the large crowds they attract, including a sizeable number of foreign tourists that have become a pariah in the times of the novel coronavirus crisis.Rabindra Bhavan, housed in Uttarayan at Visva-Bharati in Santiniketan, had already closed down earlier along with Kala Bhavana that houses many Fine Arts faculty and has many priceless artwork displayed inside.The museum closures in the city come in the wake of similar shutdowns in Europe. Staff at the Louvre in Paris forced the museum to close following fears over the spread of Covid-19 after the French government banned large gatherings. In Italy, too, sweeping shutdown included the Vatican Museums, Galleria Borghese in Rome, and the Uffizi in Florence. In Venice, François Pinault’s private museums, the Palazzo Grassi and Punta della Dogana are also shut.Jayanta Sengupta, curator of Victoria Memorial Hall, was the first to take a call on the closure. He said the decision was prompted by concerns about safety of both staff and visitors to the marble edifice. “We get around 150 foreigners daily. Though we had taken measures like providing masks to the staff and hand sanitizers at multiple points, we were uneasy as the security had to conduct manual frisking of 12,000-13,000 visitors daily. On March 11, I had written to both the cultural ministry and Raj Bhavan. The nod to shut down the facility arrived on Saturday evening,” said Sengupta.This is the first unscheduled closure at VMH in a century. The VMH had opened in 1921. The shutdown will be reviewed on March 31 and either lifted or extended, depending on the scenario.The VMH closure also prompted Indian Museum authorities to follow suit. Though they, too, were in a dilemma, director AD Chaudhury was also aware that a closure could negatively hit people’s psychology. “I was in two minds but decided on the closure because we can’t take chances,” he said. Over 70,000 visitors had been to the museum since February 1, including 2,500-odd foreigners.Indian Museum that is 206 years old had shut for a month and a half in 2013 for renovation ahead of the bicentenary celebrations.Chaudhuri, who is also the director general of the National Council of Science Museums , issued shutdown notices for Science City and Birla Industrial & Technological Museum (BITM) as well.“In view of the evolving situation on spread of Covid-19 and following the advisory of the Union health ministry, Science City Kolkata will be closed to visitors from March 15, 2020 to March 31, 2020 or until further notice,” Science City director Subhabrata Chaudhuri said. Incidentally, Science City was among the first to launch an awareness campaign on the novel coronavirus through a special exhibition on February 7. The panels were also showcased at BITM.

Title: ‘Covid-19 patients doing well at GMCH, Mayo’
Content: Nagpur: The three Covid-19 positive patients admitted in GMCH and the one at IGGMCH had special visitors on Sunday. District collector Ravindra Thakare and DDHS Dr Sanjay Jaiswal inspected the facilities in their wards and interacted with them.Doctors treating these patients said their condition is improving. “All three patients in GMCH are showing no symptoms. They are not being given any high-end medicine. We are just monitoring their health parameters frequently,” said a doctor. All three patients are having regular food, and keeping themselves busy in activities like reading and surfing on mobile phones.At IGGMCH, the first positive patient of Nagpur city is showing improvement so far. “There is good improvement in major health parameters of this patient. He is stable and doing well. He is a sensible person and cooperating very well with doctors,” said Dr Ajay Keoliya, dean of IGGMCH.The collector also paid a visit to the lab facility at IGGMCH, which is loaded with work these days. “The collector visited our lab facility and interacted with the staff. He was explained the process of testing samples,” Dr Keoliya added.As per the protocol, these positive patients will be once again tested after they complete seven days in isolation. Irrespective of the result of this test, they must complete 14 days in isolation ward. Another test will be conducted after 14 days, and the patients will be allowed to go home if this test comes negative. If the test is positive even after 14 days, another 14 days will be added to their isolation period.Two positive patients admitted at Vasantrao Naik Government Medical College, Yavatmal, are also doing well, said authorities there. “Two patients who travelled to Dubai with a 40-member tourist group have tested positive. They have been kept separately in the isolation ward at GMCH, away from suspected patients. As one of the patients has cough and cold, medicines are being given to treat these symptoms. Another patient is asymptomatic. Only vital parameters of this patient are being checked,” said one of the doctors treating them.

Title: ‘Water frequently wasted due to leakages in city pipelines’
Content:
Madurai: Leakage in the main pipeline carrying drinking water at Thavittu Sandhai in Keela Veli Street has resulted in flooding of the road, which has hampered traffic movement on Saturday night. This has irked the residents and motorists.

Residents said that water wastage due to burst and leakages in pipelines has been rampant off late and it is noticed in various parts of the city. Thiruparankundram Main Road at Palanganatham, Ram Nagar in Bypass Road and Ponmeni, Theni Main Road at Kalavasal are few other places that have witnessed water wastage in recently. V Kalamegam, a social activist from Palanganatham, said that while there is a water problem in one part of the area, water is going waste in another part of the same area. Leakages, not only, result in water getting waste, but also reduces pressure in pipelines, resulting in poor supply of waste in tail end areas, he said.

While bigger bursts are attended immediately, smaller leakages are not fixed on time resulting in water getting waste for days. Immediate attention is required to address all sorts of water leakage problems, said M Muthulakshmi from K Pudur.

An official from the Madurai Corporation said that decade-old pipelines have to be blamed for these damages. The corporation has proposed plans to replace existing pipelines throughout the core city. A project has bene proposed at an estimated cost of Rs 77 crore to replace the pipeline in and around Meenakshi Amman temple, chosen for Area Based Development (ABD) under Smart City scheme. There is separate proposal to replace old pipeline in other part of the core city as well.

We have been rectifying water leakage problems at the earliest. We have sorted out leakage problems in Ram Nagar and work is underway to prevent leakage in East Veli Street, the official added.

Title: Recreational spots, malls function as usual in Madurai
Content:
Even as health officials tighten measures to prevent Covid-19 in Madurai as per the orders from the state government, recreational facilities for public continue to function in the city without much restrictions or preventive measures. However, health officials said that they will soon discuss the matter to ensure the safety of public.

During the last few days, health officials stepped up various measures to contain Covid-19 in light of it being declared a national disaster. A quarantine facility for 100 people has been kept ready in Madurai district. It is set to mainly house normal passengers from seven Covid-19-affected countries for a period of 14 days as per guidelines, said an official.

A city health official said that they were also in close contact with hotels and lodges in the city regarding the movement of foreigners. “We are getting updates on a regular basis from hotels and lodges in the city regarding their international guests. We’ve instructed them to inform us immediately if any foreign guest shows even the slightest symptoms of illness,” said the city health official.

Though the health department has advised against mass gatherings, popular recreational spots in the city, including malls and swimming pools are functioning as usual and continue to see some of the biggest crowds in the city, especially on weekends.

The city’s biggest mall has so far not been voluntarily implementing even simple preventive measures. Health officials noted that there have been no specific orders regarding malls so far, and in Madurai, unlike some other districts, they’ve not been asked to completely shut down either. “

Title: Four in cop net for kidnapping, disrobing & trying to kill teen in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The Hadapsar police on Sunday arrested four young men on the charges of kidnapping, disrobing and attempting to murder a 15-year-old boy in the Gopalpatti area of Manjari, after a video clip of the incident went viral on the social media the night before.

The police are searching for two other accomplices involved in the crime.

Police said the teenager, who is undergoing treatment in the intensive care unit of the Sassoon General Hospital, had an argument with the suspects a few days ago and the latter decided to settle score with him. Medical authorities reported to the police the victim’s condition as in a state of unconsciousness. The boy is a school dropout belonging to a poor family, the police added.

The police identified the arrested suspects as Vinit Suryakant Biradar (19) of Phursungi, Shubham Rajabhau Jadhav (19) of Nigdi, Devidas Ghanashyam Pavhane (21) of Hadapsar and Bharat Vishal Rathod (21) of Manjari. All of them have previous record of body offences, the police said.

On Thursday night, the victim’s mother (age 49 years) had lodged a missing person’s complaint after her son, who had left home for watching a Shiv Jayanti procession in the evening, did not return. The police were searching for him when they came across the video clip and later traced the injured boy to the Sassoon hospital .

The video clip showed five to six men assaulting the boy with sharp weapons and leather belts, after disrobing him. The video clip helped the police establish the identity of the assailants.

Investigations revealed that on Thursday evening, the suspects found the boy moving around alone. They kidnapped and took him to an isolated spot at Gopalpatti on a motorcycle. The men then threatened and abused him and disrobed him, the police said. They assaulted him with their leather belts and a sharp weapon to the point where the boy fell unconscious.

The police said one of the suspects, while assaulting the boy, filmed the entire incident. The suspects then picked up the boy, abandoned him on the nearby railway tracks and also urinated on his face, the police said. They videographed the entire act, the police said, adding that some local residents found the boy motionless near the tracks and shifted him to the Sassoon hospital.

The police said the suspects had shared the video clips among themselves using a mobile phone-based internet messaging service. Some of them even sent these clips to their friends and others. Soon, the video clip went viral.

Senior inspector Ramesh Sathe of the Hadapsar police told TOI, “One of our policemen received the video clips on his cellphone. Within no time, he identified the suspects, as they have previous record of body offences registered with the police. We then showed the video clips to the boy’s mother, who identified her son. A police team immediately swung into action and arrested the suspects.”

Title: Congress MLAs screened, covid-19 test likely for other MLAs too
Content: BHOPAL: The 86 Congress MLAs who returned from Jaipur were screened at a Bhopal hotel for covid-19, said Bhopal chief medical and health officer (CMHO) Dr Sudhir Dheriya , here on Sunday.“Everyone returning from covid-19-affected places will have undergo medical check-ups and screening,” said Dheriya, a day ahead of a possible floor test in assembly. “All are in the clear and swab samples were not taken,” he said.“We have to screen or test any person who has visited locations affected by the virus or come in contact with covid-19 infected persons. We have made necessary arrangements at Vidhan Sabha,” said Dr Dheriya. All those entering the state assembly would have to wear respiratory masks, use hand sanitizers and undergo body heat temperature screening,” he added. If anyone is suspected of contracting the virus, they may be quarantined at JP Hospital and health department training centre in Idgah Hills.“We do not conduct random screening. The medical check-up (of Congress MLAs) was conducted after a phone call to covid-19 helpline,” he added. Rebel Congress MLAs, who visited Bengaluru, and BJP MLAs who travelled to Delhi are expected to be screened, too, by the MP health department. A complete report of the health condition of the elected representatives will be submitted to the government, he added.Sources said that AIIMS-Bhopal covid-19 test lab has been instructed to follow protocol and conduct tests, if needed. Magisterial powers have been vested in CMHOs and civil surgeons under Madhya Pradesh Public Health Act, 1949.MP health and finance minister, Tarun Bhanot said, “There are two national situations that are being dealt with by the Congress government. One is to combat spread of COVID-19 and another is saving democracy. Report from health experts on health of MLAs is awaited.”A March 5 letter to state governments/UT by health and family welfare ministry’s under-secretary Rajender Kumar says, “Experts around the world have advised to reduce mass gatherings to avoid spread of COVID-19. In the above view, is it advised that mass gatherings may be avoided or possibly be postponed till disease spread is contained.”

Title: Pune: Bus driver mows down guitarist on a bike while trying to overtake him
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A well-known 25-year-old guitarist was killed after a PMPML bus driver knocked his motorcycle at Pashan on Katraj-Dehu Road bypass around 11.30pm on Friday night.

Mradul Tarun Singhal, a resident of Marunji near Hinjewadi, was driving his motorcycle towards Bavdhan when the accident occurred.

“Singhal was wearing a helmet,” assistant inspector Anand Pagare of the Hinjewadi police told TOI. The police have arrested the (PMPML) bus driver, Ulhas Sarphale (44), for negligent driving.

Pagare said Singhal and the PMPML bus were headed towards Chandni Chowk on Friday night. The bus was on its way Katraj while Singhal was headed towards Bavdhan.

The Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) bus driver hit Singhal’s motorcycle while attempting to overtake him. “Singhal lost his balance, fell off the motorcycle and came under the front wheel of the bus. He died on spot,” Pagare said.

Vaibhav Bachale, Singhal’s friend and a drummer, said Singhal was practising for his performance, scheduled in the last week of March. “On Friday he had a practise session till 9pm with other musicians in the band. After it got over, Sighal decided to visit a friend of ours in Bavdhan,” Bachale said adding, “Singhal always used to wear safety gear while driving his motorcycle.”

Sarphale was produced in court on Saturday and released on bail, police said.

Sarphale has been charged under sections 279 (rash driving or riding on a public way) and 304-A (causing death by negligence) of the Indian Penal Code and the relevant sections of the Motor Vehicle Act.

Account of a fellow musician

“He had composed some new material on the day of his accident and was looking forward to release it. It's extremely shocking and heartbreaking the way he left us,” said Prateek Bhaduri, an eminent singer and songwriter.

“Mradul and I were in touch over social media for a few years till we finally jammed together at one of my events. Afterwards, we talked at length about the music scene and our love for the heavier genres of music and good songwriting,” said Bhaduri.

He added, “Mradul was an extremely humble, hardworking and talented. He was quite a riot on stage. Offstage, he was an easy going boy, soft-spoken and caring.”

Title: Poddareshwar temple firm on shobha yatra, plans preventive steps
Content:
Nagpur: The trustees of Poddareshwar Ram Mandir on Central Avenue on Sunday stood firm with their decision to hold the Ramnavami shobha yatra, scheduled on April 2. Considering the novel coronavirus outbreak, the temple trustees claimed to be taking precautionary measures at the temple and during the shobha yatra to ensure safety of devotees.

The shobha yatra taken out by Ram Mandir in Ram Nagar has already been cancelled considering fears regarding the coronavirus outbreak.

On Saturday, district collector Ravindra Thakare, while citing state government’s directives discouraging large gatherings due to coronavirus outbreak, had made it clear that religious processions will not be allowed. Even commissioner of police Bhushan Kumar Upadhyay has said they will ensure that the government’s orders are followed.

Divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar had told TOI that no permission will be given to big events like the Ramnavami shobha yatra in which thousands of devotees take part.

The trustees of Poddareshwar Ram Mandir on Central Avenue held a meeting on Sunday evening and discussed preparations for the shobha yatra, including precautionary measures to be taken during the procession.

Punnet Poddar, a trustee of Poddareshwar Ram Mandir, tried to justify the temple’s decision to go ahead with the religious procession. He said sanitizers will be distributed among the devotees visiting the temple and also to people participating in the procession. “We will stock up enough sanitizers for the purpose,” he said.

In a bid to disinfect the temple premises, Poddar said that bleach will be added to the water in tanks of the air coolers. “We are not going to cancel the procession under any circumstances,” he said.

Ravi Waghmare, organizer of the shobha yatra at Ram Nagar, said, “We have mutually decided to call off our shobha yatra to ensure safety of devotees. We have also cancelled the mahaprasad that was scheduled on April 3.”

He said that adequate arrangements will be made and devotees will be asked to clean their hands with sanitizer before entering the temple on Ram Navami.

Title: Bhopal labs prepare for swab test of netas
Content: BHOPAL: The Union ministry of health and family welfare (MoHFW) is keeping a close watch on the Covid-19 testing facilities in Madhya Pradesh , according to highly placed sources. The ministry is anticipating that state government could send swab samples of suspected politicians for Covid-19.There are two authorised laboratories in Madhya Pradesh, one is at AIIMS Bhopal and another at ICMR facility in Jabalpur. The average turnaround time for the Covid-19 report is about five hours. These labs have been instructed to carry out the tests as per set protocol, according to sources.As per protocol, the state health department-appointed chief medical and health officer orders collection of nasopharyngeal swab from suspected patients. Until test report is available, the suspected person can be placed under quarantine, and second the swab is usually collected from postive patient for added confirmation. The sample are tested at AIIMS Bhopal or ICMR Jabalpur . With opening of the two labs, turnaround time has been reduced in the past week.

Title: Pune: 60 teens edging toward a life of crime on correction course
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Fifteen-year-old Santosh Adagale (name changed) refused to go to school despite his mother’s attempts to persuade him. He was drawn to his friends who were involved in thefts and robberies in Warje area.

Another teenager from Kasewadi saw his role model in a youngster from the slum pocket involved in robberies and body offences.

But the Pune police hope to see a turnaround. The two teens and 58 other boys will join a correction programme called ‘Roshni’ to dissuade minor boys from getting into criminal activities.

The officials of the Special Child Protection Unit under the Bharosa Cell have designed the Roshni programme with help from non-government organisations in the city.

“The programme was launched on February 20. So far, it has been started for boys and girls from the slum pockets of Lohiyanagar-Kasewadi and Warje,” inspector Shilpa Chavan of the unit said.

The police have enrolled 15 boys and girls from the Lohiyanagar–Kasewadi slum pocket while 12 teenagers have been enrolled from the Warje, Chavan added.

The Special Child Protection Unit in the last one year identified as many as 605 minor boys and girls in conflict with the law.

“Soon, the programmes will start at Janata Vasahat , Sahakarnagar, Hadapsar , Aundh, and other slum pockets of the city. As of now, we have decided to select 60 boys and girls for the programmes. The number will certainly go up,” she said.

Under the programme, the police and NGOs working for children approach the parents of the juveniles in conflict with law and urge them to send their children to the special course programme in the slum pocket.

A room is arranged where police and NGO officials conduct counselling sessions for the children, she said.“It is an attempt to dissuade children from getting involved in criminal activities and to pursue education,” she said.

The programme which conducts counselling sessions urges them to have an identity for themselves and not follow their role models, Chavan said.

Theatre workshops, de-addiction programmes, the importance of a proper diet, hygiene, meditation programme and programme based on motivational songs and drama are used to help them.

“We have also sought help from the local women who want to volunteer for the programme. They will help the police bring these kids for the counselling sessions and programmes,” a woman member of an NGO said.

In order to persuade the boys who drop out of school to go back, the police and NGO authorities have decided to include their school-going friends in the programme. After watching the progress of their pals, they will be motivated to resume their education once again. It will not only reduce criminal activities in the slum pocket but bring the kids back to a normal life,” Chavan said.

Title: One dead, five hurt as bikes collide in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A 22-year-old youth died and five of his friends sustained injuries after their motorcycles collided head-on at Shelarwadi near Talegaon Dabhade about 24km from Pune on Saturday night.

The Talegaon Dabhade police have identified the deceased as Sanjay Kedari of Parandwadi in Maval taluka . “Kedari’s five friends are undergoing treatment in a nearby hospital,” Digambar Atigre , assistant inspector of the Talegaon Dabhade police told TOI.

The six friends from Parandwadi had gone to Indori near Talegaon Dabhade to play cricket. “On their way back, one motorcycle went ahead. When the other motorcycle did not catch up, the trio took U turn at Shelarwadi to check,” Atigre said.

After some distance, their motorcycle collided head-on with another motorcycle which was their friend’s. “Due to the high speed six of them sustained severe injuries. The locals took them to a nearby hospital, where Kedari succumbed to his injuries,” Atigre said.

Atigre said the youths are studying. “We have yet to record the statements of the injured victims. Our probe is on,” Atigre said.

Title: Tirunelveli MCH to begin Covid-19 testing soon
Content: MADURAI: Testing for Covid-19 is set to begin soon at the Virus Research Diagnostic Laboratory (VRDL) at Tirunelveli Medical College Hospital (MCH). Once it becomes operational, it will be the fourth lab in the state authorised for testing the disease.“We are merely expanding services in the already functioning Virus Research Diagnostic Laboratory here. Tests for a number of infectious viruses are already being conducted at the lab and Covid-19 tests will soon be included,” said Dr M Ravichandran, dean, Tirunelveli MCH. He added that the lab will be useful in getting quicker results for test samples sent from southern districts of Tamil Nadu.However, the dean said that a trial run needs to be done before a formal approval is given. “First a trial run will be held and the accuracy of the results will be checked. Only then will the National Institute of Virology give its nod for performing tests for Covid-19,” he explained.Lab technicians who are already working at the lab will be provided kits for Covid-19 testing and trained. Hence, no additional personnel will be appointed. The lab is set to become fully functional in the next few days.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Tourist spots shut in Theni till March 31
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: As part of preventive measures for COVID-19 being implemented across Tamil Nadu, all popular tourist locations, theatres and malls were shut down in Theni district starting Sunday and will remain closed till March 31. The district’s health department officials said that tourist spots like Vaigai Dam Park, Kumabakkarai Falls, Megamalai, Chinnasuruli and Suruli Falls have all been shut down. Malls and theatres, which can facilitate large gathering of people, have also been closed. Health officials have also stepped up measures to sanitize the areas and create awareness about COVID-19 at all places of worship like temples, mosques and churches. People with fever, cough and cold will be advised against going out in public.

Cardamom estate workers in Theni district have been asked to stop going for work in the plantations. Through a meeting, it was communicated that they are to be given jobs under National Rural Employment Guarantee Act. Health officials further have advised the public against travelling to other districts during the next 15 days. “We have kept ready COVID-19 isolation wards in both government and private hospitals. We have masks and kits ready for medical personnel to handle any situation,” said a health official.

Title: 4 new suspect corona patients in Chandrapur
Content:
Chandrapur: Four more suspected coronavirus patients were detected in the district, even as district administration intensified preventive measures. District collector Dr Kunal Khemnar on Sunday ordered closing of all coaching classes, after some continued to function on Sunday despite closure orders for schools and colleges.

Collector Dr Khemnar said so far 10 citizens who have returned from abroad and tourists have been checked in the district for Covid-19 infection, and all of them were diagnosed negative. Four new patients with coronavirus symptoms arrived at Chandrapur GMCH late on Saturday night. He said three belong to Sindewahi tehsil, while one is from Warora.

Sources said an elderly person from Sindewahi tehsil had returned from pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia on March 13. He developed symptoms, followed soon by his wife and son, and they rushed to GMCH. Fourth suspect belongs to Wadgaon. He had reportedly returned from United Arab Emirates recently. All of them have been kept in isolation ward and their samples sent to Nagpur for tests.

Meanwhile, the collector invoked Epidemic Disease Act-1897 and ordered closure of all shopping malls, stores, swimming pools, auditoriums, theatres, gyms, pan kiosks, kharra centres etc. However, essential services like medical stores have been spared. All kinds of gathering of crowd have been banned. Some exceptions like marriages, weekly markets will be permitted on certain conditions.

The foreign tourists visiting Tadoba Andhari Tiger Reserve are being screened through thermal screening. Details like name, country, contact number, place of stay and tour plan, along with details of people coming in their contact is being taken from foreign tourists, the collector said.

Title: Design guides to Mysuru, Chandigarh released
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The students of Trinity College of Architecture recently published two books tracing the distinctive architectural character of monuments and landmarks in Mysuru and Chandigarh.

The books have been written, compiled, designed and edited by the third and fourth year architecture students, a statement issued by the college stated.

“The two books cover all details of the historic cities, starting from their inception. The students have chronicled the growth of these cities in terms of their urban character and design features of the and the recent landmarks,” managing director of K J Educational Institute Vibhavari Jadhav said.

The authors of the book also conducted an exhibition their work, titled, “Elysian”, in their college campus in Kondhwa. “The books were released during the exhibition. The text of the books is well-supported with ample photographs, sketches and maps in a bid to reach a larger spectrum of audience. The books would serve as a focused primer on architectural styles and its evolution in the cities of Mysuru and Chandigarh,” Jadhav said.

“At the exhibition, the projects were categorised as per the academic year and the subject matter. The categories were architectural design, basic design, building construction and materials, building services, landscape, urban studies, rural settlement studies and history of architecture,” principal of Trinity College of Architecture B S Keshav said.

Keshav said few designs that were shortlisted at an international competition were also displayed. “Indigenous art installations were made and put up at several parts of the campus premises. These installations were made with the help of everyday discarded materials,’ Keshav said.

Select photographs taken during the study tours of Gujarat, Nepal, Mysuru and Chandigarh were also put on display. The exhibition was inaugurated by founder-president of KJEI, Kalyan Jadhav.

Title: Coronavirus in Madhya Pradesh: Covid-19 brings the curtain down on stage shows in Madhya Pradesh
Content: BHOPAL: Culture department of Madhya Pradesh has suspended all events and gatherings until further notice, as a precautionary method against coronavirus “We have not decided when the activities will resume as it all depends upon the situation. If the situation comes under control, all activities and events will resume. If need be, the suspension will be extended,” said Pankaj Rag, principal secretary, culture department.Along with cultural performances at Tribal Museum, Ravindra Bhavan and Shaheed Bhavan , the award ceremony scheduled to be held at Bharat Bhavan on March 17 has also been postponed. Ongoing festivals like Arjun Theatre Festival and also annual functions in schools have been postponed.HR Ahirwar, assistant director of Ravindra Bhavan on Sunday said, “As precautionary measure against coronavirus, all events scheduled by the department of culture between March 15 to March 31 have been postponed. We request private organisations and culture groups to postpone cultural activities that may lead to mass gatherings and organise them at a later date when the threat of coronavirus has passed.”

Title: Aspiring actress complains rape in Pune hotel on promise of serial role
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The Airport police on Saturday registered an offence against two men from Nagpur on the charge of raping an aspiring actress (28) under the pretext of giving her a role in a television serial.

The police have booked a Mumbai-based woman under the charges of abetment, who had lured the complainant for the role and brought her to Pune to meet the duo. The actress also stated in her complaint that the trio assaulted her with a beer bottle when she had objected to the duo’s sexual advances. The incident happened on February 9 inside a hotel room in Vimannagar .

The actress said in her complaint that she went to Mumbai as they had threatened to kill her. After getting the medical treatment, she lodged an FIR with the Airport police on March 14.

The actress said she met the suspected woman in January in a mall at Malad in Mumbai. After getting acquainted, the woman told the complainant that she would help her bag a “second or third lead role” in a serial. “She even had told the complainant that she knew a producer and director. The woman told the complainant that the duo were in Pune and told her to come along with her to meet them,” an officer from the Airport police said.

On February 8, the officer said, the two women had come to Pune and stayed in the hotel. The complainant shared the room with the woman. “The same day, the two men posing as producer and director interviewed the complainant and promised her a role in a serial,” the officer said.

Later, the duo came to the complainant’s room where they drank beer with the suspected woman, the officer said. “The woman stated in her complaint that the duo demanded sexual favours from her for giving her the role. When the woman denied their offer, all three assaulted her,” he said.

He said the police checked the hotel and ascertained the duo’s identity with the their Aadhar cards they had submitted while booking the room.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: 1 more suspected Covid-19 patient in Yavatmal GMCH
Content:
Yavatmal: One more coronavirus suspect patient has been admitted in the isolation ward of Yavatmal Government Medical College and Hospital on Sunday, taking the total number of patients in Yavatmal to four, of which two have tested positive.

Out of nine admitted in GMCH Yavatmal, seven tested negative. However, one of them became symptomatic and he has been detained in the isolation ward. The remaining six were discharged on Saturday and are now under home quarantine.

“Today, one more 50-year-old man of Yavatmal city reached the hospital with symptoms of coronavirus. He has now been kept in the isolation ward,” said dean Dr Milind Kamble. This man has also returned from Dubai.

Dr Kamble said swab samples of both suspected patients have been sent to Nagpur for tests. “We have cancelled the leaves of doctors, nurses and paramedical staff,” Dr Kamble said.

The civil surgeon has started collecting data of persons with whom the patients had contact during their home quarantine.

Title: Revival plan for Sal ready, project to cost Rs 185 crore
Content:
Panaji: The state government’s river rejuvenation committee (RRC-Goa) has prepared an action plan for the rejuvenation of the river Sal . The project, estimated to cost over Rs 185 crore, will include the de-silting of the river, replacement of the old sewerage network system and connecting houses in the vicinity to the sewerage system.

This apart, RCC has also proposed that the Khareband nullah be connected to the north trunk main sewer line. Presently, water from the Shirvodem nullah is diverted to the 20 MLD STP at Shivodem, Navelim. The treated water is then released back into nullah on the downstream side.

RCC’s proposal includes the improvement and upgradation of the existing solid waste management facilities and erection of material recovery facilities/storage shed for non-biodegradable waste at Sonsoddo, Margao. It has also proposed that treated sewage from the STP at Colva be de-weeded, recycled and reused to maintain the e-flow.

This revised action plan will be submitted to the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) for approval, as per the order of the National Green Tribunal ( NGT ).

A senior government officer said the installation of the sewerage network is being expedited through the Sewerage Infrastructure Development Corporation of Goa Limited (SIDCGL) and the institutional mechanism for solid-waste management is being strengthened through the Goa Waste Management Corporation (GWMC).

“There is no industrial discharge into any of the polluted river stretches,” one senior government officer said. Earlier, the Goa State Pollution Control Board (GSPCB) had levied fines under the Polluter-Pay-Principle (PPP) to commercial establishments located along the banks of the Mandovi for discharging untreated sewage. Further, they had been given a time frame to make provisions for sewage treatment methodology.

The public works department had also disconnected water and electricity connections of residential units found to be discharging sewage into rivers. GWMC meanwhile has initiated a process to provide biotoilets.

Title: Bhopal: Government schools to reopen on April 1
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: Following the directions of the Governor Lalji Tandon , the school education department has declared that all government schools and colleges will be closed till March 31, 2020. All schools that were supposed to open from Monday will now reopen only on April 1. “Earlier we had passed the circular stating that schools will be closed until further notice, but now it has been decided that schools will only be closed till March 31. All other directions in the order passed on Match 13 stand as it is only, only the date for reopening of schools has been declared”, said principal secretary school education department, Rashmi Shami.

All annual exams in private and government schools will be postponed while state level exams for classes 5 and 8 and board exams of classes 10 and 12 will be held as per the schedule.

Title: Yes Bank writes down Rs 8,415 crore AT-1 bonds
Content: MUMBAI: Yes Bank has said it will write down additional tier (AT-1) bonds worth Rs 8,415 crore of the Rs 8,695 crore issued. This could have implications for mutual funds, life insurance companies and pension funds that have invested in the scheme , and their investors.The lender has also said it will issue fresh shares worth Rs 10,000 crore to boost its capital, which has been largely wiped out after its record Q3 loss. The bank has limited its capital raising under a government-notified reconstruction scheme to Rs 10,000 crore with SBI bringing in Rs 6,050 crore as against the initial commitment of Rs 7,250 crore and IDFC First Bank joining with a contribution of Rs 250 crore.The bank’s capital adequacy has been boosted by writing down Rs 8,415 crore of the AT-1 bonds. The write-down of the AT-1 (quasi-equity) bonds will also impact high net worth individuals who, drawn by the higher rates, had bought these bonds. The reconstruction scheme was notified by the government last week to enable the distressed bank to exit a moratorium on withdrawals, imposed by the RBI on March 5 to protect depositors.In a letter to stock exchanges after the results on Saturday, Yes Bank said the lender is deemed to be “non-viable or approaching non-viability and accordingly the triggers for a write-down of certain Basel III AT-1 bonds have been triggered”. It added that in light of the provisions of the Basel III circular, AT-1 bonds worth Rs 3,000 crore issued on December 23, 2016, and another lot of Rs 5,415 crore issued on October 18, 2017 stand extinguished. In its results, the bank had said that Rs 8,695 crore of these bonds can be used to enhance the equity of the bank. It is not clear whether the difference of Rs 280 crore between the bonds issued and bonds written down has been converted to equity. Yes Bank did not respond to queries till the time of going to press.The bank said its common equity (tier-1) ratio fell to 0.6% after the quarterly loss. The losses were due to gross NPAs jumping to Rs 40,709 crore from Rs 5,158 crore in the previous year and Rs 17,134 crore in the preceding quarter. By making a Rs 22,328-crore provision for bad loans, the bank has managed to restrict the ratio of net non-performing assets to 5.97%, just below the 6% level which triggers prompt corrective action by the RBI.After considering a capital infusion of Rs 10,000 crore and write-down of Rs 8,415 crore of AT-1 bonds, the common equity (tier-1) ratio improved to 7.6%, which is just above the statutory requirement.Yes Bank faces a major challenge in convincing bulk depositors to retain their funds. The lender has seen a flight of Rs 72,000-crore deposits in less than six months and is meeting the mismatch through borrowings. There could also be legal challenges from shareholders holding more than 100 shares, who have been forced into a lock-in under the scheme.

Title: Dua Lipa urges fans to donate for coronavirus crisis
Content:
wow on this night we really thought 2020 was gonna be the one... thinking of you all during this difficult and conf… https://t.co/SzLvfEn6Hx — DUA LIPA (@DUALIPA) 1584272641000

Refugees are some of the most vulnerable on this planet, often living in crowded places with limited health service… https://t.co/hPoaY7QInB — DUA LIPA (@DUALIPA) 1584272642000

I know during this difficult time some of you might not be able to donate to the UNHCR emergency appeal but if you… https://t.co/myxBxr0NiP — DUA LIPA (@DUALIPA) 1584272642000

In the wake of spurt in cases of novel coronavirus in different parts of the world, singer Dua Lipa on Sunday raised awareness about the highly contagious virus and urged people to donate for the emergency.The 24-year-old singer took to Twitter to spread the word about the global pandemic."Thinking of you all during this difficult and confusing time. Stay safe, wash ur hands, be with your loved ones and most importantly remember and think of the ones less fortunate than you," the 'One Kiss' singer tweeted.Further speaking about the less fortunate ones, Lipa wrote, "Refugees are some of the most vulnerable on this planet, often living in crowded places with limited health services. UN agencies are working hard to make sure these people are supported.""I know during this difficult time some of you might not be able to donate to the UNHCR emergency appeal but if you can it really makes a difference to protect refugees and their host communities from COVID-19. Love," she added.Coronavirus, which originated in China's Wuhan city in December last year, has so far spread to more than 100 countries, infecting over 1,30,000 people. The World Health Organisation (WHO) has declared coronavirus a pandemic.

Title: Provide round-the-clock security outside isolation ward: Nashik hospitals
Content: NASHIK: In the view of the Ahmednagar incident on Saturday, senior officials of the Nashik civil hospital have decided to write a letter to the city police asking them to provide round-the-clock security at the isolation ward.At present, four travellers from coronavirus-affected countries are admitted to the isolation ward of the Nashik civil hospital.On Saturday, three close contacts of the coronavirus-infected people, who were admitted to the isolation ward of the Ahmednagar district hospital, left without informing the doctors. They returned to the isolation ward three hours later after they were contacted and informed about violation of laws.To ensure that similar incidents are not repeated in the isolation ward of the Nashik civil hospital, the authorities have decided to seek help of city police for providing round-the-clock security.Civil Surgeon Suresh Jagdale said, “Though we will seek police’s help, our emphasis will be more on counselling the travellers and telling them about the importance of getting themselves checked since they have come from a country affected with coronavirus . We will inform them that they have been quarantined only ensure that they are not infected with the virus. We would also tell them that keeping them in the isolation ward does not mean that they have caught the virus. So far, all 17 samples of travellers sent to check the presence of virus have tested negative.” Jagdale said that if the travellers refuse to co-operate, they will seek police’s help.He said that there are not more than four to five people at a time in the isolation ward. Thus, the medical staff in the ward can well keep a vigil on all of them. If the number increases, they would beef up the security.Meanwhile, officials of the Nashik civil hospital have also identified a building with a capacity of 30 beds to quarantine travellers coming from China, Italy, Iran, Iraq, South Korea, France and Spain.Security beefed up at Ahmednagar civil hospitalThe security at the Ahmednagar civil hospital has been beefed up after three people suspected of Covid-19 , had left the hospital premises. The district administration has placed two guards at the isolation ward to keep a watch on the patients.“There was a case of three suspects running away from the quarantine cell, but all of them came back after three hours. However, in order to avoid any such incidents in future, we have deployed two guards to keep watch over them,” Collector of Ahmednagar, Rahul Dwivedi, said.

Title: 50% drop in number of Shirdi pilgrims
Content: NASHIK: The coronavirus scare is keeping people away from places of worship as well. On Sunday, which is usually a busy day at the Shirdi Saibaba temple, there was a 50% drop in the number of pilgrims.Arun Dongre, the chief executive officer of the Shri Saibaba Sansthan Trust, said that while the temple usually receives more than 50,000 devotees every day, there were no more than 25,000 devotees on Sunday.“I appeal to all the devotees to stay at home and stay safe. We cannot close the temple doors and are willing to serve all those who come here, but people should avoid coming to the crowded temple,” Dongre told TOI.He also said this is a time of global crisis when precaution can save lives. People should refrain from going to any crowded place.“Saibaba’s blessings are with everyone. We have taken various precautionary measures in our Sansthan and both of its hospitals. We have prepared two isolation wards in both the hospitals for any emergency,” the CEO added.A devotee has also donated contactless digital thermometers in the hospitals run by the Sansthan to ensure the hygiene of the healthcare staff.The temple authorities have been cleaning the temple premises, including the prasadalaya, multiple times a day. The CEO has instructed the kitchen staff to clean the utensils thoroughly and more carefully.A team from the National Disaster Response Force from New Delhi had conducted a meeting at the Sansthan recently explaining the measures to be taken in areas where mass gatherings take place. The Sansthan has put up posters explaining the precautions to be taken on the temple premises.

Title: Nashik market streets wear a deserted look, city centre mall closed
Content: NASHIK: The city market, including the main road, M G Road, Shalimar, and other busy streets in the city wore a deserted look on Sunday after people avoided stepping out of their homes amid coronavirus scare.The streets are usually crowded on weekends as a lot of people turn up for shopping, however, there has been a footfall over the last few days.The city centre mall was closed down following government instructions. The grocery hypermarket in the mall, however, remained opened.
