But, there were a very few customers.In addition, shows in Kalidas Kala Mandir were cancelled on Sunday due to panic among citizens.“Usually, there is no space to even walk in the main road as well as in the Shalimar area of the city, especially on Sunday. But, there has been a remarkable drop in the footfall of customers. By this time, I make around 50 customers on Sunday. But, I was not able to get even 10 customers this Sunday as many did not step out of their homes because of the fear of coronavirus, said Mohammed Shaikh , a street vendor.Sangita Thakre, a city resident, sais that she usually goes for shopping on weekends; however, preferred to stay at home this Sunday. “We preferred to stay at home and did not go for shopping as part of precautionary measures due to coronavirus scare,” Thakre said.NMC shuts auditoriums, planetarium and gymsThe Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) has closed its all auditoriums, planetariums, gyms and swimming pools in the city as part of precautionary measure until March 31. Municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game issued a circular in this regard on Sunday.

Title: Students, techies leave Pune for home
Content: NASHIK: With the schools, institutes, malls and theatres being closed till March 31, and IT companies offering work-from-home options, students and techies in Pune are trying to return to their homes in Nashik Ahmednagar , Dhule, Jalgaon, Aurangabad and Kolhapur.Many people from these areas either study in Pune or are employed in the IT and ITes sector there. Because of the rising number of confirmed coronavirus cases in Pune, all of them are now rushing home.“All schools, colleges and classes have been closed till March 31. This leaves us with no option but to go home. Staying here won’t benefit us given that everything is closed. My colleagues from Aurangabad and Kolhapur are also leaving,” said Dushyant Bachhav , a resident of Satana.There is also the fear that the Pune city may be under complete lockdown in the future if the cases go on rising. That is why those who are not locals are leaving Pune.Ruchita Saindane, an IT employee in Pune who hails from Malegaon, said, “My company has instructed us to work from home till March 31. I think there is no point in getting stuck in Pune. What if the city gets locked down tomorrow?” the resident of Malegaon said.The MSRTC officials in Nashik supported the claim. “Generally, on Sundays, we have huge passenger traffic going to Pune from Nashik. We usually deploy additional buses. However, today, we have had a huge inflow from Pune, which is in sharp contrast to the regular days,” senior depot manager Dlieep Nalwade said. “Instead of Pune, we have had a heavy flow towards Dhule and Nandurbar,” he said.

Title: Nashik-based Schools preparing e-learning material
Content: NASHIK: City-based schools, after the state government announced closure of all educational institutes till March 31, have started preparing e-learning materials and homework for students that will be sent via mobile applications and emails.Himgauri Aher Adke, chairperson of English Medium Schools Association , said they will honour the decision of the government.“If schools cannot conduct examinations for classes up to Class VIII, it is up to the schools that they can aggregate marks of internal assessment and promote students on the basis of that. Since the picture is not clear yet, the examinations have been postponed for now,” Adke said.Moreover, few colleges have told their students that their internal tests of 20 marks will be conducted as per schedule.District collector Suraj Mandhare said that examinations cannot be deferred, but there should be another way out.“As board examinations are going on in various schools, they need to be conducted with extra precautions. School and college authorities should maintain that only one student sits on one bench during the examination. University examinations can also be conducted in a similar manner,” Mandhare said.

Title: Pune: Let your hair down, even with a wig
Content:
Pretend tresses: Vrushali Maisekar displays some of the wigs

There’s hair transplantation for those who cannot embrace their baldness easily. But for those unwilling to undergo such surgeries, there’s always the wig. The hairpiece has brought solace to alopecia and chemotherapy patients alike and much cheer to the Kardashians and Lady Gagas donning them on those big nights out. In fact, celebrities are seen as having normalized the wearing of wigs in recent years.

The first known wigs were made of human hair in Egypt way back in 2700 BC, says skin-care specialist Vrushali Maisekar. In the 17th and 18th centuries, large full-bottomed expensive wigs signified the wealth of an individual. Hair was harvested from the heads of the rural working class.

Interestingly, the tonsure shops at the Tirupati temple are today the biggest suppliers of human hair world-wide. Maisekar says that while some Indian wig-makers buy the hair during the auctions at the temple, most of it is sent abroad for a chemical treatment mainly to remove the cuticles.

Maisekar gets readymade wigs of both human and synthetic hair from foreign countries. Her Indian-made wigs usually come out of factories in Kolkata, some places in the south of the country and Mumbai, she says. She sends the specifications required for her clients to these factories and gets her wigs prepared within 10 days.

Full wigs for women are usually made in Indian factories only and can cost up to Rs 25,000. Human hair wigs are pricier and last longer than the synthetic ones, but 18 months is usually the time by which one needs to buy a new wig, she says.

The wigs are made by sewing hair strands individually or in bunches into a lace base made of polyurethane and nylon. Highly advanced bases these days offer a natural-looking frontline and hairline, says Maisekar. Once she gets a wig from the factory, it requires a little styling and customization to suit the wearer.

Maisekar sells around 30 partial and full wigs each month with the start price being Rs 5,000. Around half her clients are chemotherapy patients.

Another wig seller, Namrata Pawar, has been in the trade for the past two years. Of the 15-odd wigs she sells each month, at least six are made locally by her workforce.

A full wig for women would use 5-10 lakh strands of hair which are at least 30 inches long, says Pawar. She buys hair of such length for around Rs 50,000 a kilo. The wigs made at her workshop get an application of shampoo, conditioner, gel and serum to give it a natural gloss. She advises her buyers to also wash, shampoo and condition their wigs two or three times a month. Among styles in wigs, the preference is for the Indian wavy look, not curls or straight hair, she says.

Most wigs lose their sheen and do not appear natural after two years, says Pawar. Chemotherapy patients need wigs for around that much time; their own natural hair starts growing again thereafter.

Maisekar says wigs today have shed the artificial look and feel of the past. The chemical treatment of hair in the factories is much advanced these days, she points out. Earlier, the entire base of the wig would be stuck to the head, which was rather uncomfortable for the wearer. Today, only an outer ring of the base is fixed to the head and the fitting is such that even an intense dust storm would not knock off the hairpiece, she says.

That’s literally keeping your hair on in all circumstances, like Angelina Jolie did even while wearing an array of wigs in the 2009 flick ‘Salt’.

Title: Goa: Two held with drugs worth Rs 2 lakh at Anjuna
Content:
Representative Image

PANAJI: Goa police have arrested two Netherlands nationals for allegedly being in possession of drugs worth Rs 2.1 lakh. Anjuna police said they received information that the two were involved in the drug trade and were supplying narcotics to tourists.

Following a tip-off, police laid a trap at a junction near Tembi ground in Anjuna where one of the two was to strike a deal. The accused was caught with pink tablets, suspected to be ecstasy, weighing 8.2g, worth Rs 2.1 lakh and Rs 2,500 in cash.

During interrogation, he informed the police about the second accused, who supplied him the narcotic substance. Accordingly, the second accused was also arrested.

Anjuna police have registered a case under various sections of Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act.

Title: ‘Pakarua vivah’: Boy forced to marry a minor in Madhubani
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

PATNA: Yet another case of ‘ pakarua vivah ’ (forced marriage) came to light in Madhubani district on Saturday when the bridegroom’s father sought the SP’s intervention in rescuing his 19-year-old son Manish Kumar from the clutches of abductors.

Dinesh Mahto (40) of Kerba village under Saharghat police station submitted a petition to Madhubani SP Satya Prakash . Mahto alleged that Bhairavsthan police did not respond when he reported the incident on March 9, three days after his son informed him over phone that he had been abducted for marriage. “My repeated pleas to trace my son went on deaf ears. Then I decided to met the SP for justice,” the hapless father told reporters in Madhubani on Sunday.

According to the complaint, Manish was abducted when he had gone to meet his elder sister at Khaira village under Bhairavsthan police station in Madhubani district on March 4. He was forced to marry a 16-year-old girl, stated to be the daughter of Ganga Prasad Mahto , at gunpoint on March 6. “Manish later informed me that he had been confined in a room and was not being allowed to move out,” Mahto told the SP.

In the meantime, photographs of the ‘pakarua vivah’ went viral on social media. “I have provided the photographs of forced marriage of my son, who is an undergraduate student. The SP has assured me prompt action in the case. Since the groom is a minor, the marriage stands illegal and action should be taken against the girl’s parents under Prohibition of Child Marriage Act 2006,” Mahto said.

In the complaint, Mahto has accused Ganga, his wife Rajo Devi and other family members, including Vinod Narayan Mahto , Kishore Mahto and Vinod Mahto of abducting his son for marriage and wrongful confinement. The police have neither been been able to trace Manish nor arrest the accused, Mahto alleged.

When contacted, Madhubani SP said, “I have already asked the SHO of the police station concerned to take appropriate action in the case as the groom is stated to be a minor. I have also asked the investigating officer to ascertain the age of the ‘couple’ before initiating any action.”

Bhairavsthan SHO Santosh Kumar Singh said initially the police got information that it was a case of love affair and not abduction, as claimed by the boy’s father. “Now we have come to know that the girl is a minor. Raids are on to trace the boy. Our priority is to recover him safely,” he said over phone.

The state has got the dubious distinction of lodging a record number of 4,488 cases of kidnapping for marriage in 2019. Majority of the cases were reported from Khagaria , Begusarai, Lakhisarai, Nawada, Nalanda, Samastipur and Darbhanga districts. Last year, a similar case was reported in Patna district.

Title: Tourist jumps quarantine, stopped in the nick of time
Content: Kochi: Cochin International Airport Limited Cial ) is on high alert after a UK national , who was tested Covid-19 positive, reached the airport from Munnar and tried to board a Dubai flight on Sunday morning. The 290-passenger Emirates flight (EK 531) was denied permission to take off due to intervention of district collector S Sushas around 15 minutes before the take-off until the 19-member tourist team from the UK was detained and all other passengers were health-screened after offloading them from the aircraft.The flight later departed with 270 passengers at 12.47pm and Covid-19 positive man and his wife were shifted to the isolation ward of Ernakulam Medical College hospital. All the other 17 tourists were shifted to a private hotel in Kochi where they will be quarantined. Their blood samples have been taken for tests. Following this, the airport had to undergo a massive disinfection drive before operations were resumed and a high alert is on in the premises.The UK native was in isolation in KTDC’s Tea County Resort in Munnar after he developed feverish symptoms on March 11. He left with others for Kochi on Saturday night.As the couple did not board the flight and was apprehended right after security check, there was no direct contact with other passengers. Airport officials said CCTV footages were also checked and they did not find any direct contact with 270 passengers.“There were 290 passengers scheduled on the flight, including the 19-member tourist team. All the 19 tourists have been detained and another passenger, a Keralite, who decided not to travel on the flight, was asked to stay in home quarantine. A massive disinfection drive has been initiated inside the terminals. All staff, including security officials who frisked them and had direct contact with the UK national, have been identified through CCTV footages and were asked to be under self-quarantine. The officials are taking measures to control the situation,” said agriculture minister V S Sunilkumar, who convened a review meeting at the airport.The flight later departed with 270 passengers, who were screened for feverish symptoms at health counters. The runway was made available for departure of this delayed flight as there was no normal operation from 10am to 6pm due to the resurfacing work which will be completed only by March 28.Agriculture minister V S Sunil Kumar, who is in charge of Ernakulam district’s Covid-19 control activities, conducted a review meeting at Cial with Ernakulam district collector S Suhas and said that there is no panic situation and no decisions have been taken to health-screen departing passengers too yet.“The situation is totally under control and the airport operation will not be affected. The checking in arrival area will continue more efficiently. The aircraft, aerobridge, airport terminals have been disinfected. As of now, we have not taken any decision to check the health of passengers coming to the departure area in both sectors. Basically, these screenings are based on central government’s rules. The state government will discuss the matter whether departure passengers should be health-screened,” Kumar told media at the airport.Meanwhile, a health official at Cial said that the screening of departing passengers needs to be implemented as the number of cases are increasing. “In case of an arriving passenger, who is found symptomatic, he will be directly taken to the hospital without allowing him to enter the terminal. As there is no check for departing passengers, an affected person can infect the entire terminal,” said the official.The review meeting was attended by district police chief (Ernakulam rural) K Karthick, Cial managing director V J Kurien, airport director ACK Nair, senior health officials, CISF officials and other agencies at the airport.

Title: 3 killed as rain, hailstorm lash parts of region
Content:
Hailstorm in Varanasi on Saturday

Varanasi: Heavy rain accompanied by hailstorm hit parts of the region overnight, claiming three lives in Mirzapur and causing serious damage to crops.

According to reports, two persons, Khilari Pal (65) and Jangali (62), were killed when they came under the debris of a wall that caved in due to heavy rain at Dhasara village in Lalganj area of Mirzapur late on Friday night. Kallu Pal (32) was also injured in the incident and was admitted to the Mirzapur Distict Hospital. In another incident, a 13-year-old girl, Bindiya, lost her life when a wall caved in at Gopalpur village in Kotwali Dehat area of Mirzapur. The police have sent the bodies for postmortem.

Earlier, a 35-year-old youth Ravi Seth, who was posted at Aurai police station, died after a branch of a tree fell on him due to thunderstorm in Bhadohi district on Thursday night.

The power supply from the Suriyawa sub-station was also disrupted after a tree fell on the high tension wire near Bankat village. Several old houses collapsed in Gopiganj due to heavy rains.

The standing crops of wheat and pea were also damaged in the fields. Bhadohi DM, Rajendra Prasad confirmed a casualty and said the authorities concerned are estimating the losses due to thunderstorm.

As many as 30 houses were damaged due to thunderstorm at Barahi Kala village in Pindra Tehsil. DM Kaushal Raj Sharma sent the ADM (finance & revenue) Satish Pal to take stock of the situation and asses the loss. Heavy hailstorm was also witnessed in the rural areas of Araziline block that damaged the crops.

Title: Extreme weather events on the rise, Delhi identifies 6 vulnerable sectors
Content:
New Delhi: Extreme weather events seem to be increasing in the capital over the last couple of decades, both in terms of temperature and precipitation. This can severely impact public health, increase power consumption, deplete water resources and damage crops, states Delhi’s newly drafted State Action Plan on Climate Change .

To cope up better, not only will Delhi have to focus on vulnerable sectors, but also on improving the transport and the land-use, the action plan adds. Delhi government has identified six “vulnerable” sectors, including healthcare, power and energy, water resources, urban planning, transport and the agriculture and forest sector, to combat climate change.

“Extreme minimum and maximum temperature events appear to be increasing in Delhi. In December 2006, Delhi had the lowest temperature since 1935 (0.2°C). In June 2007, Delhi witnessed a maximum of 44.9°C. While these extreme temperatures cannot be directly linked to climate change, variability in weather patterns and possibility of exacerbation of extreme events due to climate change are major challenges,” stated the action plan.

It added that there had been several months when temperature and precipitation were greater than standard deviation from the mean. “The hottest summer was in 1944, the coldest winter in 1935 and the wettest monsoon in 1958. However, recent years have seen similar extremes in temperature in 1978, 1988 and 1996 and precipitation in 1994, 1995, and 2003,” it added.

The annual mean temperature is expected to rise between 2.5°C and 5 °C across the country under a range of scenarios, with warming more pronounced in the northern parts of India. There may be a general increase in the precipitation in the monsoon season, but an overall decrease in the number of rainy days and an increased intensity of rainfall are likely in future years.

Similarly, projections run by Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology (IITM) indicate temperature changes of about 3 – 5°C and increase of about 5-10% in summer monsoon rainfall for India. It is also estimated that the number of rainy days may decrease by 20 to 30%.

“Extremes in temperature and rainfall are also expected to increase in their frequency and intensity by the end of the year 2100,” said the plan.

Delhi’s SAPCC has been drafted on the lines of the national action plan on climate change. The government of India and National Green Tribunal had directed each state to prepare an action plan to combat the local impacts and devise mitigation strategies.

Referring to the primary exposure of people to diseases like dengue and malaria and an increased mortality rate due to high temperatures, the plan states there could be a strong decline in the number of water sources, agricultural lands and forest lands in Delhi.

“Delhiites are prone to heat stress-related disorders, such as heat strokes, eye diseases like cataract, dry eyes and respiratory disorders, and skin diseases. It is estimated that for every one degree rise in temperature above 29 °C, there will be a four percent increase in risk of mortality. In addition to heat stress, the changes in climate can also lead to an increased occurrence of vector-borne diseases like dengue and malaria,” said the report, adding that increase in temperature will also push power demand greatly.

Title: NMC takes action against four restros
Content:
Nagpur: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has continued action against unauthorized restaurants. Action was taken against four restaurants in Bhagwagar Layout, Dharampeth, on Tuesday.

The team of NMC enforcement department and Dharampeth Zone demolished sheds, seating arrangements and kitchens of four restaurants cropped up in parking lots of buildings.

As per the press release of NMC, action was taken against Sandwich Factory-Tadka Restaurant, Pasta Fresca, Uptown Café Lounge and Firangish Café and Courtyard.

The NMC had demolished the rooftop restaurant of a bar and restaurant at Takli Sim and hotel in Sitabuldi a couple of days ago.

Many restaurants have cropped up in residential areas. A few residential bungalows were converted into lounges in various parts of the city. Apart from building violations, these restaurants pose threat of fire incidents. Still, the NMC has continued to turn a blind eye towards these violations.

Title: Stick to fresh deadline, get back Rs 7.74 crore: HC to NMC
Content:
NMC and MSEDCL have neglected the completion work despite the HC fixing a deadline

Nagpur: In a relief of sorts for the cash-strapped Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC), the Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court has assured the civic body that it would return the nine-year-old deposit of Rs5 crore as well as the accrued interest, Rs 2.74 crore, collectively Rs7.74 crore, subject to submission of a compliance report and a fresh deadline to complete the work of shifting electric poles and transformers from roads. The next hearing is slated for March 18.

Hearing suo motu public interest litigation (PIL) filed on the basis of a TOI report dated June 25, 2018, judges Sunil Shukre and Avinash Gharote in an order dated March 12 said, “We would request the NMC authorities to find ways and means to expeditiously complete the entire shifting work. The authorities of the corporation can meet, deliberate and come up with a reasonable time frame to complete the pending work. On an earlier occasion, the court had made an attempt to fix the deadline as January 31. That deadline is now a passe and the work is still going on. At this juncture, we would like to leave it to the good conscience of the authorities of NMC as well MSEDCL to complete this work, which is in public interest, as soon as possible. Accordingly, a time frame may also be placed before this court.”

Talking to TOI, amicus curiae Shreerang Bhandarkar said, “NMC and MSEDCL neglected the completion work despite the HC fixing the deadline.”

The judges also said, “Following the order passed by this court on March 6, the registry has placed on record an extract of the account in which the amount deposited in this court from time to time have been shown. Through details submitted by the Canara Bank, Rs5crore deposited as a principal sum has accrued Rs2.74 crore in interest as on March 7, making the total amount available in the account Rs7.74crore. This amount is to be remitted to the NMC, informed counsel Sudhir Puranik, for carrying out the work of shifting of electric poles for which it has also incurred the expenditure,” judges said.

The bench added, “However, before any order regarding disbursement of the amount is passed, it will be necessary for this court to verify the works actually done so far and the expenditure incurred for its completion. Therefore, we request the NMC to place on record the details of the work to be completed, name of the locality where the work has been done so far and the expenditure incurred and we would also request the NMC to place on record the detailed estimated cost of all the works which are required to be carried out in terms of various orders passed by this court,” judges said.

The NMC had widened 47 major roads under the Integrated Road Development Project (IRDP) project in 2001. The NMC was to first remove the electrical poles and transformers and then widen the roads. The roads were widened leaving the electric poles and transformers unmoved, causing accidents and congestion. Between 2014 and 2018, the NMC had removed electric poles and transformers from 28 roads and work on the remaining 19 roads were pending. After HC passed strictures, NMC started works on 19 roads and is yet to complete them.

THE LONG & SHORT OF IT

* NMC widened 47 major roads under the IRDP project in 2001 without removing electrical poles and transformers

* Electric poles and transformers on roads caused accidents and traffic congestion

* HC directed the NMC to remove them in 2011 and took a deposit of Rs5 crore from NMC and MSEDCL

* Between 2014 and 2018, electric poles and transformers were removed from 28 roads and works on the remaining 19 roads pending

* TOI highlighted NMC’s apathy on June 25, 2018 which was treated as suo motu PIL by HC

* NMC issued tenders for 19 roads but is yet to complete them

* NMC requested HC to return the Rs5 crore deposit

* HC assured to return Rs5 crore along with Rs2.74 crore as interest subject to the compliance report, submission of a fresh deadline and plan to finish pending work

Title: 41% drop in onion exports from Halcon this year
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: Onion exports from the inland container depot (ICD) of Halcon at Ozar has dropped by roughly 41% so far in the current financial year (2019-20) when compared to last year’s volume of trade.

Halcon is a joint venture between Hindustan Aeronautics Ltd and Container Corporation of India (Concor). According to the Agricultural and Processed Food Products Exports Development Authority (APEDA), 61,593 tonne of onions , valued at worth Rs 113 crore, were exported from Halcon between April 1 and March 15 in 2019-20. This suggests a by 40.77% drop in exports since 2018-19 when 1.04 lakh tonne of onions, worth Rs 154 crore, were exported during the corresponding period.

The Union commerce ministry had imposed a ban on onion exports in September 2019 following a sharp rise in the average wholesale prices due to scarcity of the produce. This led to the overall drop in onion exports during the current fiscal, said the Halcon sources.

The Centre lifted the ban on onion exports with effect from March 15. However, only 15 days are now remaining for the current financial year to end. Monday (March 16) will be the first day of business since the withdrawal of the ban. Therefore, the average wholesale onion prices are expected to increase by Rs 200 per quintal when the Lasalgaon APMC, the country’s largest wholesale onion market, reopens on Monday.

Apart from onions, fruits like grapes, pomegranates, mangoes and fresh vegetables are also exported to various countries from the ICD and air cargo complex of Halcon here.

Halcon has developed the ICD and air cargo complex to facilitate exports by sea and air. All the custom clearance facilities are carried out here and containers are directly exported via JNPT.

Title: NMC issues one-day ultimatum to scrap dealers in Nashik
Content:
The civic body took major drives against encroachments in the scrap markets in the past two-three years follow... Read More

NASHIK: The civic body on Sunday issued a 24-hour ultimatum to all dealers in the scrap market based on the Ambad-Satpur link road for removing encroachments.

A public notice was issued in this regard on Sunday by the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) that warned of a drive to demolish illegal structures and other encroachments in the scrap markets and confiscate the materials if the encroachments are not removed on their own.

The civic body took major drives against encroachments in the scrap markets in the past two-three years following directives from the Bombay high court. But few days after the drive encroachments resurfaced.

In January 2017, the civic administration had undertaken a major drive against encroachments by scrap dealers following directives from the high court and the drive continued for almost a week.

The materials seized by the civic body had to be lifted in as many as 169 trucks and tractors to the NMC’s Satpur Club House. A total of 450 police personnel and 350 NMC officials were part of the drive that included 14 cranes, 21 earthmovers, 42 dumpers and 32 truck/tractors.

The second drive was conducted in the same areas in the same year between October 12 and 14. Thereafter, NMC had also appointed a squad to keep an eye in these areas to ensure encroachments do not resurface, but it did not help.

“We had been planning to start a demolition drive against encroachments along the Ambad-Satpur link road for the past many months, but we did not receive police force,” an NMC official said.

“Last month, we wrote to the police last month requesting security to carry out the drive. We received a nod from the police administration for providing security from this week. Hence, we have given an ultimatum of 24 hours to the encroachers to remove the encroachment on their own. The demolition drive will begin soon,” he added.

Title: Chance to handle PM’s twitter a nod to my work: Kalpana
Content:
Hyderabad: City-based architect and a volunteer with SAHE (Society for Advancement of Human Endeavour) Kalpana Ramesh , who was recently selected as the PM ’s ‘magnificent seven’ on Women’s Day, says she felt empowered and saw it as an acknowledgment of her work.

“I have been working on this mission to conserve water for the last eight years and to be selected to be a part of a small group of seven persons from across the country came as a huge surprise and honour. I also think that water conservation is something very close to the PM’s heart and my work in urban areas may have struck a chord,” she said.

The dependence of people on water tankers was something that worried her after she moved to Hyderabad from the US more than a decade ago. “I noticed that residents in my locality in Gachibowli were heavily dependent on tankers. I began harvesting rainwater and we began saving up on water and electricity bills. In 2016, despite four months of intense summer, we did not requisition a single tanker. ”

Kalpana has been harvesting rainwater at her home by installing rainwater harvesting pits that pass through a sump and through a bed of coal and sand for purification, which can be used for many purposes. “Rainwater does not have to be purified much. Thanks to Make in India initiatives, modular RWH pits are now manufactured in Delhi. Most of the water that we use, 20% is black water and the rest is grey water, which can be recycled,” she says.

The advantage is that this helps in prevention of sewage overflow and urban flooding, which damage the roads since the waste water discharge is minimal.

The ‘Save 10k Bores’ initiative that was spearheaded by her has also helped revive defunct borewells with the help of rainwater. By directing rainwater to a harvesting pit, several borewells have been revived through community initiatives.

Taken aback by the condition of the lakes in the city, the water warrior says that most of the lakes have turned into cesspools. “During the TedX Salon event, I saw Gandipet lake which was sufficient to meet the city’s water requirements. With the lake going dry during summer, we are moving from one water body to another to meet our needs. We cannot go on sucking out the resources,” she said.

She said a collective effort is the need of the hour by involving the people. “The RWH pits that are installed in the cities are just for namesake. Also, more STPs must be set up to recycle grey water,” she said.

Quoting Niti Aayog which said that by end of 2020, cities would run out of groundwater, she said her aim is to go block by block and reach out to as many people as possible to spread awareness on 3Rs (reuse, reduce and recycle) of water.

Title: Valpoi parish priest killed in road accident
Content:
Valpoi: Fr Daniel Alfonso, 59, the parish priest of Our Lady of Lourdes Church, Valpoi , died in a hit-and-run accident on Sunday.

Police sources said an unidentified vehicle hit Alfonso’s two-wheeler while he was proceeding to Advoi at 6pm. The priest, who had sustained serious injuries to his head and multiple fractures to his limbs, was first taken to the Valpoi community health centre and then moved to Goa Medical College ( GMC ) and Hospital, Bambolim. Valpoi police are investigating. TNN

Title: Covid-19 in West Bengal: Border vigil beefed up, movement restricted
Content:
(Contributed by Sudipta Das, Sanjib Chakraborty, Asish Poddar, Pinakpriya Bhattacharya, Roshan Gupta, Subhro Maitra, Subhojyoti Kanjilal)

KOLKATA: Movement of people via all nine international land checkposts in West Bengal was restricted from March 15 midnight in the wake of the evolving situation concerning the spread of novel coronavirus in the country. The Union home ministry guidelines allowed entry of Indian citizens from Bangladesh, Nepal and Bhutan, and permitted exit of citizens of these three countries through the checkposts. Monitoring was also heightened at 78 inter-state checkpoints across West Bengal.“People from Nepal and Bhutan will be allowed to go to their respective countries only through Jaigaon and Panitanki checkposts,” said Srikumar Bandyopadhyay, inspector general of SSB (Siliguri frontier). “Movement will be restricted at all the land checkposts, except Gede,” said Vibhu Goyel, district magistrate of Nadia.Movement through the checkposts came down to a trickle on Sunday. The Petrapol border looked empty with trucks lined up away from the border checkposts. Shyamali Paribahan, which used to run at least six buses every day between Kolkata and Dhaka, has been operating just one bus between Kolkata and Petrapole for the past three days. “There were 30 passengers from Kolkata on Saturday. The number came down to 18 on Sunday,” said Pranab Ghosh, of Shyamali Paribahan.“March is a crucial month for India-Bangladesh trade, which has tanked following the emerging situation,” said Kartik Chakraborty, secretary of Customs Clearing Agents’ Association. There were nearly 1,000 people, mostly Bangladeshis, at the Gede checkpost, Nadia, on Sunday morning.A total of 78 checkposts were put up across Bengal to man inter-state movements. The highest number of checkpoints were allocated in districts like Purulia, Birbhum and Uttar Dinajpur. “We may increase number of checkposts depending on the traffic,” said Gyanwant Singh, ADG (law and order) West Bengal.At the medical camps, people were being screened into four grades — A, B, C and D — depending on their symptoms. Persons falling under grade A classification, with symptoms like fever, cough and difficulty in breathing and with history of travelling to any foreign country in past 14 days are being immediately shifted to hospitals.District Magistrate Rajarshi Mitra said, “We have set up a screening camp at Madhupur at Indo-Bangla border.”Vigil was also stepped up at the checkposts in north Bengal. “The vigil from both the central and state governments is praiseworthy. Darjeeling, Terai and Dooars receives people from adjoining countries, which puts locals at risk of contracting Covid-19,” said Raju Bista, MP, Darjeeling.

Title: SDMC plans curbs to step up coronavirus fight
Content: NEW DELHI: In the wake of the novel coronavirus outbreak , swimming pools, night clubs, spa centres and discotheques in south Delhi are expected to be temporarily shut down as a precautionary measure. Space restrictions will also be imposed on the banquet halls hosting weddings in the time of an epidemic.Soon, South Delhi Municipal Corporation (SDMC) is likely to make the announcement. A senior municipal corporation official told TOI that a notice regarding these restrictions may be released on Monday.On Sunday, SDMC commissioner Gyanesh Bharti called a review meeting of public health department on the steps to be taken to tackle coronavirus threat. “Several measures to control highly crowded places have been discussed. We will increase the capacity of quarantine ward facility in Kalkaji hospital from 30 to 50 beds,” the official added.Another senior municipal official said that swimming pools, discotheques and spa centres will be asked to shut down to prevent any form of contamination. These restrictions will apply till the epidemic does not come under control, he added.About the restrictions on banquet halls, the official said that such establishments will have to ensure that each person has a minimum space of 1.5 square metres during the functions.“This will check crowding. For instance, if a banquet hall is spread over an area of 100 square metres, the organisers will not be allowed to have more than 65-66 people in the function,” he explained.The same space restriction will be applicable for other similar establishments and social gathering venues as well. “We will impose severe penalties and the licences may be revoked if the rules are not adhered to by the owners or the managers,” another official said.Delhi government had recently said that a gathering of more than 200 people should not be allowed.However, the weekly markets and vegetable as well as grocery shops will be exempted from the restrictions. “If we close them, it will lead to severe shortage of the items of daily need,” the official added.The new regulations will severely affect the functioning of south Delhi commercial hubs, such as Hauz Khas, Mahipalpur, Rajouri Garden, Tilak Nagar, Shahpur Jat, Chhatarpur, Sainik farms, Bijwasan and Kapashera.As many as 1,130 spa centres, 37 motels and 41 social function farmhouses function in SDMC.

Title: Maoists trigger blast, fire on police, flee
Content:
Nagpur: A squad of Hedri Armed Out Post and Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) thwarted a Maoist attack in Bodmeta forest in south Gadchiroli on Sunday. The reds triggered a blast and followed it by firing on the combined squad before fleeing the place.

The security forces, after surviving the blast, managed to dispose of another Improvised Explosive Device (IED) planted at the site where the Maoists were camping. The Maoists had earlier taken the patrolling party by surprise with the blast followed by heavy firing, but had to retreat once the security forces retaliated.

The Maoists fled the place leaving behind their belongings. The security forces seized substantial material from the camping site, including literature.

Title: 2 youths thrashed and forced to drink urine, battle for life
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

PATNA: In a shocking incident, two youths were kidnapped, tied to a tree and mercilessly beaten up before being forced to drink urine in full public view in Muzaffarpur district , police said on Sunday.

The victims — Abhay Kumar (26) and Ranjan Kumar (28) — are battling for life at Sri Krishna Medical College and Hospital (SKMCH) in Muzaffarpur. Six people have been named as accused in the FIR lodged with Kudhani police station in the district.

The victims told the police that they were held captive by some people travelling in an SUV near Balia Chowk under Kudhani police station when they were on way to meet a family acquaintance on their motorbike in the morning. The kidnappers took them to an orchard, tied to a tree and thrashed till they fainted.

The offenders didn’t stop there. They forced the victims to drink urine and threatened them with dire consequences if they reported the incident to the police. The locals later admitted the injured to the SKMCH where the Ahiyapur police recorded their statement and forwarded the same to Kudhani police for further action.

Kudhani police station SHO Arvind Prasad said nine people — Rakesh Kumar, Saket Kumar, Sachin Kumar , Amlesh Kumar, Dinesh Kumar, Ratnesh Kumar Singh, Subhash Kumar , Virajman Singh and Chandan Kumar — stated to be the residents of Anant Kamtaul and Jagdish Kamtaul villages, have been made named accused in the case.

The SHO said raids were on to trace the SUV used in the crime. Old enmity is stated to be the reason behind the murderous attack on Abhay and Ranjan, he said, adding that some of the accused have criminal antecedents.

The incident has sparked off tension in the area. The police didn’t rule out the possibility of retaliation from the victims’ side. “We have taken all precautionary measures to ward off any untoward incident,” the SHO said over phone.

Title: Covid-19: UK man escaped after health officials left KTDC hotel
Content: KOCHI: The 19-member tourist team from UK, who stayed at KTDC’s Tea County resort in Munnar, reportedly waited till the health officials left the hotel so that they could vacate and leave for Kochi airport as pre-planned, said sources.The district health officials had asked the tourist team to remain in quarantine though they had planned to leave for Dubai from Kochi airport on Sunday morning in an Emirates flight. They left the resort on Saturday night around 10:30 after the health officials left the place, said Idukki district administration sources.As the authorities pass the buck following the controversy, Idukki district collector H Dineshan will submit a report to government on Monday.Devikulam sub-collector S Premkrishnan said that the 19-member team reached Munnar on March 10. The 57-year-old UK man showed fever symptoms on the same day and reported at Munnar General Hospital. As the man showed Covid-19 symptoms, health officials directed him and other members to be in quarantine. On March 11 night, the man was shifted to Kottayam Medial College and samples were collected for tests and he returned to the Munnar hotel on March 12.“Then onwards the 19-member team was under quarantine in the resort. On March 13, the team visited Mattuppetty but returned immediately. On Saturday night, they wanted to check out from the hotel and hence paid the bills. They left the hotel at 10:30pm without informing the health officials,” said Premkrishnan.The team left in a tempo-traveller arranged by a Thiruvananthapuram-based travel agency and reached Cochin international airport around 3. 30am. “The Tea County manager failed to inform health officials when the guests sought to vacate the hotel. Considering the seriousness of the situation the manger should not have allowed them to leave without prior permission from the health department,” said Dineshan.The issue came to light only when the doctor called the Tea County manager to know the health status of the UK man around 8.30 am on Sunday. “The doctor alerted the officials and we informed Ernakulam district administration that blocked their travel. The 22 hotel officials, who had primary contact with them are under quarantine at hotel,” said Premkrishnan.Meanwhile, a five-star hotel in the Kochi where the 19-member tourist team stayed during March 6 to 8, has asked 38 of its staff to be in home-quarantine. “We have found that 38 of our staff members came in direct contact with the UK tourists. We have informed the district health officials and their health checkup was completed,” said a hotel staff.

Title: RFID tab: ‘Commercial PM count down by 95%’
Content: NEW DELHI: Use of radio frequency identification ( RFID ) system at toll booths seems to be paying dividends as far as checking pollution level in the capital is concerned.According to a report submitted by Environment Pollution (Prevention and Control) Authority ( EPCA ) to the Supreme Court , total particulate matter (PM) emissions from the commercial vehicles entering Delhi through the 13 main border points where RFID system is installed have fallen by 95% in the past five years. The total NOx emissions due to light and heavy good carriers have fallen by 87-94% since 2015.EPCA says there has been a considerable drop in the total number of commercial vehicles entering Delhi through these 13 border points. Construction of eastern and western peripheral expressways and collection of Environment Compensation Charge have helped the city, it adds.The SC-appointed body said it compared data provided in 2015 and in 2019-2020 to determine the average number of light good carriers and heavy good carriers entering the national capital through the border points.“The results from the 13 points in the city are substantial and suggest that the efforts to mitigate pollution have been rewarded. Compared with 2015, there is a 95 percent reduction in the total particulate load from the trucks,” said the report.While the PM emissions from light good carriers and heavy good carriers in 2015 were 0.6 and 1.2 tonnes per day, respectively, this has now come down to just 0.03 and 0.06 tonnes per day – a reduction of 95 percent in both.The study revealed that NOx emissions from the light good carriers were down by 94 percent – from 3 tonnes per day to just 0.19 tonnes per day. For heavy good carriers, it went down by 87 percent – from 10 tonnes per day to 1.30 tonnes per day.Data from SDMC , SAFAR and a CPCB report were used to study the impact of RFID toll booths on the pollution in the national capital.The EPCA report stated the total average number of light good carriers was down from 12,985 vehicles per day in 2015 to 900 vehicles per day in December 2019. Similarly, the number of two-axle trucks came down from 4,058 vehicles per day in 2015 to 871 vehicles per day in December 2019.The Supreme Court-appointed EPCA in its report also urges the apex court to issue further directions to cover 10 more border points in Delhi through similar RFID toll booths. These include Noida Major, Loni Main, Dhansa border, Kundli-II, New Seelampur 1st, Bajghera, New Kondli, Chander Nagar, Jharoda and Pul Prahladpur. Another 101 points identified can be covered through hand-held RFID readers, it suggested.

Title: Infrared thermometer shortage plagues hosps
Content:
Kolkata: Infrared thermometers, which have seen a sudden spurt in demand, ever since the Covid-19 outbreak are short in supply. Several private hospitals in Kolkata have been finding it difficult to procure them and are waiting for supplies to arrive from China.

Along with several other drugs that have been short in supply, following import restrictions from China, infra-red thermometers, too, have been scarce.

In its visitor protocol for hospitals, the Association of National Board Accredited Institutions have recommended use of infrared thermometers to check temperature. It has also recommended use of technology and instruments to reduce physical contact. While most hospitals have been following the protocol, some said they need more thermometers. “Thermometers are imported from China so there is an import issue there. Masks and hand sanitizers have also been impacted since most manufacturers/distributors have started exporting them due to greater demand abroad,” said RTIICS zonal director R Venkatesh.

Another private hospital spokesperson said they it had placed an order for thermometers two weeks back but they are yet to get them.

Title: Nashik: Forum directs insurance firm to pay in full
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The District Consumers Disputes Redressal Forum has ordered an insurance company to settle the claims of two consumers in full for unlawfully ‘forcing’ a one-time settlement (OTS) on them.

In its March 5 judgement in two separate complaints filed by Harsul traders, the forum headed by its president Milind Sonawane pointed out that the claim was forcibly settled in only half the amount, despite all the factors indicating that there was a complete loss as claimed by the complainants. Hence, the forum ordered the company to settle the claims in full along with a 10 percent interest on the balance amount from Feb 15, 2016, till date with an additional Rs 10,000 for mental harassment.

The consumers — Shaikh Atik Haji Abdul Samad and Shaikh Shehbad Jahi Abdul Samad — had insured their garment shops and goods with the New India Assurance Company in their shop for Rs 15 lakh each. On July 14, 2015, both the shops were totally damaged in the riots that broke out in the village. A survey of the damages was done after riots, in which the police estimated 100 percent loss, while the insurance company put up losses at around 45 percent only.

As part of the OTS, the insurance company offered Rs 6.67 lakh to Shaikh Atik and Rs 6.08 lakh to Shaikh Shehbad. Both the traders accepted the OTS and challenged the same in consumer forum on July 28, 2017.

FG Inamdar, the counsel, for the two traders, said, “The company has thrown to the wind the recommendations by the police, that there was a hundred percent loss of the clients. Instead, the surveyor surprisingly has cut down the losses to just 45 percent.”

The insurance firm counsel SC Abhyankar stated that the losses were exaggerated by the consumers. The income tax returns and other documents reveal that the losses were calculated by the company on a fair side without any injustice upon the consumers.

The forum, however, ruled the decision in the favour of consumers after checking the relevant documents and ordered the compensation to the insurance company.

Title: Board strives to retain green character of Deolali
Content:
Representative image

The 150-year-old Cantonment Board, Deolali , has over 50,000 residents staying in the area. Making every effort to be a smart cantonment, the board has taken several steps to make it a happy abode for residents. TOI’s Pragya Jain spoke to Ajay Kumar , chief executive officer of the cantonment board about his plans for the welfare of residents.

How do you plan to upgrade infrastructure of the cantonment area?

We have repaired all our internal and main roads to facilitate better commute for the residents. They will be in better shape with some more funds. This should solve a long unresolved issue. Apart from schools and hospital, our library and gymnasium are also functioning well. Although our shopping complex plan has hit a roadblock, we are working towards reviving it.

The board has come up with its maiden Sewage Treatment Plant with over Rs 58 crores. Please share details of the project.

We have set up our state-of-the-art Sewage Treatment Plant (STP) with the capacity of 11 MLD (million litres per day) which is currently operational. At present, we are driving out the residue into the downstream of Darna river , but we have big plans in the coming year to use the residual water.

The board had distributed two coloured dustbins to the residents last year. How is the response?

We have recently equipped the board with the solid waste management plant which is working effectively. We have started generating manure from 30 tonnes of waste per day. As far as the response from the residents is concerned, our 11 ghantagadis go from door to door in all the eight wards to collect dry and wet waste separately. We monitor the ghantagadis using GPS and ensure that they collect the garbage from every ward properly.

Monsoon is about to come in a few months. It creates havoc in the cantonment area every year. How is it preparedness for it this year?

We are cleaning the drains already. Now that the STP work is complete on both sides of the roads and the roads are also repaired, there should not be any issue during monsoon this year.

There is no entertainment hub in Deolali. Do you have any plans?

Ans: As the permitted FSI (floor space index) in this area is only 0.5, it hampers the infrastructural growth in many ways. But, we have plans to construct some recreational sports faciility for children in the jogging park area. There is some idle place around it where we can put up a bumper car sport and few others for children to play. The plan should materialise within six months. We also plan to keep the green character of Deolali intact and, for which, we plan to have more trees in the newly developed areas.

Title: Toddler falls from 2nd floor balcony, dies
Content:
Nagpur: A two-and-a-half-year-old girl fell to death from balcony of her second-floor residence in Saket Nagar in Beltarodi in the city on Saturday. The deceased has been identified as Unika Turale.

According to police, Unika’s mother was feeding her in the balcony. After a while her mother went to kitchen to bring food leaving the toddler alone. Unika stood up holding a small pipe near the parapet wall and climbed on it. She lost balance and fell to the ground.

The incident was spotted by neighbours who raised alarm and Unika’s family members rushed out. The girl was rushed to a private hospital where she was declared brought dead.

Cops said the toddler managed to climb on the parapet wall because of iron pipes at its bottom.

Beltarodi police have registered a case of accidental death following information from the hospital.

Title: Gutka worth Rs 47,000 seized from Satana
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The special squad of Nashik rural police have seized gutka worth Rs 47,000 from Satana on Sunday.

The raid was conducted on a shop along Tilak Road, Maulana Azad Chowk in Satana.

Acting on a tip-off, the police raided the shop and found a 30-year-old man selling gutkha and other banned tobacco products.

The police said that they have also seized an auto-rickshaw of the shopkeeper in which some stock of the banned tobacco products were found. The seized gutkha has been handed over to the Foods and Drugs Administration (FDA) Nashik for further legal action against the shopkeeper.

Title: NMC takes action against four restros
Content:
Nagpur: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has continued action against unauthorized restaurants. Action was taken against four restaurants in Bhagwagar Layout, Dharampeth, on Tuesday.

The team of NMC enforcement department and Dharampeth Zone demolished sheds, seating arrangements and kitchens of four restaurants cropped up in parking lots of buildings.

As per the press release of NMC, action was taken against Sandwich Factory-Tadka Restaurant, Pasta Fresca, Uptown Café Lounge and Firangish Café and Courtyard.

The NMC had demolished the rooftop restaurant of a bar and restaurant at Takli Sim and hotel in Sitabuldi a couple of days ago.

Many restaurants have cropped up in residential areas. A few residential bungalows were converted into lounges in various parts of the city. Apart from building violations, these restaurants pose threat of fire incidents. Still, the NMC has continued to turn a blind eye towards these violations.

Title: Mopa airport will create 8,000 jobs for locals: CM
Content:
Bicholim: Once the greenfield Mopa International Airport is commissioned, around 8,000 jobs will be created for locals in the next two years, and many more jobs after that, chief minister Pramod Sawant said.

“This will help resolve the state’s employment problem to a large extent,” Sawant said, calling on people to vote for BJP at the forthcoming zilla panchayat (ZP) elections.

Sawant was addressing a gathering at Mayem recently during his visit to Mayem and Kudne constituencies in Bicholim taluka.

Stating that both, the central and state BJP governments have always attempted to initiate a variety of schemes for the welfare of people, he said that in the future too, the government will introduce many more novel schemes.

He also said that in future, elected ZP members will be given additional powers to undertake development works in their areas.

Sawant, accompanied by Mayem MLA Pravin Zantye and Mayem ZP candidate Shankar Chodankar, later toured Chorao, Kudchirem, Mayem, Narvem, Karapur, Piligao, Shirgao and Kudnem villages.

Title: Alarm in Buldhana, markets close over corona death rumours
Content:
Nagpur: Panic gripped Buldhana city on Sunday after a rumour spread that the 75-year-old man, who died in the isolation ward of district hospital on Saturday, was infected with Covid-19 virus.

Even as authorities clarified on Sunday afternoon that the man was not infected, and he died of natural causes, markets and shops remained closed for most of the day. The deceased was a resident of a suburb of Buldhana. People in his locality were in panic due to the rumours.

“A lot of media persons called me regarding the death of a person yesterday at Buldhana District Hospital . The deceased was not infected with Covid-19,” tweeted Buldhana district collector Suman Rawat Chandra. “However, please continue to take precautions and follow all guidelines in this regard. We are committed to your health and safety, and need your invaluable cooperation in defeating corona,” she added.

Buldhana civil surgeon Dr Premchand Pandit confirmed the burial of this person was conducted on Saturday late night itself.

Meanwhile, on Sunday, a team of 12 tourists — five from Malaysia and seven from Indonesia arrived to Khamgaon, a tehsil headquarters, some 52km away from Buldhana. These tourists were in Khamgaon for religious purposes. Three of them developed cough and cold so they were admitted to the general hospital at Khamgaon.

The remaining nine are healthy, but they were sent to Buldhana and admitted to the local Ladies hospital as a precautionary measure . Samples of three patients admitted in Khamgaon will be collected and sent for testing while the other nine will be kept under observation for next 14 days.

Title: 899 more birds culled in Malappuram
Content:
Malappuram: In an effort to curb the spread of bird flu to more areas, authorities continued with culling of poultry and pet birds in Parappanangadi region on Sunday. A total of 899 birds were culled in Parappanangadi municipality and Chuzhali regions of Munniyur grama panchayat.

Authorities, on Thursday, had confirmed the presence of H5N1, a type of influenza virus that causes highly infectious and severe respiratory disease in birds, in Parappanangadi and Tirurangadi regions of the district. Human cases of H5N1, however, are rare.

The culling began on Saturday in Palathingal region. On Sunday morning, rapid response teams, which were specially formed to curtail bird flu, culled birds collected from 81 houses in Chuzhali areas in Munniyur. Their carcasses were burnt at a government-owned vacant plot at Chiramangalam.

The culling process is expected to be completed by Monday.

Along with mopping, which is the final procedure, a massive disinfection drive would also be held in the coming days.

On March 18, a special culling programme would be conducted with an aim to ensure that all poultry and pet birds were culled in the region.

Ten rapid response teams are engaged in culling process. Staff of local body members are also joining the team. Veterinary authorities have already opened round-the-clock control rooms at Malappuram and Tirurangadi to support public in view of report of the disease. The preventive measures would continue for three months in the district.

Title: Scrap dealer duped of Rs20 lakh in Nashik
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: A scrap dealer has been cheated of Rs 20 lakh on the pretext of buying industrial scrap from the accused.

The complainant — Nisar Ahmed Aslam Khan (55) — has a shop on Ambad-Satara link road. He has lodged a complaint in this regard at Ambad police station.

According to police, the accused approached Khan with a proposal to buy scrap industrial machinery worth Rs 20 lakh. Khan agreed to the deal on April 25, 2019, and since then he kept paying the money to the accused in installments.

However, even after paying the entire sum, the accused did not hand over the scrap machinery following which Khan approached the police and lodged a complaint. “We are investigating the case and will soon reach out to the accused,” an officer from Ambad police station said.

Title: Waste To Wonder Park open, but coronavirus scare leads to dip in footfall
Content: NEW DELHI: With appeals being made to the general public to avoid crowded places and the newfound emphasis on “social distancing” to slow down the spread of the novel coronavirus, the footfall in popular public areas like the Waste to Wonder Park was found to be severely reduced on the weekend. Similar scenes of reduced crowd were witnessed at India Gate, which is usually brimming with visitors from across the country on Sunday.A senior municipal official from South Delhi Municipal Corporation, which runs the Waste to Wonder Park at Sarai Kale Khan, said the tourist place has seen a reduction in footfall due to the ongoing school examinations, while the numbers have further dipped due to the scare created by Covid-19. “We are witnessing a drop of 30% in average footfall,” the official said.He added that several precautions are being taken to disinfect the common surfaces. “We regularly sanitise the common touchpoints, ticket counters, gates and railings using a sodium hypochlorite solution to avoid any kind of contamination,” he added.The weekend is usually the busiest time for the small park that hosts replicas of the Seven Wonders of the World created from recycled scrap metal, and in the past, the numbers have crossed 15,000 a day against the capacity of 10,000 people.While the municipal body has decided to introduce curbs on pubs, swimming pools and large gatherings, questions are now being raised about whether the park should continue to remain open during the state-declared epidemic.The spokesperson of SDMC said that all precautions are being taken and no decision has been taken yet to close Waste to Wonder Park, but a review meeting has been called on Monday to assess the restrictions and the matter will be taken up.The park features a 60-ft Eiffel Tower, a 20-ft Taj Mahal and replicas of five other Wonders of the World, built using 150 tonnes of industrial and other waste in south Delhi, and was thrown open to the public on February 22 last year. In July 2019, SDMC had to hike the price to limit the incoming volume of visitors, but the weekend rush still remained over 10,000 people.

Title: Masks and gloves: Kochi corporation’s waste problem just got messier
Content: KOCHI: Kochi, which has been grappling with disposal of bio-medical waste generated at homes and apartment complexes, now has another alarming problem at hand: Disposing of clinal waste generated as part of measures taken to fight Covid-19.In the absence of incinerators and trained workers to handle clinical waste, masks and gloves end up along with food waste and plastic at the garbage dump at Brahmapuram waste treatment plant. Residents of apartment complexes and houses, which do not have a proper system to treat bio-medical waste, admit they dump clinical waste along with other wastes. Not all people have the space to burn the waste as directed by Kochi corporation.“When bio-medical waste is left with plastic waste stacked on the premises of the building, stray dogs and cats, which get its smell, dig into them, scattering them everywhere. We are left with no option but to wrap them in paper and dump them with food waste. As long as there is no plastic in food waste, it goes unnoticed by the garbage collectors,” said a resident of an apartment on condition of anonymity.The untreated masks, gloves and other protective gears that end up at Brahmapuram waste treatment plant pose a threat to the workers employed at the plant as well. Kunnathunadu MLA V P Sajeendran said he will take up the matter with Kochi corporation. The contingent workers handling waste in the city need to be provided awareness and also training on how to handle clinical waste, especially protective gears, he said.Ernakulam District Residents Association Apex Council (EDRAAC) president P Rangadasa Prabu said, “We have been repeatedly asking the Kochi corporation to remove plastic waste on a regular basis from homes and apartments or from a designated point in each division. Despite all the talking, the trucks come to collect plastic waste once in 15 days or so. The plastic waste which contains bio-medical waste as well, is stacked on the premises of residential buildings for days. It is an unhealthy and unhygienic practice. The corporation should immediately address the issue.”Meanwhile, large apartment complexes maintained that they follow the guidelines issued by Kerala Builders Forum (KBF) regarding waste disposal or that their waste disposal is carried out under the supervision of Credai. “In such places, none of the waste generated in the apartment complex, leaves the building premises. They are segregated and processed scientifically. Credai also provides a monthly training for the workers employed in the residential complexes. They are provided with masks, gloves and other protective gears while handling waste,” said the representative of a premium apartment complex in the city.

Title: Stick to EPCA plan at pollution hotspots: DPCC
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: Delhi Pollution Control Committee has asked all landowning agencies and civic bodies to take stringent enforcement action and implement the hotspot plan “as cleared by Supreme Court-appointed Environment Pollution (Prevention and Control) Authority” in the 14 pollution hotspots of the capital, even though the grim winter pollution period is over.

In a letter addressed by DPCC member secretary Arun Mishra, a copy of which is with TOI, the agencies have been asked to ensure that there are no instances of waste and garbage burning and full compliance of the approved fuel notification, especially in the 14 highly polluted areas of the city, is done.

The 14 highly polluted areas in Delhi include Okhla Phase II, Dwarka, Ashok Vihar, Bawana, Narela, Mundka, Punjabi Bagh, Wazirpur, Rohini, Vivek Vihar, Anand Vihar (including Mandoli), RK Puram, Jahangirpuri and Mayapuri.

The communique has been sent to the nodal officers, civic body deputy commissioners, Delhi Development Authority, New Delhi Municipal Council , the three municipal corporation, PWD, irrigation and flood control department, CPWD, DSIIDC, DMRC , Delhi Cantonment Board and National Highways Authority of India, among others.

“In case of non-compliance, action as per the provisions contained in Section 37 of the Air Act, 1981, shall be initiated against defaulters,” the letter stated.

Earlier in February, Delhi environment minister Gopal Rai had shared data on how air pollution at 13 major hotspots in the capital had come down “significantly” in 2019 as compared with the last year. Rai also released a five-point action plan to bring air pollution down by one-third over the next five years.

The action plan included induction of real-time data to identify sources, an experts’ roundtable, a citywide awareness drive and planting over two crore trees in the next five years.

Title: Coronavirus in Delhi: Four cases prompt survey in busy Janakpuri hub
Content: NEW DELHI: With four cases of novel coronavirus infection being confirmed from the Janakpuri-Uttam Nagar region, South Delhi Municipal Corporation (SDMC) has intensified its efforts to contain its spread and prevent any panic among common people in the area.As part of the drive, the SDMC commissioner and area representatives visited the area’s busy commercial hub on Saturday. Standing committee member and former mayor Narendra Chawla said focussed steps were being taken in the belt to fight the virus. “We inspected the district centre, the busiest commercial hub in the region, and appealed to traders to keep hand sanitisers for everyone,” Chawla said.The environment management services department has been asked to make soaps available at multiple high footfall points along with water. “Soaps have already been provided at all public utilities and common surfaces are being disinfected with a solution of sodium hypochlorite,” he said.The deputy commissioner of the west zone said public announcements were being made with the help of 29 mega mikes and hired autos to spread awareness about Covid-19.The public health official who is leading the drive said four cases had been confirmed in the region with one death. Capacity-building exercises, he added, have been carried out so that any suspected case can be isolated immediately.“The surveillance system has been made more robust. All 33 hotels in the zone are reporting daily about any new arrival and the compiled data is being sent to the district surveillance officer,” the officer said. “One suspected case at a hotel and was sent to RML Hospital.”Grassroots-level staff, departmental heads and councillors, who have been trained about safety steps, are also disseminating the information, the officer said. “We have also briefed them that not everyone needs a mask,” he added.To spread awareness, all restaurants and hotels have been given banners and handbills to help them understand the symptoms and hygiene steps such as hand washing, another health official said. These establishments have been told not to allow any staffer with cough-sneezing symptoms at work.

Title: Kalamandalam checks CCTV footage
Content:
Representative image

THRISSUR: Kalamandalam authorities said the visitor from the UK, who was tested positive for Covid- 19 infections on Friday, did not move around the campus as he was denied permission at visitors’ registration counter itself.

However, the authorities said they are examining CCTV visuals to track his movements on the campus. “We had stopped receiving visitors from March 6 itself in the backdrop of the Covid-19 cases. This person is known to have come to the Kalamandalam on March 9, but the staff members at the visitors’ registration counter turned him back after checking with higher officials,’’ said vice-chancellor of Kalamandalam prof T K Narayanan.

The health department officials had visited the Kalamandalam for collecting details on the visit of the UK citizen. According to Cheruthuruthi police, there were 19 members in the group containing the UK national and they had checked in at River Retreat Hotel on the banks of Bharathappuzha on March 8 evening.

Majority of them were women, and some of them were aged, and they left in the morning on March 10. The hotel was closed.The group had also visited the nearby art institution Kalatharangini, and spent about two hours there on March 9. The staff who had come in contact with the visitor have also been asked to stay back there.

On the other side, the police officials and health authorities are trying to track the movement of the British citizen and other members of the group at Athirappilli and Chalakkudy. A police official said as per the preliminary reports they had not stayed at Athirapilli or Chalakkudy, and had returned after the visit. However they had taken a food from a hotel at Chalakkudy, he said.

Title: Once again, fire breaks out at Sonsoddo garbage dump in Goa
Content:
Five firefighters were engaged in dousing the fire that broke out in the sanitary landfill-end

MARGAO: A fire broke out at the garbage dump at Sonsoddo on Sunday evening causing anxiety among locals and triggering memories of the blaze that engulfed the area for nearly a week in May last year.

Firefighters were engaged in the firefighting exercise until Sunday night.

Nitin Raikar, deputy director of fire and emergency services, who was supervising the firefighting said that five tenders were used for the operations until 8pm.

“The fire has been brought under control. We have now requisitioned mud for dousing the flames,” Raikar said, adding that the cause of the fire that broke out in the sanitary landfill-end is yet to be ascertained.

Following last year’s week-long fire at Sonsoddo, a survey worker suffered burn injuries from electrocution in another fire incident on June 5.

The level staff held by him atop the baled stack of dry waste had accidentally touched the overhead 33KV high tension electric line thereby electrocuting him. The spark generated by the short circuit had triggered a raging fire as the large stack of dry waste piled up near the legacy dump went up in flames.

Title: Traders brace for losses as public places remain shut due to COVID-19 scare
Content: Dehradun: A day after Uttarakhand government declared coronavirus an epidemic in the state and ordered the shut down of colleges and cinema halls, the business community has expressed concern over the losses they are facing and will face due to a dip in the footfall at public spaces.On Sunday, the historic Jhanda Mela celebrations at Darbar Sahib, which usually last for a month, had to be concluded on the third day itself after Mahant Devendra Das, head of Darbar Sahib, in his address, told the visitors that celebrations are being called off early, in the interest of the people. The visitors had come from different states and even from across the border.Once the people started vacating Darbar Sahib, the shops outside were also closed down. Hotel owners in the city meanwhile claimed that though coronavirus was declared an epidemic on Saturday (March 14), the tourism business has been suffering for almost 15 days now.The number of bookings, they alleged, had been shrinking day by day and events were being rapidlycancelled as people were avoiding coming for large gatherings.Hotelier SP Kochar, who is also the president of Doon Valley Hotels and Restaurants Association, told TOI, “The losses that we have incurred due to the coronavirus scare are beyond imagination. State government should ensure that people are taking all preventive measures but also ensure that a panic situation isn’t created.”He further said that the losses are such that business owners fear that they won’t have enough money for daily operational costs and even for paying monthly salaries to their employees. “Many families depend on the hospitality business in our state. We must get past this panic situation soon,” added Kochar. Amit Sharma, general manager of a city-based hotel, told TOI, “The scare is such that several private event bookings and government programmes have been cancelled. The last minute cancellations are denting our business. We just hope that the situation improves soon.”Besides prominent hotels, caterers are also bearing the brunt as several orders have been cancelled in the last one week. Suresh Gupta, a caterer, told TOI, “We had orders for events at prominent schools and private gatherings. Majority of them have been cancelled now due to the coronavirus epidemic.”Meanwhile, retail shopkeepers at Paltan Bazaar said they are keeping a watch on the situation.Pankaj Masson, president of Doon Valley Mahanagar Udyog Vyapar Mandal, told TOI, “We are ensuring cleanliness in the market area and shopkeepers and other staff members are wearing masks at all times in the wake of the coronavirus threat. We are trying to ensure that the threat of the disease doesn’t affect us adversely.”(With inputs from Shivani Azad)

Title: Fake currency: 3 detained under NSA
Content:
Coimbatore: City police commissioner Sumit Sharan on Saturday detained three men under the National Security Act,1980, for circulating counterfeit currency.

A team led by sub-inspector P Suresh attached to the Saravanamapatti (crime) police station had seized fake notes amounting to Rs 60,000 from S Kidhar Mohammed, 66, of Vadvalli and D Mahendran, 39, of Kavundampalayam on February 22. The duo told police that E Suryakumar, 32, of Thiruvalluvar Nagar on Thadagam Road had given them the notes for circulation.

Police raided Suryakumar’s house and seized computers, scanners, printers and counterfeit currency notes amounting to Rs 2.64 lakh.

Preliminary inquiry revealed that Mohammed, who was earlier arrested for circulating counterfeit currency, had taught Suryakumar, who was facing huge losses in his business, how to make the fake notes. Mohammed asked him to make the notes and agreed to circulate them with Mahendran’s help.

Police had booked the trio under sections 489 (C) (possession of forged or counterfeit curreny notes or bank notes), 489 (D) (making or possessing instruments or materials for forging or counterfeiting currency notes or bank -notes) of the Indian Penal Code.

Title: ‘Good facilities at Mayo, being treated well. Listening to motivational songs, reading Gita’
Content:
The first Covid-19 patient from the city, who went through a traumatic experience after his name was made public, now wants to concentrate only on positive things. The IT company employee is trying to derive strength to defeat the virus. For those who may land in isolation, they should trust the doctors and follow instructions, he tells Chaitanya Deshpande over phone from the isolation ward at Mayo Hospital

It was a great tour indeed. During our stay in USA, we had been to Atlanta and Washington DC. All our meetings went well, and I returned to Nagpur via Doha with two of my colleagues. I was not feeling well for sure, but I never thought in my wildest dreams that it could have been infected with novel coronavirus.Assuming it to be a common cough and cold, I went to our family physician. After treating me for a couple of days, he advised me to get tested for novel coronavirus. It was for the first time in many years that when I visited a government hospital. I submitted my swab samples. On March 11, late in the evening, the authorities informed me that I was tested positive for Covid-19 and I must stay in the isolation ward of Mayo Hospital.We were completely scared and confused. But doctors here assured me that there was nothing to worry. I was suffering from fever, cough, cold, body ache and sore throat when I got admitted to this isolation ward. I must tell you, doctors here are very kind people. They know their job best. They are treating me with all compassion and care. My opinion about government hospitals was different, but the facilities at Mayo are very good.I started feeling well right after taking the first dose of medicines here. But the next day brought a major psychological trauma for me and my family. Health department officials had revealed all my details to a local newspaper. The paper went against the basic principles of medical privacy and humanity by printing all details. While I was down with fever and my family members were in another hospital getting themselves tested, we started receiving phone calls and enquiries from all over. My company colleagues also suffered a lot. Even today, I keep my cell phone off for most part of the day. Whenever I want to talk, I switch it on and make calls.Well, I don’t want to think about the negative things anymore. I want to concentrate only on positive things. Plenty of them happening for sure. I am feeling well now, taking good rest from the last five days, having good food and ample fluids — especially electoral solution. I was never fond of social media, so keeping myself away from these things. I go through newspapers but not in details. I know that my wife and one of my colleagues have also tested positive and kept in isolation. I am sure, all of us will come out of this soon.Yes, I am sure of it, because I believe in god. The only book I am regularly reading during this stay in isolation is Gita. It gives me strength to fight like a soldier against this enemy of life.Sometimes, I make it a point to listen to music and I prefer motivational songs. I can understand that many more people may test positive and land into isolation. For them, I will only say, keep patience and believe in God. Trust the doctors serving you and follow instructions.Who is bigger? Me or this virus? Of course, the spirit of life is going to win. I am going to win. Will see you soon. Pray for me and take care.

Title: No fancy proposals, Trichy corpn to go self-disciplined this FY
Content:
Trichy: The budget tabled by Trichy City Corporation after completing its silver jubilee has offered little for the residents to celebrate.
